description:
A Fun text based sim/adventure/strategy game.. it may been seem pretty complicated but there are instructions included.
at the moment now I only have a OS-X build; since Its written with Ogre3D and CEGUI I should be able to generate a windows build without to many problems which I will probably do tomorrow.. i'm pretty worn out right now and dealing with the library/linking issues that may pop up seem a lot less fun then a nap.
* EDIT: windows build uploaded
( windows version requires the dx runtime http://www.microsoft.com/download/en/confirmation.aspx?id=35 )
since i didn't make a fancy installer
I hope you enjoy the game; there is a lot more I would have liked the time to add (and may in the future)
author: anthonyl
title: * Zeta Prime  *
comments: Just finished the windows build and uploaded it.
The game-concept was good. It could be developed better. I missed a tutorial of some sort and it was a bit buggy. After my first unit died I had 2 unit 3's.

I was enjoying this, seeing it as well balanced and fun with a decent fighting system, then suddenly 2 of my units are killed in 1 hit each on the same place, same turn early on (84 and 68 points of damage), which just put me off sad to say.  Otherwise, its fun, fits the theme, and well programmed from what I can tell.  I might bring myself to play it further again sometime but as of yet I haven't beaten it.
Whoops on the unit auto naming.. you can if you wish rename units with the rename command
as for the epic damage you can use a scout (which can evade enemy damage) and a defender class to tank and hit before sending in units with a low defense bonus..
this is the first game I've written like this so theres a bit of tweaking that still needs to be done
also I'd like to say thanks for playing my game =D
The game progresses slowly, but I'm enjoying it. There's a slight issue with some of the help text being cut off on the right side. Well-conceived, and fun!
Won't run on Linux with wine. A port would be appreciated =). Your game looks according to description, screenshots and journal...
It starts up, then nothing really happens other than the interface screen.

description: Running while being shot from behind, collecting green squares and not knowing where you're going.
author: Wingy
title: Where am I?
comments: While simple, this was actually a rather fun, amusing little game, if difficult to keep going for more than a few minutes.
The game was very simple, but also very fun, and I really liked the way the music fit in with the style of the graphics too.

Intro is funny at first, but drags out and is unskippable. Gameplay is a little too hectic and very simple (not a bad thing though). Text messages during playing are a little annoying. Gets repetitive quick.
Jumping for green/to avoid red usually makes me swallow a bucket full of bullets, so jumping to dodge is rarely worth it.
particles are great but they mask bullets and bonuses ( which are pretty fast ). The game is fun :)
Great music and surprisingly addictive given how simple it is.
My main complaints were the unskippable intro (esp. the second time through) and the fact that I could run way off the screen and not know what was going on.
Overall, though, a solid effort. Great job!

Mmm. I found it prohibitive to watch the whole intro every attempt. The large popup texts inside the game were way too distracting right from the start when a beginner is already shocked by the sudden rapid movement and countless objects everywhere. Seems like it could be fun though, with a nice degree of floaty controls and music to back it up.

description: A Mega Man inspired platformer. Your two friends, Greg and Rory have escaped from your party. You must hunt them down and kill them to teach them a lesson.
author: Nanolotl
title: Your Pals Have Escaped!
comments: Very challenging.  I couldn't finish in a reasonable amount of time.
Very challenging indeed!  Audio would be nice.  Could use some further balancing in terms of the way the difficulty ramps up over the level.  Otherwise, it's a pretty good showing :)
This is a well-made platformer, loyal to the Megaman style you were striving for (difficulty was pitched pretty well too), but the link to the theme is mighty tenuous...

Really nice level design, very devious.  It was a little too challenging for me to put the time in required to finish but I enjoyed what I played.  It seemed like the back story about hunting your friends didn't have much of a connection to the actual gameplay.
A neat little homage to the classics. The disappearing blocks definitely needed some improvement since the next one should have appear before the one underneath you vanished.
The one hit kills were kinda strange but you managed to balance around it. Overall a good project.

description:
A guy that was brainwashed, is stuck in a cave. The guy knows where to go, but because he's brainwashed, he sometimes will change from direction.
It was supposed for the 48 hour challenge, but didn't had much time. I wanted to upload it though.
author: Sheep
title: To the Other Side
comments: not sure I understand how to download the game!
The link was broken. Probably because of Ganondorf.
I've beat him, so it's fixed.
Interesting concept, but it's not really all that much contentwise.
This was nice.  I didn't understand that I was supposed to mash space at first - but when that made sense, I can see the potential here.
I'd love to see a more polished and content full version of this.
Interesting idea, I can see potential.
Very cool concept! I'd love to see a post-compo version of this as you really had something going here. =D

description:
Thanks for playing! I learned about Ludum Dare 21 with about 8 hours left to go... so this is my 5-6 hour entry! (After 2 hours of thinking, what in the world can I complete in 6 hours?!)
Of course, your criticism is greatly appreciated. ;)
Made in pure ASP.NET MVC 3 C# -- the whole point was to make a new engine for the game and a game to test it out in 6 hours :)
author: bushmango
title: ZombieRobotAlienpocalypse Escape
comments: Fun overall. I liked fighting the grue, even though it killed me.
I'm not sure whether to 4/5 the audio for NyanCat goodness or N/A it.
I'm afraid I'm going to N/A because you didn't make Nyan Cat during the compo, but it definately fits the mood of the game (BTW 5/5 humor)
Humorous, but kind of repetitive. Quite good for < 6 hours, though :)
I have no idea what I was doing or what was happening, but it was so well designed and fun I didn't care! Epic game. :D

description:
You command a robot trapped in a military base. By mining nearby materials and building more robots, you might just be able to amass an army big enough to destroy your captors.
It is nearly complete, except I was unable to add sound, an ending, or tune the settings in time.
Here's a timelapse of me designing it: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=e4cr_uDKHd8
Libraries: None.
----------------
Software:
- haXe (programming language)
- swfMill (builds an swf from multiple source graphics)
- Paint.net (graphics creation tool)
- Python (for scripting a small build system)
author: wallacoloo
title: Who let the robots out?
comments: Haha, I just discovered a bug. When 1 robot is trying to deliver materials to another robot that is far away, the materials just get teleported. The robots don't bother to find a way to meet up. This is partially due to the pathfinding algorithm I wrote - I limited it to only calculating paths that were within 40 tiles for performance reasons.
Oh well, you can consider this a feature :P
Wow, that's a neat and complex system you've made there! It's a shame there's not more to do, but you scored really high for innovation!

Very complex game, huh. I like the building aspect of it, but the presentation is lacking a bit. There is seldom feedback for my actions (particles! sounds!), and the tiles are not so nice to look at - and there are so many of them ...
Perhaps zooming in a bit would be cool? Having a tutorial is great BTW, although the font was too small.

Yeah, I was rushed with the tutorial. I started it about 15 minutes before the entry deadline. I accidentally made the container too small, and fixed it by just shrinking the text instead since I was in such a hurry.
nice idea and quite complex, good to have a tutorial but there didnt seem much to do after completing it.

Well, this is a very ambitious and unusual game no doubt, and for that alone I am willing to give it quite a few points.  However, it is also a bit unweildy at times and it is difficult to figure out what the goal is.  The idea of programming the robots is really cool, but it seems difficult to use properly.
Very ambitious - something I like to see! Would like to see this game developed further also.

There is a lot to like here, but the main issue is the lack of feedback. My harvesters stopped harvesting and just clogged up my base once my base was "full," so I decided to build an expensive unit and it appeared to never get built. I was never sure the maximum amount of cost I could spend, how much I had, etc. So, I never made it past the turrets. The times I tried, I just got slaughtered. Sad, this seems like it would be very fun.

author: DkTyph
title: Water Escape Game
comments: It took me a couple levels to realize you had to collect two white squares to finish it. If they were more visually distinct or the level structure changed it might be more obvious.
Pretty good, could be a bit faster paced comfortably. Pretty unique though.

hm, when i click the Web-Link the game (i think) starts, no explaination, no controls given, no hints at all... and nothing happens when press the 'usual' mouse or keyboard buttons... except some flickering square and a water counter getting low
It took me a while to actually get things working -- when I pressed the "Web" link, nothing seemed to happen, but eventually the white square started responding.

description:
It's done! This is a game about a woman trying to escape her addiction from a virtual reality game console.
It's fun you should play it.
Music was done with LMMS (Not my strong point
Sound effects were done with bfxr
Graphics were done with Cosmigo Pro Motion 6
Code was done in gEdit
And I used flex and flixel to compile
yay- its a game in <48 hours!
Aug 23 2011 - Bugfix update. I accidentally left the double jump in the beginning of the stage for testing. Commented out that line, and uncommented the line saying where it should actually be.
author: splixel
title: Virtual Girl
comments: Oh man... those frogs...and is the music taunting me?!
That game was hard..For me at least :p It took me a while to get used to the sensitivity, and I had to get the double jump from the red level in order to beat the green level (is that allowed?)
Cool platformer, jump control were a little digital/abrupt - but awesome graphics :)

Nice look, interesting theme interpretation and level structure, but let down by very fiddly jump mechanic coupled with poor framerate. I had to give up after consistently failing to manage what should have been really simple jumps :(
Klare: Yes, you'll need either the double jump from RED, or blink from GREEN to collect the ORB OF GOAL in GREEN.
Winterblood: Looking back on it now, I do wish I had spent a bit more time on performance and mechanics :(
Immensely frustrating at times, especially the way enemies jumping patterns. Not too bad though.
I hate you for making me hate frogs.
Theme and plot felt kind of shoehorned on - "here is a game, and oh also you're escaping. yeah."

I loved the look of the main character! However, the background made my eyes bleed. I get the reference to the virtual boy, but ouch. The platforming was good, but my poor eyes couldn't handle it. It was really really tough though, perhaps the first door should have been easy, the second medium, the third hard, and the fourth insane? For me  all of the three doors I could get in were insane difficulty. Music wasn't bad, sound effects weren't bad. Controls could have been tightened up a bit. A good start, especially for 2 days work.

description:
NOTE: I left a bug in there, you can jump once in mid-air, but only if you WALK off a platform. It IS mentioned in-game, and you DO have to use it once, at the first room, because I decided not to take it out, as
NOTE 2: In order to use the source, you're going to have to have to set up the SDL library.
http://lazyfoo.net/SDL_tutorials/lesson01/index.php
Okay, so... It's not really (at all) my best work, as I'm only starting out with C++ and the SDL library. But here it is...
You wake up in a cell all alone, a mysterious voice coming from, seemingly, nowhere.
Controls:
Left/Right - Move.
Up - Jump.
Z - Shoot.
author: matt9837
title: You've Seen This in the Movies
comments: Man, I tried really hard, but I got stuck at the guy who rolled back and forth. One hit from him took like 90% of my health, and he seemed to have an endless amount of HP. :( I died a lot.

@John: Yeah, it's a glitch that I happened to notice AFTER submitting. When you get hit with one of the "boulders" (I guess you could call them that, but my horrible sprites disagree) it was supposed to be destroy it, therefore you would lose a little health, but the boss would be vulnerable to attack as well. Sorry for that one D:
It is really annoying that my in-transit ball disappears if I fire a new one. I never get a feeling that my balls connect with the enemy.
Hey, I compiled your game for Linux: vede.galacticgaming.net/Stuff/YouveSeenThisInTheMovies_linux.tar.gz
Need someone to test it to be 100% certain, but it should work fine on most distributions.

Some advice: don't use the standard Windows backslash '\' in your code. Windows accepts '/' in most places (including in code), but Linux is less friendly with '\'. That's really the only thing I had to change in your code to make it compile. You might also consider making it issue an error message when it fails to load resources.

Also, best practice is to have only class declarations in .h files and class/function definitions in their own .cpp files. ie. You should have Timer.h which contains "class Timer{/*Stuff*/};" and Timer.cpp which contains Timer::Timer(){/*Constructan!*/} and Timer's other functions. It's not really critical for something like an LD, just wanted to make sure you knew. If you don't understand there's a crowd of people on IRC who would be more than willing to help you if you're interested. :D

I see potential here, but I really gave up beating the bosses. The main problem being that I had no idead whether was doing the right thing or not. So some feedback, like the boss flashing red when you do damage would help. Also the ability to shoot multiple projectiles would be appreciated :)

description:
First ludum dare, it was a very fun experience ^^
I didn't have time to put sounds in the game, but i hope you enjoy it :)
it's about a wizard trapped in the fortress he made
I made a little story, so please read the intro :)
Controls are WASD, arrows or numpad
You can switch screens by either clicking with mouse, press enter or space
author: Ano
title: Trapped Wizard
comments: I FINALLY DID IT ! Beat the final boss and his ridiculously tall monster. Best art style ever. Period.
NIce job! Not having sound hurt. The puzzles were pretty simple; but difficult to get through.
Start simple, but challenging. Then becomes a little overwhelming.
hehe, cool design! I enjoyed it till finally being annoyed to the point of quitting on the smiley shooters level.

author: Jamin
title: Where's the Bathroom?
comments: Please provide a compiled version of your game for at least one platform.

Ahh, different colors (basic lighting) for all four walls would have made this a lot easier to navigate. From the screenshot I had no idea that this was a maze game. But hey, you got something out. Not sure if I could win or not. On the plus side, it didn't make me motion sick like notch's.

Not much to say, it's an extremely straight forward game. Not sure if the levels are randomly generated or not, but way too many far away and annoying dead ends for me. It was also nearly impossible to distinguish were you had been from where you hadn't.
I'm actually really liking the level names here (I think I'm up to level 5), but the game is just too monotonous for me to keep at it.
The visuals are mildly confusing, but workable.  The collision is sticky as hell, though, and given how tight the winding halls are, that's kinda a game-killer here.
Hmm, my multi-monitor setup seems to be screwing up the mouselook, making this very difficult to play.
Well you do have a 3D walk around engine with exits to find but the walls blur together with those colors and there is not much else here.
All I got was an empty black console window.
Colliding with the walls stops you, which isn't very funny.  You should "slide" instead.  Besides this, nothing more to complain :-)

description:
Stop the flies escaping your web!
Use the arrow keys to control the spider as it captures the flies that land in its web. If a fly is allowed to struggle for too long, it'll break free and you'll lose. Damaged web will slowly repair itself whenever the spider is nearby.
Recommended browser: Chrome (Firefox and Safari will also work, but may struggle a bit.)
My first Ludum Dare entry - an entire game as a single SVG image. Progress was a little slow while I figured out the quirks of the medium, but it came together in the end :)
All graphics and interface components drawn in Inkscape; animation and game logic in JavaScript. Enjoy!
author: Jeikon
title: Web of Flies
comments: Framerate was pretty low. Not sure why. Could see this as a good iPhone game.
Innovation: New ideas. I've seen similar things, but nothing quite like this.
Theme: It fits the theme, that is all.
Graphics: Everything looked like what it represented, and the UI had a nice clean look. My only suggestion is to maybe texture the web a bit and reduce the shaking effect.

Fun: Unfortunately, due to the nature of this game, it felt like a chore. Maybe adding some sort of way to move faster, or things to dodge, you could make this more interesting. Also, I didn't seem to be able to repair my web.
Overall: The gameplay needs some more work in the fun department, but everything else was pretty much spot-on. Good work!

Using a single svg image to make a game is interesting technically, but the gameplay was a bit slow and tedious for me. I agree quite a bit with Cosine, and with some tweaks to the movement speed and adding a tradeoff between building your web and consuming flies there could be some fun directions to take this.
Wow those spider graphics are creepy. Very nice done.
The spider felt a bit low while the flies seemed to rip through the web at the power of ten suns, a little speed balancing can improve that.

description: This game involves a virus being uploaded to a computer and infecting it.  You must do it before the owner of the computer presses Escape and cancels the upload.  The game has a few errors in grammar on the title page, and possible other places as well.  I could not finish the game, but at least I learned a lot and next LD, I will be ready to make a better game, with more levels!
author: Retroid
title: Virus Upload
comments: Good concept. Would like to see it expanded.
The cutscene in the beginning was too slow/uninteresting... I actually couldn't get past it? It never advanced? Not sure what's wrong.
So about the cut scenes being slow and such (or too fast), that is because I was stupid and forgot that the game would run differently on different computers.

A neat idea, but sadly let down by a lot of technical issues. For me, the intro to the game ran very slowly, and it just hung on the 'uploading virus' screen for a *long* time. Also, it repeated quit back to the menu screen on me - I'm not sure if this was supposed to be the 'user' pressing the escape key? If so, it would be nice to have a countdown timer or something, and it would be nice if you could just restart the level rather than whole game! Enough of my whining though, I like the concept behind it.
Pretty cool concept, needs more refinement.
concept is great, need moar levels.

While the idea (although it's just variation on snake) might be made to some interesting game with some levels, right now it fails to deliver. And the Virus loading... screen is... almost made me think that this is another of the "games" press escape to win.
Cool game; more levels would be great; cutscene is slow and dull; loading takes forever;

description:

YRGBO

author: nuria
title: YRGBO
comments: The download link doesn't work for me.
Download link seems working now, crazy game with strange graphics and mechanics, not bad at all!
Download link is down again it seems. :/
Download doesn't work for me either.
Sorry about that, download link worked for me when I tried it, I added a mirror now (https://sites.google.com/site/orugames/yrgbo.zip), please try again, thanks!

Mirror download works, but I'm unable to do anything but madly running around doing nothing and only way to escape this madness was to kill it with task manager... I tried whatever I could, but... no avail. If I run behind the bus station, it returns me back, shooting to enemies just makes them laugh, can't jump anywhere else... To weird for me :)
Writing a walkthrough right now, to be posted soon. :) you gotta pay attention to all the clues. To exit the game use ALT+f4
Strangely compelling. I must admit, without walkthrough, I wouldn't have had the patience to figure all that out.

An interesting, strange little world in this game. Needs more balanced difficulty, and more logical puzzles (punching pills or combining pills are not things I would have guessed at). Love the warped stick figure design that you have for the people.
I am not really sure what I've played...  Without the walkthrough I am unable to play it.

description:
this short abstract exploration game is my first LD entry. i spent most of my time making sprites and music so there is not really much gameplay. there is a lot of atmosphere however. :) a playthrough will only take about five minutes.
controls:
LEFT, RIGHT - go left and right
UP - use umbrella
R - if limping around the forest is not your style (or you just don't like the anim), press this to engage beast mode
i developed the game with the love2d library, so it works on windows, mac, and linux. i've only included a standalone version for windows though; if you want to play it on another platform, download love from http://love2d.org/ and grab the .love file. the source is also in the .love file--just change the extension from .love to .zip and you can open it up to get at the lua files inside.
i had some more grandiose plans for this game but i ran out of time so i had to keep it pretty simple. if time permits, i'd like to do a bit more with it in the future.
update: timelapse added!
author: mes
title: the dream forest
comments: I love the mood of the game !
Wow, just wow! The atmosphere is so intense! It makes me angry that there is no way to rate the atmosphere of the game (why should every game be humorous?).
The best entry I've played so far. :)
thanks guys! an atmosphere voting category would be cool. not enough LD games focus on that imo- i think it's a great way to make a more memorable experience.
Hmmm I couldn't get it to work on XP.  Looks interesting though!

sorry about that. i tried testing it earlier today on my office computer and discovered that it fails to play mine and pretty much all other love2d games. maybe you have the same issue? i didn't have a lot of time to debug but it unfortunately seemed like a somewhat fundamental library issue. :/
Very eerie atmosphere, I particularly loved the smooth animations. Sadly it`s very short. Nice job!
yeah nice ! <3 the subtle pixel graphics and the overall mood of this game. As kinta said it'd be better if the humor category was replaced by something a bit broader like "mood" or something.
It would have been cool to have more events or some branching for other walkthroughs though (unless I missed something in the cave ?).
Very cool for a solo 48h LD, hope you'll be able to add more content/story later !

Like everyone says, the music, graphics and ambiance for this game were great! Love2D seems impressive. I really wished there were more places to explore. Part of me wants backstory but part of me likes how cryptic it is... it might be nice to reveal things (either via text or terrain or something) in the terrain. As someone who also made a game which is just about exploring a world I appreciate the time you put in. Really promising, please keep developing it!
The atmosphere is definitively there.  Beautiful!  It is a shame the lack of gameplay.  Please, make a post-compo extended version!
Absolutely beautiful. I really wish more games would use this kind of story telling.
thanks for the feedback everyone. it is definitely encouraging me to continue working on the extended version.

description:
Created by mcc
http://runhello.com/
Notes:
- This was made using utility code (graphics, sound and input) from my open source projects "Jumpcore", "The Snap" and "Drumcircle", as well as the Chipmunk physics engine. See my BitBucket page.
- The Linux version was built and uploaded about 4 hours after the deadline (but uses the same code and buildscripts as the pre-deadline version).
- This game supports user-created levels. See the comments for instructions.
author: mcc
title: You Don't Fit
comments: To make your own custom level: Copy the file level0.svg out of the Internal/ folder (or on a mac, right-click the app and select "Show Package Contents") and put this file in the same folder as the app or exe; you can then edit this file in Inkscape to make your own puzzles. It places blocks anywhere it finds a rectangle; the "kind" attribute is used to tell teh game what kind of block it is. To place blocks of a special type, add a "kind" attribute using the xml editor (edit menu) or duplicate blocks that are in the default level. There is a "slider" kind that isn't used in the game. If anyone plays around with this I'd be curious to see what you make :D

Note: I replaced the Linux version linked above about four hours after the submission deadline. The originally uploaded version was missing the title screen due to a mistake in copying files to my Linux VM.
Interesting puzzle game. I like how the tone varies from brick to brick. It probably would have gotten monotonous had you just used one tone.
Pretty fun game with unique gameplay, but really nice work on Drumcircle! :)
Enjoyed testing this and playing it again just now. Nice work, it'd be nice to see some visuals but no matter :)
I liked it. Shows that a good concept can make a good game despite the lack of decent graphics.
Cool game! I like how you made the levels blend in to eachother, while still being separate puzzles.

Interesting take on slider puzzle. Too short and not very challenging, but definitely interesting and innovative. If I call on the phone number, will I really get the full version? :) (I'd like it I think)
All I got was a blank screen after the title screen using Mac 10.5 PPC :(
It was fun despite of the absent graphics. I would like to play a full version with more levels, on my iphone!
Like SusanTheCat, I only get a black screen.  I am on GNU/Linux.

description:
A simple puzzle/platformer that attempts to discuss the compulsion towards achievement, pressures of modern life and one's need for escape.
Tools Used: Flash Builder 4, Photoshop CS5, Audacity, Looptastic (iPad), Wiretap Studio, as3sfxrb
Built in Actionscript 3 with Flixel 2.55
author: refrag
title: Victory
comments: Loved it... I like how the extra "theme" came in nice and gradual - caught me by surprise before I'd realised what I was doing! It would be cool to have some sort of repercussions for taking the easier way out though...
I really liked this. It was cool that there was sort of a choice between the easy and more difficult ways out and the escape/addiction link was clever. It helped that it was a fun game to play, too!
I like this one! Fun mechanics and solid physics. Good level design too.
Well-polished, but I found it to be monotonous and unchallenging.
Wow, amazing entry. Simple yet challenging with an subtle theme to it. Congrats on an amazing game.
I like this. It's well polished and fun to play.
The block spawning could use some tweaking, maybe spawning a bit in front of the player and growing in the direction shes facing instead of always to the right.

The narrative with the suggestive story made it deeper and more interesting. I found myself to stressed to read the text often though. I think it would be better to show the text before the level starts, it's hard to give it attention while the spikey walls are closing in on you.
I also thought it was really hard to see the player when you took one of the pills. The flashing was a bit excessive, and the dark background didn't help.
Danik: I really appreciate your detailed feedback, thank you. :)

Spooky - the haunting intro voice worked pretty nicely. Managed to crush myself with a crate in the first level, but a very nice mechanic - well implemented, well used. Smooth controls, delicious pixelly graphics, and works really well with the theme! (Double kudos for hitting escape literally and metaphorically.)
This game seemed more tedious then fun. The levels were quite simple and easily solved.

As for game mechanics, the super jump seems seemed forced. The puzzles with it seemed like it was using it as a way of making the game seem fresh as opposed adding a new mechanic you had to grasp in order to solve the current level.

The motion effect of jiggling side to side for the jump seems like it is suppose to make it feel like to are moving fast by simulating the motion of going that fast, a vertical jiggling might add some more immersion to it and capture that feeling better.
The graphics were well polished and the style was attractive.

Something about the voice saying "layer number number" it sound shockingly similar to the title card voice in "Serial Experiment Lain". It does feel like it is good fit for mood, but also sounds like it might be ripped.
All in all that was a well made game.

description:
Navigate the minimalistic inner workings of a vault security system in this brain tease optimization puzzler.
Much of the fun (if any) is to be had in searching for optimal solutions to each board; thus online leaderboards!
I had fun with this; sorry I didn't have enough time to make more levels.
This was coded in AS3 with Flixel. Mochi API for leaderboards. sfxr, flan, photoshop, FlashDevelop. Although this game adopts classic hamburgominimalistic art direction, all assets were created fresh this weekend.
NOTE: It was brought to my attention that the last level was impossible. Sorry 'bout that! See post-compo link above for the fix.
author: hamburger
title: Vault
comments: this is a really neat design! great work man :)
Really unique idea, couldn't ever get anywhere tho - guess I'm too dumb! :)
I liked  the concept, really did :D
Mind-boggling.  Great take on the theme, nice setup and a really well-developed puzzler.
Really clever concept, but way too hard for me...a couple of tut levels to teach some basic "tricks" would be nifty
Very good puzzle concept. If you could ramp up the complexity slowly I could see myself getting hooked. Nice work!
Absolutely wonderful puzzle mechanic.  This was one of my faves.  Would love to see a bigger game with more colour and a billion levels, running on my phone.  Very well done!
Excellent puzzle concept and very well done game.

description:
Four little guys need to work together to push blocks into other blocks to make giant blocks that can be pushed together and make the exit for them to escape.
ZIP includes a readme.txt with directions and other good stuff.
author: wally2069
title: Smash Shove Solve
comments: The sound/music is VERY quiet, but it's there!
The puzzles you've got in here are REALLY tricky, and very well designed. Good job.
I kept blocking my small blocks with the bigger blocks, I seem very prone to do that in these types of games.

Very nice and originalish. The puzzles seem well-designed and actually not that easy. I gave up though, since there is no back/rewind and one wrong move equals restart. This is not really central to theme though.
Fun game, all in all! I must say it was pretty damn hard and very tricky, but the theme was kinda off. Great job!

Cool idea! I wasn't able to get the sound working under WINE (on Linux) so I couldn't rate that. The game has a good feel, and the graphics were simple but effective. I like some of the little details, like the eyes opening and closing when you change which creature you're controlling. Also, the team-work angle is interesting.

I agree with Rudy that having an undo button in this game would be huge, although I've enjoyed lots of similar puzzle games that don't have this feature (e.g. LoLo). It might have been wise to have some easier levels first, where only a few blocks are out of place, just to help get people used to the game strategy. I found even the 2nd level to be pretty tricky. Finally, even having some intro text creating some kind of plot would have helped the theme (maybe these are magical creatures imprisoned by a wizard? or aliens escaping a dying world but trapped by their own masonry?).
Yay for sokoban that is so much more than sokoban. Clever puzzles.

You should really show the controls on-screen in the game. I didn't read the readme first, so I discovered that spacebar skips any level long before I discovered that I had to press 1,2,3,4 to switch characters.

Quite an ok puzzle game. Doesn't really have that much to do with the theme, really. I wish the rules of the game had been communicated in-game, as well as the controls. I figured that I was just supposed to create four 2x2 squares and assumed that the game just didn't have a check for whether the level's over or not, and I'd just have to press space to go to the next level. That's until I reached a level where the blocks were laid out in the proper 4x4 manner to begin with. Only then did I realise how the game actually works.
Interesting idea. Quite hard to solve and the sound is too quiet.
I like the oldschool look of this game.

That was a hard game and fun too.  I also agree with the others that I can't see a strong relation between your entry and the theme.  However, I think that the levels are very well designed.  The music and sound effects were OK. Very well done!

description:
Well, got there in the end. Spent more time working on the cave generation/lighting system than the actual gameplay, and you can tell. Was originally going to include some sfx, but i really dont have time to now :(
Ah well.
Anyway, take a look, and give a rating/comment! Hope you like it! :D
EDIT:
For those who are interested, the base algoritm for the lighting system is Recursive Shadowcasting. I ported the code at http://roguebasin.roguelikedevelopment.org/index.php/PythonShadowcastingImplementation to AS3. the fading and so on i added myself, check the source code if you are interested :)
author: AClockWorkLemon
title: Save the Miner!
comments: Very nice!! As soon as I finish mine I'll see your source!! Always wondered how the light system works. :D
The lighting system is based on this Python shadowcasting algorithm, which i then ported to AS3 and added the fading, etc.
I hope the source is helpful :)
Not so much escape as it is rescue or find.
Cool cave generation, very pretty lighting!
Nice lighting, I really liked how the tiles would fade out when they were no longer in the FOV, nice touch.
Very nice lighting effectds! kind of wish there were some O2 pickups or something, but maybe that would have made it too easy.
Cool graphical effects.  A little lacking in depth, but overall well done.

cool idea. the vehicle reminds me of starflight (old genesis game). two complaints: the first time i loaded it up i was stuck in a room that was completely blocked in. and i found myself always looking at the radar meter and not at what was around me. replacing the visual meter with a repeating sound that got louder or changed with proximity would solve this.
Nice graphics and use of theme. Good work, sounds lack here very much, at lest "closeness" sounds effect is needed :)
Just FYI, the website you've linked to(http://clockworkgames.comuv.com/) has been blocked by trend micro :(
Really nice take on 'escape' to make a search and rescue game - well done!
Terra ah god. bloody site host :/.
Ill see if i can get an alternate link up tomorrow

description:
IMPORTANT FIX: I fixed the room_goto_next() thing now. If you still have problems, please don't hesitate to tell me!
Side note: If the screen is too small for you, you can   resize it, like you would be able to with any other window.
Jump with the space bar.
The 'O+' Pickup generates two rocks at once ;) Try to avoid or go for dodging two obstacles at once
Play Music with right click on the speaker
and mute it with a left click ;)
It shouldn't be that terrible though.
"You angered King Blob. Now he's shooting giant rocks at you! RUN. For hells sake, RUN!"
author: Folis
title: Runner! .. and his problems.. 1.1
comments: Nice little graphics, the music is a little too loud, and it always crashed for me when I tried to replay after dying

Anyway, nice little game, but the gameplay wasn't that original, but I like the scrolling from right to left, it's disturbing, and the other thing I like was the fact that when you pick up somes stuff, it actually create a rock
So you have the choice to try to dodge the pick up, but then you mostly going to take the rolling ball in you face when it arrives, Or pick it up and dodge two balls at the same time,
Hmm, never crashes for me.. I just downloaded it from here.
You always have the possibility of turning your volume down, or mute the music ;)
The gameplay isn't original, that's right, but it's the only thing I could come up with ^._^;
And it's so small, because I like that for some reason. I don't know why, though.
It crashed for me also when replaying the game.
This error message appeared when it crashed:
Moving to next room after the last room.
@Divide Ah! I know what's going on. Can fix that in a mere 12 seconds :)
Great job, fun little game. Never crashed for me, and I LOVED the music.

description:
Watch the playthrough here http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VvMJYaJ_DJ0
DESCRIPTION:
Rescue Support is a game wherein you take control of a rescue ship and help out your comrades who are escaping the monster horde.
THE TWIST:
The unique twist I made with this game is that you take the role as support. You have no guns that you can fire but you do get to help out the team by dropping turrets to help with killing enemies, and health packs to regenerate health.
The more people you rescue and bring back to your base, the more money you get for equipment and upgrades.
CONTROLS:
- Control Arrows for movement
- Z for buying and picking up items
SOME NOTES:
- For this game I concentrated on the gameplay and less on graphics and sound.
- Didn't have time to include an endgame. Basically just try to get the most number of kills and saves
SOME TIPS:
- Flinging really helps
- Try to set up a camp with turrets, soldiers and medpack and see your score and money rise
author: accidentalrebel
title: Rescue Support
comments: As I've mentioned, it has a lot of potential
I wish the ship would move a bit faster (perhaps an upgrade?).  Nice job
Excellent concept. This is the start of a pretty great, addictive little game.

This is a great little game. The graphics are simple but effective and smooth, the sounds are pretty good. I found the idea really compelling, and the implementation works well too. My only real gripes are that it seems like the turrets/AI isn't good at shooting monsters on the ground, so I had a hard time setting up a base camp as you suggested. But I played the game for a good while and really enjoyed it. It's easy to imagine all the cool places this game could go!
@recursor, yes. That was part of my original plan, you can upgrade your ship like getting faster movement, higher health etc.
@Yeah, the turrets could really use a better AI. That was only a rough implementation and I'm planning to improve it in the future.
Thanks to all those who left their comments. Keep em coming!
Great idea, need more polish and could be a hit game!
Nice gameplay with a lot of potential. Really could benefit from a level structure, where maybe you have to save a certain number of people before another number dies?

Very cool. I can see a lot coming of this, with some graphical work and some more variety. I did have problems with turrets not firing sometimes, and I think a wave/level system would make the whole experience a bit more structured (although perhaps less frantic :D)
Ah yes. A wave system would be good. it would give you some time to prepare. I'd keep that in mind. Thanks!
The sound of gunfire got a little repetitive after some time. Other than that this is a great play for those who enjoy flinging people to safety.
Good idea, pretty good execution. One of the more original yet completely playable entries. With some more polish and levels it could be quite good game (in normal terms, not just ludum dare)

description: This is a rail shooter where the player must suppress a escaping prisoners with bullets.
author: hamster_mk_4
title: Prison Break
comments: I loved it. You've got mad skills.
It was a bit difficult to play on a trackpad, but other than that, it was great! I used to play a lot of Virtua Cop, so this really brings back memories. Great job.
Excellent! Difficulty was just right - died my first time, then beat it on my second run. Reminded me of Time Crisis. :) I love that you can shoot down the knives! Great job.
Nice work! I would've liked a cover mechanic (i was searching the keyboard for one, though i probably only needed it coz i was trackpadding). Loved the deadpan voice...
@pdyxs: The Shame of it is, that is my normal voice. I am just too self conscious to scream into the microphone. Also I did not want my neighbors calling the cops on my death screams.
Really cool entry. Again the trackpad difficulty was intense. But I enjoyed it and actually played it through anyway. One of the best games I've seen so far.
But the enemy's throw there knifes a bit fast. didnt get too far :(
* Had a hard time with reloading. Is there a key for it, what I do is I click on the icon on the lower right
* Sometimes the enemies doesn't die at the first hit.
Very good entry, I liked it.
The only bad thing is the sound of the gun. But 5/5 for Theme and Graphics!
The gun sound is me flicking my note book right next to the speaker. I never claimed to be an audio engineer. But I am glad you liked the rest of the game.
I'm biased. I love railshooters to a fault. But this was an incredible piece of work for 48 hours.

Animations, scripted scene, ragdolls (I adore ragdolls - ragdolls are proven to make any game 83% more legendary) - considering I spent the better half of a day not making squares collide I must bow to you sir.
Oh yeah, great twist on the prison break meaning :D
Great game.. I always wanted to make a lightgun game... maybe for the next LD. A lot of content and really fun. Good luck!!
Neat. Although it took me 2 seconds to realize it was on rails :-)
Very impressive animations (and graphics in general) for being done in one weekend!

description:
I finally made it! My 1st Ludum Dare!
Mate Escape! Help our desperate groom escape his wedding and meetup with his secret spouse! Is he fast enough to catch up with her car?
Controls:
Left/Right Arrow keys - Move
Space Key - Jump
Down Arrow Key - Duck
Ctrl Key [Hold] - Focus (Slow Motion)
Esc - Quit Game
F Key - Switch Screen to Fullscreen
W Key - Switch Screen to Window
The game feels it needs a lot stuff, the art took me a lot of time to make. The music is reaaaally simple as it isn't my forte + I was running out of time. I was planning to add more levels, story, enemies, powerups, achievements. But 48 hours is never enough, no? ;)
I liked the weird concept I came up with though. I might expand this into a proper game later if people like it. :)
The motivation and ideas I got out of this Ludum Dare is my personal contest "prize".
Enjoy! Don't get pecked too much!
*Windows build works on XP/Vista/7 (Extract all the files/folders from the zip first)
**Source requires Game Maker 8.1 + the extensions installed from the zip
author: alexandervrs
title: Mate Escape (LD)
comments: I like the artwork, and the sound/music was good too. I agree with your assessment that it needs more "stuff", but that is normally what you can say about every 48 hour game. Nicely done!
Cute graphics, I have no idea what the story is in this but my imagination fills in the blanks for me!

The gameplay could use some tweaking here and there, particularly for enemy/collectible spawning (make it so food never appears right next to enemies or below ones low to the ground, otherwise it is impossible to get). Then again, perhaps those serve as temptation.

That was fun, although after dying once.. it ended up being easier to just duck the entire time until I won. At extreme speeds it seemed impossible to dodge any of the low birds, so I just plowed through them.  Great artwork and sound though!
For a game that was all about running very fast, it was rather slow-paced. Gameplay mainly boiled down to pressing down or space at the right time and patiently waiting for the next rollerskates.
Nevertheless, I enjoyed the artwork, and the style. The tie flapping in the air cracks me up.
Not bad, though toward the end it was too fast to react to birds coming, or to get fruits and whatnot, so the balance was really off.
Very "clean" graphics and the music fits very well.
The graphics were quite nice, and I liked the music too. It could use a couple more power ups/something, but overall its a very good game. Congrats on your first-time entry!

My end score was 52/1/1920 so it's definitely winnable, but I feel it's quite random when having high speed (from about 130-150km/h). I liked the graphics, music, and warning works quite well. Definitely one of the better games in the genre.

description:
XNA 4.0
Sound is quiet, please crank it up.
I built this game at 1440 by 900 and I think its crashing when run on a smaller resolution (any larger resolution should be fine).  I might try compressing all the game textures and source code to work at a much smaller resolution.  If anybody has any problems or has any suggestions please post in the comments!
Post Mortem:
I had something like 9 story screens and 1 game screen planed and after building the game and 4 screens I got so bored of drawing.
Next time less art and more game.
I was only able to commit 14 hours and I was still able to make an alright game, supper happy with my scoping not getting out of hand as I am usually really bad with that.
I know the musket shot stuff doesn't really make sense, I should have taken it out and used more rocks and cannon balls.
I was planning on doing a couple more but different little games and could have fit 1 more in if i had not done as much art.
The sound and the images don't sync up in the intro movie, I should have cut the audio into parts to match the images and then synked them individually.
1440 x 900 was a good resolution to work in, except people with smaller resolutions cant play the game.  Next time I'm going to look at how to build a game that can expand to full screen.
NextTime:
Less art.
Get a phsics engine before hand! (I rolled my own which took up about 2 hours of my time and leaves something to be desired with collision.)
Be smarter with the resolution.
author: poohshoes
title: HMS Lance
comments: The game crashes when I try to play it. I do have XNA 4 installed and other XNA games work for me... It may be caused by hiDef profile.
Couldn't get it to run, I'm afraid. Just sticks on the initial screen, with the giant picture of a boat.

The thing about the resolution you chose is that it's really nonstandard, you could have gone with 720p, because basically you made a game that only people with 1080p can play, and yet they don't get the benefit of their monitor resolution.
I agree Felipe, next time I will use 1280Ã�720 as my size, though it may reduce the quality of my beautiful art ;)
Unskippable intro cutscene makes Jack put it in another window and play Minecraft until it's finished.
This game was brutally punishing.  I liked the sailing controls but man.  It seemed like the goal was to kill me as hard and as often as possible.

description:
This is my first LD entry.
A harcore runner, the objective is to run as far as you can.
Controls: Mouse
author: TheVTM
title: Flashlight Runner
comments: 32 seconds.. I think the first jump is the most difficult one
46 seconds, and I concur with JohanAR about the first jump.
How long do you have to run to escape?
Neat. especially the evilness of not actually seeing the ground :-)

I missed the first jump like 20 times in a row, then got 50 seconds. Hehe. The "see all past players" was cool, but since they weren't distinct from me, they started to really confuse me and I had to restart.
43 seconds. I don't have much to add that hasn't been said already, maybe a yellow tint to the current flash light to differentiate the player from the previous shadows.

Pretty simple and fun concept. I'll echo other comments and say that the difficulty progression was backwards (the first jump was the hardest) and that seeing my previous runs though made it so confusing I had to reload the page.
The view from previous runs is cool, but after a bunch get stacked it can get confusing. I like the simple mechanic.
The darkness is an interesting twist - being unable to see the platform you are jumping off makes this much more stressful than a standard one-button jumping game.
It's fun going for a run with your past self.

description: Made using GML and Paint.net, and is my first finished LD project. Its a bit glitchy towards the end and is very hard (even I have trouble beating it). Enjoy!
author: Jackthegreat321
title: Escaping from unintelligent guards
comments: I found that the controls were very "sticky," to the point of being frustrating. This was a new level of sticky; 25% of the time, the player wouldn't even move while holding a button, which made beating it not even seem worth it, especially when you have to restart every time you're hit.
you can almost touch the guards and the controls dont work very nice.
F-Secure gives me a 'harmful' -warning for this. I'm aware that it warns about every GM game, but usually it's just a 'suspicious' one, not outright harmful. Could you look into this?

Using a grid concept with fluid movement from one point to another  seems unnecessary, as the controls feel, as someone said before, "sticky" (that's not the only problem there), but this doesn't bother me that much.
What bothers me is the fact that I have to start at the beginning of the game every time I get hit. The game needs some more work, but it's not that bad, actually.
Oh yeah, and there is no source available?
I got stuck on the other cells bars and couldn't move

description:
An 8-level (+intro) puzzle/action game about a curse. The objective is to kill yourself - or rather, the body you're haunting. Experiment with things like dying from fall damage or getting squished by moving objects.
Important: install the included font before playing. The game loves it so much, it seems to crash without it. Thanks to Joeyy from #ludumdare for helping me discover this. After that, start the game from /dist/curse.exe. The necessary few attributions can be found in readme.txt. And let's not forget bfxr for the sound effects.
A & D to move, W to jump (even when falling), S to flip switches. R to retry if you get stuck.
-
I initially submitted this game with several hours to go. Due to feedback, the update submitted on the extended time added a simple level 0.
For people with small screens (such as laptop users): I've made an alternative version which runs in a 608x448 window. This in turn made some animations play back faster, so I also slowed them down to roughly the original speed. Otherwise the code is unchanged, it's merely a bugfix. Thanks to Wallacoloo for mentioning this.
1.0d fixed a missing hard-coded event in the fifth level.
author: Jiggawatt
title: Escape the Fate
comments: Didn't really get it. Got stuck in the first level. S does nothing and killing yourself did nothing. What did I miss?
Don't fall out of the screen. Level 1 involves fall damage, try jumping down from the highest ledge to the lowest one.
Yes. I got it! There are some quite nice and tricky levels later on.
Thanks to Triplefox on #ludumdare for giving me the idea of an intro level. It does make a world of difference in explaining a what's proper death.
Also your blog posts are hilarious.

Cool idea. The game looks nice, but feels a little too hard (especially mid-fall jump can be a little hard to get). Regarding controls, some in-game hints would be nice. Audio is quite decent. It's a very good entry, congrats!
marudziik: Thanks for commenting! Regarding the controls, what kind of hints do you have in mind?
Extended tutorial (like 2-3 levels more) + text info would be enough, I think. Also, it would be nice to be able to change WSAD keys to arrows. :)
Innovation: Definitely interesting. Kinda like Karoshi in the whole "die-to-win" concept, but it has its own special mechanics.
Theme: It fits the theme. Not much else to say.

Graphics: They work, and don't hurt the eyes. Pleasing to look at. I don't have any advice on how to improve them, maybe a little more variation in the walls (more than one sprite) could make things more interesting.
Audio: The audio worked very well. I also liked the music very much.

Fun: The player moved a little fast, and the movement seemed pretty hectic. The vertically moving platforms glitched lots, I would teleport below them, and I once got one to teleport through the platform above me. I never got to the push boxes (I quit on the level shown in the last screenshot), so I can't offer any advice on that. On the other hand, movement was very smooth, and the engine was glitch free other than the vertically moving platforms.

Overall: Pretty fun, and polished for a game made this quickly. Just fix your engine and maybe offer more in the way of direction (giving the player an idea of what to do) and you have yourself a respectable game.
Community: You are hilarious. That is all.

description:
Hi everyone, we're a 2 man team participating for the first time on Ludum Dare. We wanted to use Stencylworks to facilitate development but unfortunately last minute collaboration problems led us to use Adventure Game Studio with no previous experience. Everything turned out pretty well considering we only had 48 hours.
Anyway, we decided to make a quick and fun adventure game - we attempted to immitate the classics by doing stuff like upscaling art we drew on GraphicsGale (tough 50% of the team sticks with MS Paint).
We're both pretty sure there are still some bugs so don't hesitate to comment if you find one! We still have a few hours remaining to fix anything!
Note: Due to a horrible mistake instead of uploading a version with a better font we simple re-uploaded the old version instead, here's the actual latest revision
author: e
title: Escape the Brothel
comments: Wasn't very hard to find out what to do, but it was fun nonetheless.  Congrats!
Decent humour, getting through wasn't too hard, but it was an interesting little experience. The mixed-resolution graphics were kind of hard on my eyes at times, but that's likely just me. Nice work
For some reason the mouse cursor got stuck as soon as I put the mouse inside the window. The cursor simply wouldn't move in a continous fashion. This made the game hard to play for me.
Can you tell us how to replicate that bug exactly? Me and my friend tried to put the mouse inside the window, but it seems to be working fine :p thank you for spotting that bug btw ;)
It's possible to escape without unlocking the window, using the poster before attracting someone's attention works anyway.
Thank you for spotting the bug
Nice start for a full game!
One bug I spotted: You can get the key for the window twice, if you look under the bed again, after opening the window.

description:
This is Escape Run.
It mainly runs on windows.
Linux requires WINE, or running from source.
If you want to try to run from source on linux or mac, and you're familiar with python dependencies, the dependencies are pygame and pybox2d (I'm currently using pybox2d revision 355 but other recent revisions should also work.  I put a copy here: http://www.bleepbloop.org/files/ludumdare/ld21/pybox2d_rev355.zip
You can often install pybox2d with "python setup.py install" and/or easy_install.
Running:
Windows: unzip and run "main.exe"
Linux: have wine installed.  unzip and run "wine main.exe"
or see "From source" below to run from source.
OSX: see "From source" below if you want to try this
From source: install dependencies pygame and pybox2d and run "python main.py"
Use keys: wasd to move.
To aim: use ijkl or arrow keys, or use mouse (just move mouse to aim, you don't need to click)
Note: mouse aiming quality may not be as good since it was tested on a laptop.
Use Space to restart.
It gets progressively more difficult.
It's not as finished as I'd like, but it's playable. Many details like points and hitpoints weren't finished, and difficulty could have used more testing and tweaking.  Also, the background/visible level doesn't change.  The idea turned out a lot like "Smash TV", but a lot less finished :)
You get three hitpoints to start with.
Good luck! :)
Edits:
added a more description so you know what to expect.
added directions for pybox2d dependencies.
added note on running on Linux with wine, and created Linux download link (same as link to windows download).
Aug 30:  Fix two problems making the game unplayable:
- mouse aiming was completely broken on windows (it worked in linux, wine, and a VM).  Now it works -- keyboard aiming is probably still easier than mouse aiming if your keyboard allows many buttons pressed at once.
- low resolution monitors could not play.  They are now detected and half size is used.  This can be forced with cmd-line arg "--small".
author: erko
title: Escape Run
comments: End-of-central-directory signature not found.  Either this file is not
a zipfile, or it constitutes one disk of a multi-part archive.  In the
latter case the central directory and zipfile comment will be found on
the last disk(s) of this archive.
unzip:  cannot find zipfile directory in one of game1_erko_src.zip or
game1_erko_src.zip.zip, and cannot find game1_erko_src.zip.ZIP, period.
Congratulations on your first Ludum Dare entry.
+ You did a great job on the physics.
+ It's pretty easy to get up and running on my Linux box from source.

description: In "Escape route" you have to find the exit of a forest and your way back home.
author: JaJ
title: Escape route
comments: Some of this appears to be brute force/random at times, but after I play for a bit I start noticing patterns. Its definitely a game you have to experiment around with to understand, but in a good way.
Very cool Zelda dark forest vibe, also a bit Sabre Wulf, bewildering green passages.
Broody and dark, confusing in a good way.

A promising game, reminiscent of Sabre Wulf as mentioned above, but the forest here doesn't make sense: I can turn back and end up somewhere I didn't come from. This makes the forest tiresome, because whenever I walked across the screen I felt like it was a wasted effort. Sadly, that made the game unenjoyable.  :(
If the forest made sense, this could have been a very enjoyable game.
The game music is quite nice, and I applaud you on that :)
The forest was a bit too what the bleep mate for my taste. Sadly never got past it even after collecting three of the items. Looks beautiful and good music too.

It is initially very frustrating, but it is a cool puzzle if you stick with it. The music was very nice! I think if you had a few more items it would make it much less frustrating. I'd _maybe_ even just have them permanently marked, because it felt like the "real" puzzle was learning how they map between each other. When you can't mark them all, it comes down to memorizing the movement patterns or just dumb luck, neither of which are all that enjoyable.

description:
Use left mouse button click the ground to make Character Dokey move~
Green trees are portals~
To saved 5 pigeons for unlocking the Exit-----Orange Tree!!
author: REIN1
title: Escape From Zoo
comments: Nice 3D, but limited gameplay. Looks like it could be good if it had more time.
Not very fun, but it looks nice.
Very pretty, but lacks on the gameplay front.
Mostly agree with the other comments - could do with more gameplay going on.
I also agree.  Looks nice, but isn't very deep.
Always love to see Unity being pushed hard for compo entries.
Player-controlled camera (right-click to pan/zoom/rotate) would be greatly appreciated but not strictly necessary for this one.

description:
Escape Cat is a really simple typing test game, with a Nyan Cat lookalike for good measure. This being my first Ludum Dare, I wanted to do something excessively simple and arcadey. The game has 3 modes: Standard, where you simply type out a really silly story. The full text of what you have to type is displayed along the bottom. Along the top is your text entry box and the word you should type next. The second mode is called "Nyan mode" where you just type nyan over an over again until you become sick of it (or make 4 mistakes). The third mode is the one that most resembles an actual game, it's called Fish mode. Type the words that appear on the fish to destroy them, partly inspired by Typing of the Dead.
If you have kids, it might be something they could play. Or you could use it to brush up on your typing skills. Or, I dunno, use it as a screensaver.
author: FrikaC
title: Escape Cat
comments: I was enjoying the story until the game decided that no key or combination of keys on my keyboard would print a quotation mark. :)
Different modes in a game made in 48 hours is a pleasant surprise. It's just a typing game, but it does what it does very well.
I have an unhealthy obsession with games like this, so I've had to delete it from my computer before I spend 5 years playing fish mode. Good job :)
'nyan' is surprisingly hard to type over and over
Fun. Fish mode is the most fun, nyan mode is lol and impossible to type consecutively, standard mode needs better original text presentation. Not sure how this is central to the theme though.
Each level of fish mode takes a too long, otherwise it's an interesting take on a classic typing game.

description: You are a villainous dragon, known far and wide for your evil heart and taste for fair maidens. But tragedy has struck! The honorable king and his valiant minions have captured you and thrown you into the dungeon. Now you must claw your way back to daylight and resume your vile ways!
author: B3N
title: Castle Escape
comments: This was quite fun. Poor guards :D
You should re-upload this without the installer.
Could you please upload this without the weird installer.
I really don't want to run an installer. Can you upload without it please?
Sorry about only having the installer. I've now got just the files up. Running it will require XNA.
There's something about a dragon picking up guards and saving them for later just to eat them and get their stuff that just makes me smile.
Eating guards was fun :) Overall, nice little point and click adventure, even if very short. Dragon should move a bit faster, but otherwise good.
so very very charming. good work.
It is too short!!  The visuals are great; just add some coloring and music and you've got a very nice adventure :-)

description: Very short game. There is a funny story. Not much gameplay here.
author: tequibo
title: Esc
comments: remember me knytt story and this is good !!
I enjoyed the experience, as a short story, but as a game, there is too little interactivity to do well.
Cute game, nice cute graphics. But (you already know this) I think the gameplay is way too linear. I want more!
Very charming and surprisingly fun for a game with essentially no gameplay. =)
Nice story, but with some gameplay involved this would have been much better
It is very, very cute.  It is a shame that the gameplay is so shallow...
I liked the graphics! Gameplay was almost humorously uni-dimensional, though... :)
The graphics were absolutely adorable, more could have been done here though.
Haha, nicely done :) Not very innovative but fun and stylish presentation :)

description:
This is really shitty but whatever. Next time I will do better. The Application is hidden there.
Press Z - to shoot.
Oh, but the end is fucking orgasmic. You should at least play through it just for the ending because it is the best possible ending.
author: malloc
title: Cacophony
comments: Failed to run - problem with the "side-by-side configuration".
sorry, but same with me. Would like to try it out, though.
yeah, the promised awesome end is teasing!
I'm just here to phone in the same issue. I MUST SEE THIS ORGASMIC ENDING.
Hate to make the comment section look like a broken record, but I'm getting the same error.

I'm getting "This application has failed to start because the application configuration is incorrect." And trying to rebuild it myself I am finding all kinds of linking issues that I really don't want to try and figure out right now.
Ok, you made some n00b mistakes on distribution but I think we've all been there. First, you distributed a debug build and not a release.
Debug builds rely on debug .dll's which aren't meant to be distributed - hence, nobody without your exact version of MSVC will have them.

Distributing a release build will often suffice if you're just using msvc's libraries (most systems will already have these) but to be thorough, you really should distribute the runtimes with your distributions. See:

description:
The craft is in the middle of a 1000x1000 matrix of blocks. The objective is to escape the matrix. Move with the arrowkeys, space shoots. The white blocks are indestructible.
Escape quits to menu, in the menu escape quits the game. Pressing escape in the game will DESTROY your current progress.
The movement is "newtonian", like in asteroids.
author: Piglet
title: Block escape
comments: It's too hard, but I love that =)
The avatar's movement is cool, I like this king of inertia! Nice job! I hope I'll finish it later...
This was really hard, but it's an interesting concept.
omg so frustrating. this would be good zen training.
Too hard for me, if there was anything else for me to do but to battle inertia, I'd try it more, but...

I couldn't start the game in Windows.  I could see the press start text and then the game always quit without any error message in neither stdout.txt or stderr.txt.  I had to compile the game in Linux and there it worked without problems.
Gameplay wise, it is very, very hard.  That's is what it makes this game interesting, actually :-)

description:
This game has been written from scratch in C, which I learned the day of the contest. The source code is straightforward and I encourage you to take a look.
If my personal server should go down, use the DropBox links.
http://dl.dropbox.com/u/32084539/ascape-all.zip
http://dl.dropbox.com/u/32084539/ascape-osx.zip
http://dl.dropbox.com/u/32084539/ascape-linux.zip
http://dl.dropbox.com/u/32084539/ascape-windows.zip
http://dl.dropbox.com/u/32084539/ascape-source.zip
author: oldtopman
title: Ascape
comments: Yes, I firsted my own game's comment box. Why? I've never done this before. Its a new experience. And the only person to get mad is me :D
The page looks a little sad with no comments :(

It's mildly entertaining.. With most of the early choices leading in death, and me just randomly picking a path shortly afterwards leading to winning... It's sort of a frustrating game.. Even when I won I didn't get the satisfaction I expected.

Pretty funny although too short (with everything except one path leading to death). And you've taught me that running a command-line application in wine actually runs it in the terminal. And now for some things I feel the need to reply to (spoilers ahead).
"*You'd have to recompile me to add a giving functionality, you fool!*"
How could you be so case-insensitive!

description:
EDIT: Fixed version just in time
It's my second time participating in LD!
The game is a quite short linear platformer, where you have to escape from a prison. All the graphics are hand-drawn and scanned to the computer.
Requires to run:
.NET Framework 4.0
http://www.microsoft.com/download/en/details.aspx?id=17851
XNA 4.0 Redist
http://www.microsoft.com/download/en/details.aspx?id=20914
I hope you enjoy this game even though it's not too long because I ran out of time.
author: OddOneOut
title: Abandoodle
comments: I really enjoyed this one, I love the hand drawn graphics. :)
Couldn't get it to run on Windows 7 64-bit!
really really nice, smooth movements, good gameply. With some weapons and puzzle this kind of style could make a great game!
Absolutely loved the art style! The gameplay was pretty awesome too.
I loved this! The graphics, the audio, the gameplay...basic, but perfect. Of course : too bad this was that short.
Thank you everyone with the positive feedback!
stoz: Have you installed the required prerequisites?
I loved the art! (And I'm not saying just because I'm using same approach :) gameplay seemed smooth, to bad you hadn't time to do more levels.
Unfortunately, it seems I don't have a Direct3D device that supports the "HiDef" profile :'(
I really enjoyed this game. Graphic style and sound is great as is level and enemy design. I hope for more levels to come.

In the crowd of all platformers, I have to say I liked the polish on this one. Animations felt right, enemies were interesting, the scribbles just rough enough to make the levels "believable": just before the tracking jumping enemy (for lack of a better name), there is no roof that I could see and I was thinking about what might lie on this unknown part of the paper. A very nice experience.

To be picky, I'd say that it is a bit short (of course the solution is easy) but also not very innovative. I would have loved fighting erasers, pencils and everything, breaking the third wall (I do not know how you transfer "breaking the forth wall" to a 2D game). That might be an idea for later :)
Apparently I need to upgrade my videoboard as it doesn't support XNA HiDef :(

description:
Here's The Shadows Hunger. The darkness will consume you, so run from light to light, collecting the items you need to escape and avoiding the shadowy beasts that would devour you!
Instructions and journal included.
Try #2: Replacing with version that corrects a mistake in the instructions.
author: Octoborg
title: The Shadows Hunger
comments: Good way to play off the fear of the dark, but the level doesn't reset after you die. I ended running out of bombs, because I didn't use them correctly.
Very fun gameplay, I liked it a lot :)
Not a fan of the light mechanic. It seems a bit arbitrary and is frustrating at times. Still overall good game.
The gameplay is really fun and I found it original, however the levels should restart with all the bombs otherwise one could end up stuck (as I did...)

I beat it. I thought it was cool and innovative but only ho-hum on the fun level. The graphics are pretty nice but I didn't think the lights looked good, blocky as they were. The blockiness didn't fit the rest of the graphics.
The sound is atrocious, especially the sounds the monsters make.

My biggest gripe, and it may sound dumb, is the different passage types. I didn't like always having to think, "Wait, do I push F here or R?" Also, if you place a bomb and leave the level you lose the bomb. I felt like I'd enjoy the game more if the bombs just weren't a part of it.
Yeah, if I had managed to work faster I would have smoothed the lights more and took the time to get better sound effects out of sfxr.

Running out of bombs shouldn't make you get stuck, as I designed the game to never require bombs to progress, only to get certain powerups or to skip keys. Bombed objects should also stay gone if you re-enter a screen. Did I miss something?

description:
I'm stuck, HALP!: http://dl.dropbox.com/u/1287557/LD48/LD21/HINTS.txt
Plot:
You are SUBJECT:7.  You don't know much about yourself.  What you do know, is that you've been in captivity for as long as you can remember.  You're being held against your will, and you're referred to as SUBJECT:7 by your captors.
How to play:
Move with the arrow keys.  Other keys can be useful if stated in game.
Goal:
Find your way out.  This means sneaking past guards, decieving guards, and taking the hard route out.  Good luck.
Technical Details:
Written in C.  Uses SDL, OpenGL and OpenAL.  Graphics are made with GIMP.  Sound effects are made with SFXR.  The drumloops are made with Drumcircle (http://msm.runhello.com/?p=396).
Written and best tested under Linux.  The Windows-version is known to work very well in wine.
Hoping to get a Mac-version built soon.
author: Kvisle
title: SUBJECT:7
comments: A hint button would have been really nice here, since I don't know how I'm meant to use the first item (though I can see what item I need next, I just can't do anything to the guard next to it).
You're not the only guy stuck in that place - as I see this will be a frequent problem I've added a spoiler-file, http://dl.dropbox.com/u/1287557/LD48/LD21/HINTS.txt

Figured it out, and it all ran pretty smooth, except for some reason the menu graphics and text were all screwed up and repeating for some reason. Fairly mundane and functional, but worked smoothly and the lighting system was nicely executed.
Yeah! Solved it without any hint. Liked it.
@Hangedman; Is it the background-image that is broken on the menu, or is it the menu text as well?
What graphics card do you have?
Overall a very well rounded entry. There was some fake difficultly with the complete lack of explanation. Otherwise a pretty good entry with multiple sound tracks and a really dark maze.
Accidentally discovered the cheat to turn off the dark effect. I would enjoy if a longer version were made in the future.

I liked this. The light mechanic was a cool idea and the audio was great; but the difficulty is a little weird. For example, I could not find a donut, and because of that the two rooms I had gotten to were both useless to me (lockers and the hall-like place with two guards). I couldn't get further than those rooms.
The light effects are lovely :) And thanks for the hints :)
Great atmosphere, I jumped every time one of the guard got me ;)

description: Escape the trigger happy galactic police in your shiny new stolen space ship prototype.
author: someone
title: Stormcrow
comments: It was haaaaaard, until I try the scroll wheel. And then I understood :D
Very cool and very fun. Don't forget to zoom!
Wait, you can zoom out with the scroll wheel? Why is that not mentioned anywhere? Might make it playable...

I thought the game was much more fun when you were zoomed in all the way. Gave me a greater sense of danger :p When I zoomed out it felt shorter, and it was much easier to dodge enemies completely, which wasn't as fun for me.
I love the way zoom can be used to change the difficulty setting without explicitly saying 'Easy' or 'Hard'.
Nice to play the game after seeing the timelapse, the flight mechanics are very good.

The game is pretty smooth and all, if a bit punishing, but while it is functional it is not much more so: graphics are all right but placeholdery (not a real word). Nevertheless, it was a nice sense of accomplishment to beat it zoomed in and it did have a nice sense of panic to it as others said.

I thought that just maybe you implemented a zoom feature, and I was happy you did. The enemies were relentless, but planning out a strategy was interesting. If the enemies were slower at turning it could be a bit more strategic.

Zoom is interesting but refuses to stop scrolling the page.  Not sure if this is Chrome's fault or what.  Also, mouse + arrow keys would be great as an only option if I was left-handed, I guess, but for the rest of us, for future reference, WASD and arrows is not a hard pairing to allow.
Before I found the zoom function, it was incredible hard, afterwards it was just too simple... Also even for LD48 this is way too short.

description:
Help Spaceman Spiff find the parts to repair his ship, so he can escape the planet he crashed on.
Use Arrowkeys to play!
Needs Java installed, at least in version 5.
Reported to flicker on Macs...sadly could not figure out why, so sorry for that :(
author: mlb
title: Spaceman Spiff
comments: Fun little game. The random cloud level can make for some frustrating and nearly impossible escape attempts.
Got stuck on the cloud level, kept getting to places where there was NO good path, couldn't play anything after that level.

I liked it, the random clouds made it impossible at times but at the 10th attempt i won that level. I liked the chasing level after that. It was fun but it lacks a lot. The jump noise kept beeping randomly even when i was not jumping.
The running level was a bit too easy; I won by holding the up arrow and the right arrow.
Woah the cloud level should have been a boss level!
Committed to play it past the first level I had to try about 20 times :P
Neat game. I wish the controls were a little more smooth though. I don't have the patience at the moment to get through that cloud level. I'll try another day.
Aw, no timelapse. I love my timelapses.
Cool game. Frustrating first level. Man that was frustrating. I suck at games overall, but that was a hard one. But cool cloud jumper. Gave me the thrills.

description:
You've defeated the evil aliens, and triggered their base's self destruct mechanism. The only problem? Your ship is on the other side of the base! Your only chance to escape is to outrun the explosion!
Arrow keys - move/aim
Z - jump
X - shoot
You get pushed in the opposite direction when firing the gun. Use this to your advantage when faced with seemingly impossible jumps.
author: jauntypixel
title: Self Destruct: Activated
comments: I love the explosion graphic, I'm not sure how well it blends with the rest of the graphics though. Liked the game overall, really fun and pretty exciting when you're inches away from losing and somehow make it. Nice job!
Fun game, although it would use a few more checkpoints. I loved the Metroid and Mega Man references.

Really well-done, and quite challenging. I couldn't get past the part with the stairs made of crates on the second screen, but I still found it really fun. The graphics are amazing, and the loop sounds great. The whole recoil thing didn't seem to do much, though, it only moved one a few pixels at a time. Perhaps if you used a bazooka instead of a pistol? Still a great game, nonetheless, definitely one of the better ones this dare.
@panzermancer The trick is to fire the pistol downwards while jumping - the recoil significantly adds to the height of your jump. I should probably have been more specific in the instructions.
Tough game but fun. Feels very old school. Also, it's REALLY hard.
