Nice game. I like the basic game idea. +1 for spoken manual. Too short.
Interesting, like a stripped-down Metal Gear Solid.  Good work.
Nice stripped down stealth style game. Amazing how with such simple graphics, it can still give the feeling of something much more complex.

Hey, for a first LD not bad! Beyond needing more levels and variety of gameplay the distractor mechanic needs some fine-tuning seeing as I was able to finish all three levels without using one. I found the commentary a clever touch, good job!
It was very sort indeed.  Too short.  Please, make more levels :-)

description:
*** Post-comp version (do not rate!) ***
- [tab] key toggles less/more detail (may run smoother)
- mouse cursor is now shown in windowed mode (plays nicer)
- I have not accessed a Mac yet to compile a Mac port... (soon!)
Chemical A-21 is leaking throughout the complex and, for whatever reason, only YOU can stop it!
Use the left/right mouse buttons to place and pick up barriers to block the A-21 from spreading to the edges.
You have to be quick, but steady too, as a single gap in your walls can ruin you.
Some levels require a bit of planning/strategy...
Good luck! I'm interested to know how hard it is / how long it takes.
title: Chemical A
comments: As far as I know, the source must be included.
Source is included with the game, I'll mention that.
Link to game appears to be broken.
(?) That link works fine for me... but I uploaded it elsewhere and changed the link just to be safe.
Love the art style, and it's a really neat concept. Mouse control didn't feel especially great, I think I would have preferred a real cursor to just the highlighting the selected box.
Yeah, I think the same way about the cursor instead of the box thingie.
Ah! Great concept, but I agree with the other commenters; there needs to be a cursor.
Yeah, the mouse control has felt 'wrong' to me since the beginning... I have uploaded a post-comp version that shows the cursor (which definitely helps) and adds a hotkey to reduce draw detail.
Don't rate this version! These are technically new features.
Very pretty, loved the tech minimalism.
Very difficult for me, perhaps a slightly easier couple of warm up levels would help.

description:
Aftermath is the story of a looter trying to make it home from a hard day of looting.
You must guid the player across a busy highstreet filled with police. Then you must guide the player through a maze of streets to make it to his house while being chased by a policeman on foot.
There are some minor bugs with collision. Nothing too gamebraking i hope.
I hope you enjoy my entry for Ludum Dare 21. :)
It is a light hearted take on current events/affairs and in no way supports rioting or looting.
author: fatality674
title: Aftermath!
comments: hehe, funny but blatantly unrealistic! there was no-where near that many police about! ;)
Ok game, collision snags a bit on corners but other than that decent.
Definitely funny, but there isn't much gameplay (and this is game compo after all). I guess the "theme" is relevant... :) Good effort on photos. Nice touch on controller support.
In second part there was only one policeman who run from me, I just walked to the end, is it a bug or you made it like this?
Overall... I spent a lot more time waiting for megaupload to give me the file, installing it and then getting rid of it then "playing".
Can I recommend mediafire or dropbox or something quick instead of megaupload? After the 10th game or so hosted there the wait on that site starts to get to ya.

description:
This is my first ever Ludum Dare compo entry, and my first real game of its type using the Java language.
You'll need Java installed to run it.
It's a wave-based stationary survival game, with the goal to move through waves of enemies by shooting at them.
Note: The story (detailed in game intro screens + death screen + win screens) is the important part of the theme integration.
::-- You must survive 20 waves to escape the onslaught --::
-----------------------------------------------------------
IMPORTANT:
I've seen the comments about the playability and bugs, so here's some warnings/tips before playing:
1. Due to the way it's coded, bullets are only destroyed when they exit the screen or hit an enemy. Firing loads of bullets can lag the game. Fire in single or double bursts for best gameplay - as few bullets as possible at a time.
2. Bullets have faster speeds when you fire with the cursor more towards the edge of the game field - to avoid the bullet clean-up problem mentioned in number (1), try to fire as far out as possible (again, in single or double bursts).
3. Also due to the coding, only the most recent bullet fired will have collision. This can cause problems in clean-up (for example creating a bullet shield at slow speed means those bullets will not be cleaned up as they will not get to the edge of the screen or hit an enemy) and may confuse gameplay. For the best advice, I'd say that sticking to single or double shots will help in all cases (again).
TL;DR:
Fire as few bullets as possible, aiming as close to the edge of the screen (or the enemy you wish to kill) as possible, to get best performance and (hopefully) enjoyment.
-----------------------------------------------------------
Please do feed back. It's a .jar file so feel free to download whichever "platform" you like.
I hope you enjoy the game.
- Jonno
author: jonnopon3000
title: Captain Starfire's Great Escape!
comments: Really liked this, could see it translating well to mobile touch device.  Great first entry!
Definitely not bad for a first entry. Seems a bit buggy/laggy in places. Good start, though.
And I wish there was a 'Story' category, because your backstory was really well-written.

Great first entry! I liked how much thought you put into the story and explaining the controls at the beginning. I definitely had some problems during actual gameplay (would randomly get choppy, bullets would go through enemies, bullets wouldn't go where I aim), but those are all things that could easily be worked out. :) Good job!

Gameplay was somewhat buggy and I think slowing ennemies down triggers the wrong feedback loop. Waves are dangerous only when they spawn and become trivial after a few ennemies are shot. It would be more challenging if killing ennemies made the other ones FASTER.
Apart from this, the story is very pleasant. I havent seen many games putting so much focus on it. Great job with it =)

@agersant: I forgot everyone had access to the code, so I called the "enemies get slower when there are less of them" a feature hoping it'd go amiss. In truth it's a bug...I have no idea why it's happening, but it's been happening since the first time I ran a working wave of enemies. I haven't looked into it properly (taken a day or two's break from coding after the competition), but the brief time I gave to the problem in the competition yielded no results. I have no idea why the enemies slow down. It's probably something to do with the way the game updates entities, but I reconfigured that three times in total for certain other reasons and the slowing down still exists.

Either way, thanks all for the comments on the story; it was actually the first thing I wrote to get a feel for the game before writing the mechanics, and I changed it a few times to suit the theme. Writing is a strong point of mine and I like to put work into giving context to anything I do.
There are some issues, but I've covered them in irc, other improvements could me types of different enemies, homing/dodging algorithms, different weapons and so on. Definitely not bad for a first.
Not a bad game, but the bugs do make it hard to play, I had a few crashes and the gameplay mechanics are not too clear. But apart from that seems to play well enough. Fun, if not too groundbreaking.
Pretty fun game, but the bugs make it irritating. Would be really enjoyable if not for the lag, and if every bullet actually went to the point it was meant to!

The backstory had me expecting an epic game! Unfortunately there were a few technical issues that meant I never got past wave 4 - my bullets stopped colliding with enemies (and the enemies lagged very badly), so I could sit shooting for minutes on end and never hit the last few.
Although basic, it's a good first entry that has everything needed - graphics, sound, gameplay, (community participation) and a story. So well done!
Great entry! I agree that with some polish, it would make a good touch game.
Aiming seemed to be off, by as much as ten degrees at times.
I noticed that if I put the targeting pip on myself and fired, that bullets would start piling up around me.
Lag was ok for the first few levels, then got to unplayable. Probably because of my stationary bullet shield.  :)
A good first entry - it has some bugs, though.

I'm finding the comments saying that past a certain round is unplayably laggy; on my machine here (and several of my friends') it runs fine all the way through the game, besides some lag issues for lots of bullets having been fired (and not destroyed) and the little mechanical issues.
In retrospect, maybe the bullets should have a constant speed and should disappear and be cleaned up after a certain amount of time.
I am quite disheartened that some people seem to be experiencing un-playability, though; that's one thing I have definitely not experienced.

I'm going to change the description to include some warnings about playing; little gameplay tips I know of to reduce lag. This might help some people play the game for longer and with more enjoyability.
First rule of programming - It always runs fine on *your* machine.  :)
It's been a long time since I messed with Java, but is this line from Entity.draw loading the image from disk every time, or does it get cached by the runtime?
If you're loading it from disk every frame, that would be a massive speedkill right there. Just something I noticed, as I said, my java-fu is weak.

Seibharinn: Hmm...I'm fairly new to loading and displaying images, so I never thought of it. Do you think that saving the image for each entity type to a global static Image type variable in the main class and passing that image as a parameter somehow to each new entity (rather than having the entities create their own variable)would solve the problem? That way, it'd only ever read the images once.

description:
My first XNA game. There's an installer version at http://mattmakesgames.com/games/ActionMonkeyInstall.zip if this doesn't work for you.
Gameplay Video:  http://vimeo.com/28020677
=======================================================
PLEASE use a gamepad!!! XBox 360 controllers will work natively, but I included JoyToKey for other gamepads.
Press F4 at the title screen to toggle screen mode!
=======================================================
TIPS:
-You can cling to walls AND ceilings!
-While clinging, move to a corner, you'll climb around it!
-Try jumping from a wall cling!
-Try ducking then jumping!
-Stay above the pink line or collect coins to fill your multiplier bar!
-Every time your multiplier bar fills up, you get more points for the time you survive!
author: YMM
title: Action Monkey
comments: Neat entry that feels complete. I never found out if there was an ending to the game, because I was terrible at it! (I use the dvorak keyboard layout, so the jump and climb buttons were in very inconvenient places). However I did manage to survive for a few minutes.

I was far too preoccupied running away from the lava to even consider collecting things or staying above the pink line. Perhaps if the points/bonus also slowed down the rising tide? (Or, if it did this, perhaps it needed to be a little more obvious!).
Very addicting, but of course also difficult. My current top score is 1508 but I will certainly try for better than that.
Good graphical style, but the music gets pretty irritating after a while
A bit too difficult for my taste, but it feels finished, polished and playable. Good music.
Liked the game ( like all the others you made ;) ) Good music and polished gameplay. Got a little Icy Towers vibe from it too. Good job~!

description:
A giant floating eye creature circles a remote landscape, keeping close tabs on the player and making sure they do not run away. In this game, you'll have to find some way of escaping the oppressive eye and reaching a control point at the center of the map.
In the submitted version of the game, there is only one real escape route. See the spoiler at the bottom of the game's page for a mini walkthrough.
Made with Unity 3D 3.4 Pro, Gimp 2.6, Blender 2.58, and a Kodak camera. All textures and models are original, and I've avoided using Unity assets or scripts, save those that are built into the engine.
author: Acheron
title: Under a Watchful Eye
comments: The game feels very oppressive. I tried a few times but could not get to the platform before I got cut down by the death beam.
A cool little concept and a nice take on the theme, although the loop around was a bit of a kick in the head :D
I quite liked meandering around the terrain, but I never did manage to win, because that thing has some angry lasers.

i couldn't quite grasp the strategy here.  in first-person view, it's quite difficult to run somewhere while dodging/hiding from instant death behind you.  it's unfortunate, too, because i did just run backwards to watch the thing's reaction and it's really quite ominous, peeking over your hiding spots staring at you with a laser eye.  i loved that.
Quite a rush, great job on the graphics too, the moving clouds were really worth the time.  Sadly, I didn't actually manage to escape. Very nice concept though, It has a lot of potential =)
did not escape either. once I was next to platform, but could not jump on it for few seconds, and then it shot me down again.

I agree, my game is far too challenging. There is one relatively easy way to escape, however. There is a gap on the left before the second arch. Make a mad dash for it around the corner, putting as much rock between you and the eye as possible.
First, this ran pretty good even on my netbook, which I wasn't expecting-- cool!

I really like the core idea here, and the atmosphere as well. The text taht the Eye of Sauron (well I'm calling it that) gives when you step outside is creepy. However I feel like it doesn't quite coalesce into a solid gameplay mechanic, even after reading the spoiler I don't feel that motivated to try for it because ultimately I'm on rails until the point at which I can attempt my escape.
I did make a few attempts elsewhere and perversely enjoyed being shot down by laser.
Good lord, what an evil eye.
I like the idea of the mad-dash (perhaps Mirrors Edge style) run for your life, but this needs a lot of polishing and balancing.
0.5 Seconds after you leave the circle the eye goes hostile. Once it start firing, the framerate goes single-diit, and movement becomes impossible.
i found a good place to escape it, it took me a few tries though. it feels like there's quite a bit of social criticism in there. is there a reason why the enemy looks like the eye of osiris?
meant eye of horus, of course!
Nice! couldn't win, even with the spoiler... :-)
Very nice visual work.  Never a fan of railroading, I was hoping I could run and hide.

description:
Evacuate the city. Save it from impending doom.
(Special thanks to xRedx22 for building the game for Windows! Note that the instructions aren't included in the windows build, but there's a link to them here)
author: Milo
title: The Wave
comments: I liked the concept but the controls to select the direction of the street sometimes were awkward . Specially when I wanted to make a whole street one direction and I had to do it bit by bit.
I completed the game even without knowing how to play. Seems like a good game mechanic you have there, though. Definitely a game that would be awesome with more working days :)

Yeah, if I continue developing this game, I'd probably switch out the current system (or augment it with) some sort of system based on dragging; a street is currently just any stretch with no intersection, which is the largest unit that still gives the user full control.

Gameplay quite similar to atomic zombie smasher (or how was it called), took me some time to realize what to do (since instructions ingame told me to look online or somewhere else and tehre's nothing in the windows build). And windows build crashed on me several times

description:
You need http://www.microsoft.com/download/en/details.aspx?id=20914 (XNA 4.0 REDIST) installed for it to work.
This is my first ludum dare and my first game ever.
It's not really completed and there are lots of bugs(especially with collisions :)). However, I had fun while doing it!
author: zoral
title: Tetts escape!
comments: I couldn't run this on my laptop even after downloading the xna lib. I'll try later on my desktop.
Even with XNA installed the game crashes on both my computers (running Windows XP). :(
Reminds me of the 8-bit days of my childhood :).  With a little more work it could be a really cool retro throwback game ^^
Good job on completing your first game!  I might suggest reading up on some platformer physics, lots of great tutorials out there on the web.
Can't run it; the same problem triplefox and Edsploration have.
Can't run... XNA... And I'm on Linux... But gratz on making your first game =)

Congrats on making your first game!  One big and probably easily fixable thing I noticed was that you are applying a constant velocity rather then acceleration due to gravity.  Also if you could also get the skeletons shooting back at the player I think this could be pretty fun.

Better luck next time. Not bad for your first game, pretty bad otherwise. Collision bugs and flying character... What I kinda liked was design of the levels seemingly forcing you to think before you drop down more, if it was intended, good idea, but would need more refinement.

description:
This is an iOS game, SDK-OK.  It requires a Mac to build, as well as Xcode 4.  I'll be putting it into Apple's iOS app store as a free app shortly, for those of you unable to play it.  It's vaguely based on the lyrics to Journey's "Don't Stop Believin" from their album "Escape".
For some reason, people are attracted to the streetlights. You, Perry, must run around and shake each of the streetlights to turn off the light, and let the people escape!
author: BleuLlama
title: Streetlights, People
comments: Too hard to get an environment where I could try this game out.
Followin rules you must provide at least an executable working on Windows!
Breaks the rooooools. Still I got it to run here :) Was a bit odd and I couldn't really understand what I was doing.
There's nothing in the rules that states that supplying exes for windows is required.  Read the rules before you preach them, folks.
It is *NOT* against the rules to not provide a Windows executable. If you actually READ the compo rules page it says this.
And the environment to try this is:
1. install Xcode 4 on a mac. (which, if you're a dev, you have already) - this includes the iOS SDKs
2. unzip the archive, open the Raclette Xcode project
3. build and run for simulator.  Done.
"After web, Windows is your best bet. We do have a number of Mac and Linux developers, but theyâ��re a minority compared to web and Windows."
unable to play it or rate it

I was actually able to get it to build using xcode 3 somehow. A cute game, but it seemed like there wasn't too much of a challenge. I was able to make it a ton through the levels without things getting hard. I think that would be the number one thing to do with this if you could.
jobro - yah. i ran out of time to get to game balancing and progression. Thanks for trying it out though. :)
er. *jonbro sorry.  brain not working right
Haven't been able to play it yet. I'll play it when you get it on the app store.
I don't have an iOS device therefore I can't test this game :'(
Have you looked into TestFlight? With that, people won't have to sign up as an iOS developer to play your game.

description:
I kind of ran out of time, so the story isn't clear.
Basically, these aliens kidnapped you and were about to kill you, but (for perfectly logical reasons) you had a bunch of alien gut spiders. They don't hurt you, but they kill the aliens on contact.
Use arrow keys to move. Press and hold WASD  (or their dvorak equivalents) to grab and drag stuff around.
Grab a portal to activate it. You can teleport objects with you by grabbing the portal with one hand while holding an object with another hand.
Some portals need a key to turn on the power.
Grab the cannons to shoot a lightning bolt.
There's also a ghost that can grab things, and it copies whatever you do. Find it and set it free: you'll need it to escape!
Made with flixel 2.5.... Seems to require the latest version of flash. (I couldn't get the swf to run in chrome, but it works in my firefox...)
author: tangentstorm
title: Spiders v. Aliens
comments: Good fun!  I love the ghost idea

I liked it! (quite a lot). I'd like to see more levels and mechanics introduced. After I got ghost me though I just ended up dragging the baddies in front of the turrets and killing them, which seemed cheap and wrong, but the spiders were a bit too hard/time consuming to deal with. I really dug the grab mechanic though. Was a little too easy to get things stuck in walls.
nice mechanic, seemed to work ok for me in chrome.
Once i got the hang of it, it was pretty fun :-) The pushable blocks should move on a tile-based way tho, that would eliminate the problem with collisions
Awesome start to a creative idea, keep up the good work!
Aside from the movement and collisions, this was a great game!

description:
Nobody likes being trapped in an electric death maze.
Use the arrow keys or WASD to move around.
Watch out for electric death.
author: aeonofdiscord
title: Space Captain Iodine Escapes The Electric Death Maze (In Space)
comments: Blind maze game but with the escape theme mixed in. Nice clean implementation. Good work!
Not my type of game, and I had some problem with the hitbox of the character and the eletric beams, but aside that, cool puzzle game.
The switches seem to activate weirdly. They don't seem to do anything until you step off them. Dunno if that was intentional, but I found it a little awkward. Otherwise, very nice. Simple.
It's a trial and error game.  Not quite my cup of tea.  I like that the main character animated though and that the levels had good pacing.
I beat the game (11 minutes, 26 deaths).

I would recommend making it clearer that the whole tile is affected. The electricity between the beams could have been a solid laser instead of the wavy thin line. And I'd suggest making the trigger tiles cover the entire tile, and maybe change color as soon as you step on it so you know it's active? I died a lot because I wasn't sure if I had triggered the tile or not, and it took a while to figure out exactly how they work.
The last level tricked me a few times. Well done. ;)
Cool puzzles! Good difficulty curve. Lacks some music to add ambient and keep it more enjoyable
Took me some time to understand the mechanic (switch activating after you leave it is really confusing) - at first I thought it's really just a blind maze based on trial and error

It's fun, and a good brain teaser. :) Eventually I was able to see the pattern of where the beams would go, and it became more about logic vs trial and error. My main issue though is the electrified exits: cool idea, but it was often hard to see they were blocked, and I kept walking right in to my death. :)
fun little puzzle game! quite tricky and a bit trial-and-error but worth a play nonetheless

Tile graphics weren't bad, controls were smooth and responsive. However I wasn't a fan of the buttons-don't-switch-until-you-leave-them mechanic, made the game frustrating when I'd die for what felt like no reason :/ Not bad, a little too punishing though ;)

description:
I "escaped" from finishing this game - not because I didn't have time, but because it was going in a direction I didn't like. The introduction is still fully functioning and the game mechanics work properly (although they lack the later content to be able to demonstrate such).
Escape is used in both a literal sense (the very beginning) and a metaphorical sense (escape from the physical self) although I did not fully flesh out the second.
Note: source is included in downloads under the game folder
Mostly this was a learning experience for me - as my first LD, I found it very different from a miniLD. In the future, I plan on brainstorming ideas for ALL themes before the competition, doing art by hand and scanning it, and not giving the player effectively over 1 billion options per encounter (1,889,568,000 to be precise - the main reason I ended up scrapping this project)
author: Goldendice
title: Shapechanger (incomplete)
comments: It says "You need permission to access this item." on all three of the links.
Interesting concept.  Nice to see more Ren'Py games.
Cool concept. Sad to see that you didn't finish it. Graphics looks good, music is sweet. Polished interface. Good job overall.
It must have been a good game because I was kind of sad to see it end so abruptly. Could make an interesting puzzle game out of this concept.
There's not much gameplay here, at the moment it's more of a story narration. I like the idea behind this, though!
I hope you can finish this up someday, I think you have something going on, it just needs lots of more time to be developed. Keep it up! Nice music btw
It has potential.  I liked the music.
I think it would have been more than enough of a game if I could see the changes I make as a shapeshifter. :-) Nice music, of course, and the story begins promising.

description:
Mindbane is a 2D action platform game. Manipulate physics and try to escape from the dangerous mind maze.
Developed with GameMaker Standard 8.1.
A post mortem is available here:
http://www.ludumdare.com/compo/2011/08/25/mindbane-post-mortem/
author: LegacyCrono
title: Mindbane
comments: Wonderfully creative, with a great plot. The spriting was largely good (characters, mostly--the terrain was flat but did the trick for the time limit). Massive points for innovation.
I really like the concept, though the difficulty is extremely high right up front.
Great intros and cutscenes, from the characters down to the text effects and timing. For a platformer, it had a lot of immersion!
This is a ridiculously high quality game for 48 hours.
This game is epic! I was hooked from the very beginning, so didn't give up when it ended up being rather challenging. Play through to the end, everyone - it's worth it!
Well written platformer! The intro level combined with the ghosts really works to convey the feeling that you're trapped somwhere you don't belong (which implies that you want to escape :D)
Great game! It was really really hard, but I persevered and finished it. Having instant-respawn was what made it easy to keep playing, despite the challenges. Good decision!
The platform mechanic had quite a lot of depth with all the controls in the end. Nice level design too.

The gameplay is very different - being able to float and hover is nothing new, but integrating a conditional double jump and "ability bar" was a nice touch. Well done. Probably the best game I've played yet...probably :P
Amazing music, definitely one of the better soundtracks, the hover controls proved interesting, I got stuck somewhere but that's mostly my fault as I've never been great at dodging while falling.
Good platformer idea, but too frustratingly hard.
A solid game with a neat mechanic.
I didn't think it was particularly hard. The only thing that caused frustration was the way you keep moving left or right while jumping, even after you let go of the key.

Damn, I just don't have reflexes for this, or i'm doing something wrong, because I just can't get over the part where I'm supposed to use hovering to fall down and don't hit the spikes directly under the platform. It really annoys me, because I'd love to play more (music got me hooked :)
Super punishing, but a really nice progression of difficulty as well. I liked / hated the blind jumps at the end.
The only two quibbles I have were the hitbox seemed about 3 pixels too big (that may have just been the difficulty though) and I couldn't figure out the difference between the down and up keys.

Shrugging off the last vestiges of my testosterone I have to admit that I was almost teary-eyed when reading the various comments and the music kept reminding me of my best times at LAN parties during the late nineties.
In 48 hours you've managed to compile the struggle of so many desperate existences through clear graphical silhouettes, trance-inducing music and hauntingly telling platforming mechanics.
All that does sound lofty, but sir: I tip my hat to you.

Very nice, the pixel art looks great. I enjoyed playing around with the different mechanics, it was refreshing to see a spin put on something so ubiquitous as jumping. One small critique would be perhaps to lower the difficulty but I understand that that could have been an aesthetic choice. Overall a great game!
Really, this is better than VVVVVV!

description:
Well, it aint gonna win any prizes (most probably due to the meagre number of levels; I suck at level design!), but I'm not really bothered.
What matters to me is that I created a game in less than 48 hours, and for that I am very happy!
The basic premise of the game is that you, as King Midas, turns everything you touch to gold! (Well, just empty tiles actually. I'll claim that as artistic liberty.)
You get +10 points for each tile you convert, +100 for bonus tiles. The aim is to get through all the levels, converting as many tiles as you can to get the maximum points payoff!
Controls are simple, arrow keys for movement and Z to use your pickaxe (breaks a gold block in the direction you're looking, but costs you 200 gold!).
I hope you like it, and please do make levels if you want to. It's very simple, just go into res/level/ and make a 32x24 PNG for the level layout, and a txt file with the same name as the image for the description that appears at the top! Finally add your level name (filename without the extension) to list.txt in the order you would like it to appear and enjoy!
If you make any cool mods or whatever, do email them to me at BackwardSpy@gmail.com, I'd love to hear from you :)
author: BackwardSpy
title: King Midas: Escape from the Deadly Block Dungeons
comments: Problem for your game is not the idea (I like it) but level design. Not in level building, but in adding some sort of danger for player: nothing can harm him or make it think faster, so the game is soon boring. You need to add some gold-eating monster, so could be a run against it :D Think about it!
I see this game as a web-based game, try Flashpunk or Flixel it's easy to do a game like this one, add kongregate api ad put on kongregate :D
Thanks for the feedback; I'm aware that it has a rather gaping hole in terms of hazards to the player! I will aim to rectify that in a future version :)

Nice game! I really liked it; the style of your graphics was especially nice. Another thing I liked was that opposed to other games, if you get stuck you don't just have to restart the level, you lose a bunch of points, but can keep going.
Nice idea (reverse boulder dash), but it's too boring - it needs better levels, some sort of challenge

Thanks for the comments! I'm glad you liked the game, and rest assured that next time I will allocate more time for making better levels and some sort of hazards to the player as well. Thanks for playing!
I don't think the game is boring - 17770 score; beat that, loosers! ;)

author: Orz
title: Heist
comments: Haha, sweet idea! I like how this gives the Mission Impossible-like feel where even long hair can be a problem when avoiding lasers. A bit repetitive, and the alarm time is so long that nearly halfway through I could just let them touch the hero and still win.
Simple and efficient idea. I like this game but (I think) the timing when you trigger the alarm is too long.
Neat idea. I love the artwork for the woman!
Hi! nice idea, I like it but... I don't know how to play again, is it possible? if it isn't would be a ni idea I think.

You can actually touch the lasers with your hair without setting off the alarm.  But teah, the timer is too long, the gate takes too long to close, and there's no "play again" feature.  I might add those along with sound effects in another revision.

Very nice idea, with some polish it might be quite good, problem is that it gets boring quite quickly. (But I just see it as ocassional level in some more complicated game). Some mission impossible music in the background would be great :)
Neat concept. Definitely needs a play-again feature!
Interesting game, but it needs pixelperfect collision ... lost the game although no laser touch me. Still, great idea!
as previously mentioned, very nice idea.

description:
wasd to move
x to open doors
z to activate bullet time wich slow down time plus it let you move alot quicker and avoid stuff easier
r to restart if the game glitches
you can
wallrun
walljump
crouch slide
the longer you run the more your speed and jump height increases
TIP: do not do as the first arrow says when it points down, you will fall and die and if you havent made it to a checkpoint before you die your game will crash
author: scrapworks
title: Flow
comments: A very unforgiving platformer. Starting off the game with the quote, "You are running from some shit i cant think of" doesn't really give yourself any points, either. Collisions felt unfair at times, well demonstrated by the sawblades on level 2.

It took me a good deal of time to get accustomed to the controls, and only through trial and error did I finally figure out how to run up walls. If there were some sort of tutorial or even written explanation of how to play at first I'm sure I wouldn't have gotten as frustrated.
I also managed to crash the game on the first level by falling through the wire (like the arrow directed me to!) to my death.
On the plus side, I really enjoyed the music. The level design seemed solid as well, and I think it would have worked very well if the mechanics were tweaked/improved a little.
Overall, good job on finishing your game! I feel like if you had a little bit more time to iron out the bugs/have others test, you would have had a much better final product, but it's almost there!

like the previous commenter, it crashed when i followed the initial down arrow into the saw blades. :( some interesting gameplay ideas but very hard to control. i couldn't figure out how to run up walls. the music is nice and cheesy.
2shared hates me, I wasn't able to download and rate it.

description:
Guide the teddy bear to the exit of each level. Watch out for the nasty orange bears! Stay in their sight too long and they'll shoot you! (With invisible guns.)
Created mostly under compo rules, except I decided to finish after the deadline instead of pulling an all-nighter on a work night (Sunday). :)
author: chrisp
title: Flight of the Teddy Bear
comments: Figuring how the game works is part of the fun!

I'm kidding, besides having no instructions whatsoever (I started bashing keys after my first death. I even thought I would have to close the game to keep playing!) you created a pretty slick mechanic.
Not alot of variation, a bit repetitive. Cool that it's a 3d game tough. No sound at all? The orange teddy bear is the silent-killer-agent-boss.
Oops - I really should document the respawn key, shouldn't I? :)  Pure oversight on my part. (It's spacebar when dead, or R at any time.)

Yeah, ran out of time to add audio unfortunately. I also wanted to add tutorial text, and effects to provide better feedback on enemy state. And the AI logic could use some tweaking. Still, I'm happy with what I managed to get done in the extra-constrained time I had available (fitting around work).
Didn't quite understand what was going on.
It's an interesting mechanic, but it's a bit repetitive since not much thought is required to pass through the levels.

Decently done, this has a potential for a younger audience game. Very cute if not lacking animation. Not a lot of variety and the walls are too high. Camera may get a little frustrating zooming and jumping by itself.
The camera going back and forth all the time is a real problem.

description:
epacse - an alternative physics platformer.
Controls not explained in the game:
F - toggle FPS display
Esc - exit the game instantly
Edit "SCREEN_ZOOM" variable in settings.conf to make the game window bigger or smaller.
The game doesn't save your progress, but it takes 20-30 minutes to beat. It's almost impossible to accidentally get stuck, so keep experimenting!
There's also a hidden SECRET ENDING to discover!
System requirements:
About every modern PC will be able to run epacse. Braid would be a good measure. On Linux, you'll need SDL, FMOD (fmodex) and zlib.
Compatibility issues:
epacse has problems running on Legacy Radeon drivers on Windows. It works fine on Linux with the same hardware.
Development:
epacse is written in pure C, using SDL, OpenGL, SOIL and FMOD. The game was built on my basic, incomplete, opensource engine. It was tweaked, modified and expanded heavily during LD.
All the graphics and levels were made in GIMP, sounds in bfxr.
Thanks:
Randati - for testing and support!
kosinus, mcc - for Mac ports
#ludumdare - for laughs
You - for playing!
Have fun!
author: Marach
title: epacse
comments: Very nice implementation.  I got stuck tho

Really well done. Needs some more coaching. The puzzles are quite hard to solve if you don't get the mechanics, and some introductory levels teaching them (see portal for this done at it's best) would help a lot.
Very very cool! This is totally sweet.
Absolutely fantastic! The puzzles were a great deal of fun, and not impossibly hard. I recalled Limbo, for some reason. Managed to epacse.
Wow, really fun, it gets a bit frustrating later on, but definitely in my top games from the compo.

Works nicely on Linux! But I think the cavernous areas are WAY too dim so see... A little more brightness wouldn't hurt =) Love the light effects made by the particles. Very interesting game. I also gave up on it, on frustration... =X
I really liked this game, for the innovation. The puzzles were interesting and hard to complete (not in a bad way) and it was definitely fun. Good job!
really nice game, one of the few thats actually fun playing til the end ... although some puzzles are kindoff an endurance test - it's still great

The puzzles were a little tedious, but ingeniously designed. Gameplay was pretty good as well. The only problem is that the game's resolution may be too large for some people's monitors. That can be fixed by changing SCREEN_ZOOM in settings.conf

The water level was maybe a bit too tedious however.  Jumping on sinking dirt while being in water is a difficult task.  The sounds were annoying so I had to mute it.

Only by looking at the source code did I figure out where the trick was.  The secret level (not so much of an ending?) was pretty sweet.
All I can see is a black window :'(
What's your graphics card? Do you have the latest drivers? Is there any text in the console window?

This engine is pretty impressive, I liked the main idea. Some puzzles are a  bit tedious but still tolerable. I think adding better control when you blast particles would help, or some cursor that indicates the direction, as it's not easy to tell what direction you are gonna blast them towards otherwise. Good idea, solid implementation!
I really love how the graphics are simple and complex at the same time, nice level design! really great game !
First time I see a sandgame with a real gameplay. The level were great, some of them have a kind of "Another World" ambience !
Looked this up, went "wow, this looked cool, I should port it to mac so I can play it!". Ported it to mac. By the time I was done kosinus had already ported it to mac ^_^; oh well.
However it looks like Kosinus's mac port currently only works on Lion, whereas this version should (?) work as far back as 10.4 (Intel only), so I'm posting it anyway:
Now I'm going to go play this.

description:
BombusaXX - by Daniel Horne
This is a clone of an old game that came with my Atari ST - Bombuzal
How to play
-----------
The idea is to detonate all of the bombs on the level. Without killing yourself.
To detonate a bomb, you go to that square and press space to trigger the bomb - it will then fire when you leave the square.
There are three sizes of bomb - the smallest will destroy the tile they're on and set off any bombs in the surrounding squares
the medium size bomb will destroy adjacent squares as well, triggering any other bombs in a two-square radius.
the large bomb will destroy an area of 3 square radius (triggering secondary explosions in any other bombs in the 4 square radius circle)
Complicating matters, there are other types of tile
"Fragile" tiles can only be stepped on once and will disintegrate when you leave them.
"Ice" tiles, on which you cannot stop - if you enter a patch of ice tiles you'll skid all the way to the other end.
"slot" tiles, which allow you to move the bombs to other adjacent slotted tiles. (To do this, press "p" to pick up or drop the bomb).
Development
-----------
BombusaXX was developed in c++ with Visual studio Express 10. Though I reused some window-and-opengl setup code from other projects of mine, there was no framework involved beyond that.
Graphics are done in the Gimp.
Didn't get around to doing sound.. It was on the todo list but I ran out of time.

Like that! I think you really hit the Theme.

Nice! I also found it a bit too challenging - I would suggest keeping the spider toward the bottom of the camera, so you're not flying blind. Nice job with web physics - it had a good intuitive feel to it.
Reminds me of one of the first Flixel games, and I see you also used flixel. Simple but gets the job done.
Quite bare-bones, but I find the mechanic intriguing. Now just to add more stuff and nicer graphics and you'll have a neat game.
Like others, I keep getting stuck at the bee...
I could get to 240, using the hug wall technique, but after that, the web seemed to stop working. :( Switching walls is quite inaccurate. Playable, but needs some more work.

needs some polish but not bad, bee's were pretty hard to get past, and sometimes the webs didn't seem to fire properly which felt a little frustrating. very nice idea, i had no idea where about i was also, some indicators similar to what was at the start left hand side perhaps.
Stuck at the bee for some reason. I had a good wall hugging technique going (like the rest of hte player seem to have used) but could never get past the bee.

description:

I've since begun an 8bitfunding project to try and raise some money to turn "It's A Bunny Story, Actually..." into a full commercial title. More info available here: http://8bitfunding.com/project_details.php?p_id=221

"Tell me, what IS a bunny?" Hahaha awesome!
The graphics are really cute, and the soundtrack is fantastic! The gameplay was very simple and straightforward, but quite pleasant too. Well done!
This one's pwning! How much for the soundtrack? :p
I really liked the funny voiced sound/music.
No bugs (as far as I can tell).

That is one hella happy sun! Gameplay isn't very original, but the controls are very smooth and responsive - controlling the bunny was a breeze. Liked how you utilized various animals and creatures instead of the generic spikes and lava pits.
And the music was made of epic win! :D
I laughed so hard that my head hurts >_<
After reading the comments I felt I really wanted to play, or at least see how it was like, but no windows here. Any possibility to upload a screencast anywhere?
The audio and humor made me push through this one. It is definitely worth polishing up a bit.
The bosses had to much health to make you restart from them after one hit. Also they could have used some kind of on screen health meter.

description:
Here is my entry for my first Ludum Dare. Initially I wanted to make a game similar to a virus, which couldn't be killed. But it was not in my skill's scope...
So I did this game. I don't know if it's really fun, but I tried to do something which I like myself.
Here is the pitch : the avatar is trapped in a succession of rooms, and there are 8 ways to escape. Are you going to find all of them?
EDIT : Downloadable version added for Windows 32 & 64 bit and several for Os/X  (I didn't know which one I should build with Unity so I built all the existent possibility )
author: Meedoc
title: 8 ways
comments: I found myself playing this for a very very long time... getting new (and sometimes bizarre) objectives as you go along is very compelling.  It would have been nice to have a clear (not obscured by fog) panel with the current objective on it.
Maybe with wine? I'm sorry Unity doesn't support linux. The best I can do (and I'll do it) is adding a downloadable version soon =)

I did quite like the structure of the game. Gotta agree about better indication of current objectives/etc, but still fun and an interesting take on the theme. Graphics were functionally simple, but I think with some odd and unsettling lowpoly or some low-res panel 3d, wolfenstein style, this could have a still lo-fi but creepy air to it.
This was rather confusing do to the bizarre layouts of the rooms. At first I didn't actually realize it was 3D until I started moving around. The 8 ways to win part is innovative, though.

description:
Vampire runner is some kind of Canabalt where you have to avoid obstacles by using a super power to move through them. The original idea was to be escaping from the Sun light, that is why you play a Vampire, but I forgot to add the Sun... small detail :(
Instructions - PC: use click to activate super skill
Instructions - Android: touch screen to activate super skill
(note: on Android looks a bit wrong because I did the game for another aspect ratio).
Hope you like it.
UPDATE: Added timelapse -> http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=osN0gO6ajNs
author: arielsan
title: Vampire Runner
comments: I went in to this game skeptical. "Canabalt but you just run through walls? How could that be fun?"
I was happily proven wrong though, it's a fun little timing game. I like how it kind of strips out all the unnecessary complications and is just a pure simple timing challenge.
Graphics are pretty, although the walls are rather bland.
Didn't really feel like I was Escaping anything, just running. If I was running from something, I didn't really get that.
Yeah, it is a bit incomplete in that, the first idea was to make the "vampire" to run away from the sun but then I never added the sun light following you so it doesn't transmit the idea of escaping.
Happy the game resulted to be fun though.
I kept smiling all the time while playing, it's really a fun game! ^^
I like how simple but good the concept is! 4*
fun was up there :D Felt like a nice twist on a rhythm game. Good stuff
Feels like Bit.trip Runner meets Vampire the Masquerade (or Requiem if you are one of those new school hipster kids :P). Very fun to play.
The game is pretty nice, although some audio would definitely make it better. Fun to play anyway!
This is an awesome start, and I can see this becoming really addicting with some better graphics and a few more surprises. Well done.
Nice little game. I would like to see more gameplay mechanics though, to keep things more interesting.
What a simple concept, yet so much fun! :)

description:
#############################
#Read this bit:
#
#If on CHROME and the web version fails to load repeatedly,
#close all browser windows and restart it,
#if you can't do that use a compiled version.
#It's a chrome thing apparently.
#
#There's an issue on the compiled linux verion caused by
#https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/sun-java6/+bug/457144
#so there might not be sounds
######################
A game about running away, a planet running away actually. First I tried to think what I'd like to escape from: cities came to mind, then I thought that's too much of a cliche  since the whole world wants the same. Suddently: BINGO!
The game features a story mode and a free run mode (with leaderboards).
The story progresses through increasingly difficult levels as the player guides Urth to his uncertain future. As a genre Story mode is a combination of puzzle and abstract platforming.
Escape mode features a large area populated by planets and stars, reflexes and timing are everything in this mode, as players try do distance themselves from the central star. As far as genres go escape mode is a cross between maze and reaction games. Players may also chose to add their scores to a leader board.
Coding was done in processing, sounds with a mandolin and audacity. The leader board wasn't in the original plan, but I had spare time as the bulk of the code was done in day one, while day two brought more levels, artwork, menus and everything else.
Contains many fast moving shapes, consider short pauses between levels if subject to vertigo!
author: Andrew
title: Urth
comments: A very simple but intuitive game mechanic. Played a good enough amount of it until I reached the escape mode, that was too much for me to handle Haha.
Makes me feel sick but other than that its a great game! I'd love to see a more polished version after ld.
I love the gameplay! I haven't been able to escape from escape mode (assuming thats even possible..) but i completed the story mode.
Awesome! It took me a few minutes to figure out what I was supposed to be doing, but once I caught on it was really addicting!
I absolutely loved this game; had a lot of fun. It's very innovative and I'm sure I've never seen anything like it!
lol "Urth". Very nice idea. Graphics could do a little better though. Music loop gets repetitive.
Absolutely fantastic, one of my favourites!

You said in your journal that you were getting addicted to your own game- after playing it, I can see why!  The design is absolutely brilliant. My only complaint is how the leaderboard pops up after every level in story mode if you have entered a name, but that's a minor quibble.  I've only played a few games so far, but this is easily my favorite of those.
(p.s.: I'm gunning for the top of that leaderboard).
You do have a very solid and unique mechanic for your entry. The goal was kinda confusing at first. You may consider adding an in game tutorial after the competition.

Really brilliant game mechanic! It's very simple and yet there are lots of different goals that you give in the different levels. The story was also quite nice. I liked how you tied Urth's existential struggle into the goal for each level. The various modifiers on the planets felt a bit superfluous: I didn't use them very much, and I feel like the gameplay would have been about the same without them.
My record in escape mode is 3047!

Very fun mechanic. It did make me a bit dizzy but that's ok. The hand-painted text was kind of hard to read, no big deal though. I found the game to be challenging but fun. Sadly the sounds did not work for me under Linux, I got a bunch of JavaSound Minim Errors.

I wonder how the game would play if the planet moved but the viewscreen showed the whole level? It would probably lessen the vertigo a bit and make it easier to click on planets (right now it's hard because you have to predict both where the planet will be in its orbit and also where that will translate to in your updated viewscreen). If you're taking this idea further might be something to try.
Anyway, great idea and good execution!

Awesome concept with some rough edges. Clicking on planets close together was usually a coin toss, and there were a few graphical glitches. But the goals were varied, and different planet types kept it fresh. Great use of the theme.
Great game, great mechanic. Much too addictive. I also wish the high score window wouldn't pop up every time (or maybe if it only submitted when I beat my previous best score).

description: Just click to play.
author: TaslemGuy
title: Tiny Mansion Escape
comments: The game is a bit short. But I like how it turned out. First dare. Woo!
The game was actually very interesting. I had a lot of fun with it, the puzzles is what kept me playing till the end. It was slightly short, but other than brilliant.

Thanks. The puzzles were annoying to code, because the scripting system I wrote (it's very simple) couldn't handle them, and suggested that I would need to have 40+ files devoted entirely to the puzzle tiles. Luckily I gave up and just coded it in the applet.
Dude, seriously, I can't even see the game.
Yeah it would have been nice to have a more zoomed in view of the map but no biggie. I quite enjoyed it!
There is a reason it's called "Tiny" Mansion Escape. At the same time, yeah, I probably could have made it a larger view.

A neat little game (little being the key word! - I know it's 'tiny', but a 2x zoom on the graphics would've been nice perhaps. Nice mechanics and gameplay. I would also like to have seen a little more storytelling - why am I here? Where is here?
I would have liked if the floor plan would expand as you explore rooms, but it was a lot of fun.
Very nice adventure game (but you really should have made the screen at least a bit bigger), congratulation :) Bit too short, but for the compo it's quite acceptable.
Fun, a little short, based on the fact I'm disappointed about that shows that it's a good game. Nice, cutish graphics, although a little tiny. Funny, good jokes. :D
I'm sorry to say I really didn't understand this game.  I think this was because he icons were too small for me to discern and there didn't seem to be a way to scroll back the text.
Played until the end, but I want more!  However, it would be very nice of you if the tiles were 2x or something.  I don't have a very nice sight...
I can't access the game  :(  (themage.x10.mx seems down )

Fun little game!  Like others said, my aging eyes, while appreciating the charm of the "Tiny Mansion", could have used a 2x zoom option.  All the puzzles played well and made sense, the writing was entertaining, and I thought the length was about right for an LD entry (both for the developer, and for people who are trying to play it alongside a whole lot of other games).  Great first entry!

description:
Hi all, this is my first LD entry, hope you like it.
In this sandboxy game you help trapped souls by placing your "Holy Light" beam that attracts them and lets you guide them to the Gate of Hell, where they can escape. All while several types of baddies attempt to nibble on the delicious, innocent souls. You can zap them with a "Divine Lightning". Plus a few more fancy features.
Software: VS (C# + XNA), Photoshop, Maya, sfxr
Requires: Windows, .NET, XNA, mouse/keyboard
XNA 4.0 redist: http://www.microsoft.com/download/en/details.aspx?id=20914
.NET 4 redist: http://www.microsoft.com/download/en/details.aspx?id=24872
author: Rudy
title: Soul Hellscape
comments: game looks great :) I think it's a little inaccessible to jump straight into and start playing, there's a lot of elements presented all at once. I actually think streamlining it to just guiding light and electricity might have made it easier to make and easier to get into to play. still, well done for the complexity in there!
Help souls escape by crushing their foes with lightning and using light to lure them to the portal which will set them free.
The help screen did a decent job of explaining the goals for a 48 hour entry. If the game got expanded upon, a tutorial would be nice though.
I love this game. It's simple and it's addicting. I just spend over an hour playing it and got 374 souls. The audio is a bit painful at times though.
That's really cool! A complex, deep and yet complete sandbox game! Great job done here!

The only problem is the high resolution or too small objects. I once had at least 10 souls following my light beam, and I led them all to a Hellrose because I thought it would be the Gate of Hell. ;-) Well, clearly my mistake, but I think setting the contrast a little bit higher and zooming in would help to make this an outstanding game!
great concept. apart from being constantly out of mana, it was quite enjoyable. i'd love to see some smaller levels with less features to get used to the gameplay. great work mate
Thank you for comments, everyone; the feedback is appreciated!
Cool concept, but poor/unbalanced mechanics.  I'm waiting for mana most of the time.
May want to tone down the religious overtones, but overall a cool concept!

Well done! Needs some sort of end goal, gets too easy once you have a few structures.  I spent too much time waiting for mana.  You should be able to get full mana and delete all current souls or something.

I actually found the mechanics quite balanced, with mana fountains and all - I didn't really have any problems with having the right amount. I think this is a very good game for a 48h competition. Graphics are quite nice (maybe a little small, but it's not really that much of a problem), and the game feels very much complete. It's an interesting exploration of RTS genre, and quite addicting too (I spent like 45-60 mins. playing).

description:
This is really just a proof of concept that something like this could be done in SVG + Javascript (apparently it can), but it might briefly entertain a certain kind of person.
Longer-term it's supposed to be a logic puzzle game, which may explain why most of the development time was taken up getting side-tracked and solving logic puzzles and drafting terrible stories to go in the left-hand panel.
author: madmaw
title: Something embarrassingly bad
comments: I couldn't get it to to work but your description made me laugh
I really really love the idea behind this game, but I can't quite get it to work :c
Maybe a hint about how to get past the first level would help!
Fantastic concept, I'd happily play a full game around this idea. :D
Does it work at all? I think I understood your idea, but it didn't help me... random attempts to say something had no result either.
I didn't know how to play...
Cool proof-of-concept, let us know if it gets developed further.
Tried it in Firefox. Maybe I didn't get it but couldn't get much to happen. :-)

description:
This is my first Time for LD48.
Story:
You have just infiltrated a corporte building and stole Research and Development Documents. If you are seen or heard you will be captured.
ESCAPE!!
Tools:
OS: UBUNTU
IDE: Eclipse
TEXTURES: GIMP
3D MODELING : BLENDER
EXPORTING FROM BLENDER : http://code.google.com/p/blender2ogre/
SCENE GRAPH: jmonkey engine 3 Nightly Build
MUSIC: Hydrogen Drum Machine
SOUNDS: Voice of my wife
BETA TESTES: 10BITWORKS.COM
author: scriptblocks
title: Scriptblock's Escape LD48
comments: Thanks to everyone who has downloaded my game.
Please let me know what you think good or bad.
Also let me know if you have any questions on how I made the game.
Is it possible to get to the exit? I tried several times and I always ended on one of two blocks, your wife said "surveilance detected" and gameover (followed by crash of java).
Either I'm missing something, or it's completely blind trial game, try all ways in the maze until you find some which won't kill you.
hi, for me nothing happens when I click run.bat. a command window flickers up then closes real quick
@Shigor The goal is to get to the Green Box on the mini map. There are two rooms that if you go in you get captured. Thanks for trying it.

I feel that I didn't really have any control over the outcome. It was pure trial-and-error with no skill involved. If you were to add something that required skill (avoiding cameras, shooting baddies, etc), I think this would be more fun to play.

I guess the point is to memorize the maze and complete it in time? It's an OK mechanic. To be honest, it's not much fun with just that. The constant "Unlocked" sound was annoying and unnecessary, IMHO. Overall, it's a game :).

Couldn't tell if I was captured due to time running out, or if it was a certain room. One thing I really liked was that the circular viewport combined with the music did create a nice suspenseful atmosphere!

description:
Try to save your and your colleagues monday morning by getting some refreshin coffee! Try to avoid producers and make sure you get lots of coffee! Arrow keys to move your character.
Needs XNA 4 runtime installed.
Check out a video of this game if you can't play it!
author: Wukkopi
title: Profit
comments: Some of the humor in this game might be a bit too insider-y for people to get it, but I know that you guys had fun making this game. :D
Aside that, the graphics look very nice and the game seems pretty complete the way it is. I like the animations.
(The little person with the laptop should really consider changing the battery, though! It's always empty!)

The art/graphics are very well done. A lot of work went into some of the detail. Unfortunately, the gameplay is a bit too simple. There is not much challenge except randomly waiting for guys to move away from the coffee mug or catching occasional spawned one. Unsure how this is central to the theme though.
P.S. Redistributables in archive should be optional.
It does nothing for me.  I can see the process in the task management for a second and then it quits without even showing a window or an error message.

description:
when he needs me, i will be there.
when he is hungry, i will feed him.
i couldn't bear to see him sad.
we are perfect together.
made in about 24 hours.
controls:
arrow keys to move
down to enter door
space to pick up / throw
author: Zillix
title: my escape
comments: could be more polished with more time, nice game btw :D (add sounds and music!)
I almost wrote it off as totally boring but then I kept going. Neat stylish game that I would love to see further developed.
I thought it was a slow and boring game until I entered the door, it was quite fun afterwards. Poor cube got left behind when I reached for the stars =/
not really sure what was going on, but it seemed fun enough. nice job :)

Yeah, wasn't really sure what i was doing or why... what was the levelling about? Why was i collecting circles? And why was the cube wanting triangles? So yeah, confused... it was nice to look at though, liked the contrast of b/w with colour.
I really love looking at this.
Okay, I don't know whether to praise this game or condemn it but I've invested at least 3 hours into it and won't rate it until my rage has subsided.
*SPOILERS(?) AHEAD. (If an arcade game can be spoiled)*
This will get 5* innovation from me. There is more than one innovative mechanic going on and they interplay with each other.

description:
Do your best to escape the darkness in Momentum.
**Note on Controls:**
The controls are gravity based.  You don't move the ball, you change the gravity. So if you hit up, you only change the gravity to pull the ball up; if you hit down, you change the gravity to pull the ball down.
The key to movement is to time the key hits so that the combination of gravity (up, down, left, right) moves the ball the way you want.  once you get the hang of it, we found it to be quite fun.
author: WiggleWorm513
title: Momentum
comments: I recommend you edit your entry and say it's "Web (Unity)" instead of "Windows". I can assure you more people will try it!
Nice gfx and idea, but controls are too hard to handle!
If you don't get is right the first time you end up 1 minute trying to get the ball through the hole on the last segment.
I have to admit, I didn't get past the first hole (and I tried at least ten times...). The controls are very hard to handle, which killed all the fun for me.
But the graphics are very nice. :)
I added some notes about the controls.  Please give it another try with that information and let me know if that helps or not.
Changing the direction of gravity to move is an interesting concept.
On the second level, if you only press up and down (or left and right) you'll end up slightly off-centre at the end and miss the hole, making the controls feel a bit loose.

description:
Escape the evil Cuboids with your sneaky sphere in this adventurous physics-puzzler!
You are a Sphere, taken prisoner by the evil Cuboids. Try to escape. Avoid Enemies. Avoid being seen. Be sneaky. Be stealthy. Escape!
Features:
- Asthetically interesting environment
- Atmospheric soundtrack
- Physics-based controls
- A heartwrenching story about friendship and escape!
- Highscore-system, so you keep coming back to kick more ass
- Geometry-based adversaries and allies
- Completely unrealistic glowing spheres.
- The largest amount of story I ever put in a game
Controls:
Arrow-keys - movement
WSAD - movement
M - mute sound
R - restart level
Also uploaded, in addition to web- and windows-files: A timelapse of me building it and the soundtrack.
Have Fun!
-Matthew
UPDATES
I got a review!
http://jayisgames.com/archives/2011/08/metal_sphere_solid.php
And I wrote a post-mortem. Go read.
http://www.ludumdare.com/compo/2011/08/28/thoughts-on-metal-sphere-solid-a-post-mortem-if-you-will/
Another review!
http://gaming.thedigitalfix.com/content/id/283/just-browsing-ludum-dare-special.html
author: matthias_zarzecki
title: Metal Sphere Solid
comments: Don't know if it is supposed to happen, but when I pushed the guard into the spikes it exploded and sent me out the track. Then I went around by the planet and supposedly escaped in less than a minute...
Don't know if it is supposed to happen, but when I pushed the guard into the spikes it exploded and sent me out the track. Then I went around by the planet and escaped in less than a minute...
What an unexpected mashup of mechanics! Nice!
I liked the music, but it does not loop. Things that could add: The movement is waay to smooths and it is not very clear whether you are seen or not. May be the bots could chase you if your are seen.
metal gear! where is the cardboard box? ;-)
Really solid game! Good mechanics and graphics. Really enjoying the games I've played so far done in Unity.
Beaten! Nice, but the originals of this type of game had better moving for the ball. Anyway it's nice. Thanks!
Really polished, but chugged a bit on my laptop, which made it a bit of a chore to finish. Dash of story really helped keep it interesting right to the end. Good job!
At one point I got knocked outside the course and couldn't get back in.. had to restart it all.
Well this made me feel all nostalgic on the inside. Good mechanics borrowed and tweaked from very different games melded well into an amazing game.

Great game! Absolutely gorgeous graphics, love the lighting. Music was nice, pity there weren't any sound effects! The controls were good but felt perhaps a little more sluggish than I'd like. I like the mashup of ball-rolling maze game and stealth action - great stuff! :)
The movement was too heavy for my tastes, but I guess it was fitting for an atmospheric type of game. You wouldn't really want to breeze through the environments because there's lots of eyecandy.
Your contributions to the community shouldn't be ignored either, you've written a couple of interesting blog posts and currently have the highest coolness rating on the site.
One of the best 3D games I've seen. And the story was truly heart-wrenching! :p

Very nicely done. Camera angles are a little too short and narrow at times. The combination of mechanics is innovative, but the basic concept (escape maze, roll ball) isn't. The controls are surprisingly smooth. The atmosphere/visuals is indeed great, even the short story.
Cool game! Graphics and music is nice too. No sfx yet, but it's understandable.
What I didn't like was the ball movement is too heavy. It feels less responsive, perhaps add more pushing force?
The visuals is unclear too sometimes. It's hard to see the guard's viewing frustum or to tell that the alarm had gone off. You can surely fix this given more time.
And you have rated more than 100 games, already?! Kudos to you!
what a clean and 'solid' entry. i absolutely loved the lighting and shiny surfaces.
Great little title :) This would be perfect on a mobile device..
I got sent out of track too...
If you look past the physics, there's very little game left and since the physics were most likely just a precoded affair this game has very little to offer.

description:
You wake up not knowing where you are. But you know one thing: you must ESCAPE!
To escape you must reach the ladder. Beware of demons, as they will chase you if they see you. You can turn your light off so they won't be able to see you.
Controls:
Keyboard Arrows - movement
Enter - select
F - toggle light on/off
D - run
M - mute music
Tools used:
Allegro5
Code::Blocks
Graphics Gale
sfxr
musagi
author: Doft
title: Mazes & Demons
comments: I loved the light effect and the agonizing atmosphere (and I do mean that in positive way) and the story fit in well with that.
Only negative thing I could come up with was the really small size of the screen .
The really small visibility (even with the torch) is a bit of a bother but the atmosphere and the maze generation was really cool.
The mazes are a bit too complex for the size of the viewing area, but if the area would be bigger it would probably be all too easy :)

Thanks for the feedback! @puffi, if I release a new version I can put a scale option to increase the size of the screen (zooming x2). And like Andrew said, if I made the viewing area bigger it would be too easy.
Good game, would be nice of there was a scaling option (in order to have a bigger window). Walking through mazes isn't my thing though, I like rooms and corridors more. :)

description:
Lost World Lucy and the Temple of the Swine Lord!
It's an arcadey-shooter where you try to outrun the clock while bustin' caps into floating undead pig heads. As Lucy advances through the tomb's chambers, the pigs get harder, better, faster, stronger! And also just more numerous. Good luck, Lucy!
Totally intend to keep working on this in the future, so feel free to leave any suggestions down yonder! c:
The Windows link goes to the Ludum Dare build, with the source GM81 file included.
For future builds, go to http://www.hamstapowah.com/downloads/games/Temple.zip
author: Zaron
title: Lost World Lucy
comments: This is fun! Also, the presentation is lovely.
A problem though is the size of the pickups. They are quite small, and I can never tell if they are supposed to be pickups or enemy attacks.

Not the most original thing ever, but the execution is superb and the game is very fun. There are a few balancing issues with being swarmed at later levels, but still one of the top LD48 games that I've played.
Fun fun! Very stable and well polished. Good audio too.
Very fun! However, I felt like I was instead travelling deeper into this temple, rather then escaping it.
Nice graphics though, I like the protagonist :)
Nice and polished game! I agree that the pickups should be a bit bigger though.
Very good, one of those I'll be playing a while after LD is over.

description:
This is my first time using Flixel, having decided originally to work in CS5. A hasty rewrite on Saturday followed by another two days of development resulted in this, my second Flash game!
The jam's extra time was very much appreciated and meant my brother could create music for it. Fun!
author: Vidd
title: Idol Run!
comments: too much spikes, couldnt get far because I jump too much on those spikes
A simple concept, but very polished and challenging, and really nice music.
I got to a point where I saw white light. I think I managed 99 metres, so I suppose I came 1 metre short from epic win.
Simple, well put and challenging. Very good overall.
Simple and fun, fits the theme perfectly, great execution!
The collision detection on the spikes seemed a little wonky, but a good game all around. Challenging, but far from impossible. Decent sound and graphics. Nice work.
Very good sound, but the graphics could be a bit better for a jam entry. The mechanics were very well thought, simple and effective, but I think his jumps could be a bit higher/farther.
Nice graphics and excellent music! The controls were a bit dodgy and lacked the mario feel. =)

description: A (hopefully) challenging retro-style platformer. When fortune frees you from a dire predicament, you must make the most of the moment to escape the warlock's clutches -- and his fortress of hell.
author: hulahulahest
title: Hell Fortress Escape
comments: You succeeded in making this game really hard. I love the artwork!
Really sweet! My only problem is that several tiles resemble a tad too much ones from La-Mulana.

Best game I've played so far. Wonderfully realized world, great level layout, good difficulty level, and excellent artwork and style. Haven't finished it yet but I absolutely intend to come back and beat it.
One thing, is there really no audio or is that just on my end?

i love these kinds of games and the art style is awesome.  there are some just annoying mechanics, though.  there are a couple of room where if you walk into them you will likely just immediately die from having held the 'walk forward' key.  and more frustrating was that grabbing a rope was pressing up instead of holding up.
Great game! Good difficulty level, with a good level design and with sweet, sweet graphics makes for an overall pleasant experience. To bad you dont have any sound at all(?)
Really love the graphics, it would be great to have audio too.
There is no feedback the talisman hits the enemies.
Some times it double jumps when I touch only once.
It was a bit hard, mainly because checkpoints are far away from each other, that sucked a bit.
Good work and good luck with the game.
I thought I was into hard platformers but this is driving me mad :p. Very well build game, awesome job building this in 48 hours. Im missing sound and epic music though :(
epic music is definately amiss, it would ease the pain of failing all the time :D

If you are going to make a game that's so beautiful and has such potential, please be kind enough (especially to us reviewers) and have an easy difficulty! i.e. a lot more checkpoints or being able to try over from the same room. Frustration (due to my non-Godlike-reflexes) caused me to abandon the game when I'd rather keep playing :( Other than that, very solid! Controls were good, graphics were awesome, the Metroid style gathering of items and free-form exploration of the castle were awesome! Similar to notch's game but a lot better as it was in 2d :)
Great game, although very frustrating in some parts. Would've been nice to have some sound. I managed to beat it with 11/12 secret coins and 213 deaths :D

Very impressive entry! You really got a lot done with your time and did a great job prioritizing gameplay. Sadly, I didn't actually beat the game as the difficulty was just a bit too much for me to do while half asleep, bookmarked so I can play it again at a later time though!
Now if I could figure out how to get that orb/coin in the belltower...
Had great fun, completed the game a couple times and I'm now trying to get a 100% run.
Figured it out literally seconds after posting that!

When you jump off the cliff right at the beginning of the game and move to the left you can get trapped in a cliff to the point where you can't kill yourself or move. Was that intentional because I find it funny to do? :D
Great game... love the (insidious) level design, graphics, feel, etc.

If you check out my game (Red Rover) and like the music, I'd be willing to write some music for your game. That's my biggest gripe.... no sounds or music. Especially for when ghosts appear, fire shoots out, etc would be nice to have sounds. But overall great game, fun, fleshed-out, etc!
I am really impressed by this entry. I wouldn't say that it's hard, but it's really unclear how to progress at times.

Art's perfect and level design seems to be done well, although I got frustrated too quickly on some places and hadn't finished... difficulty is a bit too high (but I might get back to it and try it again, it really seems as one of the few entries worth playing. 8 bit style audio is sorely missing :(
Nice work, although on your page you say you fixed a minor oversight after the competition ended. Isn't that not allowed?

description:
This is my second Ludum Dare and the first time I submitted a game. The game is a short and buggy platformer. It doesn't really tell you why Mad Scientist want to kill you but at least it's a game that you can play through.
UPDATE: I fixed two major bugs that caused the game to not load in Firefox or Safari. For best performance I would still suggest Chrome.
Controls:
Left and Right - move
SPACE - jump
If you disappear into flames - reload
If you are hit by a mad scientist - reload
If you jump into a wall and get stuck - reload
If... - reload
Tools:
Acorn
bfxr
CoffeeScript
Vim
author: leksapeksa
title: EvilMegaCorp
comments: You need to add support at least with Firefox or IE 7/8 :(
I'll try to add support for Firefox this week but I cannot support IE 7 and 8 because of lack of Canvas support.
First thing I did was jump through the wall to the left and into the fire and get stuck. But I guess I have only myself to blame. ;)
Couldn't get it to do anything :\
A little bit buggy and very short, but it works! I like the sounds, especially the chopper sounds. Obviously the game needs a lot of work still, but it's a promising start.
I don't like that when I die I have to reload the page.

Needs a restart button, pretty badly... but pretty good fun nonetheless! I quite liked the graphics, they reminded me of playing games in Windows 95 when I was a kid (sorta like capture the flag: http://www.carrsoft.com/ctf/capture_the_flag_game.html).
Thank you for your comments! I made the game to work in Safari and Firefox and I'll try to get it to run on IE9 later this week.
And yeah.. It really does need a restart button :D But when time is running short you have to cut some features. Next time. I promise.
Big props for finishing something, even if it isn't the most dramatic thing ever shipping it is all important!
Too slow for my PC, not rating.

description:
A survival horror game involving spiders and fatalism.
Arrow keys to move
Stepping on a spider hurts you and makes the other spiders upset.
Health is indicated by background colour (lighter greys = bad)
Spider upsetness is indicated by the white noise.
Hint: it's easier to escape spiders to the west, but you don't want to be late.
author: sstrandberg
title: escape.swf
comments: TypeError: Error #1009: Cannot access a property or method of a null object reference.
I am slightly technophobic, thanks for the nightmares.
Seriously, don't play if you don't like spiders. Zomg nightmares.
I really liked it and did not mind stepping on those spiders at all
I played this before you submitted it to the competition, and it makes me laugh now as much as it did then. It's not the best, but it definitely has that fun and humour factor (for me at least) :)
Everything is nice and peaceful until you squish one too many spiders, then it's all over before you can blink. And the noise OH the noise!
hah, this is great.. truly terrifying when stepping on a big spider :D. Love how such a simple game can make a big impact.
If your goal was to creep me out, mission accomplished

description:
made with python + pyglet.  if you're not using windows, you should be able to run the game on any system by downloading pyglet from http://www.pyglet.org
