If you get errors about AVBin missing, please download appropriate file for your system from http://code.google.com/p/avbin/downloads/list
Sorry about this inconvenience.
graphics with adobe photoshop cs4
sound with sunvox, guitar pro and garageband, with adobe soundbooth for tinkering
notepad++ for code
it's a thing, maybe it's a game, maybe not.  it's probably not fun.  i wanted to try to do something a bit experimental and - dare i say - artistic with a bit of thought underneath, so take it how you will.
you need to escape!  watch out for monsters.  interact with things.  if nothing happens, try to motivate yourself some more.
dont read the source, cause that's where the real monsters lie (=terrible coding!)!
author: shinD
title: Escape...
comments: pyglet.media.riff.WAVEFormatException: AVbin is required to decode compressed media
You forgot to include AVBIN library (it can be easily googled and downloaded, but...)

Very nice audio which sets quite a good mood together with the art... but as you said yourself, is there a game? - Character walking slowly half a pixel at a time (if not less, i was sure i'm blocked somehow in collision, then i noticed he IS moving.... superslowly.

You're right, I didn't think about avbin, since I had it and stuff just worked.  Sorry about that.  Slow movement is intentional, though it should be at least noticeable.  I haven't been able to test the game on any other computer configurations so it could be due to general performance issues too, I'm not sure.  But yeah, it's very focused on audio and art - and I'm glad those parts work as I intended - not so much on gameplay at this state.  It can be 'won' or 'lost' but that's about it.  So yeah, up to your interpretation of the definition of "game"!
Congratulations on your first entry. (It works on Linux by the way.) I'm glad you didn't pick the platformer (there seems to be too many around).
I think you need to at least double the speed and give more feedback to the player. Then I think this would make an interesting game.

After "losing" 3 times, I ended up changing some of the code and made it print some (hidden) value. But I was still not able to win. I wasn't even able to take the pills. I think the player could use some more feedback with respect to those values.

description: Tested in chrome only. Incomplete, no damage from spikes, no enemies, and only only 3 partial levels :(
author: beeglebug
title: Escape from the Tower
comments: Something obviously went wrrong with the submission form, as the link to the game is missing!
Go to udlr.net/LD48 to play it.
it seemed like I couldn't die! The graphics are great.
Yeah, I didn't manage to add damage before my time ran out, so all you can actually do in this version is drop down a couple of levels and run out of the castle!
Thanks for the nice comment on the graphics. I think I spent too much time on them and not enough on the actual game though. Still, lesson learned for next time!
We had slightly the same game-idea, but Very different implementations :). I think you're off to a nice start, but needs more challanges.

Short and simple. Nice graphics and presentation. This shows great promise, it's a shame you ran out of time. But yes! Let that be a lesson - code first, graphics later. It's always better to have something that plays good over something that looks good.

description: Make in 24 Hours because im on the Gamescom 2011;
author: dotslasch
title: DarkRun
comments: The game does strange things when I press "c".. still, I couldn't get the second cube :(

Hay press a for get the second cube press o for the local deth match press p for the local coop press c for getting funny press e for respawn press x , m , for the cecond multiplayer controls press v for the second multiplayyer shoot
press a and then the left or thew right key for move the second cube
Very strange, what is the "second cube" ?
controls need some explaining in this, also art could do with a bit more effort. Congrats on completion.
I'm at a loss at what the controls are. Couldn't get the second cube.
Definately needs a better explanation of the controls. I don't mind exploring the input, but it's really annoying that the game plays counter to the expectations you set with the red text.
The first levels can usually be completed by holding a and right, dodging is much trickier than it needs to be

description:
Hey there!
This here game is my first Ludum Dare entry.
After raiding a dragon's treasure trove you seek to escape with all the gold you can. In order to avoid dropping any you need to do bunch of dodging and flinging of your sword.
Features:
- Random level generation!
- Basic physics!
- Multiple endings.
- In-game control list.
IMPORTANT:
If you've not run an Xna game before you will need to install:
(The XNA re-distributable):
http://www.microsoft.com/download/en/details.aspx?id=20914
(You may also need the latest version of .NET):
http://www.microsoft.com/download/en/details.aspx?id=17718
author: DecsterB
title: Cave Runner
comments: "At least you got away, I guess" ;)

Enjoyed it! Seemed a little bland at first, but honestly it turned out to be a pleasant little experience. The sword-throw mechanic hugely helped out gameplay, and the number of obstacles was just right at three (fireballs, bats, blocks).
A bit more explanation at the beginning would be beneficial, but overall not bad at all. I liked the game-over screen too, I'm assuming it changes depending on your results :)
I did intend for a explanation/intro just before you start but unfortunately there just wasn't enough time in the end. As for the game-over screen, it most certainly does.
Anywho, I'm glad you enjoyed it. :)
The first keyboard/mouse sidescroller I've seen so far, and it's pretty good! The premise is great and the obstacles are varied. If I could make one suggestion, speed up as you drop loot.
Not bad, but the movement felt like everything was taking place on the moon, which actually made it more tedious to play than if it were twice the speed(I imagine).

I thought I was looting boxes... until I lost all my gold. Nice simple gameplay, but lacks gameplay, depth and better art. It could have been faster with more action. Boomerang sword is fun and nice mechanic.

author: intmain
title: Astar
comments: So I get to level 14, and with no end in sight, I decide that coin isn't worth it, and finish with a 7/8. Ugh.
Other than that, I like the slower pace puzzle feel. Some of the path finding made me feel like I didn't have a say in the move at all, but overall pretty good.
I like this! A simple but versatile concept.

I almost ended in level 8 after few attempts and it's good I played more, level with disappearing tiles made me to play few more, but lev 12 with two bats was the end for me... just couldn't find a way to dodge both flying mice at the same time.
Simple but effective and working design, same as Josh, pathfinding annoyed me a bit in some places, especially near holes.
I actually thought that the pathfinding was what made the game good.  You have to base your moves knowing that the pathfinding cuts corners.  Simple yet awesome game.
My only complaint is that it doesn't select a tile when you are on a line.
Like the Concept this could be a fun flash game with some polish like a level select screen and some of the things to see on popular games on places like Kongregate.
MMM really liked this one! Planning out the movement against multiple enemies got tricky but was quite fun. Really would like to see this explored more, please continue.
Wonderful game. Very cute aesthetics, both visually and musically.
I agree with Chevy. Great concept and execution. Adding more level elements would make this game even greater.
Lovely game, I really like the music.
I liked this game. I think the sound could have been better(I would have preferred sound effects to music if it came down to a choice) but it was overall very well presented.
Finish this! add a level select screen and get it on kongrate!

Good idea, good implementation. Progression feels consistent and does well to add new concepts and apply them. Enemy AI is very predictable, and that's good or bad depending on what your goals were, but it produces a nice (imo) puzzle feel to the game.
This was a very fun game. Nice concept, well executed, and nice music to back it up. I liked the graphics too :)
The difficulty was also well balance, introducing a new concept when I thought I had got everything figured out.
I somehow managed to end with 12/8 coins though... I have an inkling it doesn't take on off when you die after getting a coin?
Lovely game concept and art. Though not my personal type of game (to impatient).
Fun game, lovely music, fantastic and innovative concept, and challenging to boot! More community involvement would've been nice though.
It took a bit to figure out how the enemies move but once I did, the level design became quite interesting.

Nice, cute little game. Cute isometric graphics that I really like. Good choice using mouse for primary control with isometrism because otherwise that's just a huge pain. Nice game concept too. Good all around.

description: This is a crap game that will hopefully make you give up and then suddenly carry on.
author: GreaseMonkey
title: A Crap Game
comments: Definitely a game. Music is a bit annoying but the gameplay is there - not sure how it's an escape but I'm sure we could world out a way to rationalize that later.
kevglass: You press the escape key.

A fun game. I like your deliberate misinterpretation of the contest theme; pretty funny. You seem to have gotten sick of making levels pretty quick there, which is odd considering how simple you made the level mechanism. Still, good game.
description surprisingly accurate. i couldn't figure out that i had to press esc i looked at the source though. :(
I really like this and it opens up for some interesting puzzles. I didn't really get the escape key thing. You should really do something about that :)
Really enjoyed this, you scored top marks for humour. :D
In the way of constructive criticism, I guess there might have been a better way to bring the game to a close.
This game certainly isn't crap though! Simple, fun and pretty original.
Nice game, I had fun playing it.
Your host seems to be down. I can't download the game :(

description:
Unrest is a game where you have the goal of escaping hopelessness. You are set upon by all the issues that plauge your life, and must fix them without creating too many issues, or making any one issue too big.
The issues you face scroll by in the background. As they become bigger issues, they become bigger, and if any one issue becomes too much, the game will end as you are overwhelmed. Likewise if you let everything build up, you will notice that the chance of espcaping hopelessness (visualised at the bottom of the screen) will fade.
If you start to sort out your life, the issues will reduce in size, and your goal of escaping hopelessness will become clearer.
It is intended that the game is very easy to loose, and juggling all of your issues is a hard task.
Note there are a few issues with the bindings, and the static versions. The best bet is to run the source version, if you can handle installing the dependancies. The Linux precompiled version will probably only work on 64-bit systems, and the Windows one may give some errors in a command prompt, and may 'crash' when you exit - but the game itself will work.
Overall, I'm happy I completed the task, and I hope the game is something a little bit different. I'm no artist, so the art and (lack of) animation is not great, and I feel I could have done better, but there we go.
author: Lattyware
title: Unrest
comments: I keep getting "uneducated" floating down no matter how many times I go to college :)

They will reduce in size as you do things (allthough some will also increase) - this isn't instant, so it's best to be careful about doing lots of things quickly in case you are causing a big issue elsewhere. The aim is to simulate the hardship of juggling all of the issues that make up your life - and focusing on one mere element will lead to disaster.
As I mentioned in IRC, crashes on startup! :(
Spent a long time playing this.. I could not figure out how to get rid of addiction.. I never took drugs in the first place? Great concept and execution though.

What operating system, what build, and how does it crash? If it's 32-bit linux, try running from source rather than the prebuilt version, as that was built on my 64bit machine, and from what I gather it won't run on 32bit installs. Unfortunately, I don't have a 32bit install to create another version.
You begin with a small ammount of addiction, and you also gain it (in much lesser amounts) from alcohol. The answer to that one is sleep, sleep in your bed and addiction will go down.

Good idea, fairly well implemented. Might have been good to see what actions have what effects (is holding down a relationship purely to stop loneliness, or does it also reduce stress? etc.) - also, the idea of essentially 'acquiring' a girlfriend for your house who then becomes a stationary action-fulfiller (ahem) doesn't chime well with me, but maybe that's just a victim of the very static art style.

Yeah, I wish I could have done more with regards to that kind of thing, but it was simply a time and art issue - I'm no artist and so animation was virtually non-existent, and hence I was really limited on what I could show well. I initially wanted to do a lot more properly (you'll notice there are some sprites that are unused for stuff like watching TV) which I had to replace with just a fadeout.

I was torn as to whether to show the effects. I felt that showing them made the game a) really easy and b) less interesting. It made it a pure maths game, which while technically what it is, it made it less about experimenting and juggling everything, and more about 'got to do this stuff in this order'.
If you are really interested, if you grab the source code you can take a look at what each event does.

description:
Requires XNA 4.0: http://www.microsoft.com/downloads/info.aspx?na=41&srcfamilyid=a88c6dec-aeae-42cd-a108-d35c013c3b97&srcdisplaylang=en&u=http%3a%2f%2fdownload.microsoft.com%2fdownload%2fA%2fC%2f2%2fAC2C903B-E6E8-42C2-9FD7-BEBAC362A930%2fxnafx40_redist.msi
.Net Framework 4.0:
http://www.microsoft.com/downloads/info.aspx?na=41&srcfamilyid=9cfb2d51-5ff4-4491-b0e5-b386f32c0992&srcdisplaylang=en&u=http%3a%2f%2fdownload.microsoft.com%2fdownload%2f1%2fB%2fE%2f1BE39E79-7E39-46A3-96FF-047F95396215%2fdotNetFx40_Full_setup.exe
Help secure the borders of Best Korea by eliminating those who would seek to leave.
Controls:
W - Forward
Mouse Move - Aim
Left Click - Primary Fire
Right Click - Alt Fire
Don't run out of ammo or it's game over!
Get to 1,000,000 Points to win!
author: billknye
title: North Korean Escape
comments: Great game! My only complaints are that the 1000000 point goal takes a bit too long to achieve and the final rank's weapon makes the framerate drop below 1 FPS when fired for longer than 1 second :P
Only moving forward is terrible =/ Game would be a lot better if we could move with with WASD

Moving only forward is very clunky at first until you realize that's all you really need :P It's a bit hard though at first, I'm not even sure why I lost at first (out of ammo). Some in-game explanation would help. I thought since they are escaping, they are trying to reach bottom of the screen. Though once you get past start, it turns into a fun mass-murder simulation. This is like a zombie game, except everyone's alive and are not trying to kill you. And minigun is just lol. 1M is a bit too much tough, I didn't see past 350K.
Fun! I liked that each new weapon was more ridiculously powerful than the last.
I agree with the comments about the goal being a bit high and it being a bit hard to avoid running out of ammo at the start.

I particularly liked the arrows pointing to the escapees. The arrows blend together nicely into a ring that is darkest in the direction of the greatest concentration of people, which looks cool and is very useful once you have the more powerful weapons.

description:
NO ESCAPE is a game made by jukimv1986 with HTML5 canvas and audio.
You play a character trapped in a fuzzy maze, using green portals to move to the next level, which you may find with the help of a strange beeping sound...
The idea behind the game is that you are actually in a vegetative state, being the maze a representation of your damaged brain.
author: jukimv1986
title: NO ESCAPE
comments: Wow, good 3D effects for HTML5. warping of objects as they got to the edges of your field of view were very cool.

The range of the frequency of the beeps could have been much larger though. It was sometimes hard to tell if I was getting closer or not. Also, considering there's only 1 sound in the game, it would have been nice to make it a little more polished and not as harsh. Aside from that though, pretty decent game. I didn't finish though, because by the time I got to level 12, I wasn't sure if there was a finish, or if it was randomly generated.
I had some problems with implementing sounds and at the end I decided to stick with just one, that played depending on the distance you are from the portal to help you get to it.
By the way, there is no end level, there is no escape.
Interesting engine, nice concept and well executed, but doesn't hold attention for long.  The sound can become quite irritating pretty soon too.
Interesting mazes you generate, The view distortion effect was a bit hard to get used to, but I grew to like it after I got used to it.
OK nice tech but the game gets monotonous quite fast, also the sound is quite irritating after a while. Congrats on finishing!

Nice work for twelve hours!  I did think it was cool how close/frustrated I felt when the beeping was fast and I couldn't find the exit sometimes.  The warping of the player's version as he turned made things feel disturbingly non-euclidean and helped the general vibe.
That said, it was a frustrating experience and the beeping really got to me.  I'm very impressed with the implementation and it does a good job of conveying what you were going for, though.

description:
WARNING: This game is 38 MB, so be prepared for a little loading.
WARNING PART 2: The source is a 60 MB .FLA file.
My first Ludum Dare game - actually my first attempt at a game in over three years.
Don't expect to have a lot of fun though, this a dark game and the name is quite literal - there's no way to win. But if you're gunna go down you might as well give it your all, so you can still try for distance.
Graphics were created in Cinema 4d and After Effects.
Game was assembled and coded in Flash CS5 and ActionScript 2.0.
Music was recorded and mixed in Pro Tools.
Sound Effects were created in Pro Tools, based on sounds found at freesound.org.
author: kato9
title: NO ESCAPE
comments: The graphics and the audio were great! I missed an actual gameplay element, but it was still an experience for me!
reminds me of slo-mo canabalt, but this is not a game. altough nice graphics and sound.
Super super pretty graphics and audio. I think gameplay would have distracted from the experience, I like it this way.
Nice trick on making complex 3d-models, only to use the silhouettes. I'll remember that one :-)
this looks and sounds awesome.. but seems I can't get anything on the screen moving. SPACEBAR is supposed to do something ye? I'm on Chrome 14.
Great graphics. But as others (and yourself) said, more gameplay would be nice.

@ippa Just tested it in Chrome and it worked fine for me. My only guess is that the .swf wasn't in focus - as in, until you've clicked somewhere in the boundaries of the Flash media it won't recognize keyboard controls.

Very interesting entry, I have trouble considering it a game and more an interactive video. I felt this fit the theme very well, and the aesthetics really help sell the fear and distress, conveying a heavy mood that only makes you feel like you want to escape.

I really regret the lack of a more interactive experience that would move it closer to a game, I think this could be done by making exploration possible in multiple directions, and perhaps even removing the time limit and allowing the player some interaction with the world of some kind (crows that fly away when you get near?).
All in all, while lacking in the interactivity department, a memorable experience, and interesting enough for me to press the try again button a couple times.

Can't get the game to do anything (and yes I clicked multiple times to put the SWF in focus.) It just sits there for about a minute while it rains and then the robot(?) whines and dies and it says I ran 0 meters.

Appears I can't edit my comment. Anyway the game works fine in Firefox apparently but couldn't get it to work in Chrome at all.  Unless I'm missing something you just hold spacebar until the end?  This thing looks and sounds great but definitely lacking on the 'game' aspects which is a real shame.
This game doesn't work in Chrome, seems fine in Firefox. Fitting that I just switched from Firefox to Chrome today, and a game called "No Escape" is forcing me to go back to Firefox ;)
Gameplay was... Well, you made the game, you know how it is. :P Makes a nice art piece though!
Unfortunately I couldn't get this to run in Chrome either. It animated and looked lovely, but there was no interaction whatsoever. I checked I had the flash focused too.
Although awesome atmosphere, I can't help thinking it's just a glorified movie - that required 38Mb to download something that should probably have been a 1Mb flash file.
Overall it was a very innovative take on the theme, that created a real atmosphere. I'll remember this game/movie/application/art piece longer than most entries I've played.
I'm not even sure I would call it an interactive experience if you wedge down the spacebar :). however, as far as mood and audio go it's great :)
This is a game where my desk lamp is a better player than I am.
Great atmosphere. Read your Layers Breakdown, congrats on focusing on what you know and building a "game" with the tools you're comfortable with.
Please, make a game next time
Not really a game, doesn't fit the theme, and doesn't belong in this compo.  But I really liked, the graphics & animation and hope you make one for the next compo.

description:
MoveOut is a puzzle game. You need to move walls away to get escape from the level. Some walls you can't move, than you need to pick op a bomb and blow up the wall. Watch out. If you move a wall on yourself the level will restart.
The game is created with the haXe compiler and FlashDevelop. All the graphics are done using Paint.NET and the sound effects are done with sfxr. The music is created with a modified version of Autotrack-C (Included in the source in the folder lib)
author: cornedor
title: MoveOut
comments: I'm not sure if it was just me but I couldn't drag pieces more than one square which made the game a bit tedious to play. Looks like it could be fun otherwise.
foobaz, yeah i know, tried to fix that but wasnt able to fix it on time. I was already happy that i could select and move those blocks :p but did it a bit wrong so you can only move it one block.
that's fun we did almost the same game :)
Got the idea to implement dynamite too but didn't had the time :)
Yours seems to be harder than mine! and it's a quality for a puzzle game!
Not my kind of game but I can see how people would like this, so good job. And the tune is nice too.
uuav: Seems that you select the walls by color too :P
Interesting. A bit uncomfortable to play and some pieces duplicated when I killed myself. You also kept the bombs for some reason.
A bit too tedious to keep playing for a longer time, imo.

description:
Run away from angry mob. Avoid large stones and logs.
CONTROLS:
<space> = Jump (The longer you press, the higher you jump)
<esc> = Exit
author: platypus
title: Monster Hunt
comments: I was unable to run this using Netbook and Windows Starter 7.  I got "Unexpected error occurred when running the game"

I believe the problem comes from insufficient RAM. There are 3200x480 images used in the game. I tried it on 3 different computers, and the oldest one gave me the same error. I could chop the pieces to smaller ones and change the code, but I am siply too tired to do it now. Sorry for the inconvenience. It runs fine on my netbook with 2Gb of RAM.

A pretty interesting game!  I really like the art style.  I must admit, when I first started playing I was very frustrated because I couldn't understand what I was doing wrong and always got caught.  The obstacles are much larger than they look and I would hit them even when I was some distance away (I didn't actually understand that I was hitting the obstacle).  I enjoy the reversal at the end, it was an interesting twist!
I liked the twist when you finish running away, not going to spoil it here, but I literally laughed out loud.

I'm glad you all (or most of you) like my game. As for the collision issue, the game uses pixel perfect engine and all the obstacles have pixel perfect masks. However, I was afraid that the player character would get stuck because of automatic running, so I made its mask a circle. Thus it is not 100% accurate, but you're testing your luck if you run that close to an obstacle ;).
hehe cool ending :) Very short though would of played more
Very funny ending! I like the simple idea with a twist! Congrats!
Simple and cute... well, except the thing that happens when one gets caught, that is.
I enjoyed the art style, it creates a nice dreamy atmosphere. I liked the ending, too.
Nice graphics. Gameplay was good but too short.

description:
It's Right Behind You! is a race to escape the lava chasing you down into the caverns.  Can you make it to safety?  Features destructible terrain, multiple difficulty levels, and fast-paced platforming action!
This game was made in lua, using the love2d framework.
There's a demo/speedrun of me beating nightmare mode up on YouTube: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pvZEqWZdy_Y#t=5s
Cheers and thanks for checking my humble little game out.  If you have any suggestions for improvement, please let me know @mikelovesrobots on Twitter.
author: mikelovesrobots3
title: It's Right Behind You!
comments: So no real story or audio to speak of.
Run and dig down through the earth to escape flowing red stuff. The digging mechanic was more interesting than other versions, but the only the difference in modes was the speed of the lava.
Interesting prototype, could have used some more mechanics to make it a real good game but a start.

Fun little thing.  Would have loved to see the map layout change, if only between difficulties.  Digging down is slower than sideways, which is a subtle touch to stop people from just trying to drill down forever.
Very fun game! I like how the lava flows.
Pretty cool gameplay, it was quite challenging at first, the lava that was just sitting there got me a number of times.
The graphics don't look that good, and there's no audio. Nevertheless, a nice little game. (And of course, bravo for using Love2D.)

I agree with dramble that it could have used more mechanics. Maybe some special blocks that required obtaining a certain item to break. I think some sound effects would have really made the digging mechanic more fun to use.

description:
Well, here it is.
However, it isn't really completed.
I stopped working on it since I knew I couldn't complete it in time.
However, I have learned a lot and that is the real reward!
YOU NEED XNA FRAMEWORK 4.0 FOR THIS
author: Takkenrakker
title: Infection Run
comments: Hey dude, I'm a bit stuck, I unzipped, tried running it but nothing happens... just a bit of egg timer action, then nothing. Nothing in processes either. Am I being dumb?
Tis a pity that you couldn't see it through.  I hope what you learned from it is applicable to your next #LD48 game :)
I got an "application failed to initialize properly (0xc000000035)" error. I'll try a few more entries to make sure it isn't something goobered up on my machine, but as it stands now, I can't run it.
Sorry guys, I will try to see what is the problem.
Oh yeah, I forgot to say, you need xna framework 4.0.
Darn, can't play it because my computer is too old to use the graphics...
I hope you do a complete game next time, I did the same thing... :)
I get a crash about 3 seconds in.

description:
Use your mouse to grab a cube of sugar and guide all the bees out through the nearest exit. But be quick ... time's running out!
Tools used: HTML5 canvas + JavaScript, Inkscape, Komodo Edit, Professor Cloud's SVG converter, Chrome and Firefox all running on Arch Linux. Background photos taken in the garden and converted using the GIMP editor.
Please see comments in source for additional credits. The game design, code and art were created on my own.
Looking forward to your feedback, suggestions and forks! Did you manage to complete the game? Get at least 500 points? Too easy, hard, any other issues? Let me know in the comments below.
author: seism
title: Free Bee
comments: It's a bit glitchy, but I found if you do a sort of swirly motion, you can move the bees pretty easily. Very nice, all in all.
I couldn't make it through the first level... =/
576 and won on first try, but when I tried to do better I kept losing. Bees are frustrating critters, aren't they?
All it need is Flight of the Bumblebee music!
I second the Flight of the Bumblebee suggestion :-D

description:
Warning: you must click in the flash box to be able to control
Controls: Spacebar - It will knock over a trash can and slow Ctrl.
author: Haversack
title: EscCtrl
comments: By the way you could fix the "gotta click the swf to play" thing, you could add a little intro screen. Mine was this:

author: Staggy
title: Escape the Space Nazis
comments: Nice idea but could use some more work. I would really like to see inertia on the ship, I think it would liven up gameplay quite a bit. And get rid of that thrust sound, it is killing my ears! :D
It would be nice to be able to turn the ship in place, maybe add some more things to dodge.

Nice rescue game idea, but lacks gameplay and depth. Also, parallax background would have helped immensely to make this feel actually in space. Some physics (inertia, acceleration, deceleration) to make the ship feel like an object would help.
The basic idea isn't bad, the execution wasn't very good. I hope you can work on it more and you may have a good game here! :*

description: this is a HTML5 game, should work on all platforms with a recent version of Google Chrome, not tested with other browsers but should be OK if they are compliant.
author: callidus
title: Escape The Dungeon
comments: Well hello callidus. This is a nice little game you got here. I feel like there either is not much in it or I just don't understand. I couldn't find a gameplay explanation anywhere. I sort of just waked around, apparently was killing by a slime, tried to open things that look like chests or coffins but couldn't, and then I apparently reached the exit. Seems like you've got the start of something here, but it's not complete. I'd love to see where it goes though, you've got a good atmosphere and engine.

Thanks for the feedback demonpants, yeah there was a lot of other stuff I wanted to put in. Locked doors, keys, monsters, items ect ect :-P none of it really got done in time. I will be working on this post LD as well though, I hoping to turn it into something more fun.

Although it is nice to see HTML5 based games, but I dislike your game. I am not here to bash it, just to do constructive criticism. There's no explanation on how to play it. When the player moves, the screen does not scroll smoothly, and it kinda makes me feel dizzy. And I don't know what is a good tile, and what is bad a tile. Put some smooth scrolling, an explanation, I am sure you'll have a great game =)
Also it worked fine on Firefox (played the web version). But the offline version (on the Linux link) does not work (neither on Firefox, neither on Chromium).

thanks @NO_Named_Guy, criticism like this is the most valuable feedback I could get! Also thanks for confirming it works on FF, ill have to take a look at what's up with the download versions, many thanks.

Good looking game, just needs some actual gameplay. Simply walking with WASD wasn't enough to draw me back in after I died. While not a huge deal, the footstep sound was really hard to listen to after a while.
Does not work on chrome neither on firefox :(
Works in Firefox 6.0.1. Not a bad entry, but it does need more gameplay. I don't mind screen not scrolling smoothly, but it does need some clear in-game explanations or deeper mechanics.

description:
The game is largely unfinished - there is no real gameplay to speak of.
However there is
- 3D engine written from scratch rendering in HTML5 Canvas
- motion capture from Kinect used for the characters (although it doesn't look like it) :)
author: ondrew
title: Escape from Space Cannibal
comments: Not much of a game here. While the kinect mocap technology is impressive, I would have liked something to inter act with. Even press space to advance the dialog would have been an improvement.

I would've liked to have seen the interaction with the Kinect. And while I understand you didn't have time to implement any gameplay or anything, I still have to rate you low in those areas. Very innovative though!
Nicely animated-- but there wasn't a whole lot else to it.

Framerate bizarrely choppy - fast for a second then stalled every second or so. And it took forever for a character to even cross the screen. Nice to see Kinect used in LD though! Maybe for the next one you could do something that would really show off a variety of animations, like a fighting game?
aw, I was looking forward to figuring out how to free them.. seems like maybe you didn't get to finish the ending? I really enjoyed the conversations though :)
A look at your timelapse confirmed what I suspected: you spent all your time with the mo-cap animation! It's cool though :)
While the motion capture is interesting, having no interaction at all doesn't really qualify this as a game. I would have much rather like to see this in the jam but playable.
Sadly I can't watch the timelapse due to german restrictions. Still points for that.

description: You are poor. So you beg for other people's money. You can gamble also. Help your mother become rich.
author: tusongtupa
title: Escape From Poorhood
comments: Awesome! The gameplay itself could have been better, but the amazing graphics completely made up for it!
geckojsc, the graphics in this entry are majoritively stock sprites from RPG Maker VX.  They are not his.
I didn't think you could use stock graphics for Ludum Dare.

Now that I've actually played this; serious bugs, you can just repetatively talk to the guy with blue hair at the table and he gives you money each time... and everyone else it'd seem too, unless its simply glitching for me.
This is nothing more than relentless buttonmashing and a sloppy game even by stock-sprite RPG-maker games.  My guess is this is crap thrown together as an excuse to vote on other games.
It's a jam entry, you guys. Just field testing some stuff in my flash RPG engine. Ya, it's a crappy game.
Yeah I was pretty amazed until I realized it was a jam game :)
Did you manage to stand up the whole time?

description:
Escape from Hell is a physics platformer where you must make use of boxes stuffed with tortured souls to make your way to freedom.
It is Windows only. No installer. Made with Scirra Construct.
I entered it in the jam because I went over the comp time a bit. There is still a lot I planned to add but I'm burnt out :) Would have been nice to have time to think of harder puzzles. Oh well, maybe someday I'll add to it.
author: Soggyclog
title: Escape from Hell
comments: Nice graphics, makes a pretty good platformer.
Only thing I would say is the controls are slightly counter-intuitive.
Pretty hard one as controls are a bit clunky. The art is nice! Physics are cool, if a bit too buggy.
very great pixel art, and love the background.  I agree, the control was a little tricky, and the puzzles seemed to be about mastering the controls.

I really like this game, it reminded of the amiga days, my friend had a game called the apprentice i think, i'm a bit fuzzy on the game play, i think it was with a wizard that jumped around grabbing boxes. Anyway, very cool art style, cute sounds,though i also found the controls to be counter intuitive which was a struggle, maybe even half the challenge, if it was a longer game then i would of gotten frustrated and want the buttons switched around, but for this it just made it part of the games challenge.
overall its really good, though right near the end i thought i was gonna lose a box, it went straight up very fast past the ceiling,but it came down again a few seconds later :)
The graphics look very impressive! I didn't play very far because of the slippery controls, but I like the idea and setting.

description:
I didn't have nearly enough time for this, as I only worked on it for about half a day. :) I haven't missed a LD yet though (since I started) and I would be sad to submit nothing at all. So here is my game in its quite incomplete state (needs a LOT more background art, more npcs and music to make it properly interesting.)
There are bugs for sure. :( (One invisible wall I have no idea why it's there!) Please forgive me!
Arrow keys to move, X to do things. Look for secrets!
author: bentosmile
title: Escape From Emag Castle
comments: Interesting idea with the invisible walls (that is, if that is a feature, not a placeholder/bug :-) )

This was cute.  Nostalgic a bit of finding secret places in very old Final Fantasies.  At first I was annoyed that the text boxes didn't freeze enemies and they'd wail on me until I realized what was actually occurring and it made sense that I'd be getting hit while people talked at me.
Cool! I had been in the last room twice before I walked up to see the exit was in it XD

I like it, though I can't say if I beat the game, or if it's even possible. :P Nice retro graphics, and the pop-us are a nice touch. Maybe pause the game when they're active though, got bitten by a snake when I was reading them!
As you said, it needs a bit more content to add variety, but it was fun and I enjoyed the conversation over the top and the interesting characters in the dungeon.
Spent three levels in the same room before I quit. Not sure what was supposed to happen. The other comments mention other rooms and snakes.
Nice retro graphics, it's great that you could put this together so fast.

description:
Written in Java using Slick2D and LWJGL. Hopefully runs on Linux, Windows and Mac.
Initial project failed so I threw this together in 3 hours.
UPDATE:
I've now uploaded a post compo deluxe version with animations and slightly better graphics. Use original for rating. Total time spent on project, about 10 I think.
author: JohanAR
title: EscApe
comments: Well it breaks my personal rule number one of game by not having any explanation at all. Not very much content and I really want to rate this lower, but cannot justify it.
The appropriate categories of not fun and no music are marked while it does have decent innovation, theme, and graphics. And the joke at the end did make me laugh pretty hard.
I totally didn't see that coming, though the clues were all there
I won't give any spoilers but that was pretty funny :) Would like to have seen your game in Scala though (I do some Scala development myself)

Thanks for your comments!  Hoping for high points on theme and maybe some humor. I regret not recording any sound effects, but it was in the middle of the night and I didn't want to wake my wife up by making monkey sounds :)

Maybe next compo I'll get something done in Scala. I know a bit of Haskell and Erlang, though I'm not taking advantage of functional programming in Scala, just using it like an improved version of Java
cornedor & maxx : what OS are you using? If you start it from a text prompt (cmd, terminal, etc depending on platform), do you get an error message?

is the command, otherwise it will complain about missing lwjgl. If you just try to start the JAR you won't see the error though. And I haven't tried the .bat file, I just assumed that's how they work :D
Haha, that was great! Nice little puzzle. ^^
Can't make it run on Linux =(
Seems to be some issue with Java 7 :( Will continue looking at it when time permits

Haha! Not very big on gameplay but both versions are pretty freaking awesome considering how much time was put in them. Love the artwork and especially the animation on the gorilla in the deluxe version.

description:
(29-08-2011, polished the game, added instructions and 3 more levels, try it here: www.martinf.dk/uncube/)
Unlock the cube by marking the 6 pieces on the board that could be folded into the cube.
Controls:
Mark pieces with left mouse
Rotate view with arrow keys
Work schedule:
1/2 hour brainstorm during family dinner
1 hour paper prototyping in train
8 1/2 hours of development
(Would have been 3 without the extension which saved me)
10 hours in total
author: Martin Fasterholdt
title: Cube Collapse
comments: The idea is great, but sadly I don't see much connection to the theme. :-]
That's really slick (and you definitely have a screenshot advantage ;) ).  I was hoping it was procedurally generated, though, and would keep zooming indefinitely.  Very pretty.
@ratking: You're opening a cube to free what's inside.  I think that qualifies as "escape".  :)
Smart game ! And I agree with Martoon, this cube need infinite zooming levels !! ^____^
My mind was blown when there was a cube inside the cube.
Too bad that happened only once.
A "You Win" screen would be well-received, as I kept on clicking the sphere thinking the game was still on.
Very cool game, if you gave it a bit more polish it would be a great puzzle! Congratulations!
I second Martoon and all of them. So I guess that means I fourth them?
I like the concept but there's no feedback on how close you are to solving, which made me feel frustrated pretty quickly.
I am glad you like it :)

The plan was indeed to make it zoom multiple times and of cause have more than one level as well. I was considering procedural levels, but I think they do need a bit of design to control. Difficulty, pieces which almost look right, or correct pieces in wrong places, or even levels with a theme or certain visuals in the pieces and patterns would be tricky and time consuming to get right with procedural. However a tool that generates a board and a cube as a starting point would be very useful. When I get time I will make a few more levels, and add a bit more feedback. In game tutorial would also be good.
Is it allowed to just update my entry or should I place updates separately?

Could you post a non-web-player version of this? Based on other Unity games I have seen in this competition, the Unity web plugin cannot be installed on Linux, but a standalone Windows Unity game works fine on Linux using wine.
Was rather frustrating before I found the rotate controls :)
Here is a link to a standalone windows build as James Paige requested: martinf.dk/cubecollapse/CubeCollapse.zip
Sorry Andrew, I am aware that the game badly needs some ingame intructions.

description:
This is my first LD, and its been really fun! Met some great people and hope to be doing this again soon.
Any feedback you can give would be great! I'm sitting in IRC as Warrozo or you can twitter me, @DGoodayle!
Thank you and I hope you enjoy it!
author: Warrozo
title: City Runner
comments: Cool, although it's a little weird the sentry lasers don't have a little turret sprite attached to them, seemed weird to be getting shot at by nothing!

Great! Nothing I haven't seen before, but it was still pretty fun. The graphics and sound (apart from the missing sprites) are quite well done! As is common with procedural map generation, the challenge level can be inconsistent. Sometimes I made it through the first level easily, and sometimes not.
The spotlight effect works quite well in creating tension. I wish there was music to go along with the visual style.
I got an error on startup. I'm using IE, on a computer other than mine, so I'll try again when I get home.
User Agent: Mozilla/4.0 (compatible; MSIE 8.0; Windows NT 5.1; Trident/4.0)
Message: 'root' is null or not an object

Neat idea, though it really isn't as much fun as it could be.  Also needs some audio.  The levels seem really imbalanced, as the ones I got seemed to have most of the enemies on one side of the map, and next to none on the rest.  After some more work, it could be really cool :)
Ok, I tried it again with a non-sucky browser, and it worked.
Graphics were good. Light effect was nice. Targets were pretty small.
You seemed to have some kind of collision error. There were times when I couldn't advance down the street until I moved to other lane, even though there was nothing visible in front of me.

@siebharinn: there are little rectangles that block your path. I think that's what you mean. I have to agree that the enemies were SO SMALL! Geez! And I got to an exit, but it wouldn't let me go in, so I died! lol
Very nice game :) but those guy's shooting on my where I cant reach them. don't like that much, very frustrating.

description:
XNA 4.0 was used to make this, so it's likely that you'll need Windows with XNA Framework 4.0 installed in order to play it!
You are a charged particle with a clear disregard for the laws of physics.
Hit SPACE to invert your polarity, causing different particles to attract/repel you.
Navigate using WSAD, but use sparingly - it drains your charge.
Regain your charge by touching oppositely-charged particles.
Escape the electromagnetic foam!
www.audiotool.com was used to make the music!
author: thasc
title: Charge
comments: Interesting idea (reminded me of Osmos), but the randomness threw me off. It feels very uncontrollable. Other than that, I liked the overall presentation and style.
A very innovative test of patience and foresight!

More or less agree with ratking. It's not the first compo game  I've seen (although none so far in this LD) using idea of + an -, but it's just too damn uncontrolable... game for very patient or very lucky
Indeed, some introductory material with details on the mechanics might make it more easy.
The theme feels very much tacked on, but I did enjoy the innovative mechanics (Osmos but not Osmos, indeed).
It's a bit hit and miss and I often leave the game area after just starting. Could do with some fine tuning but otherwise a great idea.
It seems I don't have patience enough to play this game...

Took me a few goes to 'escape' (I'm afraid I have to agree with others that the theme is kind of shoehorned in there) - it's an interesting idea and the animation is really smooth. I found the controls pretty difficult, though.
1) keep the player contained within the play area (i.e. you can't go offscreen - at least not top and bottom)

author: summaky
title: Ascii Maze
comments: Controls get annoying when trying to move at higher speeds. Also somewhat disorienting when going fast since the grid moves so far per step. Cute idea using ASCII.
Nice little game. I checked out your source code (as you mentioned) and it's kind of amazing. 3500 lines, with a bibliography at the end..!!! We need a technical category for people like you.

Great coding style--I gave you a high community score for your commenting, sourcecode, etc. I like the ASCII art character (is it a penguin?). One nice feature to add might be to mark your path with a trail of dots. That way when you backtrack you can see where you've been. Maybe you want the game to be super hard, but it would make it a lot easier to play, especially since you can't see most of the maze most of the time. Anyway, fun idea. Incidentally, do you play a lot of roguelikes? I wrote a labyrinth generator for Angband, so happy to see other people in LD using libtcod and generating ASCII mazes :)
This reminds me of my very first game ever! :D
Good use of ascii. The game itself lacks some additional features. Gets boring quite fast.
Your source is amazingly well structured.

description:
What a wild ride it's been, that's for sure. Oh, I forgot to add any kind of tutorial feature this time, and the UI is horribugly, so here's the control and premises:
CONTROLS:
Left/right keys - Move / Toggle between terminal logs and memory logs in menu
Up/down keys - Scroll through terminal logs and memory logs in menu
Z - Jump / Start game
X - Use / Fire
C - Control nearby guard
M - Open/close menu (you can also close the menu with X)
PREMISE:
You're a psychic alien locked up on a space station. You know there's a teleporter out, but you don't know where. However, you can use the terminals and hijack the minds of the guards to try and escape. Good luck. You'll need it.
ASIDE:
I am missing nicer graphics, sounds, and music, but I got a little further in terms of complexity this time around than I did with LD20's Throwbots in a totally different environment, so, success to a degree! I already gave credit to some people in the game proper, but props to all those who supported me and made this thing possible!
I learned a great deal of lessons and I should be writing up a post-mortem by next weekend. See you then!
EDIT: Fixed a showstopper bug involving the game locking up when hit by an enemy (pretty critical) and a duplicate (and a missing) terminal.
author: Cirrial
title: Aphelion Incident
comments: This game is pretty amazing. The graphics are charming, the gameplay is fun, if a bit easy, and the characters are made surprisingly endearing by making them more than faceless guards, possibly by having them have relationships with each other (it's adorable how romance driven these aliens are). I played another game that tried this and failed, but this one really made them like people who I felt too guilty to kill. I really like the aliens in this, they're imaginatively designed and feel like they've been thought about much more than most people think about their game enemies (which coincidentally reflects one of the points of the game). It's definitely not without its flaws, though. I'm bugged a bit by how the guards can't jump high enough to climb around their own base, and it's kind of difficult to maneuver them.  The fact that only like a third of them fire at you is also a bit confusing, and although I noticed that they're the ones with violent personalities the other ones probably wouldn't just walk up to the dangerous alien that breached containment to say hi and make friends. I also felt like the controlling guards mechanic wasn't expanded on as far as it could have been, and I can imagine it being more puzzle oriented and successful. Still, these minor detractors are more than expected with the limitations of the competition, and I must say that this is my favorite game yet. I'll be sure to look you up and watch for more of your stuff in the future.
Also the teleporter room door opens waaaay before it is supposed to.
Yes, the amount of monologue is very impressive. Made it to the teleporter room much sooner than I expected; figured I was lucky. Very nice game, overall.
Best thing I've played so far, nice game and very enjoyable to get lost in.
I didn't really get it, perhaps I missed something important looking at all these other comments. Nice art but the design and gameplay weren't the best.
This was pretty fun.  I would have loved for the thought-reading to be important in my escape, though.
I think this game could do more: more levels, more audio, more ui (lol) more polish on controls: for me just feel "wrong" :(
Very cool - an amazing amount of flavor content that feels like it gives real actionable information about the game world (like who will attack you, etc).  Nice job.

At first I thought it's just another generic platformer, but the mind reading (although not used enough imo), background informations, monologue etc together with nice clear art made this one of the winners :)
While game could of course use some more work (especially audio), it's excellent entry and one of few I really played till the end because I wanted to see what's awaiting me and enjoyed it a lot.
a lot of depth to this game, and i hope you work on it more after the compo, you could make this into an excellent game. not to say it's not good as it is!
Loved it. Reminded me a lot about Iji, as you sure made a way for us to feel guilt about hurting the aliens...
I really liked the mind reading.  Made me feel bad getting them to shoot each other.  The gameplay was a bit annoying, in trying to maneuver the (non-player) aliens

Managed to get through most of it with only a few casualties among the enemies. Felt bad whenever they died, though eventually they began to shoot each other when they recognized a friend being mind controlled. Lots of moral gray area here, between an amoral protagonist and the punch clock villains. Loved it.

description:
The theme of the game is that you are an "Idea", a white block navigating a "thought" maze. The player can use the arrow keys to navigate the maze and by pressing the Escape key, "change their mind" (aka, randomize the entire maze). The Idea is searching for various "Goals" though out the maze so that it can travel deeper and deeper.
As the Idea travels into the thought maze, new obstacles such as grey permanent walls (was going to call them "Beliefs", a la "beliefs set in stone") and red "Doubts" (monsters) that randomly toss the Idea into another part of the maze. Once the player gets through 20 levels, they get the ending message that I was, in my own heavy handed way, trying to convey.
author: mattperrin
title: The ESCape
comments: First time I tried playing I thought it was broken, then I went back and read that you should use the escape key to change the map :D Pretty cool idea I think, maybe you could turn it into a full game if you keep developing it
Very innovative idea! Interesting tension in choosing when to ESCape when there are doubts around.
The idea is actually quite neat! The graphics are understandably very rough and such, and I had trouble getting back to the main menu after looking at the help screen. I hope you'd work on this more!
But if you don't want to  bother looking for a path, you can "cheat", just alternate "esc" and the direction you want to go really fast, and you'll get there really quick.
Cool idea, would've been better if the game was actually on the surface of a cube rather than the paths being randomly generated.
Had to look at the comments to realise that the 'escape' key was important though.
Really liked the idea, I expected another ending message but liked yours too :)
Interesting and pretty fun concept. The map-changing mechanic was new to me.
The idea is original, but it would need more tweaking and experimentation to get a gameplay that really works.

It's quite a fun idea, but the biggest problem was that there was no real challenge aspect, each time all I did was most to the closest square to the goal I could reach, pressed escape and repeated until i got to the goal. I realised after a couple of levels that the doubts were so slow I could avoid them by running if I had to, so I didn't worry about letting them into my section of the maze. But it's a clever idea, with some tweaking I think you could make a really fun game out of this.

description:
I made this using the Ren'Py framework, a handle of 3D resources available from http://www.renderosity.com/mod/freestuff/index.php and http://members3.jcom.home.ne.jp/mowais/freestuff/freestuff.html and the fractals are made with the Mandelbulb 3D program, music with Ableton Live, sound effects using increpare's excellent bfxr download (please play his http://www.increpare.com/2010/11/activate-the-three-artefacts-and-then-leave/ it was an influence on me!) and Photoshop for postwork.
Thank you for taking the time to play my entry! Please let me know if you have any problems!
author: ButtercupSaiyan
title: (Escape from) The Temple of Nepenthe
comments: Crappity crap, I forgot the timelapse: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OMQnel0_ka8
Won't download from mediafire for me :(
I just download it with chrome. Yesterday I had a problem with firefox (in order to download, you have to accept first a popup... It was strange)
Your graphic design is really great! I'm impressed about what you drew in less than 48h... However I'm not fan of the gameplay and there are too much text for me ^^
Okay. Way too much text though. Very nice looking!

It's good to see a female as a main player, and a man as a sidekick. That's always good. About the game: it was a nice game, but not many choices... I felt it like an interactive story with little choices. Because there is so much text to read, I wouldn't backtrack (it was boring to me). The story was good, the background images great and you've got the best UI I've ever seen so far in this LD. Keep it up!
This seems like a very good entry overall, my main gripe being how linear the story feels and that I couldn't tell how my decisions affected said story (both very common with this type of game).
I couldn't find a combination of choices that didn't result in my death. After seeing each of the final choices killing me, I had no inclination to go back and just try different choice combinations.

description:
Well! it's finally done with, isn't it. This is a little ditty I like to call THE DARING ESCAPE OF ES CAPE; THE FABULOUSLY FRESH LUCHADOR. This is my first real game ever with something that isn't GameMaker (I've had a bit of practice, but I haven't finished anything), so I'm pretty pumped about that (I used C++ and SDL and whatnot). Huge props to nguillemot who was always ready to answer my questions. Arrow keys to move. There isn't much gameplay, I like to call it an "exploration game" just explore the different rooms, maybe catch a glimpse of story! there are only 15 rooms so don't fret!
Also props to SpaceManiac for setting up a Linux Build
author: moltanem2000
title: The daring escape of ES CAPE; the FABULOUSLY FRESH Luchador
comments: I'm going to be honest with you: this awful. It's just whole bunch of boring, linear rooms without any gameplay at all. Your "game" would benefit a lot more from investing in something that's actually playable. I guess the theme interpretation was original, but in all frankness, this just isn't fun at all.
Sorry only 30 hours was spent on the gameplay, I won't sleep next time.

I agree you should have spent less time on room design and graphics and more time on gameplay. If it was half as long and only had one type of enemy, but that enemy pursued you or at least moved, or you had to collect keys or something, I could have rated you higher. I think the graphics and room design are really quite good, they just don't stand on their own. Congratulations on your first "real" game! :)
I dig the art and theming!

Without any branching paths or anything that you have to react to... it's just walking around, which isn't super interesting.  Maybe if it was clearer that you were being timed, that'd do it? Replaying it going as fast as I can was definitely more interesting than the first playthrough! 53.741 seconds!
I echo others' comments that the gameplay is very lacking.  The idea is good and somewhat funny :-)
Hardly any challenge, and the ending was unsatisfying.  Just had to trek to any stairs, ignoring enemies as they ignored me.

description: :D
author: john_coffee
title: The Copenhagen E. Coli Epidemia
comments: I found the game quite amusing and funny, although I got a game over when I blasted off from the toilet each time? Not sure if that was a good game over, or I lost somehow else.
me too on the game over
I think the rocket toilet is a good game over... I think. But ya, I found it funny and liked the visuals just a bit confused about the game overs.
I really liked the art style- it has a very painterly feel.
"We had to cut down all the pine-trees to make emergency toliet-paper during the 50-year-squirts" <- reminds me of that :-)
Idea is hilarious :) too bad that gameplay is a bit lacking, at least few more levels or something which will stretch the game over dozen or two seconds usually required to get to the RocketToilet

Funny concept, but I was not sure if I had won or lost the game when I reached the portal, so some clarification in terms of that during gameplay would help. The art is not bad but could use some polish as with the gameplay (it didn't look like the enemies actually deterred me or lowered my health on contact but perhaps I just didn't notice). Beyond that not bad!

description:
Tea Powered Escape was originally supposed to be reverse dungeon crawl instead it's a straight forward escape from the water, though with added tea! (There was a lot consumed during the weekend).
This was my first entry for LD and wow did I underestimate it, I'm fairly happy with what i've done but really there is so much more that is needed, still I've learnt a lot from the process.
author: Gachuk
title: Tea Powered Escape!
comments: Left/right arrow keys move but up doesn't jump? In general for Flash games, the arrows would be the primary controls with WASD as the backup, rather than the other way round.
Would be good to have the ability to restart from within the game if you die.

Your jump seems to go to wildly varying heights even if you just keep the jump button held down the whole time. Sometimes clicking on a block wouldn't remove it. Both these issues might be frame-handling code going wrong maybe?
Very cute game, kind of easy once you figure it out and get a few cups of tea, though. Very short, too. Perhaps a little variety like enemies or something would help. Great submission though!
Now, for a cup of tea...
I enjoyed the game very much, it was hectic and fun at the same time. :)
Now I'll make myself a nice cup of tea. ^^
I have nothing to add that other people haven't said yet.
Both of the following are issues that I also came across while playing the game.
"Would be good to have the ability to restart from within the game if you die.

Your jump seems to go to wildly varying heights even if you just keep the jump button held down the whole time. Sometimes clicking on a block wouldn't remove it. Both these issues might be frame-handling code going wrong maybe?" - Draknek

description:
You are living on a spaceship, suddenly it is under attack.  Enemies are boarding and blowing the place up.  Get to an escape pod before it self destructs!
WASD - movement, jump and crouch.
Left mouse button - shoots
Alt+Enter - toggle fullscreen (recommended)
NOTE: You may need to update DirectX to play my game!  Do this if you get a missing DLL message when you run it.
I also put a link to an enhanced post-deadline version with some bug fixes and gameplay tweaks for non-judges.
author: KilledByAPixel
title: Spacescape
comments: Absolutely beautiful game. I adored it from start to finish. There are so many little graphical and audial details that make this a delight to play. And I actually thought the voiced sounds added to the charm :)
Very good and I'm not saying it just because I've used similar style of art and planned to use sounds like you :D

I was pleasantly surprised by this one. You managed to do something with your level design that is rare and awesome: you made me feel like I was just wandering around/exploring, yet I  end up finding the goal without backtracking. Great work.
The vocal sounds are awesome as is the art style.

description: I promise it's beatable! My first LD
author: mcatominey
title: Press Space!
comments: This is probably too hard for me (a pity that there's no control over how high, and thus how far, can one jump), but I like the idea. The world falling apart is a nice touch.
A bit difficult. Or maybe I'm just "not very good at it." :D
Falling down felt a bit strange and I fell through the stairs above the ice once (diagonally). I like one button games though.
Not bad, isn't too fun for long though. Why is the file so big? Now that's a mystery... :) thanks for finishing on time.

description: "Not Without You" is a fun and challenging puzzle game in which the player must guide blue spheres to unique escape hatches.  The catch?  All blue spheres move in unison, and all escape hatches must be occupied for the level to end.  This intuitive and addictive game was developed in less than 48 hours for the Ludum Dare 21 competition.  Enjoy!
author: davidjsushil
title: Not Without You
comments: Game didn't work, some whining about .NET and XNA and stuff. I didn't understand what I should have done to get game work. Instructions in README didn't help, because doing what it said didn't work either :(
@stRana (and anyone else having issues), here is a more detailed set of instructions for running the game.
1. Extract the files from the .ZIP folder onto your desktop (or any other convenient location).
2. Run xnafx40_redist.msi, which will install the required .NET and XNA files necessary to run the game.
3. Make sure the Content folder is in the same location as  NotWithoutYou.exe.
If following these instructions doesn't help, let me know, and I'll try to work with you to find a solution.  Unfortunately, not every graphics card is capable of running XNA 4.0.  :'(
Really very cool. Very clever. I assume the 'killscreen' is the end of the game? Or am I missing some ingenious hidden thing?
Well done with the puzzles, they got progressively harder, although I did not manage to get passed the 2nd to last level.
@Zed, thanks for the compliment!  Yes, Killscreen is the end of the game.
@blackbird, getting the difficulty curve just right in such a short span of time isn't easy.  I took my best stab at what I thought would be a good progression.  I'm glad you liked it.  :-)
i got an unhandled exception error, im on a small netbook so iam guessing it doesnt run XNA, will give it a go while i am in work tomorrow,
Enjoyable game, nice design, good art. I thought the difficulty curve was fairly smooth, with the exception of the final level which was easy, but maybe I just got lucky there
@AJMilsom, XNA 4.0 has issues with some integrated graphics cards, which is likely why the game won't run on your netbook.  Sorry!

Well, this is a pretty standard sort of puzzle game, but the graphics are nice, and the puzzle designs are good. The puzzles never felt like I was just scrambling for a solution, which I think happens often in games like this. I felt like the solutions here were clearly deductible, which is good.
Really well-executed puzzler.  I could see how this could be developed further with the addition of other features like teleporters/destroyers and translation level geometry.  Great work!

description:
Escape the mountain and the lava within using
only your athletic ability your trusty Hazardous
Environment suit!
This short, fast-paced, game was a fun opportunity to implement some cellular automata based fluid simulation, based on this article: http://home.comcast.net/~tom_forsyth/papers/cellular_automata_for_physical_modelling.html
TIMELAPSE: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5xWFk9VPz1U
Have fun!
author: epaik
title: Mountain Break
comments: So neat little platformer. Run from rooms as they flood with lava. The flow went mostly intelligently. A nice five minute time waster.
Could have been better if there weren't so many jumps with a block directly over the players head.
Needs better level design but good work overall.

Pretty fun! I liked the various level designs and the smooth functional controls. A bit too much relying on the jumping to the (1 up and 2 left/right) as a puzzle mechanic, which could get difficult at times with the player hitbox. Nevertheless, a solid entry.
I liked it a lot, nice work on the lava.
The player being the same size as the blocks make some of the jumps a bit too hard. Apart from that I really enjoyed the music and the lava physics were impressive.

I'll have to echo the complaints about basing one's head against the block above, but other than that it's a good game. Filling the cavern was a good idea, it gives players less time to loiter around the level and forces them to think quickly.

description:
---- SPACE ----
Adventure, Freedom, Interesting people ... Which want to blow your sorry a** out of the skies. You don't have much options, make a run for it!
You're the hardened chief mechanic on board of a space freighter piloted mainly by noobs.
And now you've discovered a asteroid field. Wich is surrounded by pirates. That have bond with your enemies of war. Dang.
Hold that ship together as long as you can, you'll hope that the old girl will make it to the jumpgate out of this system.
author: barigorokarl
title: Make a run for It
comments: Oh, and I had complains about windows 7 and firefox running really slow. Sadly, I can't test that :( But Chrome should run fine.
FF und xp runs without a problem at all on my 5 year old machine.
And maybe I should have sticked a "Rated Adult" sticker on the humor, I got that thought from that "Rebruary" Month from spoony and a little bit from Red Heat - Thats the cap you're wearing :)
I really like this concept! Good work.
I seem to be way too dumb to understand this game =( Can't play it, can't rate it accordingly... But I like how you didn't have to use flash or other proprietary thingy :)
I really like the idea! I seem to suck at it though ;)
I have no idea how I'm supposed to play.... Could you add instructions?
Same here... Couldn't understand how to play >_<
Hi, yeah, I guess I have a blind spot on usability ... and am able build really hard games ;)
I like such games as millenium 2.2 where you didn't know what to do either, but I guess that's a special kind of sadism ;)
At the beginning you're only able to repair systems and you have to keep the important systems running.
After the bridge is destroyed you are able to set course and put in the "overdrive", which is some kind of afterburner that is constently hurting your hull.
Best way (Sad to say, I guess nearly the only way) to win is to put 2 Mechanic on Hull, Engines and Energy, 1 on Sensors and Point defense).

After the bridge is destroyed try to avoid the asteroids and if possible enemy ships, put in the overdrive and take ignore Point defense and Sensors and put at least one of them to Hull, the other where it is needed.
Ok, I need to balance this more and remove some bugs, such as system health bleeding without even beeing attacked. yeah, that happens :(
Thanks for the patience and testing this brutal piece of software! :)

description:
Arrow Keys to move, X to jump, and C to dive.
Made in Flash with Flashpunk and Flashdevelop, as well as Noel  Berry's "Advanced Platforming Engine."
Other tools: BFXR, Audacity, Game Maker (sprite editor), and PXTone
See if you can find the secret alternate route to the end :D
author: Connor
title: Hollow
comments: That was a pretty wicked and wicked pretty game. Found that secret leprechaun cave by the way, very tricky.
This was a beautiful game. Aside from its length, it left no indication that it was made inside 48 hours.
Very well executed, This had much more content than I would expect from a 48 hour event.
Really like it, great game Connor!! You have to extend it, right? :D

Took a long time (and help of someone) to figure you could walk through the spikes without getting hurt. Nice game anyways, loved the graphics and the sound effects (music was a little repetitive), and it was fun!
Awesome, can't wait 'til you extend it! :D
@Rolpege: I only wish I had more talent with music... I've only made a few songs before, so that was the hardest test of my skills with all this haha
@WITS: That's what I want to hear! ^_^
Great art, great sound.  Very polished.  Great work!

Very nicely done.  I loved the dive mechanic, and the secret exit.  One critique would be to have more interesting death animations for the character and enemies.  It was a nice touch to get encased in the blob enemy, and I would have liked to see more of that.

@obedientarrow: I had plans initially to have different death animations and things for all of the enemies, but time restrictions made it difficult :(  I had to do the blob one though!  I will probably make that change once I extend the game.
Well done. I liek the heft of the movement.
Great game! Cool graphical style - reminds me of Miyazaki films (Nausicaa, Mononoke, etc). I love the dive mechanic too.
I agree with everyone above; very nice. I somehow met the leprechaun my first time through, and I have no clue how it happened :P
Outstanding!  You must make a full game out of this.
Totally dug it! You should make a full version and sell it. Fun game :-)

Kinda hard in some places, but it just adds to the challenge. Great graphics and I like the atmosphere.  All you need is to sprinkle a little text here and there to tell a story and you could easily get a sponsor for this.

description:
This is Escape from Dorf Bay, a mix of two ideas, where none got the appropriate attention as I actually had only about 20 hours to create this submission.
I hope someone gets the idea and the soul of the game and create something worthy of it, as I think it could still have a long way to go ahead.
The dorf part was made in paint, the one a capellaing is me using Windows Sound Recorder from XP, the font used is Symbol.
The scary house part was done using the following:
-Music: Mi chord on my crappy and broken guitar, recorded using Windows Sound Recorder
-Sound effects: Random noises recorded and distorted on windows sound recorders
-Graphics: My Nokia N8 Camera, with some messing in the light sensivity settings, all the pictures are from my house.
-Coding: Everything done in processing.
I've included the source code, but not the actual data files, such as the graphics or the sounds, if anyone want them, just send me an e-mail at NicholasPassy@gmail.com
edit (23/08/11 04:30AM):
Postmortem version is up, I've switched the download links for the v2, where the arrows ALWAYS appears, so you guys won't need to pixel hunt anymore.
author: KavuDX
title: Escape from Dorf Bay
comments: There is a permission error when trying to run on Mac OS X. I tried chmoding everything but that didn't help.
NVM I got it to run with the following:

Well, you did a good job setting up atmosphere. I was ready for something to kill me in the house, that's for sure. But then I couldn't go anywhere. I just couldn't find where I was supposed to put my mouse in order to make the up arrow appear, and I became trapped after hardly starting. I suggest removing the hover mouse and just leaving the buttons there at all times.
I'll take on it. A lot of people complained about that, so I guess it's my fault.
I liked the photos - your friend is right, your house _is_ scary! The sound was great too, I wish there was more of this.
Thanks for the compliments, I really got proud of what I did in under 1 hour with the sound.
Messing with windows sound recorder is awesome!
well.. tried the windows version: "Java Virtual Machine Launcher - Could not find the main class. Program will exit!"
Have you extracted everything to their correct folders?
This error usually happens when the .exe cannot find the path of the /lib/ and the /source/

description:
Here is my entry. Not as full featured as I wanted but I'm sure everyone knows how it is with the time pressure.
Uploaded the source files via megaupload.com. Sorry, I don't have a hosting site. [EDIT: You can now access the screen grab off of imgur instead of having to use megaupload. Sorry for the previous inconvenience.]
Enjoy!
author: Apogee
title: Duke Ludum Forever
comments: lol, your game's name is most excellent! If there were a section for best game name, I would vote for you. It makes me want to make a game called "Luke Dudum" haha. Maybe it's Duke Ludum's brother hehe

Just to save people the time. You don't need to actually download the source code. The game has very limited functionality and what you see in the screenshot is all there is to the game. Of course you are free to download if you want! :)
I thought this was very amusing, tho it only fits the theme tangentially
Sigh... If you're trying to annoy people with long wait on megaupload only to find one screenshot... you've succeeding.
The third boss fight was a bit harder than I expected and the physics could have been improved but overall there is no fault WHATSOEVER I can find with the core game play mechanic .

description: Only had a few hours, no sound. First game ever.
author: atlantian
title: Defenses
comments: Welcome to Ludum Dare ^^ I like it, though I'd prefer a little more challenge.  Grats on your first game though :D
Okay for a first try. Get involved in the community! And please, sound makes a game so much better.
I liked the fact that you made it get more difficult the longer you played, smart. Awesome for a first game! Sound would have made it fab! Welcome to LD48

Definitely a very good first game. The graphics look pretty good. Biggest comments would be about sounds/music (as people have said) and also maybe giving some cannons a cool-down. Right now I feel like the game is easy as long as you mash the mouse button right before one hits, and then becomes impossible when there are too many. Using the keyboard + cooldown might make it easier to control the difficulty (and turn the challenge into one of coordination). Overall good job, I definitely haven't played a game with this exact feel before.
227 points. It hooks you up nicely: I'll hold the next wave too! :)
It's a good first attempt. Second the need for sound and music. Also, I didn't like having to mindlessly, repeatedly click so much.

description:
Congratulations adventurer! After a long and grueling journey, you have finally made it to the dungeon exit! All that remains is to jump over a simple spike pit!
Z to advance text/jump, arrow keys to move.
This is my first Ludum Dare!
You can find me on twitter at @angrygeometry
author: angrygeometry
title: Dungeon Exit
comments: I seriously thought it was broken ! Great idea, but its more of a narrative than a game ? Nevertheless I was entertained :D
I liked the part about escaping. But seriously now, it made me chuckle.
That's fun. Also, I think I broke the game.
One more thing (to all devs): Z and Y are swapped on german keyboards. It is enraging having to deal with games that assume x and z are next to each other.
I am guessing this wasn't your plan from the start? :)
I actually liked your unusual approach to the theme. I must say I failed to find the way to escape but it was fun trying, lol.
I laughed, but that sound hurt my ears.
WHY DOES IT SAY PISS ON MY SCREEN?

description:
WASD to move, C to close Menus
find all four parts of the spaceship scattered in the caves
(mine a rock ten times to get down there)
warning: this game may take very, very long to complete =P
sorry, the "win" screen is very poorly done, only had a few mins left in compo.
the only code i reused was a one liner about importing images when running an applet, because im pretty bad at that.
author: tmathmeyer
title: CRASH!
comments: I can't get it to run. After title-screen everything goes white. (Tried on Windows and on Mac)
runs, but I don't get it, just ran around digging holes getting exceptions
Strangely blinking menus, quite confusing controls, lack of any gameplay but diggining holes randomly (or I'm really missing something?
