bach: trying to define yourself is hard and unpredictable, hehe :)

Quite a difficult game. That's affected by the fact that I didn't realise that I could drag the brain in with space... Not sure though, because it seems like it would be pretty easy to screw yourself over with it.
Interesting.... Too difficult for me to ever win but I sure wish I could. :D Great theme interpretation.

description:
Well, the "plot" of the game is that you are a dragon who just escaped from a dungeon. And all you have in mind is escape, until you start to escape the game itself.
The game didn't turn out as I wanted to, and the code got very hackish as the deadline approached.
author: Kiloku
title: Red, The Dragon
comments: Weird game. :)  Also, I really don't like the idea of setup.exe and polluting my registry, so I recompiled it instead.
Probably could be clearer on what projectiles are harmful and which are just background. I like the 'Playing tennis with the boss' mechanic.
Want to try this but don't want to install anything special for it. Could you repack it into a simple exe?
@NO_Named_Guy Yes, unfortunately, XNA is a .NET based framework, and .NET is Windows only.

description:
You are a sentient water particle, and you need to collect other water particles so you can ESCAPE from your "Prison of Air".  Use the mouse to move, touch water particles to collect.  After beating the game, you can use your browser refresh button to start again!
So, at the start of this compo, one of my good friends wanted to team up.  As I normally submit little games that I make in my own "engine" with very few tools to work with, I needed some form of middleware to handle assets.
Initially, we went with Cryengine3, but currently, you can't log in with the same developer account and all level files are encrypted to the login.
After learning that, we switched to Unity.  Neither of use had used Unity before so there was a lot of learning involved; I spent about equal time making this game as I did looking up documentation and going through tutorials.  Still, we managed to make a little game and hope to make a bigger one next time!
Code/Script/Final Deployment/Crappy Particle Shower at End by Max Maroe (Drakfyre)
Particles/Music/Sound/Game Design by Justin Moravetz
Rain sound effect found here: http://www.freesound.org/samplesViewSingle.php?id=118514
Special Thanks to MasterHyjinx for hosting TWO days of barbecue for the event!
EDIT: Added ports to Windows and Mac; I have not tested the Windows port but will later; let me know if it gives anyone any trouble.  Source is available as well; includes all assets and Unity files and stuff.
author: drakfyre
title: Prison of Air
comments: flOw much? The music was fantastic, the game was kind of dull.

Yeah, it needed more progression and more love; as I said, spent a good deal of time just getting the ropes; I downloaded Unity at about 10PM PST on Friday and had never used it before.  Thanks for playing, and I'll pass along your praise of the music!
Would have been nice to see some sub goals thrown in there (special limited raindrops or something). By the end i felt like a OCD predator, trying to clear chase and kill all the raindrops.
Music took an unexpected but interesting turn. Me like.
The idea of becoming a rainddrop and escaping the cloud made me smile :) Very nice interpretation of the theme!
Music very nice, fitting to the atmosphere, yet the game kind of lacks enemies. Or just a clock. Something to make you collect those drops. That would have changed a lot.
Nice idea, very good interpretation of escape!

description:
Mazix, or Rubix Cube Maze, is a maze, built on the foundations of a rubix cube, where you can rotate the sides of the maze in order to make new paths.
You can only rotate the side you are on, by being in the center sphere of the side.
You start in the black sphere, and have to make your way to the white sphere, collecting all the keys along the way, in order to access the white sphere, and win the game.
You have a limited amount rockets to break through the walls, that get in your way, if you cant rotate them away.
The controls can sometimes get a little messy around the edges, so if you get stuck, just keep trying to move around and it usually fixes itself.
author: calrk
title: Mazix
comments: Good god, this seems complex. Also, fun :-) (although I do had to understand that the missile-pickups look like missiles in flight)
interesting idea, quite complex to wrap your head around the whole thing to actually get there. i ended up shooting my way through :)
That's one of the most original entries I've yet found :) And of the more original purely maze moving games I've ever played.
Very cool game! If I had to nitpick, the guys moves a little slowly and the graphics are kind of plain, but those aren't a big deal!
I like the use of color and the game's distinctive appearance.

Having both the option of using rockets and the ability to rotate was a bit much for me - I didn't have much patience looking for rotation-based solutions because I knew that sometimes there was no solution and I would have to use a rocket anyway.

Unsure of what to do?  Collected all the missiles, and the yellow glowey thing, and all I could do was move around the world and hit 'q' and 'e' in the center.  An interesting mechanic, but need to know how to proceed.

description: SPACE, ARROWS to control. ESC to restart. Music written by David Bowie but played by me.
author: PsySal
title: Major Tom Rocket Driver
comments: Really loved this game so much. The style is very striking and the gameplay I found quite addictive. I just HAD to beat it even if those last levels were quite hard. Europa was very tough but after about 10 tries or more I finally escaped. Really like the writing that takes places between the levels and the piano riffing on the Bowie song set such a good atmosphere. This is one of my favorites from this LD.
Yeah. Music, writing, graphics. Just like HybridMind said, they set such a good atmosphere. I bet even the President of All Humans would like this game.

Neat little style, and a fun game, if a bit frustrating: one mistake usually cost you the level. Nevertheless, I liked the physics and the controls and graphics were good. Some visual feedback on when you can fire again after discharging an engine would be nice.
I like the atmosphere of the game quite a bit.

Very nice idea and done in the right way. But the utter randomness at the later levels is very frustrating. I'll need a new keyboard after this LD. With a little polish, this could be a pretty awesome game.

I really played this game a lot - very fun.  Great music (I know that was Bowie, but you played it well), fun visuals, I liked the style too.  Trying to steer against the wind when you had no way of knowing how it was affecting the ship was frustrating.  I actually found that the most successful technique was just tapping the steering randomly and only occasionally making obvious corrections :D
Overall, though, this was a really enjoyable game.
I really felt that the controls really had no effect on the rocket. I got very frustrated.

description:
You are Bob, a guy who somehow ended up imprisoned and is guarded only by lasers.
Good luck!
Requires XNA (http://www.microsoft.com/download/en/details.aspx?id=20914)
author: MadrMan
title: Lasertrap
comments: Other than the snagging on corners thing I was talking about this game is pretty solid.
The lasers do have some pretty tight timing but a welcome breath of fresh air given the entries I recently played.
Once I figured out that the walls follow the floor tiles and not the actual wall graphics, it became a easier, but it could have been really improved with checkpoints.
Nice concept, but starts to repeat itself. Collisions are a bit buggy. Needs checkpoints, although it is indeed well timed.
Did find it a bit frustrating at points. Agree with the idea of save points. Nice work! :-)
Why I always get stuck on walls in games like this?!  The lasers got me more than once and twice at the corners.

description:
Well... its in no way finished, but here's my firstest ever Ludum Dare entry.
The idea behind the game was that you had stolen an ultra-fast prototype military motorbike and then had to make a quick getaway. Unfortunately there wasn't any time to include any mini cutscenes explaining this. In fact there was not time to implement much in the way of gameplay, but oh well!
The game is based on a heavily modified version of this tutorial:
http://active.tutsplus.com/tutorials/games/create-a-racing-game-without-a-3d-engine/
I'm not sure if that's breaking the rules or not? If so, shove me in the Jam...
author: Chinchilla
title: Escape Velocity
comments: Getting a lovely outrun, space harrier and after burner vibe here. Sad it isn't very finished yet.
When it turned into a jet I was like "Whoa". So in other words, I liked the idea. It was a little hard to tell where the enemy jets would be shooting or coming at you from.

I really liked the warping land scape during the flight stage, but a couple of times it seemed like I was standing still or going backwards. Adding some clouds or random objects to the side of the road might fix this.
The gameplay reminded me of those old handheld electronic games with vacuum fluorescent displays. :)
Woah! This game is all shortlylike. But it's pretty cool, nonetheless. I never quite understood exactly what was happening and it just kinda... ended, but it's still pretty cool and a good start.
nice old school style racing effect that managed to surprise me when it gets "upgraded".
Pretty good attempt, thanks for making this.
Nice! I love the scenes where you switch modes and go a level "higher". The rotating terrain also helps a lot.
Enjoyed it, loved the warping terrain. Good work.

description: Save files created in the same directory of the EXE, starting a new game and hitting the first atom will result in your save being overwritten.
author: NaturallyMade
title: Escape The Void
comments: There were a few collision detection bugs that I bumped into (I clipped into the ground at one point), but nothing hugely game-breaking. Game Maker's a bit of a pain for that kind of thing sometimes.
A fair effort for a game made in 48 hours, good work :D

Thanks :) Got myself into a bit of flashpunk this morning, I don't like coding in game maker an awful lot, the temptation to use D&D is too much! Anyway, this is like my first complete game so, thanks for the feedback, the glitchy collisions were irritating to say the least!
Freezes Wine so I canÍ�'t play it :( Once I could play the first level. Looks kinds cute though
Sadface :( hope you can play some other entries for web and mac, thanks for trying :)
First: This is a really nice first game. Great job. Cute graphics, good level design.
One of my favorite decisions was how you introduced the cannon before the powerup. That's a clever way to go about things.
Don't explain too much - I think the first few levels were a little too walkthrough-y, since the player can probably figure things out on his own.
I eventually got stuck in a wall and couldn't progress further or die, somewhere around level 14 I think? Still, I won't mark you down for that little hiccup. Good stuff.
Fun, although it gets a bit frustrating due collision bugs. Loved the graphics. A really nice entry overall. Congratz!
I glitched and got stuck in a wall, but besides the spotty collision detection it was pretty fun. There were enough different mechanics introduced to keep it interesting.

Wow, amazing! Really polished graphics, the music was pretty cool, although each song was a little short. I agree, the collision could have been a bit better, but everything else certainly makes up for it!

author: cowsheepo
title: Escape Puzzle
comments: There is an error at the end... i'm sorry, but i couldn't figure out how to upload a newer one
oh, the os/x one is actually the source, yet again, i don't know how to upload a new one
Nice work :).  I've always liked these sorts of spacial reasoning puzzles, and I think you did a good job of puzzling here.  The game crashed for me after the big level though, so sad :/
sorry about that, i updated that but couldnt re-upload it (that was the last level) i just forgot to add to only go to the next level if it existed.
Part of the Ludum Dare is creating your art assets WITHIN the 48 hours.  Only the player looks like it's not from Game Maker's sprite library.

description:
The game was made in RPG Maker VX due to the basecode I was making for the compo not being ready.
Your mission is to escape limbo, average playtime is ~5-10 minutes.
The game is terrible due to my lack of being able to not take 3-4 hours to do one tile >.>
Please donate to a poor student
author: ZeroLRS
title: Escape from Limbo
comments: Good effort.  Please donate to a poor game developer.
Looks really nice and the dialogue trees were interesting. :) Guiding the player a bit more may help.
I don't want to be a jerk, but I wouldn't be surprised if that "Donate" thing is scaring people off from playing your game. You might try linking to a personal webpage instead. Just my $.02 though.
At first I thought this is another stupid joke, especially considering your donate link, you're lucky I gave it another try and walked off the platform. Then it crashed in one of the shops.

Before rating I have one serious question and I think I know the answer beforehand - are the sprites and character images your own work or are they standard RPG maker stuff? Because if yes (and I think it is that way considering quality of obviously new stuff), you've broke the competition rules "all content must be created in 48 hours"
Hmm, well I crashed in the inn trying to get a rest. No rest in Hell I suppose!
@Shigor, the sprites and faces are made using a content generator.
@PaulSB, that glitch is fixed and I will be uploading the new version after the rating is done.

description: Escape this fortress of evil. WASD to move around. Press space to drop explosives (if you have any). Beware the birds.
author: kryger
title: Escape From Beyond
comments: Impressive graphics but there doesn't seem to be much gameplay here.
Really nice graphics, the shadows look so cool! I was able to kill a bird with a bomb which was kinda weird..but funny! Character movement could be a bit faster. Good job overall.

It's got a really slick look and feel to it, and the ambient music is great. I wish the character moved faster, though: I kept getting killed by birds and didn't seem to be able to do much about it. I'd definitely like to play a more fleshed-out game in this world.
Music ambience is suitable creepy, but there didn't seem to be a good use for the bombs you carry?
Very nice look! I could see this expanding into some kind of Diablo like dungeon
Atmospheric visuals and music, but really lacking in the gameplay. The bombs take way too long to explode and the game is just slow in general. Nice use of the Unity framework though.
Guy moves painfully slow. I always got killed the second time I saw a bird; seemed like there was nothing I could do to stop him from draining my health? Cool setup though.

description: You have been abducted by aliens who want to probe you. In the name of their 'science' and because they just like it. But you escape there cell and now need to use there own teleports to find your way back home. Story is not well put into the game i had plans to do an animated intro but didnt have time to complete some story driven features. Movement: A+D Jump: Space Action: E Hope you enjoy the game. Timelapse: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MIK2laz_T2c
author: AJMilsom
title: Dot Matrix
comments: A solid and interesting game. I'd love to see it expanded.
Cool concept! I wanted more levels, cause I was really getting into it.
Btw, you still say "Working Title" on the about screen :p If you are still working on it keep at it, cause it looks promising!
Innovation: I've never seen anything like this before, which certainly gives you a good score in this category.
Theme: The theme relevance wasn't fully explained, but it was present.
Graphics: Simple, but they work. Things resemble what they were and work solidly.
Audio: Grating on the ears. This is what could use the most work of anything in this game. Solving puzzles to doot doot doot doot doot doot is a little tedious. :P

Fun: This game certainly has a great charm and personality to it. I felt happy whenever I solved a puzzle, because I thought I did well even though I was pressing buttons until I could win. There was no time-limit or pressure to solve the puzzle, meaning the game is open to all audiences and the player can solve at their own pace, which is good. The puzzles themselves were a little "Let's try this and see if it works," but they were puzzles at their core. I certinaly enjoyed it.
Overall: Fun, silly, and mentally stimulating. Just fix those sounds, make more levels with a smoother learning curve, and you've got a pretty solid game there.

I enjoyed this and got all the way through it but never felt like I totally understood the mechanics of the teleporters. Maybe there is some other way to represent them that would have made it obvious to me?

description: Bomber Planet is a copyright-groping mashup of The Legend of Zelda, Bomberman, Metroid, possibly the Soviet national anthem, and apparently Pokemon.  There is a huge island to explore and some upgrades to discover before you escape the planet!
author: adamatomic
title: Bomber Planet
comments: Looks pretty good. I think you made the map a bit too big for the amount of game content though.
One thing I've discovered is that static terrain pieces (unlike animated characters) are easy to make and add a lot to the atmosphere to the game, creating landmarks and such.

Though, in this case, perhaps random strange tiles here and there would've raised questions (What's the meaning of this? Should I do something here?). For them to work they have to look like mundane stuff (trees etc.). Strange stuff would need a string associated with it so some storytelling could be done "A grave... I wonder who died here?", but it takes time to code of course.

A little too much of the same - games like this with no map are difficult at the best of times, but I started to recognise the tile patterns when in differently textured areas, so I didn't persevere to the end.

That comment seems a bit cruel, so I should add: The graphics and sound effects are very accomplished, and the classic screen transitions were a pleasant shade of retro. I do hope you liven this up a bit and make a full game of it.
Nice retro adventure. I like the soundtrack, it conveys the right sense of "movement" and "adventure".
Also, Bug: Stuff doesn't get blown away when it isn't on the same screen. It's like Schroedingers Cat.
Nice mechanic, and I love that you got to create such a ridiculously large FlxTilemap.  Lonely game.

Didn't really understand where I was going. The mechanics are cool, and the scrolling, and graphics and such are all very accomplished, but I struggled to find any kind of 'objective' and found myself just sort-of wandering, which can only really last so long.

Nice game, but I do agree that the map is too large. :) I had fun exploring, but ultimately didn't finish the game due to feeling like the game world is miles wide and I didn't have any context for my progression toward the end.
I'd love to see this blown out some more. :D
It's pretty and sounds good. But like the others said, the exploration feels too maze-like despite the changing sceneries. There's little incentive to check every nook and cranny.
Cool looking and feeling game. Didn't really find a goal though, though randomly blowing stuff up was fun in itself.
Simple but nicely executed. Agree that the map was a little large, and the extra bomb slots didn't seem very useful. Liked the music, and the bittersweet epilogue text :)
I walked around for 20 min blowing stuff up and then got back to where i started and quit, well done otherwise (woulda loved a minimap).
I have a horrible sense of direction IRL, and the original Zelda was got me lost very quickly. While I like the core game play, I couldn't beat it because I got lost and frustrated.

It was at once powerfully nostalgic and meandering.  All it'd need is a new ability or two or a different enemy.  Also I was annoyed at not being able to kill some of the tougher enemies because they'd eventually wander offscreen into some other part of the map and disappear or get stuck in rocks and water.
I did play through to the end and enjoyed it, nonetheless.  And I'd do it again.
I enjoyed it enough to find my way to the pad, the huge map speaks for the game, although I admit it did get repetitive.
I like the graphic and game style, a long with the classy background music =)
nice but without some clues or a minimap is boring after a bit :(
Very cool idea, bomberman mechanics in a zelda-sized world. Would love to see this fleshed out into a full game!
Hey cool, you were mentioned on Wired: http://www.wired.co.uk/news/archive/2011-08/23/ludum-dare-21

I Liked the intro text, it set the tone (and the controls explanation) well :) Surprised at how massive the map was (bravo!),  but think i would have preferred something a bit smaller to stop me feeling so lost.
A little bit aimless, but interesting. Nice graphics, nice style, functional mechanics. With some development and variety it could be a lot of fun.

This world begs for more content, whats there is really great but the world is so huge I didn't have the patience to find the end. Of course that would be hard in 48 hours, so I just wish the game was a bit more linear. Really nice art and audio!
I wanted an automapper in it. It felt 80's in the bad way(time to break out the graph paper) without one.
I hope you expand this one, it could be a nice Zelda-style game with more items and truly unique areas.
This game was neat! The world felt too big tho, and I got lost, maybe a little minimap or making the game more linear would have helped. Nice anyways!

description:
Built in flixel + tiled + garageband + flashdevelop + photoshop.  I wanted to build something that tries to explain why I would spend 48 hours writing script and making crude pixels, why I would quit my steady job making AAA games to make small things that are given away for free, why if something is too good to be true, you should run from it, because it's fake.
UPDATE: due to popular demand from some people on my google plus, in the next day or two I will be releasing a Director's Cut version of this game that has all the levels (approx 8 more) that I had to cut because they were either too hard or unfinished (once I finish them).  This version will also have a timer running (with a leaderboard for those what complete it), and each death will add some amount of time.  Oh and when I release it I'll unlock all the secret rooms, too :)  I'll post on the frontpage when this happens, as well as a post-mortem shortly after that.
UPDATE: Post Mortem posted:   http://www.ludumdare.com/compo/2011/08/23/and-just-like-that-a-post-mortem/
author: skelethulu
title: and just like that
comments: Nice point, nice way of making it, but cool game too. Ever consider being an indie full time? ;)
I actually have, and did a couple months ago!  But man, taking the jump from a company that won't be going anywhere was super scary for my family.
Hey, don't be giving me any guff game, Flixel was just quicker to use than C++. *cries*
Never saw the 2nd and 3rd screenshots in the game.

Easily my favorite game so far, has it's minor issues and the gameplay isn't unique, and that section with all the guns was a tad too difficult, but an excellent game for sure and deserves to do well.
Beautiful game! Good sense of humor, music really sets the tone, the difficulty ramped up nicely... well, until the part where the music went out and became bullet hell. This game is a favorite.
Yeah, once the music changed, it was game over for me.  Much too hard >_<.   Fun though, and it felt like I had a companion with the messages popping up! Nicely done.
This was beautiful. The best way to escape indeed.
PS: "is this distracting when i do this mid jump?" MOTHER FUUUUUUUU.... *crash*
PS2: If you have played the game but haven't finished. do it. it's worth it.
I felt the same way, escaping life for 48 hours. Best game so far.
YES IT IS DISTRACTING WHEN YOU DO THAT.
I'm mostly just annoyed now that I didn't see some of the secret areas, apparently!
Awesome, really liked the atmospheric feel of the game and the music was perfect. Great job!
Fantastic game, best one I've played so far for LD!
(also, DAMMIT, I took the tunnel assuming it was to some super awesome secret area, then I had to do all the hard parts again to get back!)
Good times! I wondered if the music came from a royalty free site but no you made it too.. really impressive (and a good length despite the cuts!). well played
PS, I like how it felt melancholic, but still gave me an uplifting feeling at the end
Supercute.. I love the atmosphere. I just had to play it until the end.
I thought the ending would be something other actually, but in either case, very nice.
What happens if you take the tunnel.. you really do start over on the flowerfield? :)

I escape from life to where you escaping from. I program all day every day and I like it very much, but sometimes things isn't going well or anyhow. Now that is when I go out with my girlfriend or with friends and play with my dog for some hours. But those hours getting boring soon so I need to get back to programming. The only problem is when I get back to the code, I just don't want to continue it anymore. Does anyone feel something similar to this?
Anyway the game is good, I liked the music very much, those blocks are awesome, cool guiding and hell I didn't find it distracting or hard at anywhere... Thanks for making it!
Good point! The graphics are beautiful, the game is very nice!

Amazing atmosphere. Everything just clicks so well. Usually entries are have an obvious angle where the developer knew "I'm bad at <thing> so I'll skimp on that and compensate elsewhere". In your entry I don't see such weaknesses. Even the level design feels well thought out; with the timings all lining up nicely to avoid forcing the player to wait for a platform.
I'll be finishing this one later :)
I actually got sent back to the flower field at the end, and didn't mind playing through again because I noticed the "alternate path" and wanted to check it out. Glad I did. Very enjoyable!
"Falling down this pit will give you the good ending". This would have been ok if I didn't leave it till a 3rd playthrough! Nice game though. I will never be good enough ;_;
Great graphical style and lovely music.
This is absolutely wonderful; love the 'nice' music, graphical style, simple yet enjoyable platforming, and the wry humour. :) (Did I tell you I love the music?)

This game was great! Fun platformer with good controls, the right amount of difficulty, and an interesting unreliable narrator. I know you plan to add a timer but I found that I really enjoyed the simplicity of the game... I didn't feel rushed and could absorb what the narrator was saying and the graphics. I think this was a fantastic job, especially when I think back to creating my entry for LD21 and what it felt like. Great!

description:
Source version requires python + pygame.
This is a platforming game about a self-reliant princess who decides to rescue *herself* from a tower. Here's the video I watched when the "Escape" theme was announced, for inspiration:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jJ1VbUrRVZI
Controls are left, right, and up. The game auto-saves when you quit, so you should start at the next checkpoint when you restart it.
There are 3 levels in the game (the dialogue should make this clear, but sometimes it doesn't show up). Level 3 is pretty hard, though, so feel free to rate the game after finishing Level 2.
The game should be pretty playable as low as 10fps. If it drops below that for you, check out the README for tips on boosting performance, options, and cheating!
author: Cosmologicon
title: Abigail's Descent
comments: Really great dialogue! Better than what I see in LDs usually, for sure. The idea is nice but quite simple. Timing became a bit aggravating at places, especially with the double jump, due to the awkward way double-jumping early gives you the biggest boost. I quite liked this one!
The game suddenly slowed down and crashed at the last level (every thing was fine before that). Amazingly, when I opened the game again I started at my last checkpoint :)
Splendid game, good job! Reminds me of an old C64 game ... don't remember the name. :(
The only thing I don't like is that the gray characters don't fit with the 3D background, but the overall presentation is superb!

Good dialog, albeit too fast to read sometimes. Jumping is hard, because of a lot of misjudgments. The ledge thingy took some time (and dirty tricks) to understand... Couldn't beat it, (can't judge distances correctly). But apart from that: great music, good graphics... =) Try adding some dumb birds, and ease on the platforming, and you got an insta seller =)
Very nice, well implemented. One thing is ledge jumping could trigger for longer, I kept jumping too late.
Sweet, Funny dialogues, interesting twist on the climbing genre. although i only got to the second level so far. nice game :D

Ok. I completed it. Was going to comment that level 2 was way too hard and unpredictable for me with all the doors. I got lost a number of times going around in loops. Finally beat it, and level 3 was a piece of cake by comparison. Strange.

The characters are really charming and expressive despite their simple appearance, and the premise is fun too. Implementation could have used some polish, but it does work reasonably well. As has been pointed out, the jumping mechanic isn't perfectly intuitive, and I also had trouble landing on tiny platforms more often than not. Would have been more enjoyable if the difficulty didn't ride so much on pixel-precise jumps where the actual collision boundaries are hard to judge. Makes it feel a bit soft and chancy. Tweaking the movement and/or changing the character graphics into something more solid and indicative of collision shapes should make this a great(er) game, for sure.

I like the mix of 2D and 3D, and the way the knight jumps enthusiastically while being completely useless. You have to make sure you're on the edge of platforms when jumping sometimes, and that requires a bit of precision, but it's doable.
Very well done. I wish I read the readme earlier (it was running a bit slow which made it difficult and the warning about level 3 would have helped).

I was going to put a comment that I now withdraw after finding the second power-up. Although for some reason my cliffhanger disappeared and I had to get it twice. It also crashed for me at the end of level 3 (which I promptly reloaded without problem).
The text was a bit fast for me (but I think this also relates to the framerate problem I had since it was much better after I restarted with --fast).
All in all, I'm glad the spirit of teetering towers lives on, although in a very different form.

Great game! I really like the story and dialog, the music is fun, and the scrolling tower jumping is something I haven't seen a lot of. Great job! Biggest gripe is that the cliff-hanger is pretty annoying to use... it's very difficult to predict how far you can go, especially given how precisely you have to use the double-jump. It might have been fun to reverse the mechanic... rather than let you jump from past edge, the cliff-hanger saves you right at the end of your jump. Anyway, good game.

description:
A HTML5 Canvas game writing using CoffeeScript.
Has only been tested in modern browsers.
Help Tom escape by controlling bridges as he runs.
UPDATE 23/08/2011: Fixed bug stopping it from loading on Firefox 6
comments: Firefox 6, MacOS X 10.7. Game shows up as a solid purple square.
Worked for me (Win7/Chrome) Found a score bug :o) Hold enter and your score increases! I got over 9000m! What's with the bees though?
i couldn't get it to run either, solid purple square :(
Fixed the bug stopping it loading in some browsers. (Seemed like the general consensus is that youâ��re allowed to fix that type of bug?)
And about the bees: I didnâ��t get time to implement them! Just like all of the other obstacles and random level generation I was meant to do.
Learning CoffeeScript whilst doing this slowed me down way more than expected.
Love, love the game concept. Enjoyed not having to control the little man and just provide bridges for him.

description:
Game Name:  "Get That Fellow Out! "
Genre: Homage to the NES Battletoads speeder bike level
Platform: Android 2.2, confirmed working on Evo 4g, Nexus S, Droid 1 (playable with drawing issues on Honeycomb)
Source and APK
http://1337.pro/Shared/LudumDare/
Sorry for the lack of sound, years of working at big companies left my actual coding skills atrophied and weak, so I wasted Friday and Saturday goofing around and making a worthless class design, then it took a surprisingly long time to write functional OpenGL code.. :*)
author: SharkApple
title: (For Android) GetThatFellowOut
comments: Hey guys, I'll try to round up an assortment of Android phones/tablets and port the game to them this week
It was playable on my galaxy tab 10.1, but it had some graphical issues
PS: This should work on any phone running 2.2 (FroYo) with an 800x480 pixel screen or higher, so Nexus 1, evo, thunderbolt, galaxy s, etc will probably handle it gracefully
If you give it a shot and it explodes on you please drop me a line, bugrep@bigpen.us
Heh, nice! Works fine, Samsung Galaxy S here.
Works on my moto droid! Game itself is rather simplistic, but it was a fun diversion while it lasted.
Don't have a smartphone, but it's great that you made a droid game for this competition. I can't vote on it but I'll put this comment here so the system knows to give me more to vote on!
same here, no android phone unfortunately :P. could you create a gameplay video and post it on youtube or something? at least that way we can see the game
I couldn't get this to install on my EVO4G.  I dropped it onto my SD card and tried to run it with EasyInstall like I usually do but it wasn't recognized.  So sad :(
Confirmed NOT working on my crappy Motorola Backflip. I kind of expected that; the phone is shite. Wish I could play!
Ok, I soooooo need to get a Smartphone for next LD :-p
Sorry about the lack of desktop compatibility, everyone!  Next time I'll try and plan ahead to make a desktop version, or at least come up with a way to record a decent quality gameplay video
It must be pretty frustrating if you're going for the "Play & Rate All Games" achievement but this is standing in the way :*(
I don't suppose there's an Android simulator somewhere we could get?

description:
YOU NEED THE SOUND to understand the game, turn the speakers on ;)
It's a HTML5 game. If something doesn't work, or works badly (no sound, game too fast, game too slow...), please report it (I tested only with Chrome and Firefox, without hardware acceleration)!
This is my first Ludum Dare.
== Cool quotes ==
"OMG I won, it was epic..." -- geekshadow about the ending
"Lol, that's priceless" -- PaulZ about the ending
"Hey, check my humble, totally awesome and super-funny HTML5 game!" -- Marin spamming LD's IRC channel about the ending
"I can't even get out of the first room." -- wademcgillis before the ending
author: Marin
title: Escape (what an original name)
comments: Welp, I think I've tried everything from jumping at walls to climbing and standing on all the platforms to clicking the light and pressing all the normal control keys. No idea what to do.
Nice ending. I wish it was longer.
Please never become a game developer.
Very funny - cute demo. Never mass release - you're likely to get death threats.
@kevglass Death threats? Wow, that looks cool :D
I love the "doom dudu-du doom" music.
Odd, maybe like-able, but it lacks an objective, direction, i do not know what to do. Keep working anyway, maybe if it was any longer..
The direction is: finding something to escape.
I couldn't get past the first room, so if there was some humor past there I didn't see it. The music was incredibly annoying in my opinion.

description:
You are a fireman trapped at the top of a burning skyscraper. You have only your axe and some water.
Get to the exit, taking as many helpless bystanders with you as possible. The fire is already spreading...
---
Towering Inferno is a roguelike firefighting game where water and fire interact in interesting ways. You can never extinguish the flames, but maybe you can control them, and escape the building.
It was written in C++ with libtcod. You can find me on twitter @tenpn, and the devlog for this game is online at http://tenpn.tumblr.com .
To run, you'll need to install the Visual C++ runtime: http://www.microsoft.com/download/en/details.aspx?id=5555
EDIT:
Man! A typo on the GUI suggests that you should use the A key to activate it, but it's actually the X key.
author: tenpn
title: Towering Inferno
comments: Really neat idea. I like the decisions the game has you make. Great use of ascii, too.
I really like the concept, especially the water bombs. Oh and the changing tips at the top of the screen were extremely useful and a great way to ease players into playing the game.

There's really a lot of gameplay here for having just a few key elements. Couldn't get the axe to work but it's a fun game without it. Many levels are created too easy, or too hard, and I often wonder which decision is the best one, so I think a level save feature would be great addition. That way I could collect levels which are just barely beatable.
What about the axe didn't work? It should take 3 hits to dismatle one wall tile, and you need to stand next to the wall tile.

Thanks for the feedback about difficulty - the only concesion to the random nature of the procedural generation is that fire is not allowed to appear in the exit room. Didn't have time for any thing else there. Something to work on.
This application has failed to start because MSVCP100.dll was not found. Re-installing the application may fix this problem.
Sorry, you probably need to install the Visual Studio 2010 C++ runtime. http://www.microsoft.com/download/en/details.aspx?id=5555
Please can you try again with that and let me know if that fixes it?
I loved this game! Played it for probably 30 minutes beyond my normal review time. :)

I wish you had more time to add some fire spawn logic, as I found it was totally random if you could beat a level or not. There were instances were I spawned in a room with all of the fire start locations, and relinquished them with a water bomb and I could walk wherever I wanted. On the other hand, there were times where both fire spawns were in rooms adjacent to the exit and I spawned across the map, so there was no hope of me ever making it out.
Anyway, I love what you did with it and had a ton of fun. I liked making decisions about how many people to save before I got myself out instead. Felt bad to leave them behind. ;)
I just loved it! Gave me a Desktop Dungeon feeling...you know...when you can't stop playing until you've beat the game more time than he beated you (yeah...sorry for that english)
Fun game, but despite the axe option, and after 45min testing, it looks like the generator luck is 50% of your final score. Work pretty well in any case.

Very good idea, very original setting for RGL. It would need some finetuning (generator especially) and bug hunting (at least I consider burning walls completely surrounded by the water from hydrant a bug) for me to be completely satisfied, but i'm rating high anyway.
It did feel like each level was either easy or impossible. But nice idea!

description:
Wow. Well that was a whole load of fun. It's finally finished.
"To Hell And Back" is a classic LucasArts-style point and click graphic adventure. Featuring the hero Ragnar, who finds himself unexpectedly somewhere he'd quite like to escape from.
Can you solve the fiendish adventure and ESCAPE BACK TO THE REAL WORLD?
I wrote the whole thing from scratch just for this, including a SCUMM-style adventure engine. I'm actually fairly happy with that; you could almost write a production-quality game in it, if you didn't mind it not supporting save games.
I decided to take advantage of the server downtime to polish it up a little, tweaking some of the dialogue. (hopefully that doesn't count against the 48hr limit) :-/
I'd originally planned for it to be about 2-3 times bigger than it is, but this was my first time writing adventures, and it turns out it's way more time consuming than you'd think.
Windows only, source included.
author: Kayamon
title: To Hell And Back
comments: Small update: Fixed a couple of minor bugs which could prevent you completing the game.
Oh, this is funny. Also, soundtrack is great.
Liked the game (didn't complete it, but I liked it!)
I really loved this game, it had that old Point'n'Click Adventure vibe all over it! It was fun to play and very funny!
Great job, I hope you'll make a longer Adventure game someday! :) 5*

Fun little game. hard to really enjoy the dialogue with the slow auto-scroll though. I would have really liked clicking to advance the dialogue. Also a "smart" right mouse as seen in later adventure games would be nice as well (such as right clicking on the door defaults to "Use"

Allright, out of few dozens LD entries I've rated you've got the biggest overall score :) Mixing "final fantasy" characters style with SCUMM adventure, adding enough fun and coding it all in 48 hours, respect. There's only one thing I disliked and that's the speed of the dialogue, it's very annoying for me (as a speed reader) to be unable to skip to the next line.

But really excellent, one of the very few entries I've passed link to my friends. I even decided to forgive you for abusing the time extension which was supposed to be only as a safeguard for upload problems - you're not the only one, but you're first I rated even if you did it.
I didn't expect such a positive response to it.
Monkey Island reference? Hell yeah! :D Awesome entry, liked this one very much.
This is a pretty solid adventure game :)
Yeah, I'd also like to advance the dialogue by left-clicking since I'm a fast reader.
But that's just nitpicking, it's quite impressive for a 48 hour game.

description:
The Grind is a simple game about escaping from work at a reasonable hour by avoiding responsibility.
The goal is to acquire as little work ("to-do's") as possible throughout your 9-5 workday. Wander around the cubicles and hide from the men in suits--if they're coming your way, that means they want to give you work to do!
Use the arrow keys to move, space to start, and escape to exit.
Gameplay video: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rKPY5R4reJY
The game and assets are licensed under the terms of the GNU GPL. Enjoy!
author: Deraj
title: The Grind
comments: Neat idea, but perhaps a more clear goal, or somewhere you had to get to in order to beat a level would've made it more interesting than just hiding in a cubicle the whole time! :D
Wish there was a way to work off the TO-DOs! ;)
Love the idea, but I feel powerless to really get an effective strategy going. The suits move more or less move randomly so I end up hiding at one spot for a long time.

It's an innovative theme, but as other commenters have said it felt pointless hiding in a cubicle all day. Although I imagine that's what a lot of bored office workers feel, so perhaps you achieved your aim!
I also wish there was a way to work off the TODOs! My high score was 6.
Can compile, but can't play it on Arch Linux 32 bits... Whenever I press any arrow key it stops working. Here's the console output:
ERROR: [string "TheGrind/TheGrind.lua"]:171: attempt to call method 'reset' (a nil value)
ERROR: [string "TheGrind/TheGrind.lua"]:1277: attempt to index field 'eventHandlers' (a nil value)
If you need any help debugging this, please PM me on IRC (N0_Named_Guy)

Many apologies, N0_Named_Guy, the source tarball specifies a required version of radius-engine of 0.7, but it actually requires radius-engine 0.8 which is currently only available from the Git repository (git://radius-engine.git.sourceforge.net/gitroot/radius-engine/radius-engine).
Sorry for letting that slip in. I think I can actually remove the dependency on radius-engine 0.8 without affecting the game. I'll try and do that tomorrow.
This is a brilliant interpretation of the theme. I am *ahem* I mean I have coworkers who are experts in cubical ninjitsu.

N0_Named_Guy (or anyone else compiling from source), I've uploaded a new source package that only depends on radius-engine-0.7.tar.gz (which can be found here: https://sourceforge.net/projects/radius-engine/files/). Thanks for the heads-up, and sorry for the trouble!

description:
You are an FBI agent. Your plane exploded. You must Surf to Survive. Escape the rocks and rogue waves... if you can.
Tip: When starting out you're falling from the sky, wait until you hit the water to turn.
Tip: In order to have a successful landing you need to be facing in the direction you're moving.
Tip: Write down your longest time/distance and try to beat it (if you're into that).
Arrow keys Move
Space or Enter restarts
title: SurfN
comments: Awesome! reminds me a ton of the surfing section in california games.
Simple graphics, but used to great effect.  The music and sound effects are good, too.
I really like the jump mechanic, but couldn't find any reason to actually use it (besides that I thought it was cool).
You might want to consider rendering the current distance/time at the top of the screen, so that the player can see exactly how close they are to beating their previous score.

Pretty cool, like Basilios I liked the jumping. Maybe if you had some sort of collectible people had to jump for it would be more motivation to risk the jump itself. Or just walls or rocks there is no other way around.
i love the "succum'd" fail messages. nice little game.

I've had some framerate issues (drops here and there), but it's playable (this might be Firefox-only issue). I've made as far as 11821.98 meters, but with no jumping (which should be encouraged because it looks and feels cool!). Really nice game.
I'm too tired to play this right now, i find it irritating that I can surf for less than a second then have to wait 4 seconds to try again. I promise to play and rate this later.
A surfing FBI agent dodging rocks! This not only looks retro but acts retro. I could totally see this as having been a game title over 20 years ago :D
I don't quite understand the landing rules, I guess it has something to do with the tide, because some I had different results just from the beginning.

description:
The game is complete and has six levels (each with 6 waves of robots). The only controls are Up and Down to move the player. For every 30 robots with a blue outline you shoot, your weapon gets upgraded.
There is only a Windows version which I have tested in Win7 64-bit, but it should also work in Windows XP and above. There is no audio.
I kept progress updates on my twitter: @DigiJerm. The game doesn't really follow the theme, but too bad. :)
------
Update (2011-9-3): I have made a post-compo version that makes the fireballs from the red-stripe robot easier to see. It also fixes some rendering glitches. This version requires OpenGL 2.0 or higher.
author: Jerm
title: Robot Tunnel
comments: No sound, you loose life without being hit and doesn't loose life when being hit. Nice try though :)

@daandruff: The robots with the red stripe shoot very fast moving (almost invisible, unfortunately) fireballs which is probably why your health is going down. To avoid them you need to be constantly moving.

I'm not sure why you're not losing life when you get hit, but it only counts as hitting if the fireball hits right in the center of the player sprite (which for the smaller fireballs can look like the collision detection is not working :)).
Neat!  It could really use some sound, and visual distinction as well.  It's really really hard to see most of the bullets, which is bad in a bullet hell like this one.
Those grey fireballs are really fast.
The enemies could have used a bit more graphic variety. The lack of sounds made this hard to play and the unclear collision box made getting hit feel a little arbitrary.
I like the variety of projectiles but as others have said, the bullets are often invisible. As is the white text on very light blue background.

description:
NEW: Linux support with curses! (Do note that it requires a very large terminal window; you may have to mess with your prompt to get it to fit)
The story is described in-game, but in short: You are an AI in a Shadowrun-style futuristic setting, trying to evade those who wish you destroyed.
Written in Python using only the stdlib and WConio.
Purely console based, Windows-only.
I was extremely happy with how the UI turned out - it captured that Movie Interface feel quite nicely. Much of the gameplay itself was coded in under 12 hours, and there's so much more I wish I could do, but I'm satisfied enough.
You can view a screenshot progress archive at https://github.com/jtruscott/ld21/tree/master/snapshots
Notes:
- Please use the Windows Binary (Fixed) link!
The original submission would get completely wedged if you got purged from a node.
- Typing long command names can get tedious. However, once you've disambiguated a name to only have only matching command, it'll happily run it. For example, 'neighbors' can thus be shortened all the way down to 'n'.
Happy hacking!
- Spigot [Rectifier on IRC]
author: Rectifier
title: On The Run!
comments: I've never seen anybody break the fourth wall like this before, this is really a great concept!

I'm a big fan of console games (Nethack, Dwarf Fortress and Liberal Crime Squad), so I was surprised by this entry. A very fun game, reminds me of Uplink, which I spent hours playing on. I got the feeling I was really trying to escape, rushing commands to go as far as I could. But the Purge action is somehow broken, I don't know if that is intended but every time someone purges me from a node, I can't play anymore because it raises an NPC exception.

I keep running in to a bug where it says ERROR: Cannot travel to a node you are already connected to. in the home node, which makes me unable to travel at all since I can't back out. Maybe I'm just doing this wrong.
There was a game-ruiningly severe bug in NPC purging; I've uploaded a fixed binary. I believe it's allowed by the "fixing crashbugs" clause, but I kept the original up just in case.
Indeed reminded me of Uplink. But that also points out one of the downsides of command-line tedium. Very well implemented for 48h game. "neighbors" is a bit of a pain to type though :P
As soon as you narrow it down to a single legal command (which the autocomplete is supposed to help with), it'll run. By the time I implemented that I never did anything but "nei" or "nei -s".
I'll add that to the documentation here.

Quite a good game. I loved the concept and your approach to the theme. I kinda missed the ability to scroll through the console log though. I also didn't know exactly what to use as ID for things like defending a node. There's no "ID" next to each entry in the tunnel list (although I assumed a zero-based index). A VERY good job nonetheless, I actually enjoyed it a lot. One of the best games I've tried so far.

It seems really cool but really involved. I'm going to have to give it another look later. One thing I really wish for is a faster way to input commands. Being able to press the up and down arrows to scroll through previous entries would help loads.

description: Yeah. It's really horrible.
author: asfdfdfd
title: Horrible Escape
comments: I like those useless boss001 xD
boss001 can kiss my butt. Simple enjoyable game!
Loving the placeholder (I believe they're placeholder) graphics. The game was enjoyable and I liked the dialogue system. Overall, quite nice :)
An unassuming little entry with definite fun and charm :).
Short and simple but pretty fun while it lasted - despite the basic graphics managed to have some character to it.
Things too a little too much shooting to kill than necessary, but nothing was more complicated than it needed to be.
Fun little game. Make it pretty and it'd be killer :)
Not one on my favorites. The graphics needed improvement. None of the triggers resets when you die. The boss was kinda rough given quick death and no visible life meter. Better luck next time.
I think you should polish the "placeholder artstyle" extract some laughs from it, expand the content a little and you've got something pretty cool. Currently it's funny yet a little too short

description:
Facebreak Escape is a game where prisoners are trying to escape a dungeon. You have to escape the prison by fighting against hordes of security guards with your allies and reach the freedom which lies ahead.
To reach the end you have to brawl with 11 waves of enemies, collect loafs of break to gain health and free your friends from cages haning from the roof.
You can move using arrows and pressing up your character will jump, use X to punch enemies and cages.
Hope you enjoy the game!
author: T8000
title: Facebreak Escape
comments: Neat game. Love the graphics. I've not quite figured out the "trick" to not getting hit when attacking guards, but still fairly fun. Nice to see cooperative AI.

Thanks FireSlash! Oh i'll be posting a gameplay video soon about the combat how to deal with the opponents. You'll have to be rather careful how near you go to them. Oh what? I can't upload my source files anymore? Oh well here you go anyways: http://dl.dropbox.com/u/3142599/FBE.gm81
...and I thought my game was weird
One question: why does each wave end in a hoard of mini-prisoners?
fun and violent, I can see more rampage than escape in this... :) The art is pretty unique too !
Andrew: Haha, I thought that it'd be fun and to have something to show that you're helping out the other prisoners by doing what you do. :D
Very cute (and slightly odd) gfx. The gameplay could probably have been more polished, felt a bit random :)

description:
Help your bird pals escape from bird jail through the power of beatboxing! I recommend having some musical experience before playing this game, otherwise you will probably suck. Feel free to prove me wrong!
Made with GameMaker, Paint.net, and Sonar Home Studio.
Have fun!
author: Cosine
title: Extreme Beatboxing Bird Jailbreak
comments: Could probably use some helpers for the player so that they know where they're going wrong. Like maybe showing which tracks are still wrong? I played until Morgan Freeman, but I felt like it was too tedious to go on when what I had pretty much sounded like what the bird was singing but I guess a note here or there was missing or too much.
My friends have been freed, I am the beatboxing master! Great execution, enjoyed finishing it :)
Nice, love music games! The final one was really tricky.

@Pekuja: I agree: I wanted to add a feature that showed which tracks were wrong if you didn't succeed, but that would require rewriting the success/failure-checking system. That isn't something you want to do with 2 hours left. :P
very cool, finally some music game \o cute grahpics, and also:
your bird friends are in bird jail. free them with your drum machine
thats the most epic quest title ever :D
Awesome. This  game made me feel like I could actually do music! :P I like drum machines, but I don't think I've ever seen a game using this mechanic. Great idea and a very good execution!
Lovely game! I'm a big fan of audio components, so well done! And the concept is hilarious.
I'm one of the people who suck at this by default, but I can appreciate the innovation and fun-factor. Well done.
i am so glad someone made a music game. really really good fun.
Nice entry, really enjoyed it.  Another favorites to add to the list. Thanks! :-)

description:
First time touching unity. Turned out fairly well. Added decent audio this time. Left out music as it seemed to cover up the audio cues of the player being detected. The heightmap was made in geocontrol 2 and then I threw together some textures for it.
When playing try to use the terrain to your advantage. Running like mad usually ends up with the player getting exploded off the map.(Weeee!)
The terrain is a bit over 16 square km. All of the artwork and sounds including the particle sprites were done by me this weekend. I didnt use a single premade unity item.
Tools used:
3d studio max
photoshop
unity
geocontrol2
notepad++
I havent tested the mac version but if it doesen't work give the web version a try (it is an offline html.)
Update: few hours left. Increased the "Oh Sh!t" factor a bit.
Unity has a undocumented feature where it culls a bunch of stuff when you change the FOV of a camera. Zooming will lag a lot but it is still good to use if you are not getting shot at.
author: Falcon256
title: Escape the Drones
comments: There is a nice star wars feel to it,

but I didn't finish it, because the escape seemed to be really too far, and they weren't any dynamic or unexpected things to happens, plus I don't think the game is really optimized, It lag alot when zooming

The drones can call in their friends when alerted and wander around the world. I think I might have toned down the difficulty a bit too much. The goal is placed randomly each game and sometimes it can be a bit far.
I haven't been able to figure out why the lag starts when the camera's FOV changes. It has something to do with Unity.
I just walked 1300 meter without meeting a single drone in my path, only off in the distance. Also, the game lags MAJOR time when zooming in.

Since I have a bit of time left I upped the difficulty to where there is at least a challenge (blame the girlfriend playtesting and loosing for the previous difficulty(yep I just got smacked.)) I also changed how the zoom worked. might lag a bit less.

I had a hard time understanding what to do, the text in the lower left corner was only partially visible and there was no other apparent visual queue as to where to go or what to do. Besides that the game looks great! Nice to see some more 3d games as well. Cheers
Ideally your "Web" link should go to a playable page, not a ZIP download :(
Never really managed to find the sphere and the terrain didn't offer much protection, though I was probably using it wrong

Never got more than a few meters, over several attempts.  I really couldn't figure out a technique for avoiding the drones.  They saw me even when in a trench, and they moved so much faster than me that getting out of the way when they  were heading toward where I was wasn't an option.  I think I'd like it at "girlfriend difficulty" better. ;)

description:
About:
So here is my LD48 #21 Entry...
Don't expect much from this, but it plays and I am happy since it is my first LD
There are only 5 levels too.
To play:
If you have python and pygame installed run the .py (the source file)
if not, run the exe.
Controls:
mouse to target
LMB to launch an ESCAPE ship
RMB to place the launcher
and when in Launching mode, RMB fires a bomb that will disable a ship
m to turn off that annoying music
q to quit
Known bugs:
Can't launch bomb if all ships are launched, oh well.
q to quit, no alt-f4 or closing the window, sorry I forgot to add it.
Everything, source and executables are in the zip file
HenryPenface<3
author: henrypenface
title: Escape Lines
comments: A fun little game mechanic, it'd be nice to see it explored a bit more. Also seemed like it could be moving about about twice the speed, once you fire off all the ships there is quite a bit of sitting and waiting.
If I get around to updating it for a post-ld version I will be sure to toy with the speed a little :)
Nice idea, but it really is too slow
Nice idea. As others have said, a bit too slow. Also, it seems that there is no disadvantage to launching everything at the same time right now.

Originally the enemy ships were not limited to 3 tractor beams at once, so the game was more about trying to find a path through, a balance between this and how it is now might be nicer. (Thanks for the comments btw guys)
Great idea, but quite difficult in higher levels. I like the graphical presentation.
I liked it! Was a bit on the slow side but still fun none the less. :-)
This is the best game featuring Burnley I have ever played! xD Liked it, but yes I turned the music off pretty quickly, sorry :) Congrats on a good effort!
Very interesting idea although it was a tad too slow for my tastes.  The last level is a marvel of game balancing :-)

description:
You are some kind of ball creature that needs to escape the pull of an elastic band that is attached to you. It gets pretty tricky, so props to anyone who finishes it!
Made using Java, LWJGL, EasyOgg, Photoshop and Ableton Live.
author: bitbof
title: Elastic Prison
comments: this is great! very nice physics game, can be frustrating but still very fun, and really dark too! the audio is really atmospheric.
to start, in case someone gets errors.. difficult game :P
I can't execute *.jar files, but I can run java-based games and applications. What do I have to download? Maybe make an *.exe?
@Jorjon Try downloading it again. I fixed the native library path.
I had a lot of trouble with the elastic 'resetting' on me. I'd get down to what I assumed was a 'checkpoint' (the larger balls) and I always seemed to randomly get pulled all the way back to start.

I only seemed to be able to make progress when I had the ball in what appeared to be a glitched state. I was moving way faster than I ever had and managed to get to the second large node in one go. Unless this was just me figuring out the physics for a split-second. :P
I loved the audio, the art, and the vibe. I just couldn't finish due to constant resetting and got frustrated.
Very nice concept, control feel weird though. As if the longer you hold them the weaker they get.
Failed to finish it on first run, tried now the second time and was screaming in frustration... I seriously don't get the controls. What is mechanic of "weakening" of controls?
Anyways got till lot of small dots continued by few moving dots and was thrown back to the start.
Anyways, I really like the concept, with some more work it can make in to a great game. If you re imagine controls for touch you can make it in to a decent Android game!

I also like the concept, audio and graphics are really nice, but there is something weird about the controls, that makes the game a little too frustrating for me (there's a part where I cannot gain enough distance with swings, which I suppose is the way it should work, at least when strings are involved). This is, however, a minor problem, and easily fixable.
Also, stable checkpoints would be nice. :)

description:
Run away and save the kingdom.
This is an early release. I hope I can update it later :)
If you like you can watch the timelaps at http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=m5Kf03v1Uws.
Update: I can :).  There is music in the game now.  I used the ingame sounds (like jumping, checkpoint) as samples.
On Windows you can extract it and start the batch file.  Other operating systems needs Love2D to run (http://www.love2d.org) at the moment.
author: neosam
title: Dragon's Bloodmoney
comments: I know I'm not a good artist :)

I love to see LOVE2D getting some exposure, it's where I learned lua ^^.  This feels sort of unfinished to me though, like there were supposed to be enemies or some element of challenge that didn't make it through.  Maybe next time :)
I also learned lua this weekend :)

Yes I made the Enemy "class" at the beginning.  The Enemy-Object walks in left or right.  When it collides, it switched it's walking direction.  But there was no collision detection and I had no idea what I should do if the player hit the enemy (dead, subtract time, ...).
On the other hand I had not enough time to do more stuff.  It was the first time I took part on a competition and my first project on lua :).

I'm really really really really frustrated by the jumping. Halfway the second level there is a lot of jumping going on. I spend 10 minutes trying to get past this row of bricks, and when i finally got past them to the checkpoint and fell down, there was a checkpoint which actually set me back again. Not wanting to jump all the way AGAIN I gave up.
I admin that this part can be very frustrating.  If you made it once you should be able to do it faster.  This is the last hard part in the game.  Especially the second checkpoint is not fair...
Because I was testing the game all the time I thought the game is too easy and so I made this part.  Lots of friends told me the same.  Sorry, next time I will make the game easier.

description:
Tools used: Blitzmax/Photoshop/cfxr/Audacity.
Framework: homemade miniframework (public sources)
My first entry!
cosmoZ is a try to create a game with no tile map, no characters, and the most linked to the theme.
You have to escape from your dying planet to the promise land, using your space ship (the violet square on your screen...).
Mechanic is based on travel range (depending of the planet around which your in orbit. There is also special planets: asteroids (destroyable after take-off) and satellits (attracting your ship automatically).
I think there is something good in the gameplay. However, this is really unfinished. For example: difficulty curve is bad, and gamefield is not everytime fun to play (too much random, need some improvement).
It took me around 15 hours of work (or less) as I took some long break, and start late on the first day (and sleep a lot :)).
Enjoy!
author: rockford
title: cosmoZ
comments: Segfaults in WINE, no Linux build.
Just made a lot of noise on OSX, no controls seemed to do anything.
Hum... The game works well on OSX (was made on OSX...). There is no controls except SPACE to play, and then use the mouse. There is a short help pressing "I" from the menu screen.
Please rate my game. I know it is a weird concept, but worth a play! Once you understand the mechanics, it's quite fun and very innovative.
Please note that the game play with the mouse. Except the menu (shortcuts displayed on the screen: SPACE to play, I for Instructions (ESC to quit instructions).
There is some bugs (invisible sentinels...) bu I don't know if I can fix before end of rating...
I quite liked it up until I had to wait for too long to reach a planet. Worth building into something bigger mind you.
Yes you're right. The "wait too long" is the issue of the mechanic. I think to implement a better gamefield generator, and a tweak to avoid this, but it's was not possible in 48h. Thanks for playing!
Played a few levels, hit 'n' by accident, wanted to see how many levels there were but they appeared to just be randomly generated forever.
Would make for a fine touch interface game if there were a few more mechanics added and you could zoom in, things were just a touch small.

I really like the pathfinding mechanic. There's definitely some potential there. Unfortunately the map generator seems to have some problems (not surprising for a 48 hour game =p) there were times when the only way to advance was to sit and wait while my orbit slowly expands to bring the next planet into range, which killed a lot of the fun for me.

description:
CAPTIVE
A game by Nate Wiesel
for Ludum Dare 21
You awaken in a strange, unfamiliar place. All you know is that you need to escape.
There is a post-compo update that fixes some major bugs. Here's the list of changes from 1.00 to 1.03:
-Added a few tiles to some rooms to make them slightly less dull.
-Fixed a music bug with the red terminal (for real this time)
-Added a secret 4th Boomka game you can unlock after beating the red terminal.
-Added a "portal" object to a single room. It's related to the secret.
-Made it so that checkpoints remember what key cards and doors are open when you save (as well as other variables, such as the music playing). This prevents you from grabbing a keycard, getting killed, but keeping the keycard after respawning.
-Added sounds for the fireballs.
-Randomized the fireball-pipe's first alarm a tiny bit.
-Fireballs now destroy when they fall off the edge of the screen.
-Made it so that using a terminal will reset the "used" status of checkpoints, so you can save again if you've just played a Boomka game.
-Removed a couple of very frustrating spikes.
-Moved around and added a couple of turrets, as well as some fireball-pipes.
-Closed one of the exits early in the game, past a blue door. Turns out I never added a room past there. Silly me. :p
-Refined the controls a bit. Feels a lot less slippery.
-Added version number to the opening.
-Fixed a few broken tiles
-Added simple particle effects for sparks and blood.
author: NateNaterson
title: Captive
comments: Simple platforming but it kept my interest. The mini-games were a nice touch and distraction, but those red potatoes can die in a spike pit. Nice game, good job.
This is really good! I like the minigames and the brutal death animation.
Fun, Mini-games were the best part. It was weird that the key didn't open the door on its own, though that may be Doom talking.
I really like the simple but brutal deaths (including corpses). The platforming works but it feels a bit slippery sometimes.

Pretty creative beginning. Sound gets repetitive and annoying later on. Nice touch with minigame. It's a bit hard though since you often can't get form one side to the other in time. Gameplay is solid, but has too much air-control.
the minigames were very cool, not a bad game!
I liked it very much, although the moving platforms were a bit frustrating to get on some times. Good work!

Game is cool, but man... It bugged out on me...After getting the blue key, and unlocking blue doors, insted of going forward, I went down... It gave an error (in which I pressed ignore). It was something about an undeclared var, on goto something level... Music is great, except for the first one (before getting the green key). Controls worked great for me, and liked the intro =) Nice job, nasty bug that kept me from playing more...
@N0_Named_Guy: I believe the bug you found was one that is fixed in the most recent version. 1.00 had some problems, sorry. :(
Arg, I also hit the bug with the blue key.  It is a shame (I actually screamed "NOO!!") because the game was fun up until that point.
Fun game! I played through the whole enhanced version and scored 67 on the extra BoomKa!

description:
[edit3]
Post-Mortem: http://www.ludumdare.com/compo/2011/08/23/bunnies-back-into-your-cage-post-mortem/
[/edit3]
[edit2]
Because of public demand, the Kongregate version now got an update for the control scheme. In order to pickup/drop the blocks, you have to use the Shift key! This should make the game more user-friendly.
Also, it is possible to use WASD for movement now, zooming works with Q and E.
[/edit2]
[edit]
I uploaded the original LD version as SWF now, as the Kongregate version got an update. There was a bug (sometimes, when you clicked a button, there were two levels loaded) which I fixed, and I made the last level a tiny bit harder (deleted some blocks).
[/edit]
----------------------------
In this game, you have to allure bunnies into cages, by building a path with the arrowkeys and holding a carrot.
Sounds easy? It is! But beware of the goblins and trolls!
I had only less than 36 hours or so to make the game, and I learned a great portion of FlashPunk while doing it, so please be aware that there are some bugs. The biggest one is that the trolls somehow make invisible blocks ... :-/
Other than that it is pretty playable, though I don't know if the last levels are beatable, or fun. ;-) [edit]I can confirm now that they are beatable.[/edit]
----------------------------
Controls: (for LD version)
Arrowkeys -> Movement (+ Picking Blocks)
R -> Restart Level
Q/W -> Zoom (because it's fun)
1/2 -> Switch Pick Mode (in Mode 2 you don't pick blocks anymore)
----------------------------
BTW, the game's gameplay was inspired by great classics like BoulderDash and Spherical.
...
*cough* And Minecraft. *cough*
author: ratking
title: Bunnies, Back Into Your Cage!
comments: cool game, I find it a bit hard to play since I always drop the blocks when I want to jump around! But great concept !
Interesting, but it could do with some more interesting blocks, and the controls get tedious really fast. I like the cute graphics!
@uuav That's why I made two modes ... press "2" and you won't pick up and drop blocks any more. Press "1" and everything is back to normal.

@RandomMOO Yeah, I also had some other / more ideas for the game, but time was too short as I started late with this. I did something with Unity3D, got frustrated, and much later used Flash/Flashdevelop.
Sorry for the bad controls, I worked hard on them and they still are not perfect. :-(

The concept is good but the execution is lacking. The controls are awkward; it's as if the game can't decide whether it's a top-down Sokoban-like game or a platformer. It takes much longer than expected to clear each level, to the point where rearranging the blocks over and over starts feeling tedious.
I really liked the music and the style of the game. Annoying controls but who cares? ;)
Novel and interesting. Graphics are fantastic, controls didn't annoy me too much, once I got the hang. LOVE ZOOM.

@ointment The game was never meant to be a classic platformer. The controls probably feel awkward because you can't accept that they the movement is per-block only (with interpolation for the eye candy).
BTW, this comes from the fact that I planned the game to be a "PixelCraft", where everything really is a pixel. ;)
The controls were a bit frustrating, and I'm not entirely certain how it fits into escape seeing as how you capture rabbits, but I like the open ended solution to the levels.
@Andrew The rabbits have escaped and you have to recapture them!

Well, but it's true. I started Ludum Dare with Unity3D and was frustrated with my project. So saturday evening I opened FlashDevelop without any real plan and started coding. This time I began to create something more fun, but the theme lacked. So I confess it really is tacked later on, sorry.
I have to agree with previous posters, controls could have been better. And "pickup mode" 1 or 2 isn't really self-explanatory. Even on/off would have been better :)

Graphics are very cute, and it definitely has potential as a block based puzzle platformer. I like how you used the escape theme, that it's not the protagonist who is escaping and the escape isn't the goal.
I changed the controls in the Kongregate version, please tell me if you find them to be better now.
cool artwork and music, but the controls ruin it for me.
Funny. The first words in my game we "Oh Noes!" too :-)
I like this idea, especially the "carrot"-block. It's immeditely recognizable, which is great.
@mes Sorry to hear that. Did you try the Kongregate version, too?
@matthias_zarzecki Hey, we should bundle our games and make a "Humble Oh Noes Bundle"!
Well polished and fun game. I thought the grid movement and overall controls were kinda harsh but fit with the game. Good job
Good concept, pretty fun, but frustrating due to the controls. It's very hard to move around and place blocks like I want to.

description:
Bubba's Escape is a block sliding puzzle game where you have to guide Bubba out of his workplace storage facility before his angry boss comes to yell at you!
This was my 1st LD48 ever so I started with very simple game design =) but I reached my goal and actually finished something, which is nice.
Controls:
Left mouse button - Select objects in the game area
Right mouse button - Undo
ps. Code is total mess (full of quick and dirty fixes)
author: puffi
title: Bubba's Escape
comments: It's kinda hard to tell what order to play the levels in, is it left to right or top to bottom? Besides that it's a good game. Gave up at the level in the screenshot.

It's kinda hard to tell what order to play the levels in, is it left to right or top to bottom? Besides that it's a good game. Gave up at the level in the screenshot. I especially like the Linux support.
Well there isn't a strict order to play the levels, but the top-left level is by far the easiest one and kind of works as "introduction".
Congratulations on a great game! It took me a little while to realize I could move the red objects (presumably dynamite) to blow up blocks, but once I did realize this, I couldn't stop playing!
Yeah I should've added some sort of instructions to the game, but hopefully people can figure it out without too much of an effort, as there's relatively few objects in game.
Once I figured out how to play it was easy to blow through these levels. Very creative and would enjoy seeing more of this in the future.
Great concept! Simple to play, addictive, fun. Probably the LD21 game I've enjoyed the most so far. Congrats! :D
Thank you very much for your nice comments!
I have some plans on improving the game (actually quite major changes), tho I will rewrite the code from scratch as the code is just way too messy to start playing with.

Good job! Sliding block puzzles are nothing new, but the dynamite added some new layers to the classic formula. I'm kind of big on puzzle design, and I would have liked to see puzzles with fewer blocks. 6 blocks is plenty to make a very challenging sliding block puzzle requiring 30-40 moves, and the number of blocks are small enough for the player to wrap their head around, so they come away with a better appreciation of the solution. With 15 or 20 blocks, there's no way, there are so many billions of possible permutations of those blocks. But like I said, good job!
Yeah one part that I was able to give too little attention due to the time limit was the level design (which ofc makes or breaks puzzle games) which was bit of a shame.
But for the post-compo version I will definitely give level design the time it deserves and requires =)
Love the concept. Although this is more of a "build your own level" theme. Nice graphics, dig the style.

description:
This morning I looked on the ludum dare website and I saw, that i had only a few hours left to make a game. I wanted to enter this competition, so I decided to work hard and here it is!
play with the arrow keys.
in menu: up to continue, down to go back.
>update!<
-2 new levels.
-Achieve stars for each level.
-Pushers added.
-Saving added.
author: jazeker
title: Beetle escape
comments: It would obviously use a few more levels, but it looks and plays nice. Good job making it into LD in just a few hours!
thanks! I am planning on making more levels, but i think ik will take a while, cause I have to go to school again...
Not exactly innovative gameplay, but I love the presentation.

Liked the graphics, but they soon (well, level 2) got too repetitive. Tutorial is very nice. Enter as Up in menu is confusing. Very short though, and not truly central to theme. But polished, if simple.
nice work in such a short amount of time!
Nice graphics! The press up on title screen to start is little intuitive, I was pressing everything but up never crossed my mind as arrows were used to move cursor.
Graphics are simple, but the game does feel complete and it's definitely nice, especially when you've done it in only a few hours. Not very innovative, but fun to play beyond any doubt.

description:
