I ran out of time on this one so there are a few things left un-done. The physics still has problems on some machines and I didn't get time to add sound effects. However the game is playable and I'm pleased to have got it done in the 48 hours!
You have to help your colonists escape the apocalypse by building them a safe bunker and then enduring five destructive attacks in the form of a flood, a plague, a hurricane, an earthquake and an a-bomb. There are three difficulty levels. I hope you enjoy it!
author: Lucas Tiridath
title: Apocalypse Escape
comments: Everything seems small and it's kinda hard to see, is there a way to rectify that?
Really nice idea, it would be helpful to know when blocks are stuck together and when they're just next to each other.
Wow, this concept was brilliant.. once I realised what was going on, shame you couldn't pixel double everything because it was tiny :)

The game definitely needs some kind of tutorial. The blocks never stuck together for me so first I tried making a building which only caved in. It should have crushed people but everyone survived despite being under five layers of brick and metal combined.
Also the game overloaded on the fourth round for having too many objects on screen. Maybe being able to place 800 blocks was not the best idea.
Download link is down here, shame because looks like I would really enjoy it :(
was tricky to predict what different disasters would do, but that was 80% of the fun!

hahaha I had a lot of fun playing around with this, partly because (owing to its being a 48 hour game) I had no idea what was going to happen when I hit Go. It's fun to crush those little guys and watch the physicsy goings on. Sadly I got a crash at the beginning of the earthquaqe stage - message said 'sprite not setup for physics'.

description: Move with arrow keys, attack with Ctrl. Unleash special attack with the ESC-key, but beware: they are limited and can only be refilled through white chrystals. Can you escape this wicked world?
author: Tommislav
title: Abandoned
comments: Really scary artwork, very original.  But I couldn't hit anything -- timing when to shoot out the small eye as it is rotating around and while you are moving is almost impossible... well, at least for me.
Very original, would like to see a version of this with easier firing controls :)
Totally awesome, completed the game without firing at all - but still totally engrossing.
this game is amazing. the graphics are completely brilliant, the concept simple but the whole experience was just great. brilliant job!
Nice feel and I like the different kinds of powerups.  Wasn't hard but felt like I could of gotten lost pretty easy.
great artwork, but about gameplay? get lost is too easy :(
I like the whole idea and the graphic are great! I just got lost and couldnt find my way back. Great job tho!
I like the art style, very cool. I ended up kind of just wandering, not really sure where I might need or want to go, though.
The design is awesome. You should add some music and sound

It was a really cool game. I like the artwork and the movement feels familiar. I got kind of a Ghost4Koin feeling over it and that is a nice game. You should have added a button at the end that just reloaded the browser silly, that would have solved your problem with the map reloading. What i really was missing tho was some penis lions. That sure would have been ceepy!
Nice and peculiar game! Loved the artwork, controls were a bit odd - but I managed to escape! Yay!

description:
I finished a bit late sorry. I added a game over slightly past the hour but then I tested my game and had a last minute show stopping bug that I was too stupid to solve quickly at 4am. I hope that's OK usually LD is rather relaxed but if people get upset about that you can move me to the jam category.
FOR TESTERS: One thing that can be misleading is that the arrow will point to the general prison area when you go pick up prisoners not individual prisoners, you have to look for them yourself. Sometimes they spawn in the shadows and are hard to see. Also no sound, sorry I barely managed to finish a game this time.
Next time I'll try not to OCD over texture details, UV mapping and small misalignments in the meshes. I spent most of the weekend doing tedious adjustments that have little or no impact on the big picture v___v.
Hope you like it!
Edit: Made one last mini bug fix 1h30 after the compo, the restart after the game over had some leftovers. I figured I might as well fix it since I was already late and for the convenience of the testers so that they don't have to restart the game.
author: Codexus
title: A Helicopter Named Freedom!
comments: So the important question is of course: Why doesn't it play Ride of the Valkyrie? :-)
Reminds me of Sim Copter which I loved to play. I had fun contemplating with a buddy why the inmates keep waving instead of running to the chopper when it's just a few meters away :P
I was disappointed that I could get on that big mountain.
I liked it! Beautiful world you constructed for this 48hr ditty. I liked the gameplay mechanic but did find it got dull a bit quickly. I'm more of an arcadey-fan than a Sim fan so maybe that's it. ;)
Great controls, good looking game. It just lacks meaningful gameplay. Just being a taxi is a bit dry. Would also love some sound.

description:
Programming - Josh Schonstal (me)
Graphics - Ian Brock
Music - Guerin McMurry (aka spamtron)
We've gotten a lot of positive feedback on Kongregate, so we'll be fixing some small issues.  If you still want to play the official jam version, play Web (Old).  To play the up-to-date version, play Web (Latest).
And if you liked the soundtrack, you can download it here: https://8bc.org/music/spamtron/Escape+OST++Gameplay/
author: schonstal
title: / ESCAPE \
comments: Absolutely amazing game! It actually took me a few tries to figure out I could hold escape to alter the height of my jump. :p
woah, this is so awesome!!!! these graphics, the playability! go for gold!
Holy crap. Graphics, controls, and music are all top notch. Very cool, man.
awesome artwork and music! and it's fun too!! excellent work gentlemen.
Absolutely amazing! All the elements are very polished, simple but the music makes it very engaging.
Amazing graphics and sound. I like the single button too. Things seem to be a little bit unfair at a certain point though.
Very fun game, polished, good sound and is very fun.   Unfortunately my Esc key now sticks :(
Wow! This is amazing! Great graphics, great gameplay, good sound, and lots of polish. Well done guys!
Fantastic, the music really sold me too.
Wow, the music reminds me a lot of old Konami NES games. Was that a conscious influence?

My only nitpick would be that some of the collisions are off. Like jumping near the bottom part of a spike causes death even when the player doesn't hit it. It is pretty amazing otherwise and fun for a short platformer style game. The wall jumping sets this apart from other entries.
The physics reminded me of N: The Way of the Ninja. This is a very, very good thing.

wally2069, it's actually weighted so that you can go 2px into the bottom, and 1px into the top of the spikes.  It does feel a bit frustrating to die when you're only 3px into them still, though (since it's basically only your ear touching it), but I found that it seemed a little weird when you could go through it more than that, like collisions weren't working.
Is the web (old) link broken? It doesn't work for me :c

Wow!  This is amazingly polished!  The only thing is that it does seem to be a bit frustrating, but the addicting music and slick presentation kept me coming back for more.  It feels almost like a pachinko machine, I want to keep dumping more tries into it.
KevinWorkman, could you be more specific?  I can't find a problem.
It's awesome! I love this game.
I hope the little jumping guy has health insurance.
Very polished and fun to play, top scores on audio and graphics too. Well done gentlemen!
It's about the first purely "mash escape key" game which I enjoyed :) Excellent music (I'm just sucker for the old SID style music...)
Really nice entry, although a bit hard and unforgiving (monkey slides down quite fast so when there are spikes on both sides, sometimes it's hard to see when to jump). Music is super-awesome.

Very nicely done, like the idea. Controls/sliding is well done, but can be randomly punishing on an impossible spike/jump combo. I suppose it sort of fits the theme by combining escape key pun with escaping giant laser thing. Good music/sound. Love the death animation.
It was fun and very polished, tho it may be a little too hard at times.
It works now, must have been a hiccup on my end. Nice job!
Fun game! Loved the use of escape. You sure didn't want to escape the escape theme!
This game is perfect in every way :o Loooove the soundtrack!
A simple concept, but great presentation and so much fun. Games like these are Ludum Dare's speciality.
This is awesome. So polished and everything just WORKS.
I wish I could see a little farther ahead as I ended up with a few unfair deaths by jumping into the unknown. Reminds me of "ninjump" on iOS quite a bit, but thats not a bad thing.
If this ever ports to iOS... you have yourself at least one sale.

dogbomb, I take it you've only played the LD version.  If you try the version on Kongregate, I've fixed most of the issues people have complained about, including the player's maximum height on the screen (you can now see ahead a little more than a full jump).  After adjusting the height, I never feel like I'm unfairly killed by a random spike group (you can be reckless and have it happen still, so you should still try to be careful).
If you liked the LD version, check out the Kongregate version!  I think you'll have fun with it.
Whoa, one of the best entries I've seen so far. Simple mechanics, but oh so addicting. Well done.
I really suck at this game, which is a pity cause the impression is great.

description: Escape the bubbles!
author: quak77
title: "Escape from Bubble land"
comments: I took me a while to get hang of the controls, but once I got the controls, they we're rather cool. I thought the game was a bit hard at the beginning, but after that it got easy quickly. The music was good, a shame that it didn't loop correctly.
kind of interesting controls... but the music is not original: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NRCkAumK5b4
You're supposed to use only assets you've created yourself... so the music kills you :)
Aside from the aforementioned not original music,

description:
I wasn't able to finish my procedurally generated RPG in time, so I restarted and made this.
Better to submit something than nothing ;-)
Should work on windows 95 / NT4 and upward.
Control with cursor keys.
Source code is included in the zip.
author: digital_sorceress
title: Thruster
comments: Use cursor keys to control the craft:
Source is included in the zip.
Solid execution overall, but not much fun - sorry. Perhaps I'm just bad at such games. ;)
Thankyou for your comment. I understand what you mean about it not being much fun, but I do feel it is relatively easy to experience flow with the game.
ie, If the player is patient and relaxed, they can pilot the craft slowly and with care, and easily not crash it.
As they gain confidence, they can find pleasure in skillfully piloting their craft at higher speed, and that's when they can get into a 'flow' state. :)

description:
Playigitx is proud to present The Bachelor's Escape!
John McPlayer has risen to fame and fortune. Will he be able to escape from the clutches of all girls worldwide?
Arrows (or W/A/D) to move.
Space to use ugliness potions, for a brief relief.
While ugliness is in effect, you are kind of evil, so you may steal girls' money.
IT MAKES SENSE, TRUST ME.
Have fun!
Bugs:
- Sometimes (rarely) the game freezes. Sorry.
author: Yoni
title: The Bachelor's Escape
comments: Pretty hilarious concept, although if you have no ugliness potion you're guaranteed to get tackled by the swarms of ladies -- there's no good way to avoid them.

Amazing instruction page. Really funny mechanics - kind of like a demented platformer version of pacman. The controls could have been a little more solid, and the death screen could go by faster, but I'm loving the concept.
Funny idea, really annoying audio :) (and slow game over screen)
Not the biggest fan of being tricked into an inescapable pit.
I thought the audio was less annoying than advertised. The rarer sound effects (win, lose, etc.) were great.
I really love the single-mindedness of the gamestate (johnfn's likening of it to pac-man was spot on). But because it's on a platforming course, there were some interesting patterns and strategies.
Really well done, especially for a first-platformer-ever. good work man!! Looking forward to future yonigames.

description: "Stranded" is an episodic game about a crazy scientist, his trusting (but gullible) assistant, and the small brown barn spider that binds them together.
author: Tulrath
title: Stranded: Episode 1
comments: Seems my web server is getting pretty hard after I submitted this.  Please be patient, your request will go through.

Not bad, audio was a little loud but somehow that seemed kinda fitting. The gameplay doesn't represent the theme, but the story you've worked in there fits it nicely. Enjoyed the gameplay, simple but effective mechanic. Not bad :)

Not a bad idea for a game, although it felt only loosely connected to the theme via the scientists' story :) Would be nice to see some more variation in gameplay - I liked the introduction of moving targets!
Thanks for the feedback - it's greatly appreciated! :)
Decent idea for gameplay, but it doesn't ever really evolve. It would be nice to see more mechanics come in.
Before the moving butterfly, the games looks more like a puzzling. Which I prefer :) Different sets of blue ball and flies for difficulty increase would be perfect
@wbobeirne, you're absolutely right - ran out of time :)
@Benjamin, that's exactly what I was thinking -- but of course, ran out of time.  This was my train of thought at 1 hour from the end :)

1)  Change the ball colors and the fly colors so that you would have to jump from ball Blue to ball Yellow to catch Fly Green -- but in that case you could change the positions of the balls, either rotate the circle or swap two of them.
2) Create bonuses that you could catch that would change color of the ball you are either jumping from or jumping to in combination with 1 above.
3) Create obstacles that you don't want to have your web touch -- like fire.  If your web touches fire, the fire goes back and disintegrates the ball you just came from.

description:
A ZX Spectrum RPG.
Worked for 72 hours, amongst family things, really more like two day's proper work.
This is an biographical tale of my papa's arrival in England in the 60's, based on an unpublished novel he wrote.  As he's not around to fill in the details, I had to make some of them up.
It's ... it's ... I don't really know what it is.
author: superflat
title: STOPCOCK
comments: Exactly the sort of utterly charming stuff I've come to expect from you Jasper.  Lovely :D
I *think* I'm getting an error during the install. Couldn't get it running anyway :(
I launched setup.exe but i can't read anything (only sequences of ?????).
However, I was able to play, unpacking the .lzh file with 7zip.
Nice work (the "writer's block" as a weapone made me laugh): however, I find the game slightly off-theme...
Oh man, an installer? I loved the graphical style and the music, though it was pretty hard to read the text on a 30" monitor! Nice stuff...
Yeah unfortunately I don't know of any other way to distribute RPG Maker 2K3 files...
The installed copies stuff to C:/Program Files/rpg2003/Stopcock, where the EXE is placed.  Sorry for the terrible unfriendliness!

I was unable to play this. The installer was full of ????? and even after unpacking the .lzh, the game didn't work. It did change my screen resolution to something really small though. I only saw a quick splash screen and then just blackness.

description:
Slip Away is a ghost story platform game created in Flixel and FlashDevelop.
Instructions:
Arrow Keys: Walk or Fly (While Phasing)
Z: Jump
X: Phase
Up: Climb up (While Hanging)
Down: Crawl
Down: Drop Down (While Hanging)
author: Cambrian_Man
title: Slip Away
comments: Can you... be more specific? Did you need/want more of them?
I agree. Should have made the items as checkpoints. It's frustrating to retry again after you have reached an item.
There were some extremely tight spaces which made me wonder if I cheated through a wall that I shouldn't have. And I gave up on the items. They should have stayed collected if you got them once.
It wasn't actually humorous or funny but the mood was so well set that it needed to be reflected in the score. Everything worked together so well and in so very few words that this was amazing.
I liked the phasing mechanic, but the movement controls were too slippery and slow to really make this reccomendable.

I had a hard time phasing back into areas the same height as the character, I think the phasing back in should have been more generous in that respect, but I also really enjoyed it- very nice mood and music
The phasing mechanic is pretty nifty (although phasing into tight spaces can be pretty annoying). The theme of this game is incredibly well-done.
Liked the phasing mechanics. I died a lot from jumps I thought I should be able to make only to hit the spikes or him not grab onto the edge.
Atmosphere was nice and creepy. Biggest frustration was that the checkpoints were too far apart compared to the difficulty.
I love the idea, and especially the skeleton-ish arms which are remisiscent of Shadow of the Beast.

Pretty frustrating. Could do with a few more checkpoints. Very nice visuals and ambience, and the music really adds. Some of the parts to progress felt as though they needed frame by frame perfection. The phasing mechanism was really interesting and is pretty promising. Solid entry that could do with some tweaking, same as any LD game.

A good effort. One thing that frustrated me was the inability to control the character mid-air once you jumped - it meant that unless you lined up the jump before you started, you'd miss (it was also a bit odd when you could control where you went after dropping, but not falling...).
As others have said, the checkpointing could use work as well.
Liked the C64ish art and ambience. Best luck
Not enough checkpoint for a LD game. All the tester must have a chance to see most of your work. But I think the number is correct for a challenging game. Pratice make perfect :)
Phasing was fun, but I also think you should be more lax with the recal box.
I like the shadowofthebeast-ish arm too !
Loved the atmosphere in this game. Awesome job!
The controls were a little too buggy to be fun on my machine.  I love the artwork, it kind of reminds me of Splatterhouse.
Very nice, all around. It needs some balancing, of course, but the atmosphere is tense, disturbing, and interesting enough to keep me moving forward.

description:
Hi everyone, here is Not Without my Zombie, a little action plateformer made with AS3, Flashpunk, Photoshop and gsxr.
Hope you'll enjoy it !
Controls :
Arrows : Move and jump
Mouse : Aim and shoot
author: BlackDogg
title: Not Without my Zombie
comments: Obviously the best part was the graphics and it shows. It was your basic run jump and shoot. The physics worked out well for a platformer. The to be continued at the end makes it feel incomplete.
I found it more fun before I worked out how to shoot, getting over the zombies with wall jumps.
Innovation: Nothing new here, but the genre hasn't been overdone to death (like match-3 has).
Theme: What am I escaping from? Nothing here is really explained, and I'm spending most of my time in the game going downwards. I don't see the correlation at all.
Graphics: Everything looked like what it was supposed to be, and the lighting effect gave a nice eerie glow.
Audio: Very rudimentary audio. The walking sound was far too loud.

Fun: One thing that bugged me a lot was the walljumping. I spent most of my time fondling my keyboard into submission in hopes that what I wanted to do might actually happen, mostly to no avail. The rest of the controls worked fine, although I would recommend enabling WASD controls. Also, you are required to use the controls to find out what the controls are, which is a little backwards.
Overall: Kinda fun, kinda meh. Needs work, yet definitely not a negative experience.
I re-spaced this for easier reading, I apologize in advance if this makes another comment with nothing new to say.
Innovation: Nothing new here, but the genre hasn't been overdone to death (like match-3 has).

description:
A rat that is trapped. You choose its fate!
This is a game that runs PURELY with javascript and HTML5 features. No need for flash! This game was developed on Arch Linux, without the need of proprietary software (apart from my nvidia video driver...)
author: N0_Named_Guy
title: Mouse Trap
comments: I like the soundtrack, really adds to the feel of being trapped in this maze. Also the maze in this game is a metaphor for life, isn't it? :)

The truth is, I write this "storyline" in the lines of what I felt while writing it. For you is a metaphor for life. For me is what I felt when writing the game. For others it's whatever they feel =) Also, thank you for you kind comment.
Also, ignore any kind of type. Engrish (not English) is the language I am more proficient on =)
I thought the game was neat. The sorts of comments the mouse made could easily be interpreted as the mouse's internal emotions OR metaphors for life. A bit brief, though.
Awesome concept, and great implementation. I love the way you can experience the mouse's smell and thoughts as he walks through the maze, it's actually quite sad. Great job :)
Really nice concept and execution, though I wish it was a bit longer and had some more obstacles other than just mousetraps.
Love the atmosphere. The traps were still dangerous after being sprung which was kind of weird and the levels were short.
Great atmosphere, good controls and musi and well done with Javascript :D
a bit short, but i really liked the narration. would love to see some variety to the events the mouse can experience :)
Very nice music. I didn't really feel like I was escaping, it felt more like I was chasing the mouses nose. Kudos for using canvas though!
Removed music... Forgot that music not made during the LD48 would violate the rules... =X Soz...
I really liked the atmosphere in this game =)
Solid entry. The written comments and the smell sound are the highlight of the game for me =)
The respawn was a bit confusing when it happened but great job anyway.
Kudos for using Arch Linux, my favorite distro.
A mouse trying to escape - a classic! :-)

Technical a little bit wonky (sometimes I see black lines of pixels between the tiles) and graphics could be more interesting (e.g., tiles with textures, especially most on the screen is darkness). Hopefully next Ludum Dare you will have more time to add some more gameplay elements, "Mouse Trap" would have deserved it!

The lines are a Firefox only issue, because of the way Firefox interpolates stuff or whatever... On Chrome and Opera it runs fine (not an excuse, will see how to fix that). But yeah, I had the engine "pre-done" and I still messed with it to make the fog... Making it all dark (and showing only the mouse) would help the player empathize with the lonely mouse... To you and all raters, thank you =)

A pretty simple idea, but quite well done, especially for your first time! The graphics and text worked quite well. I like that you could use either the mouse or the keyboard, that was a nice touch. I just would have liked a little more depth to the gameplay. I also like that you used HTML5+JS. I'd really like to see that emerge as a serious competitor to Flash.
I feel like the "freedoom" you get at the end could have a double meaning, although I realize it was probably just a typo. :)
Let's just say it is not a typo, and that is has double meaning :P
Simple and cute, and it's aaAAAaaall about the cheese.

description:
LD21 - Escape : Mountain above the clouds
*** Story ***
The legends say that each year, and for 3 minutes only, the great mountain above the clouds opens it's mouth to breath new life onto the world.
Today is that day.
You play the role of a magical seed that is buried inside the giant mountain. Your task is to escape from the mountain's belly and into the sky, before it closes its mouth again.
*** Controls ***
This game uses the mouse only. Click on the screen to cause the seed to fly.
When the mouse button is pressed, the seed will fly towards the cursor.
*** Other ***
- Flying near to the walls and ground will often cause new plants to grow,which in turn release more spores.
- For additional challenge, collect as many of the spores as you can before leaving the mountain.
-Then try collecting them all in as short a time as possible.
-this submission has no sound. Sorry :(
I hope you enjoy playing.
Any comments and criticisms welcome!
[source link fixed]
author: trialbyfun
title: Mountain above the clouds
comments: Beautiful game. The controls feel very elasticy - but to be honest that kind of adds to the experience, keeping you on edge  at all times.
Really beautiful graphics!  Smooth controls and animation too. Great entry!
The controls are a little sluggish but I got used to them quickly and then it felt natural and fun.

It was annoying to have to start all over when you were caught though, the game punishes you for being curious and exploring. Some indication of what is dangerous would help, or starting from the beginning of the screen instead of from the beginning.

Thanks for the feedback guys. I wanted it to feel quite soft in how you moved the character across the screen, but i agree that things could be tightened up a bit (especially what happens when he gets too close to the cursor). I also had a more gestural control scheme in mind but i didn't have time to try it out. Maybe next time!

Totally agree on the restarting in the same room. Restarting at the beginning was a product of time more than anything. I was tempted at one point to remove all dying from the game, but kept it in to maintain the sense of challenge. sorry about that.
Great! Finish it and release it for mobile touch-devices. I WILL buy it.

Fun game. I really like the visual style too. Were their various air currents? It felt like there were and that was kind of tricky but cool.  I tried collecting a lot of the orange things the first few times but died and became frustrated. I ended up just speed-flying out and escaping but it still rated me an 'F' haha.
really really charming experience. I struggled with the controls a little, but overall I loved it particularly the character design

Glorious and original art style! I kept dying for no obvious reason - presumably I crashed, but other times I got away with  worse bumps. Delightfully surprising new mechanics every few rooms. Love it!
Nice graphics and atmosphere, neat game!

Thanks for the latest feedback guys! Yep there are air currents in some rooms, indicated by the flowing particles. At the moment your rank is determined by the amount you collect before leaving, not the time you take. That would probably make sense with a context to it. As for what kills you, its if you bump the very top of your head on the spinning leafs, bumping any other part of your body is fine. A health bar or (reducing leafs with each hit) might have been a better idea than one hit kill.
super beautiful. I bet you could make this into a winning iphone game without too much work. It might be cool to make it a endless arcade style thing, rather than a bunch of level.
Very pretty! Would love to see some more squishy walls (loco roco style). Slightly static as it is now. As previous user said, go iPhone!
I keep waiting to hear "la la la la" in children voices, very very nice looks! :)
I especially like the coloful lo-fi approach and the intuitive one-click control.

It seems and looks nice, but what confused me was that I failed almost randomly, some kind of feedback if you're doing the right thing would be nice. I got to escape in the end after getting stuck in one one place for several tries (one of that "random" death in the room with two air currents) - it's too short, but if you made longer levels, add some sound, it would charming little game.
cute, very enjoyable game. feels very polished, and although it took some getting used to the controls, it all came together. great work!
Haha great! It totally has that nintendo feel without coming off as trying too hard/immature. It instantly reminded me of loco roco - very colourful, friendly and just fun to explore and play.

My only real critique was that the game rules were never explained - I still don't know what made me fall to the ground and die every once in a while. Beyond that excellent art, the transitions could've been tightened a bit (the main character doesn't animate during scene changes and sometimes you can see seems in the levels but that's just me being nitpicky because there's nothing else really for me to critique). This game desperately needs some music, it would round it off really well, good job!
Haha great! It totally has that nintendo feel without coming off as trying too hard/immature. It instantly reminded me of loco roco - very colourful, friendly and just fun to explore and play.

description:
A little platformer, in which you play two 'characters' at the same time with the keyboard and the mouse. Only by combining their abilities you will be able to escape the horrible prison.
Controls:
'A' and 'D' to control the body
'W' to jump
Use the mouse to move the head
Left-Click to stretch horizontally
Right-Click to stretch vertically
Both to turn into a disk saw
Made with Game Maker.
Hope you enjoy it! Comments would be appreciated! :)
Kinta
author: The Game
title: GTFO
comments: Nice take on the platform genre. Fun to play and innovative! Maybe could use a little bit of polish to make the gameplay slightly faster. As it is now I alternated a lot between using the head and the body.
I did have some problems however with the tutorial-text, which was quite hard to read, and the fact that you needed to illuminate it. Also, the enemies were quite hard and unforgiving.
Yeah, the gameplay definitely needs some polishing, but unfortunately I didn't have the time for it.
The tutorial text was only a workaround, because I didn't have the time to implement a message system.

That's part of the concept, that you use the head for certain parts and the body for other parts, but also use both to reach the exit. The levels have been made rather quickly, so perhaps they're not good enough to really motivate the player to use different combinations.
But thanks a lot for the comments! :)
Awesome, it's really well done. But after 4 or 5 levels, I got errors and had to close the game.

description: This is my entry for Ludum Dare 21. This was my first time. But i'm sure i'm going to enter again.
author: Bartje321
title: Freeway escape
comments: The controls were really smooth and it felt good dodging through traffic. Often I found myself stuck in a spot in traffic I couldn't quite pass, I think to keep the player feeling awesome about evading the police there should always be an opening to move through. If the game was purely about traffic avoidance, without cops, I would probably keep the traffic how it is now.
Cool blur effect on the lights. Felt that the highway was a little too packed and the car moved too quickly side to side, but those just come down to taste.
Not a very creative game... sticks to a formula with nothing new. I made a game very similar to this myself once. I don't really like the damage meter/system.

Otherwise it's quite fun to play! I loved the acceleration/brake controls... felt very smooth and realistic. I thought side to side was a little to drifty but I got used to it quickly. I do actually like how the traffic blocks you out and you have to pay attention to the relative speed different lanes. The lights are nice but they seem to trail with the screen.

super cool! I liked the graphics and the damage effects. I wonder if by making the traffic more sparse, and adding more cops and good samaritans that came out of nowhere and tried to run you off the road if that would make it more exciting. Also ocasional intersections, or the opportunity to jump the median and run against trafic.
haha, tons of dumb ideas from me... too many police chases on tv.

Good first entry! I've played games with a similar feel, but the controls were smooth, the game ran well and things looked good. There did seem to be a tendency to hit walls of cars, which wasn't great. Also, you could imagine having turns which might make the game a lot more challenging. But given the short amount of time I think you ended up with a very playable game!

Very nicely done. Controls are pretty good, graphics are very nice, smoke effect/sparkles are epic. Collisions could be better, such as, brushing against someone doesn't cause damage as much damage as crushing into them. I would have liked it to be faster with less cars though, sometimes you get all nearby lanes blocked and no way around.
Awesome control system, and a fun game. The low res was a bit of a problem for me, as i only realised that there was a damage bar on the 2nd game (it was below the line). A really good first effort.
Very cool game. I especially liked the smoke when the car got too damaged. Somehow I got the highest scores when I moved as fast as the other cars and avoided collisions this way :)

Really nice start. To take it to the next level, you could have the other cars respond more to being hit- let me knock them out of the way, or into each other, or into the cops! Or make the cops more aggressive so I have more of a reason to escape them - and give me an oncoming traffic lane that I can swerve into to cause the cops to crash!
I think it's a sign of a good game when you make the players start imagining what they would add. You've done that. Good job, especially for your first time around.
Excellent visuals and gameplay, my only complaint is that there should have always been a way I could go. Sometimes all lanes were filled and I couldn't keep going.

this looked and felt really smooth, the graphics were really nice, but i found myself stuck in traffic far too often. though i can't help but feel games of this genre have kind of been done to death...
A fairly fun game, though a few little problems were very annoying (solid wall of traffic in front for example). A lovely concept well executed given the time!

description:
Forklift escape!
Escape from your evil employer to freedom!
Developed by: Allan Hollenberg
Designed by: Dennis Brinkhuis
FFFFFFFUUUUUUUUUUUU MAJOR bug which elimiates all game-play :( plus all the levels got removed D: D: D: D:
WHY GOD WHY!!!!!!!
I reverted to an older but playable build for the entry. sorry :(
author: nitrocrime
title: Forklift Escape
comments: Sadly, no way to test, will try if go to a friends house (he has a mac, i dont :-p)
Well, no points for innovation on this one :) But Sokoban puzzles are still cool.
Unfortunately I have to say the same thing.
Can't test this as it's only on OSX. Any plans of a port?
Alright - I found a mac. Very solid game. If only it was longer!
Did you really make the music by yourself? Well, as it is a jam entry it is okay I guess.

description:
Your job as Data Entry Sentry is to escape any gremlins hiding amongst the chunks of incoming data. Just tap (or click if you don't have an iPad) any chunk of data to escape/unescape it.
Progress to the next level by filling the buffers (the blue columns at the bottom) without allowing any one column to overflow. The Overflow warning will change color as you get closer and closer to a buffer overflow. Tap the warning to clear out some room at the bottom of the buffer.
Meet the Chunks:
- Norm, the sleepy gray guy. He's good people. I mean, data. If you escape Norm he'll burst before he even hits the buffer.
- Chubbly, the rotund greeny. He's cheerful enough but if you don't escape him he'll take up three times as much space as Norm in the buffer.
- Chomply, the toothy ill-tempered Chunk. Left unescaped he'll chew up all the data between him and the next Chomply Chunk. Best escape him posthaste.
I'm really pleased with how this turned out. The first couple of hours this weekend were spent writing the clunky little JavaScript/canvas framework (view source on the game to see). Then I just started programming. With ugly colored rects. Just trying to get a grasp on the game logic and data structures. This morning I got up and designed the sprites and board. Then around noon I essentially rewrote the entire game to use the new assets. I'd love to do some 8-bit sound effects and chiptunes but I'm out of time (and HTML5 audio isn't there yet).
author: Shaun Inman
title: Escape! Data Entry Sentry
comments: Although an interesting way to view "escape", it felt only loosely related to the theme. Or perhaps that's because puzzle/matching games aren't my forte. However, it was a fun diversion and I've never seen that mechanic before. It felt complete, and worked smoothly.
Only loosely related? The theme wasn't "run away from something!" or "get out of that place!" it was "escape!" :)
I like the use of the theme and the graphics. It's a pretty cool mechanic, although more types of blocks would be necessary to make it truly interesting.
More block types? I had enough trouble doing well when there were only 3 block types.  Loosely related to the theme,  but probably one of the best games in the compo.

Thinking about adding one more, very rare block type: Phillup, a fluffy white cloud Chunk that if left unescaped fills each buffer column to the height of the current tallest one. Could be dangerous if you're close to a buffer overflow but helpful if an unescaped Chomply has prevented a single column from progressing with the rest.
I love to see weird nerdpuzzles show up in LD!  Also the art here is super charming.  Would buy the iOS version.
Somehow the game doesn't work on my PC. The controls are broken, when I click with the mouse, a totally different block gets highlighted. Or did I misunderstand the game logic?

That's a drag. Which browser? I was pretty lax with browser testing (developed in Safari on an iPad). Last Dare I used Flixel and didn't have to worry about it. We can still make bug fix changes to our code right?
I can't beat level one. What is wrong with me oh god this is hard

Ah, didn't realize Firefox didn't support the CSS `zoom` property. I've patched it to use `-moz-transform: scale() translate();` too. Works now in FF6 Mac. Still, good luck keeping up without a touch screen :)

description:
standard wasd, left mouse shooter
unfinished, buggy, unoptimized, but whatever, i'm going to bed
author: brachyonic
title: Escape The Overgrowth
comments: I want to give feedback, but I'm not sure what I could tell you that you didn't know. The growth thingy looked cool , when I got to see it. Pretty much every complaint could be simplified to "finish the game!"
I packaged it up to be easier to download and run: https://s3.amazonaws.com/excitemike/ld/brachyonic-Escape-The-Overgrowth.zip
If you are on Windows, you should be able to just extract the zip and double click the exe without installing anything.
Finish it! the growing thing seemed interesting
Simple. It;s not quite finished, so no real feedback. I like the idea where killing main bad guy means killing its legs (threads).
This shows some promise, too bad you hadn't time to finish it at least a bit more.
Well, too bad you didn't deliver an executable or anything finished. ;-) I like the idea, though.

description:
Game home page: http://code.kevinworkman.com/EscapeFromMonsterCity/index.html
Jar: http://code.kevinworkman.com/EscapeFromMonsterCity/EscapeFromMonsterCity.jar
Java Web Start: http://code.kevinworkman.com/EscapeFromMonsterCity/EscapeFromMonsterCityWebStart.jnlp
Armed only with your flashlight, escape from a city infested with sleeping monsters! Don't get too close to the monsters, or they will wake up and eat you. Do you slowly sneak past the beasts, carefully looking around every corner, or do you run through the narrow alleys and risk the chance of running into a nest of monsters?
author: KevinWorkman
title: Escape from Monster City
comments: Spotlight/buildings are nice. Would be nice if there was a goal or something to aim for (# of monsters woken up maybe?)
This game was AWESOME!!!! I absolutely loved it!!! I played it for forty five minutes and still haven't beaten it... XD
Then I showed it to my 60+ year old great aunt, and she played for half an hour, then my brother, etc... this is my favorite so far! Great little game! With some sound and music, would be perfect. :)
In all honesty, this game is ridiculously fun! I can't stop playing it! What are your post-mortem plans for it?
Bloodyaugust : Wait ... What ? Are you serious ?
I played the game for 1 minute, and it sucks.
Have you gotten into it? Beaten it? It rox! XD

Draknek: Thanks, and you're absolutely right. I started implementing a few different "win scenarios", such as giving the city a boundary, or recording the time or distance walked, but nothing felt quite right. And given the time constraints, I didn't want to implement something half-assed, so I left it open.
LumdumDareisCool: Sorry you feel that way! Did you play long enough to run into any monsters? What specifically do you think should be improved? And just out of curiosity, how do I play your entry?
Bloodyaugust: Thanks so much! You pretty much just made my day.

As for plans for the game after the competition, I suppose that depends on what kinds of ratings it gets. If people seem to like it, I'll spend some time fixing it up, adding an ending, etc. I'll keep you posted.

Theme-wise this is really good in my opinion. I like the look and feel, the running works quite well. Other than that, game doesn't state the goal, doesn't give any direction (I suppose it's not possible to escape at all?). Buildings seem to be randomly generated - few times I got stuck just at the beginning.
This could use a little polish, but isn't that bad.
@LumdumDareisCool: It certainly doesn't "suck", in my opinion. There are lots of bad/mediocre games in the compo and this isn't one of them. It just feels a little unfinished.

Thanks marudziik! The title screen does say that you're trying to escape the city, and I tried to keep the text to a minimum, but even so, people tend to click through text descriptions. So maybe I should have added a short one-liner at the start of the game, or as the game progresses?
And yeah, the game goes on forever, and the building/monster respawn algorithms leave much to be desired. I plan on fixing both when the contest is over.
But hey, really good but unfinished is pretty much the best I can hope for in 12 hours! Thanks again for playing!
Great work with the game, played on linux and didn't hear any sounds. The game is funny, however, is there any way to escape from the from the monsters city?

Awesome that it works on Linux- which version did you use? And there are no sounds, so I'd be worried if you did hear anything! And, sadly, there is no way to actually get out of the city- that will come in the post-competition version. Thanks so much for playing!
Its kind of entertaining, however without a real goal (I guess there is not exit, as I went far without any in sight) it seems unfinished.
Also, some of the monsters are placed withing the buildings, and even if they were awakened, they couldn't move at all because of the collision system.
Yeah, the game doesn't really have an end- for now, it's mostly a "see how long you can survive while escaping the monsters" game.
And I know about the monsters spawning inside buildings, another thing I couldn't quite get to in time.
Both of those things will be fixed after the competition! Thanks for playing!
Not bad, I run far enough and the game just frost!! :) you got some bug. Still.. a goal won't be bad, and maybe a bigger area of sight.
Yeah, there's definitely a bug that will freeze the game (it's not exactly common, but it's common enough to be noticed by a few people). I realized the bug about an hour after submitting, doh!

I'd definitely like to see an end game for this and some bassy slow music would add about 10x more atmosphere... maybe with some horrific violins when the eyes go red (thinking witch from Left4Dead here)...
Fun game though and I had fun running through the streets with monsters tailing me.

Thanks! I think you're absolutely right- I'm not usually big on sound (I usually play games muted, listening to other music), but I think some mood music would go with the mood lighting pretty well. I'm definitely making a post-competition version, and I'll shoot to add that to the list of enhancements. Thanks again for playing (and for the hilarious video)!
This is fun! especially the panic-moment right after you are spotted :-)

description:
A game by Abel Toy (Rolpege) [http://aberustudios.com] for Ludum Dare #21: Theme Escape.
In this game, you are a guy who's trapped in Ludum Dare and you must escape by beating microgames, each based on a different historic Ludum Dare theme.
Made using FlashPunk
Controls: Arrow keys, spacebar and mouse
author: Rolpege
title: Escape from Ludum Dare
comments: Really fun game! Loved the menus and just the large variety of things to do (even if they were easy) kept me playing.
I rage quit however when I couldn't complete #1, #18 and 8.
This was hilarious. Some challenges were far too difficult (Swarms, Advancing wall of Doom), but most bought back funny memories from the challenges. I escaped in 262 seconds.
oh my goodness, this is incredible. I couldn't beat the protect the princess.
I like this little game (and both hate it because some little minigame are evil!!) because it's a good game ;D
The "Swarms" game was evil, and now I need a new keyboard. Thanks Rolpege.
( this was a LOT of fun, congratulations ! )
Woo!  169.4 seconds.  Nice, I like it a lot :D

Those games were fun, with nice graphics :P . Sadly the game bugged a little for me (Flash on Linux...) and forced me to play a few levels I had already won, and validated one I hadn't. Anyway, some levels were a bit too hard, but still fun (wall of doom...). Nice entry!
That was fun. The level screen did a lot of difference from the WIP version I tried on irc. Can't believe you made 21 games in one weekend. :D
Great game Rolpege. :) I loved it. Swarms pissed the shit out of me but it was so worth fighting the boss! ;)
Also: 357.538 seconds. Half that time was on the swarm level, alone.
Liked it! Although at this hour (4:24 AM now), I can't defeat the boss, because my spacebar is too noisy, and I don't want to wake up anyone in my house =X
The Swarms game makes me want to give this entry negative ratings... everything else was good
182! Very fun, simple, good execution. A little annoying at times, but nothing gamebreaking.

description:
Your country is under enemy invasion, and the only option to launch the successful counter-offensive is to first save your President. You are the pilot of Freedom 01, the ultra-tech powered special aircraft of the President.
Can you escort him to safety across the fortuitous Faermort Sea?
Team:
Yadu Rajiv - Engine and Level Programming
Nandeep Mal - AI
Kinshuk Sunil - Sound & Music
Ravish Malik - Art
author: kinshuk
title: Escape at Faermort
comments: Where's the gameplay? I just point toward the compass marker and win? The plane's controls are pretty sweet, as it feels really heavy, and the shooting is pretty cool. But beyond that, there doesn't seem to be much.
I only encountered one plane on my entire trip, and it was right before the landing pad. I could have avoided it entirely if I wanted, but I shot it down to see how it felt.

I was bored just driving across open ocean and didn't have any reference for how fast I was going. Next time, I'd suggest adding some more detail in the water tilemap or adding more islands so I feel like I'm exploring or getting somewhere.

I'd have loved to see a 'range' on the compass as well, so I know how long I have to fly in that direction. I almost quit because all I saw was water and no enemies, but if I had context for how far to go it may have been better.

The graphics and audio were nice, but the whole game seemed slow.  I found it difficult to know how fast I was going and the effect Up/Down had on my speed -- I wasn't sure whether I was supposed to hold or tap the buttons, nor when I had reached the  maximum speed.

The gameplay also feels unbalanced when switching between mouse and keyboard.  With the keyboard controls, the plane takes too long to turn; the mouse is much more responsive, but I found it harder to stop.

description:
Escape from the Paparazzi! Don't let them take too many pictures or you'll be lost! Avoid the cars and cross your fingers, let's hope you make it 'til the taxi arrives!
Controls:
WASD or Directional Arrows.
Software & Libraries:
Flixel <- old version, 2.3 (not sure) I think that the current version is suffering from feature creep. (Tho the allure of Flixel Power tools is strong)
Flash Develop <- Love this IDE.
Pixel Bender <- I made the camera flash with this. Really fast and powerful tool for simple shader work.
Aria Maestosa <- really simple midi sequencer (and Flight of the Bumblebee was one of the first songs I learnt on piano, so i tought, why not?)
GXSCC <- Pretty lame I know, but i wanted the oldschool sound without having to learn how to use a mod tracker during a 48hr compo :-p
Audacity <- Easiest way to record, remix and export sound.
ASEPRITE <- The oldschool feel, yet powerful feature set makes me all fuzzy inside.
SFXR <- I think we are all familiar with this piece of sheer brilliance.
author: Felipe Budinich
title: Escaparazzi
comments: An interesting take on the snake-like genre. Love the music !
Really loved the game, especially the music. What SW did you use to make it?
Also, I took a while to realize the papz were following me in a snake-like pattern, so I shouldnt worry about them catching me.
My only complaint would be the money taking too much time to appear, maybe you should increase the requirement to 10 monies, while increasing the spawn rate of it.
I genuinely enjoyed that, nice idea and well executed :)
I love the way you've approached the snake game with this.  Makes it much more challenging than the original :).  Good job

Nice. It took me an embarrassingly long time to realize that this was basically Snake. I kept trying to get the paparazzi hit by cars until that point. I like the music! Flight of the Bumblebee makes everything better!
I really like the sprites and the music.
I only really have two criticisms: firstly, that the "Extra Extra!" screen never seems to stay up long enough to read it; and secondly that I can't lead the paparazzi into the path of a car. ;)
I planed on expanding the entry with more info, but since the LD webiste was having issues i thought that maybe it wasn't a good idea to overload the server with requests :-p

About the cars running over the paparazzi: I tought about that, but the function needed to remove one of them from the array, then moving the remaining ones one spot was too complicated for time i had remaining.
I'll add the softwares I used now ;-)
Anyway yeah. I'll polish this a little more, and paparazzi WILL be killed by cars hehe :-D
Very charming and clever snake "clone"! I agree that it takes forever for the $ to appear, however.

This was a really original way to approach the theme. The frantic music was great, and even though the graphics were simple I thought they were cute and fun in a retro way. I'd say the biggest problem is that the gameplay isn't deep enough. I just ran around randomly, it didn't seem to matter if I got hit by cars or not. Maybe if you could get killed by cars, but could also lure paparazzi into them to thin out their ranks? Kind of grim but it might be fun. Overall I thought the game could use a bit more depth, but it was funny and original! :)
the game was a nice clone and i really liked the idea very much.
Excellent spin-off of Snake. Excellent work!
Very good idea. Original and fun
HHaha, nice use of theme, liked music :D Good work :)
It might make the game better if the sides didn't loop around - it's really easy if you always go right, except to go up/down to get money.

Overall, I think it's a nice concept but I didn't like the implementation too much (except the audio - well done sir). I think it'd be a lot more fun if the paparazzi members were either slightly further back or the player was much easier to distinguish - my main problem was the wobbly motion and actually working out where I was.
Thanks for the feedback guys and gals, i'm taking note for the post compo version ;-) (I think the solution to the moneiz problem is to make paparazzi drop it when they are ran over by cars :-D)
Lots of fun, solid concept, good execution.

I do like the "jiggly" motion, but I also don't like it. I guess I wish there were better cues for collision, I couldn't tell if the positions were on a grid +/- a little bit or if they were just random offset.
I wish I could kill the paparazzi by running them into cars, of course that would change the game significantly.
Good job, quite challenging to get that last $ and cab!

Genius concept. I like your take on the good ol' snake and how it fits the whole escape theme. I second what jonnopon3000 said though; I didn't like the wobbly motion nor the fact that the character looked exactly the same as the enemies.
I loved the music by the way. Good Job dude.

Nice addition! Would have been nice to be able to use the cars to shake the papparazi a bit (it seems you should be able to use them to your advantage as well as to your detriment), but overall awesome work!
I was so disappointed that running the paparazzi in front of the cars didn't kill them.
Can I just ask, honestly, did you remake "dance of the bumblebee"? Not accusing you of anything, just curious.

Not bad, but the slow rate of the screen refresh made my eyes hurt. :D I found the player blended in a bit too much with the paparazzi and it might have been more helpful to have him flash colors, or have some kind of background or other stand out feature so it's easier to track.
A very interesting/creative take on the subject. The music was spot on. Not a lot of game gameplay wise, as it is basically snake with a humorous twist.

At first I was like WTF? Then I realized I'm not controlling the car but that one guy who doesn't have a camera pixel and realized I play snake... Not bad idea, but I was really annoyed I can't let the paparazzis die in pain under the cars :)
Download the source, go to the assets folder, search for the *.aria file. From there I exported to midi, and then I used GXSCC to make a WAV, then I used Audacity to make the MP3.
I even made some mistakes (it does not sound exactly like the original song), and as far as I know, Flight of the Bumbleebee does not loop :-p
I used a song I knew because:
a) Theres no time to compose something really good. I'm a better performer than composer.
b) I'm not yet familiar with the software, I learnt to play piano, on an actual piano.
I played this before voting stated. It's really fun but paparazzi and cars seem to teleport around rather than move.

description:
Mostly a tech prototype, but it turned out surprisingly nice!
Use arrow keys / WASD for moving around. R for restart level. Shoot through blocks to split them.
author: timgarbos
title: Cut Here
comments: I will upload downloadable Windows and Mac builds tomorrow. The Windows build might work in Wine.
Also it doesn't restart if you get stuck or jump a cliff. Press R to restart!
Very neat application of a concept, although I think you could have touched on the theme more. Fun, interesting, functional, and easily expandable. Loved the filter fx.
Cool idea, nice art style with the filter.  Could easily be expanded into a full idea with storyline etc..
Very cool stuff!  Great concept and interesting tech.
Stunning visuals!!! But did I get it wrong, or have you not created the music yourself?

Thanks, I am only using three images. The character, the gun, and the laser beam. Laser beam texture is reused for the goals because I was super lazy. Everything else is just solid colors and shaders.
I created sound effects with Bfxr and Audacity, but borrowed some background ambience sound.
Good idea but I think I have seen something like this before - not sure though. Nice visuals and good guiding.

Shouldn't the ice been cut where I cut them? Sometimes they just disappear and some little piece comes up instead. And They need to fly away if I go against them or not because sometimes they do. Also can I push them or not?
The physics were buggy sometimes (does Unity have built-in physics? I haven't used it) but this looks great and the game is fun -- it's fun enough just to cut everything up!

The 'escape' theme is sort of there... since you have to 'escape' each level... but it could be used more. And technically you shouldn't be using anyone else's audio in a compo entry, even if it is background noise.
And one miniscule bug: the jump sound plays when you hit W even if you are in the air!

description:
So this is my game, you play as Bob. Bob hates his job so he must escape before they make him stay and work overtime. Bob knows if he can get out in before 5 O'Clock he will be safe so you must navigate his maze like office place.
The controls are simple
WSAD/Arrows - To move
P - To pause
Esc - To return to main menu or quit if you are already there
I used SDL and OpenGL as extra libraries, I included the proper dll's in the file.
Edit: I added a separate file with the fixed levels, please judge based on the old version.
author: tordre
title: Cubicle Escape
comments: Can't get it running in Wine

Cool game. I got stuck in the small room (level 5 maybe) with the white wall tile, am i supposed to wait there? I didnt understand what role motivation played. Could have used some sweet sound =) Good job overall!
@JohanAR I don't know what version of openGL wine uses that might be an issue, you might be able to get a newer version of the dll.

@Mstrp2ez yeah I played through at work today and I realized something went horribly wrong with the the level file for the, I don't know am I able to post an updated file? or would that be against the rules?

I also noticed at work that I was relying on nvidea's locking of draw cycles because the game plays too fast on other computers, In other words I was lazy and didn't change the movement based on time and only clock cycles.

There was something about the graphics that I really like, for some reason. Believe it or not, I really love the level transition graphic. It's so simple and sleek without looking all Web-2.0-ish. Idunno why, but it just looks really cool to me. The whole motivation bit was funny. Good job, I'll definitely check back if/when the levels are fixed.

I really liked the way the 3D parts looked, I dunno, but they just looked really cool. The motivational poster thing was cool, but it didn't feel like it helped much. I would really like to play it the rest of the way if/when you get level 5 fixed.
Thanks for the nice comments about the graphics, it is inspired a bit by the new pokemon game, I liked the way they used a similar method to convert a 2d game into very solid 3d game.
Uploaded the new version with the map fix.
You included windows.h but didn't use any of its functionality...

Also, pro-tip: don't use '\' when you're coding. Windows accepts '/' just fine, but Linux/Unix are less friendly with '\' and it breaks. That's the main thing I had to change to get your code to work.
Thanks vede for the port and the advice, I wasn't planning on porting so in many cases it when I did type in file names they were just me copying and pasting from explorer (I was lazy).
I know I wasn't using windows.h but from the looks of my compile errors SDL for windows does use it, and VC++ was complaining about me not using it, so I just wanted to shut up the bitch.

description:
Finally finished!
In Cityscape, you're trying to survive the oncoming zombie hordes. In each level you have to survive for 60 seconds, before heading to the exit point (which appears on the mini-map as a yellow dot) - if you make it that long, you win the level. Each consecutive level is increasingly difficult.
You've got to also keep your food levels up, and refill your ammo occasionally. There are shops that spawn randomly (marked green on the mini-map), which sell these goods. If you run out of food, you'll gradually lose health until you die.
Aim with the mouse, shoot with the mouse button, and move around with WASD or the cursor keys.
author: mattdev
title: Cityscape
comments: Food and ammo always seem to be more expensive than the amount of money I have. Also, if I shoot too much my character seems to decide to tard around regardless of the direction I try to send him in.
However, you did a good job of making the situation feel tense by swarming the player with an assload of zombies, and the music is very nice.
Nice game, good theme and although at times it can be a little overwhelming fighting so many things/getting stuck it still leaves you trying to win and thats fun.
Didn't even really need the gun, there was no way I could kill all the zombies and so the only thing to do was keep moving. Overall alright.
This was sweet! Music was fitting and most of the mechanics were self explanatory. I think it'd have been nicer with a warm up period and barricades but I enjoyed it a lot, solid effort.
Classing gameplay and it's fun :) Well done, one of the best I've rated :)
good submission, I enjoyed playing it. Zombies! Would have been nice to have had some sounds on the gun fire, zombie death, shop buying ect but I really liked the music.
It's easy to get stuck against walls, which makes it more frantic but it could've been a bit more forgiving. Cool game overall.
Not bad, can be a bit overwhelming too soon, maybe impossible XD but I dig the idea, time didn't allow for good balance but I hope you can work on that later.

Fun, but zombies die too slow. If you are cornered, you're toast. Although that may be the point. Could use a little variety. Overall, nice art and music. Could use sound effects. Could you more interesting layout, but of course I realize this is a 48h entry.

description:
Challenge your sense of orientation in 'Bloppo: the great escape'!
I've made this game with Game Maker 8.0.
Graphics have been done with Game Maker's sprite editor and the GIMP 2.6.
Music have been composed with Anvil Studio and transformed to MP3 with Hamienet's online tool, and the guitar tracks have been recorded with my BC Rich Virgo guitar, my Peavey Vypyr 30 amp, and Guitar Rig 4.
author: Selkie
title: Bloppo: the great escape
comments: This game was fun and cool. It has the right ammount of levels, graphics look polished enough, music is just awesome and it fits the theme (you must escape).

err man (sorry for double posting) can i use the character sprites on my game and maybe the music (not for lundum dare game, just when i make one for fun) i'll give you credits and if you have a site i'll make a button for it :D
Wow, great looking game. Reminded me very much of Gish, though I can't put my finger on why. Was amazed when you switched it up in to a platformer.
My chief complaint would be the sheer amount of backtracking I had to do. It became really tedious.
I can't test this game.  Game Maker doesn't work inside a virtual machine and I don't have a real Windows box :'(
I found the game a tad boring, but the graphics are neat and the music is very nice if a bit unfitting. Solid entry.

description:
You are a robot attempting to escape from a robot prison.  Enlist the help of deactivated robots for assistance.
Arrows or WASD to move
Enter or Space to upload your A.I. to deactivated robots
Escape to pause or get help
This was kind of an experimentation for me in using Silverlight as a game engine.  Let me know how I did.
author: TravisTX
title: A Robot Escape
comments: Nice! Takes a mean jump in difficulty suddenly, but I like it a lot. The CAPTCHA joke is great, too.
Challenging, but it is very hard to give in to defeat! Very nice entry though. And I agree with lilserf, 'you are a winner' text is hilarious.

I liked it! It could really have done with a restart button, and I think the levels could all have been about 4 times smaller, but I too thought the CAPTCHA joke was great and the gameplay was enjoyable.
Thanks guys.  FYI there is a restart button in the pause menu.  Hit ESC.
I love the captcha joke! The game is smart and well realized! I really like it!
A fun idea that looks and feels very solid.
It would be helpful if you could see the layout of deactivated robots' rooms before activating them so there isn't a need to remember exact positions from previous attempts.
A quite good puzzler. Easy introdutction, then the difficulty ramps up, and introduces new variations. good work.
The jokes are quite good as well :-)
Interesting concept. Captcha was a nice touch. :)
Really neat concept! The captcha was pretty hilarious!
I'm not fond of the "multitargets control" game, but the fun ending sentences pushed me to level 8 :)

description:
Had problems with looping music so it only has special effects.
You require a HTM5-compatible browser to play. Internet Explorer won't play the sounds though. Opera, Chrome, Firefox and Safari shouldn't have problems although I only tested on Firefox 5.
EDIT: A friend of mine tested it on Chrome 13.0.782.112 m and worked fine. Sound included.
P.S: Correctly avoid/enter 50 doors to win.
P.P.S: High-score is not saved so if you manage to complete the game in a jaw-dropping time, you better take a screenshot.
author: Shadow
title: [ESC]'s Escape
comments: Not sure if others have this problem, but I'm getting at least a one second delay after every correct door (but no delay after escaping from function key doors).
The challenge ramps up really fast, could never get past about 20 doors.  Simple and easy to play, though.

Anyway, yes, the game becomes hellish after around 30-40 doors. It's still possible to end the game by simplifying your strategy once it gets real fast to only pressing ESC whenever you see a Function Key. You can still make mistakes there since there's no penalty if you accidentally escape a door where a friendly key resides (no penalty beyond taking more time to find the exit, that is). In fact, you can end the game by pressing ESC on every single door. You'll eventually account for 50 correct moves.
I would't be surprised if some crazy dude manages to end the game properly though.
Also, my personal record is 1:16 with the strategy outlined above.
I'm interested on the delay you are getting though. Will try the game tomorrow at the office on a few computers. I'm done for today.
Gave this a try but F keys didn't respond properly and there was a distracting delay between pressing the key and being approved. Neat for 48 hours tho!

It's an interesting idea, although it doesn't feel as though much time was put into it. I simply couldn't finish the game the "proper" way , and so resorted to mashing the escape key until it said I'd won.
Perhaps if there was a penalty for making false escapes, and the number of doors (or the reaction time) was adjusted, then it would work a little better.
I got 45.889. I did NOT use the following script. I repeat I did NOT use this script:

javascript:var obj = new Object(); obj.bbisBad = false; obj.bbname = "MILO";  var needsYes = 0; bb_keyboard_Keyboard_GetNewKey = function(){ needsYes = 1; return obj; }; bb_input_KeyHit = function(x){ if(x == 13){ if(needsYes == 1){ needsYes = 0; return 1;} } return 0;}
Good fit for the theme but unfortunately not much gameplay.
@Surrealix If it feels like not much time was put into it, is because not much time was put into it. I roughly had around 8 hours to do it so it's kinda natural it looks and feels like a quick game.
@Milo, oh, I was expecting for someone to come up with a script but didn't think it was going to be THAT soon. lol

@foobaz I know. It's a VERY... VERY simple game. I took my time constraints into account from the start. I couldn't afford to do anything more complex. You can read the journal entries for a detailed retelling of the fact (if you are bored enough).

description:
Viral is a 2D top-down escape game. You are a Virus. The objective of the game is to escape the anti-viruses who are trying to catch you, to delete you, for as long as possible. There is no win condition.
There are three viruses with different behaviors:
Scanner(Purple Magnifying Glass): Slow, but will always follow you
Integrity Checker(Blue Alarm): Will only give chase if you get too close
Emulator(Yellow E): Fast and will hone in on you. Only lasts for 30 seconds at a time.
To aid in your evasion you are given two traps to use:
[/0] - Logic Bomb - Roots the first anti-virus who runs into it in place for 5 seconds
[?] - EPO - After a 2 second activation period, the EPO will become part of the map for 13 seconds and block anything around it
Known Bugs:
Anti-virus pathing is still a little iffy at times. I ran out of time to polish it. I'm sorry!
You will experience some slowdowns if a lot of anti-viruses need to generate paths all at the same time. As above, I wasn't able to fix it in time!
No music disable feature - Ran out of time!
I hope you enjoy my first Ludum Dare entry and endure the programmer tier art and last second music. Thank-you!
author: torokokill
title: Viral
comments: Simple and fun. The programming-specific powers are great. If you keep working on it, a portal that opened up after X seconds to take you to another level would give a nice change of scenery.
cool game. i like the 1/2 abilities. agreed with mr forkbomb that an objective like that would help.
Nifty! I did find it a bit difficult and it was hard to use my "powers" effectively.
Good work on a complete entry.

That's an interesting game which I enjoyed playing and which reminded me of pacman: you did a good job for your first LD ! :) As you said, the graphics aren't really the best, but the sound/music does its job. Maybe multiple levels would have been appreciable. It's great that you took time to write progress reports and also a postmortem (try to make a timelapse next time too) !
This is an awesome start and I'd like to see what you do with it next! I'd love to see this as a multiplayer with more powers and enemies.
Cool game, clear instructions and fun to play. The powers are interesting and work well with the maze.
Nice little pacman style game :) Congrats on first LD

description:
Made using Javascript, JQuery, SoundManager 2, lots of testers and some hard love. Most input is done via the mouse.
NOTES: It's possible to lose, but not obvious if you've lost. If you can't continue, you've probably lost. Refresh at that point.
You can skip the beginning (up to Mike disconnecting) by putting an exclamation point in front of your name.
If you can't get past Mike disconnecting, try another browser :S cross-browser compatibility is a bitch it seems
Welcome to Paradise.
author: thristhart
title: Upset
comments: Both Firefox 6 and Chrome 13 don't work with this... I wish I could have played this :c it looked interesting.
That's weird, that's what I tested with :S
Latest Chrome 13 on Windows 7 x64 doesn't work past mike disconnecting

I like it!  It was really non-obvious when I was stuck, though - the fact that you have to wait for more channels to open up from #public wasn't clear.  I restarted a bunch of times trying to get what I needed from ParadiseBot alone.  In the end I peeked at the source, just to see how things ended.
Working perfectly for me(I think?), and I'm also on Chrome, Windows 7.
I enjoyed it, but I never managed to achieve all the goals. I wasn't sure if I had lost or not, I kept going anyway and the public room just reset back to the beginning.
I thought the writing was really good though, and the interface felt right too. Overall an enjoyable game :)
It was pretty damn cool. Couldn't find transport though! :p
Because of the way the engine works, it was hard for me to figure out if the player couldn't win anymore. I eventually gave up and hoped the player could figure out if they'd lost :P
for the record, there's at least two ways to get every goal - and one option actually gives you two of them!

Interesting, i got nostalgic from all those text adventure games. I laughed at times. and it fits the theme very well. I liked it! I managed to get three goals but i was too lazy to do it all over again.

Terrific game, the only drawback is the losing thing, and not being able to fast-forward chat messages. I think you can do a full escape-adventure game based on this, redefining the point-and-click adventures to chat-adventure.
I enjoyed it a lot. Good SF, with a few nods to classic books in the genre.
Extremely fun and well written, although it would be nice to be able to speed up the chat messages.
Randomly fails at Mike disconnecting (Win7 FF6 and Chrome13) P.S. Naming myself "Mike" seems to fail it at greeting message by Mike. :) Anyway, can bypass that by doing the exclamation mark thing.

I noticed one option at one point that I couldn't click (I don't remember what it was/where it was). But I still managed to complete it. That was a wonderful game, and proves that a game doesn't need good graphics, sound, or effects to be fun and engaging.
How can I play it? Or what needs to happen? Nothing seems to work after Mike disconnecting. Win7 FF6
Ok, I tried It with different answers and there are some people in the chat. Maybe I answered wrong?
I suspect the reason it doesn't work for some people is that the public chat is failing to load properly. Retrying /should/ fix it.
Really liked this one, decent writing and interesting concept.
And I liked the typing sound:)
Damn straight the Lord Master is my lover.
would be nice to be able to speed up the chat
I approve of the chat idea and the way it works (although need to wait on the #public channel until new channels open wasn't very clear). What I disapprove is:
a) speed of the chat... I've spent a long time staring blankly at the screen (yeah, I know, it was mostly about the speed people would write, but...)

b) possibility to be unable to finish the game without even noticing (while most dialogues are quite straightforward, in some of them I wasn't sure what to choose, probably because usually I wasn't sure what I could get out of the character) - after I ended up without destination I gave up because I didn't want to spend another several minutes watching the chat on public, instead I've checked the sources to see what I've missed. Considering you can fail in the game very soon (for example not getting ID which can happen VERY easily) you really should have invested few minutes to add simple check if the goal can't be done. It wouldn't be hard at all, especially the way you've coded your data. For example, increasing some kind of counter for goal fail in every "failed" conversation   and then checking it against global number of possibilites should work.

description:
First time entering game could have gone better, but enjoyed it though!
Not really much to do in the game but pick up logs and drop them on the beach to build raft but ah well.
Left it as a (slight) puzzle on how to launch it...(it also doesn't matter what its shape is or even if the logs are touching!)
author: shockham
title: The Sonata of Crayfish Jeff.
comments: I don't think the mechanic of not telling the player what to press on a controller as large as a keyboard is a good one (yes, I did figure it out).
The final win condition made me smile, very clever. Though I hoped the raft building had more of an effect on the game.
Well, I figured out how to escape... although not even having to make a raft was kind of disappointing. The jumping animation was entertaining, too, but overall I just don't think there's much to it.
Didn't take very long to figure out which button to push, in order to launch the raft. Kinda nifty, but there's not a lot 'to' it.
accidentally won in just one button push. Really like the Jeff sprite though, especially his eyes

description:
Quite a rushed up entry. I forgot to add controls description in game :(
Use W-A-S-D or Arrow keys to move.
Left Click to shoot.
Objective is to reach the right end of the game world in ONE piece! The game world is randomly generated. You can use any of the game objects like bushes(yes, those are bushes!), trees, houses or bunkers for cover. Enemies can't shoot you through these (neither can you) but unfortunately, they can walk over them :(
NOTE: There might be a bug that causes the game to crash. However, if you restart the game, it will work fine.. Make sure that you're playing after extracting it to a location.
Thanks to Ruman, for play-testing the game!
author: tecfreak
title: The Great Escape!
comments: It stops working after about a minute and a half. Also, enemies and their bullets sometimes randomly disappear. Good job finishing something though!
The archive seems to be corrupt for me.
Please re-download, I've made a fix for that bug.

Cool, you fixed it! Nice little game. My primary complaint is that I didn't feel like much skill was involved. I just ran through and shot everything and won. It seemed like it was almost impossible to dodge the enemy bullets, and I only rarely succeeded even though I was constantly strafing. On the other hand, you balanced the game well, and I was very close to dying when I won - so good work there.

@johnfn: This was the first time I made a top down shooter type game, Getting the whole shooting, mouse-aiming mechanic took a lot of time, and the fact that I started coding after 24 hours adds didn't help.
The bullets are too fast compared to the player but they can still can be avoided by strafing (but of course, its rare!).
Infact the game's aim is to escape quickly, if you wait too long, then you're a dead cat!

@Jacic: I forgot to reply to the other part of your comment. The enemies can shoot only when they're on the screen (actually from 20 to 620 pixels), otherwise, they start chasing you and since the player is slightly faster than the enemies, you may not see them behind you.

description:
You are a robot!  You are being chased by a voracious shadow octopus.  It's okay, these things happen.  Run for your life!  Shoot, too.  Shooting always helps.
WASD moves, moving the mouse aims and left click fires.  Try Jedi mode for extra fun :)
NOTE: Some older AMD drivers have issues with this game.  Please update your video card drivers if you're experiencing random stuttering or low frame rates.
author: TyrusPeace
title: Run Run Robot
comments: Probably one of the most fun games I've seen here so far, will keep this to play every now and then I think :) Looks very pretty too!
Entertaining, although the health thing is sort of unfair, especially at the beginning when he hits you because the game is just starting... Doesn't matter though. Fun. :D
