Looks fun, and has pretty neat graphics, but for some reason I had some crazy jumping, character was jumping off the screen with a speed of a jet. Looks like a bug to me. System - Windows 7 32 bit, nothing unusual.
great fun, the music is friggin ace, megaman flashbacks
This is awesome. the graphics are cool, and the gameplay is quite nice.
Excellent, one of the few games i've tried and tried and tried till I killed the octopuss instead of giving up after a while :) Nice megamanish music.

description:
Game can be played at http://jamieclinton.com/escape/
Code can be found at https://github.com/jcclinton/LD21-Game
author: nannite
title: Roman Rush
comments: This one troubles me. I love it, but I'm not sure what to make of it. Your graphics look great, with a bit of polish, (maybe replace the waypoint lines with scrolling dashes), they would be fantastic. Controls are simple, and intuitive (once you actually read the first page ;) ). A few levels, a  target rescue number for each level and some other obstacles and we have a winner. Well done!
Graphically cool, and a good idea, but strangely passive game play.
The graphics were great, and there is the beginning of something cool here. Shame there's on end screen, multiple levels or goals of any kind. Overall though I still thoroughly enjoyed it.
Seems to freeze when anything is dragged. Clicking close to Spartacus moves Spartacus. But then it freezes when a solder escapes.
I'm marking overall and fun as N/A for now.
I hate to say it, but I just didn't have the patience to understand what the heck is going on.
Thanks everyone for the feedback. I just want to make two points:
1-Please read the instructions. Theyre not as long as they seem! At least read the 'instructions' section.  :)

description:
I based this game off of a scene from the movie "The French Connection" (see if you can guess which one).
The purpose of the game is to lose your pursuers by getting on a train without them following you. I had a lot of fun creating some of the more chaotic train stations for the later levels.
This is my first Ludum Dare and it was a lot of fun. I hope you like my game.
author: Line to Shady Grove
title: Red
comments: I like the twist of how the agents don't want to catch you but want to follow you on the train, however I would sometimes stay in front of a door and I couldn't go in.
This is really creative - exemplifies the theme almost perfectly!
A very solid entry, I liked using the pedestrians to shove the agents around the map.
Interesting concept, looks decent and plays well.  Figuring out that timing is the most important thing does tend to make the game a lot easier though.
God game, quite a few levels, there's audio and decent graphics. And it's fun, on top of that! What would I want more? Congrats!
Good game, but annoying that I have to click for next level, when the rest of the game is keyboard controlled

Pretty original, nice retro arcade feel, I would love if it had some music and also I didn't like that you had to use your mouse to go to the next level, a key press would've been much better. But, pretty awesome! Cheers! :D

Interesting entry. I also liked how the agents just wanted to follow you on the train, meaning you were free to do whatever you wanted to lose them rather than directly avoid them. Nice variety in the levels. A key press to advance levels would be nice as well. I enjoyed this a fair bit. Great work!

This is one of my favorites. It's really creative and actually matches the theme really well, and you did an awesome job of slowly introducing game elements in a fun way without any text. Really nice job.
By the way, you're a DC guy, aren't you? I used to live just down the street from Shady Grove! Now I live near Silver Spring. You should sell this game to WMATA, haha!
This is a really good entry, lacking only better sound design and music to be a 5 star for me.
Nice. I'm kind of disappointed about the lack of tactics... I won most levels by just standing right next to the train doors and waiting until they were about to close.

I think you should probably remove the fact that you have to press your mouse button to continue and instead make it any key. The game was really original, but sometimes I felt like there wasn't a real tactic. It does have the possibility to turn into a really cool game :)

description:
EDIT: If you tried a Windows build and it failed, please try again. Jiggawatt has generously built (another) version that seems to work for people. (Clearly, I need to get better at using cxfreeze/py2exe.)
Red Rover is an introspective game about a robot on a scientific mission. It is a puzzle game with more than one ending.
You can choose to explore, carry out your mission, or simply contemplate the vast loneliness of being stranded on an alien planet.
*** There may be more to the planet than meets the eye! :) Please explore a little bit before deciding to analyze every rock! ***
Currently requires Python2.6+ and Pygame. I hope to have an app and an exe built if I can figure out the respective tools.
If you are having trouble grabbing rocks, it helps to imagine the grabber claw in the exact center of the rover. So try to position yourself directly over the middle of the rocks (or where you want to drop the rocks). In retrospect I should have put the claw on the front (or back) to make it visible, but there just wasn't time.
I have put some spoilers online here http://plastic-idolatry.com/ludum/redrover-spoiler.txt in case you find the puzzles hard or want to cut to the chase.
author: d_m
title: Red Rover
comments: I put some spoilers at http://plastic-idolatry.com/ludum/redrover-spoiler.txt in case you find the puzzles hard or want to cut to the chase.
I have put an updated version which contains icons as well as README fixes.
Sorry can't play :( I'm on windows.
Cool implementation not sure if you'd finished or not?
A windows version should be made/submitted - http://cx-freeze.sourceforge.net/ should do the trick.
Jplur, thanks so much for packaging it for me! I don't have Windows so I can't test it but I mirrored the zip on my server and added a download link to it!
Kevin, I did have more ideas for the game for sure, but it is complete in the sense that you can play it and finish it, and I think the emotional tone is about what I had hoped.
I got 3620, but I didn't think there would be anything more to it than picking up rocks, crushing them and listening to the catchy music :) Maybe I should've thought about the theme hehe
Had a fun time while picking up the rocks... For science...

I couldn't run the game even after installing pygame specifically (other pygame games didn't require me to do this), but I still left a rating based on your screen shots and the audio files inside the source. I was as fair as I could be without playing the game.
After having you (the author) help me run it on Windows, I came back and really really enjoyed the game. It's very charming with the characterisation and the audio is awesome.

Yay, I sacrificed myself for science! The screen scrolls a little too late and the bot turns a little too slow for the screen:bot size ratio. And I'm not sure how it fits with the theme? I like how it leaves tracks. A minimap would have been awesome. Gets a little repetitive, some terrain/item variety would have helped.

I had a bit of bile about the theme I wanted to get rid of first, but in retrospect I saw a really nice interpretation of escaping. Being stuck in a thankless job that will ultimately be your end, and the attempts at fleeing it. Excellent :D
That aside, I dig the technical features. Although simple in its own way, the dirt tracks wheels really come to their own in the graphical aspect - I dig 'em :) Particul
Finally, the music deserves praise. Beautiful harmonics and some nice chilly riffs kept me going through the game without really feeling bored. It kept me going. Imo a real strong point :)
Lovely entry! Sad thing it was too short. I was enjoying it and was kinda excited to see what was underground, lol.
Great concept! I found both good endings but didn't manage to get the bad one. (The non-linear score also makes it hard to keep track).
There are lots of nice details in this game (sand tracks, monologue,etc).
@Rudy: yeah, in retrospect the turning radius is a bit wide for the screen size. I did want to create plateaus, butes and other terrain but didn't really have time.
@Shadow: Yeah, I did have plans for an underground cavern area, but again, time ran out... thanks for your kind words!

@foobaz: I added crushing rocks to try to help people keep track of which ones they'd catalogued. Maybe giving rocks a variable score was a bad idea but I wanted to kind of simulate how a rover won't know exactly what minerals a rock has until it's analyzed. Maybe the score should say 100/3500 or something?
Great puzzles! I wouldn't have completed the puzzles without hints tho

description:
Short abstract shooter. Help the creature reach Freedom from the depths of an alien planet. Arrow keys to move, X to shoot, C to strafe (hold direction), or additionally WASD to shoot.
Tools:
Flash Develop
Graphicsgale
Photoshop
Libraries/Frameworks:
FlashPunk
Cheers :D
author: Noel
title: Reach For It
comments: Nice one! Loved the graphics and the polish!
Well, it kept me playing until the end. Not many indie games manage that. Nice, simple idea that was pretty fun to play.
First entry I finished to the end! Great stuff. Very fun, great presentation. No audio though?
A very strong entry. Loved it.

Refrag, sadly, no Audio :( I didn't have the time (or skill) to write my own music. I think I'll eventually get a version of the game up with some music composed by my brother, after the competition is over.
I love it, you must expand it, upgrades are welcome!! :D
Very good, not very innovative, but polished, working and fun to play. Next time just add few sound effects :)
sweet mechanics, ossom effects, nice art, good gameplay. love it <3

Flawless. Need some music and sfx but we can see is really pleasing. The whole game is so in one piece. Also level design is good. Not too hard, not too easy. I would play several levels in one seat. Congrats, this is one of the bests. Thank you for making it!

Very nice!  Very polished gameplay and some excellent level design.  I especially liked the forced run down a long hallway with the pink stomping block close behind.  Music would definitely help, but I got through in 8 minutes and had a blast the whole time :).

description:
Description:
You play as Persephone, who has been captured by Hades.
In order to ever see the day of light again, you must do the unthinkable: Escape from the underworld.
Instructions:
Use [w,a,d] to move.
Press [q] to respawn.
Later use [SPACE] to use ability.
This is my first Ludum Dare submission. Please tell me if anything is not working properly! Thanks!
PS: While playing the other LD games, I suddenly realized I did block collision in a really, really stupid and over-complicated way AND that creates a bug where you get stuck a bit in the wall.
*DO NOT use the extended version for rating
Extended Version Updates:
-Added sound
-Fixed collision problem
-Fixed slippery-ness
-Decreased explosion waiting time
-Changed acorn throwing from [SPACE] to [RIGHT CLICK]
-Changed restart from [q] to [r], but you should not need to restart
-.....etc
author: thonk
title: Persephone
comments: I like this game. I noticed on how floaty her jumps her...!
Love the story and art style. With fun gameplay to boot! Good job.
Nice gameplay. Explode yourself like Splosion man or Explodemon(if I recall correctly).
I think that the girls movement is too slippery, though. And collision bug appeared quite often. I got stuck a few times.
Thank you for the comments. The movement is definitely too slippery for a game that requires really precise positioning. By the way, did anyone think the game was too difficult in some parts?

I love that you used processing and I love mythology games. That said, I think the controls were a little floaty for my liking. I didn't really feel like I had the control of the character that I needed.
Got stuck on mountain side so couldn't finish game.

It was pretty neat, and I like the bomb mechanic.  However I have two major complaints:  1.  The controls are way to slippery.  2.  Waiting for the bombs to go off is a bit tedious.  It seems like it would almost work better if they just exploded immediately.

Nice game. Really liked the art style and theme, however there seems to quite a few physics related problems. The platforms feels like that theres barely any friction which precise really difficult. Also when you collide below a platform it causes Persephone to get stuck. I encountered some collision detection errors with the explosions as well. Even though I was half a screen away they sometimes sent me flying anyways.
Besides that it's a very lovable bastard child of Bomba Man and Splosion Man :)
I liked how you managed to add dialogs without pausing the action. I missed the sound, but I know it's tough with so little time... Game mechanics are cool too, good job! :)
Gave up on island surrounded by lava.  Wrist hurts, slippery movement twitchiness not helping, 3 AM!  You win, I quit.
Not a bad concept.  The controls are just too slick, though.  Kinda wondering why spacebar is used instead of a mouse click for placing mouse-aimed bombs, too.

Upgrade system is nice.  Level layout is more hit than miss, but there are a few points where the difficulty darn near convinced me to give up, before it... ultimately did exactly that.  I might have pressed on if I wasn't so tuckered, but I played enough to know it's competent, just needs some refinement to be totally solid.

description:
Game play instructions:
WASD to move/jump. holding space while moving towards a wall grabs onto it. pressing jump while grabbed onto a wall allows you to wall jump. Left click throws a shuriken and right click throws a smoke bomb.
Tips:
Pick up a thrown shuriken from the ground to be able to throw it again immediately. Use smoke bombs to obscure the guards vision.
Note:
I ran of time and couldn't add as much as I had planned and I'm aware there are a few minor bugs still in.
author: Bezza
title: Ninja Escape
comments: Ughh, please no installers. They're such a hassle to handle!
My apologies, I have added a version that does not use an installer and should work fine if you have XNA 4.0 and .NET installed.
The version I had used the installer, which I actually went through with but it made me /sadface. :( Happy to see you fixed that.

I tried to play this on my laptop and the ninja just glitched around the world, then fell out? Maybe the laptop isn't running well enough to play this game, but it was completely unplayable for me. :(
Except for the menus, at least!

Hi!, it looks very nice but there are two points I think you should consider: try to put the download file outside megaupload (because of the waiting time), if you got a dropbox account would be nice to put it there, the second one is more important, I think, I downloaded it and played it but... is there any possibility to jump higher than the first big wall? I could not, not sure if I'm very bad playing or that is a bug, check it and I will try again :).

@gokuhd Thanks for the advice, I'll look at uploading the files to dropbox. For the wall you're supposed to get over it by making use of wall jumping. Just hold the space bar and tap jump while moving in the walls direction.
@kavs I asked a friend of mine with a slow PC to check it out but it ran fine for him so I'm not sure what is causing the problem for you but it most likely boils down to bad programming on my part.

description:
You were once a powerful wizard who dedicated your life to fighting evil.
Yet your power could not match that of the MazeMaster, who banished you to his personal realm of mystery. If you can escape through all 50 floors of the Labyrinth the realm will collapse, and the MazeMaster's power will be destroyed.
It won't be easy, especially when death is final...
==============================
Features
==============================
*50 Floor labyrinth that must be cleared by one character.
* Full RPG progression system: levels, skill points, elemental attack/defence, speed.
* Permadeath: that's right. Make sure to stock up on potions if you want to survive, and you'll have to manage them well!
* All battles are automated, but you get to watch!
* Single world for all players: if we are online and "nearby" I can throw my items on the ground for you!
* New Game +: If (by some magic) you complete all 50 floors,  you can restart with a new character and enemies will have 2x health. Do this again for 3x, 4x etc: THERE'S NO STOPPING THE FUN!
* Secret and visible items litter the labyrinth for harvesting: you aren't just looking for the stairs all the time!
author: gigitrix
title: MageRunner
comments: Please let me know what you think: if there's enough interest, I've plenty of scope for easily extending the core gameplay, adding more enemy/item variety (and therefore maze traversal strategy) and so on.

Hmm ... the beginning is tedious (registration with captcha) and the animations of the boxes are just timewasting. It doesn't help that the game hasn't any graphics nor story (calling your red box enemy "red box" doesn't help my imagination). Also, it's kind of sad that the labyrinth really is just a maze. Thinking of roguelikes I'd like to see some more interesting room-corridor-constructs.
As a whole there isn't any reason for me to play the game further. Sorry!

Yeah I couldn't really figure out how to dump the captcha: it's tied to the authentication library I'm using. Enemies and content really do need a lot of work: the idea was that it would be a resource management thing where you have to try and aim for various goals (other than decending to the next floor) otherwise you'll die. Potions are a primitive form of this but there just wasn't time to implement my ideas! The mazes themselves are too big as well, in hindsight! Also the multiplayer component was going to be fleshed out a bit so it was beneficial to play in groups.
Thanks for the feedback, and if I work on it further I'll hopefully address some of this!

I can see this is quite a technical achievement, but between the very limited character advancement options and the zero-interaction combat, there's very little to play for. I suspect it was just a bit too ambitious for 48 hours. That's no reason not to work on it and make it something interesting, though.

Yeah that's my thinking as well. Bit off a bit more than I could chew really. I would have made it a Jam entry but I was completely mentally drained and as this was my first "go" I figured I'd just release it! It's more of a game engine than a game, really, but I'll probably end up abandoning it as I have other projects (that have much more codebase stability than this, which was bashed out without any thought to design patterns, commenting and maintenance!) Don't understand why the source link isn't visible, I'll fix that.
I want to play, but I don't want to log in, is there a guest mode?

@Daniel, Sorry there can't really be, although you can put any bogus email address in. It doesn't send any email, that and the silly Captcha are just part of TankAuth which is what I'm using for the login system. I can remove the email/captcha, but it would have cost precious dev time :D
A bit too much clicking for me. It should have some keyboard shortcuts. Interesting technical achievement as others have mentioned.
@gigitrix: I think you should create a bunch of accounts and post them here so we can try the game more easily. I don't think uninitialized empty accounts would affect the game much.

description:
Lost in the Depths is a multiplayer roguelike where you play as an adventurer who must escape the dungeon after things go awry.
Note that while this game supports multiple players on the server, it is still winnable with only one player.
Controls:
1-9 - Activate ability on target near cursor
Numeric Keypad - Move one space
Mouse click - Move
H - Help screen
C - Carve on floor
I - View inventory
P - Pick up item(s) on ground
Enter - Chat local
G - Chat global
The web link goes to an applet which should automatically connect to the server. However, it may fail for some reason. If this happens, you will get a black screen after pressing "Connect". If that happens:
- Check that TCP port 17998 is open outbound if you have a firewall
- Close your browser, wait one minute, and then open the link again. This may be able to correct an issue with the Java plugin
author: quadtree
title: Lost in the Depths
comments: The graphics were not very good. However, the gameplay was interesting. It looked like it was a fairly well-executed variety of multiplayer roguelike. I'd have like to played when lots of people were online. Also, the movement way pretty slow and it was hard to locate and target enemies, which made the experience feel a bit like random blundering.

Good attempt to put online rgl together in 48 hours (and it might be bit more enjoyable if there was somebody but me online), but slow movement, pretty much purely random fighting and boredom of walking in mostly completely empty halls... but it really plays like a basic prototype without much fun.
This looks interesting, but I just get a black screen with a NPE in the Java console:

description: This is my first time doing a Dare, made with Flixel. There are 15 levels total, each adding a new enemy to the mix. I hope you guys enjoy! :)
author: AaronYip
title: Left Again
comments: I would have liked it more if the counters didn't reset when players leave the square. Twice in my game I moved a character by accident and it caused the counter to reset.

The resetting was intentional. Being on the timers steamed out more zombies, which loses a bit of its effect in small doses. However, I do agree with you--accidentally resetting them is frustrating. I couldn't think up a quick fix though. :(

Good stuff. Kinda like a tower defense with moving towers, heh. There's enough variation between levels to keep things interesting, and the upgrade system is a plus. Enough challenge as well, and it doesn't end just when the fun's gotten started.
This is pretty incredible. Well done! Really enjoyed this.
fun game, I like all of the upgrade names / descriptions, and the text that the guys said was quite amusing, quite impressive for your first ludum dare =)
Very nice, like the humor. It's a little addictive. Doesn't involve a lot of strategy though. I would prefer less upgrade options, but bigger impact. Also lol at creeper.
Thanks for all the feedback, guys! :D
I thought it was pretty fun, but I couldn't really understand where the strategy was. I simply ran people from one city to another and that was it. There's a lot here, but it needs a bit more to it.

I definitely agree, the strategy aspect is lacking. I was hoping that kiting/upgrade choices were going to be more meaningful, but I was too focused on adding content and the balance suffered. In hindsight, I should have focused a lot more on tactical encounters. Thanks for the criticism, guys :)

Any game which says something about radish and mothers must be good :) (at least I've got that idea from Dungeons of Dredmor). It's quite funny and enjoyable game, upgrading gives and possibility to choose party gives it that something little needed extra.... and the oneliners uttered by zombies.... This... is.... BADGER BADGER BADGER!
Very good, one of the few games so far which made me laugh and deserves stars in Humor category.

description: The sirens go off. There's been another jail break and they want you to find and kill the prisoners. You've done this countless times before but you're conscious can't ignore this anymore. You can't do it, you want to escape this life. So you decide to aid the prisoners in their struggle for freedom. Your job is to provide covering fire for the prisoners.
author: pmeier747
title: Keep Running
comments: A really neat look at helping others escape from somewhere. A good use of theme to look past the obvious. The obstacles had a nice variety between shooting dogs, bear traps, soldiers, and running guards.
Overall a very good entry. I hope there are more that leave me this satisfied.
I'm afraid I can't download the game to try it out, I recommend you check the link to make sure it works...
Thumbs up for nice retro style art, one of the better entries I've tried.
Surprisingly entertaining, definitely one of the better ones. Also, animations look really nice, as well as the graphics as a whole. Fantastic take on the theme. A really nice game!
A pretty decent game. It worked as you would expect - to the point where you could accidentally shoot the escapees - and the game was fun and exciting to play.
The only thing I wasn't so fond of was the graphical style. I feel the retro-ish graphics don't quite fit with the smooth scenic background. It's a bit of an odd mix, in my opinion.

description:
Escape from a zoo that I ran out of time to draw, and make your way to the moon! Use the arrow keys to maneuver things in the sky while collecting health and speed boosts. Included are the XNA and .Net libraries, if you don't already have them installed.
Apologies for windows only, such is the way of XNA.
If you're curious, you can read my development logs on my website @ http://wbobeirne.github.com
author: wbobeirne
title: Jameson Livingston Penguin
comments: Solid and polished, but perhaps too simple.  I liked the notifications for incoming vehicles!
Redistributables in .rar were probably unnecessary, my poor dial-up.. :) But the game is well-done, if simple and a bit hardish.
@Rudy Apologies, I'm too used to dealing with average users as opposed to other developers so I kind of went overkill. To be fair though, it's no more than 5-6mb compressed!
Penguin with a rocket pack leaves planet. A bit simple but a fun time waster. It doesn't need to be any longer and it appears as though most of the details were refined brilliantly.

A lovely game, but the difficulty curve remains rather constant throughout. One solution would have been using upgrades, but that has been done to death so it's probably better that you kept it simple, more obstacles with less predictable paths could have probably helped the most.
I reached the moon!  The most difficult part is the space with the almost unpredictable UFO's movements,  however it wasn't much different.
The game play is solid and the art is cute.
I actually thought that the UFO's were easy to avoid, and that the planes were a little harder.
The menu at the end didn't seem to quite work; I could select items but not 'choose' them.
@Jacic, I noticed that bug just a couple hours after I submitted the game. It's an easy fix, but I'm a man of my word. Thanks for the kind words!

description:
UPDATE: I've posted a link to some shaders that use GLSL 1.4 and have the GL_ARB_texture_rectangle extension declared. If you get shader errors, then try these. Replace the shaders in the 'assets/shaders' folder with these. If they don't work, then I won't be able to help I'm afraid, but if you post a comment about it then please can you state your OpenGL version and GLSL version.
UPDATE: I won't be able to get GLSL 1.1 shaders up =( The game requires instancing by glDrawArraysInstanced for the floor tiles, which isn't supported by OpenGL 2.1 or GLSL until GLSL version 1.4. And using glDrawArrays normally 600 times would make the game grind to a halt. Sorry guys! =(
UPDATE: Windows exe finally up! =D
Hi everyone,
This is my first Ludum Dare, I've had fun, and I'm extremely tired and need to get some sleep! I was quite busy this weekend but I'm pleased with what I got done. I wish I had time to make more levels though (there's only one. Levels are split up into 12 short stages/rooms).
At the moment there is only a zip for Linux (which may require installing some extra packages, such as SDL). I'll try and get a Windows executable up as soon as I can!
The game is written in C++ with SDL, OpenGL and my game library (https://github.com/supermaximo93/SuperMaximo_GameLibrary). Graphics made with Gimp/Pinta and music made with FL Studio.
Thanks for playing!
author: Miner
title: Fred the Astro
comments: I'm on linux and I can't execute the binary, and there's no makefile so I have no idea how to compile it. I have SDL installed.
Same problem for me, SDL and most common addon library's installed.
Only error message I get is: "bash: /home/puffi/Desktop/LD/fred_the_astro_miner_supermaximo93: cannot execute binary file"
Uh oh. I'm already having a painful time with Windows, and now this! I'll try and get this sorted ASAP
You might need to install libsdl-gfx which is a separate package from libsdl.
I could start the game, but I just had to uninstall fglrx because today my computer wouldn't boot with it :O so it fails when GLSL 1.50 isn't found
Maybe I'll try again if I get the fglrx driver working
Thanks JohanAR, I'll make some GLSL 1.1 shaders and upload them
let us know when there's a windows version ;-)
Reinstalled latest Catalyst so the game is working now :) Fun but nerve-wrecking being chased by that big monster
I needed to download libgcc_s_dw2-1.dll and libstdc++-6.dll to play on windows. Seems like a fun game.
Cool, I added libgcc_s_dw2-1.dll and libstdc++-6.dll to the Windows zip
Still can't play in windows, I only get a white square on the upper right corner.
Okay, I've posted a link to some GLSL 1.4 shaders. Bear in mind that these might not fix the problem, as I've recently found that my game requires a minimum of GLSL 1.4 and OpenGL 3.0 =/

Like the idea. Obsid... i mean Uberstone is quite indistinguishable against background. Not sure I get the level layout, I started going in circles and soon the urgency of monster behind died. Could use better level design, more interesting levels. I see potential. Would be epic if the monster chewed all the bricks in front of it.
Thanks Rudy! Yeah, the levels were a very last-minute job. I wish I had time to do better ones but time was running out!

description:
Android app. Load onto your SD card and install from APK.
Didn't get that far in, but there's a test level to play with. Walk to the gun to win the game.
author: Superdeath
title: Final Escape
comments: Controls feel weird and register strangely on the screen "joystick". There is not much gameplay, so not much to say. Works fine on Galaxy S, characters are very tiny though. It also doesn't explain the relevance to the theme.
P.S. Why is it marked "Windows" if it's Android?
I don't like the controls at all, but that might be because I loathe "virtual joysticks".  I had no trouble finishing this game, as there is no game play at all.

description: My first entry to ludum dare! Make sure you install openal else the sound won't work D: The installer is included. The source has few comments...I don't comment. Sorry :P
author: ben1066
title: Escape!
comments: A good looking game, but the level design absolutely killed me. Way too many false paths with dead ends, after the 4th or 5th long pathway I followed, only to hit a dead end, I couldn't push my self to keep looking. The footstep sound also made it hard to keep playing, it was definitely too distinct and sharp for something to be repeated constantly.
I hate to be so negative, there definitely might have been a great game in there. I just didn't have the patience to find it.
Crashes on startup. Also, could it be possible to get it in .zip -format rather than 7z?

I didn't have the patience to see it through to the ending. Also the footstep sound was too hard on my ears. Graphics were good enough though and I liked the descriptions even if it was a bit limited (from what I saw in the part I played).
Anyway, good job on completing your first LD , and I hope to see you more in the next ones ! :)
I can see the text bar and the text but the rest of the screen is black for me
I reached the end, but I had to disable the speakers because the step sound was too annoying...
The graphics and the idea good.  It would be better if the level was generated, in my opinion.

description: I decided to polish this a little bit and enter it into the LD jam (which has longer timeframe and less strict rules) Arrows to move, Z to jump, X to pull. Push same-colored blocks together to make more blocks. Enter to restart.
author: GigaClon
title: Escape from the Sea of HeartBreak
comments: Holy lag and broken physics Batman! Haha. Good idea, but the implimentation is quite buggy/broken.
An interesting and fun concept, not as easy as it looks. The physics are very buggy though, distracting from gameplay.
It has a lot of potential, but not everything works as it should, and often blocks slide around unexpectadly

An interesting idea, but it was too easy to get stuck, and the mechanics (push/pull) didn't seem to work all the time.  Would have benefited from some description about how to play and what controls to use.
Interesting concept, but very buggy. Couldn't ever get out of the pit. :)
Interesting idea (and very melodramatic title!) - I found I got stuck quite quickly and never really got a handle on what "pull" was going to do at any given time.

The game was good, the mechanic was good, but the implementation was buggy, verging on completely broken. The blocks did not move in way that were expected. Making the blocks more grid-based, instead of a superfluous physical engine would help alleviate this issue.
well i only had 48 hours and ran into snags with the other approach.
Unplayable due to bugs in physics and controls.  Try to polish it a bit further and I would be a lot more enjoyable.
neat idea, but holy heck does it need some polish!

I must say this game has very strange mechanics and controls. I couldn't quite understand the specifics of how exactly the blocks will explode into more blocks. It seems like I need to get two of the same color near each other, but sometimes that wouldn't do anything, and when two were already next to each other, like in the screenshot, I didn't quite understand why they wouldn't blow up automatically, or if there was a way for me to blow them up. Also, I never quite grasped the whole function of the X key. It seems like it allows me to pull blocks, but which block exactly seemed to be a bit of a mystery to me. The game screen has all sorts of space for instructions, so I think you could have spent a bit of time making some.

description:
This is my entry for the LD #21 and my first game as well. I hope you like it.
Here you play a game from the death, it calls you and others souls to take a chance to come back to life and escapes from the death domains.
Use WASD to control, Mouse to shoot and E to create your own path until the exit. Only one soul can get it's life back, will it be you?
I doubt... huuhuh
author: Falleco
title: Death Game
comments: Cool game, I like the block placing mechanic, however you might want to try changing the controls for placing blocks to something other than E, it was really awkward to use.

Good game! I found the controls a bit challenging, but the mood was good and I definitely had some scary moments being chased by the enemies. I had a bit of trouble playing on my laptop and either the block placing thing was a bit wonky or I never totally understood it. But well-done, especially for your first game for LD!
Not bad at all (especially for your first game :D)
The idea was nice, but the mechanism to build blocks was quite challenging...they never appeared where i wanted :)

I liked the atmosphere and the story, but the block placing mechanic is a little fiddly. I understand the difficulty in creating a block, however, anywhere other than either in the direction you're facing or in the direction you were facing, so it's forgiven. Overall, a very good first game :)
I like it!! Need more polish on controls like other people said before me :D

It is really hard to place blocks and move to the right at the same time.  I almost feel like the mouse would be a better button to use for the blocks, and perhaps e could be used to toggle between the two modes.  Also the looping background noise gets a bit old.
Cool stuff! Placing a block under yourself would be much more fun IMO :)
Sos, actually, you create the block in the last direction you 'look', so, if you type down (S) the block will be created under yourself (then you can jump and create it). XD
I think i didn't make it clear in the tipbox :(
Atmosphere is nice, the intro is too. didn't like the game mechanics though. the block building killed it for me, slowed the whole pace, didn't make sense.
love the menu screen distortion though :)

I use a non-qwerty keyboard layout so the wasd controls were tough, adding support for arrow keys would help me out quite a bit. Then I placed a block and it stuck me in the wall, trapped for eternity in the pits of hell. I also didn't want to kill any of the other poor lost souls, but maybe I'm a contrarian.
The mechanics definitely need more development to bring out a smoother flow to the gameplay, and the audio could use a tiny bit of variety to avoid driving players insane.

description:
The theme is here. Find it.
Greyish X-blocks don't match. This is never taught to you.
Things that ARE taught to you:
Remember to press R to restart.
Remember that advancing screens is done by pressing SPACE.
If the game freezes and crashes don't get too upset -- you were likely already in a position to lose all progress (i.e. you would have been sent to Level 1 anyway; kill and reload the page!)
If the game freezes and crashes while normally advancing levels, I apologize profusely.
author: droqen
title: Block Faker
comments: Nice puzzle game, but lack of music and variety in levels keep player in playing more than one game. Why not add level select and time/moves count? Could add an highscore to it, no?

Liked the puzzles (particularly liked that you could move a whole row at a time), though was a little confused as to why you had 4 5 games, many of which had duplicate puzzles (as opposed to just one game with more levels). The controls were a little slippery - was a bit too easy to overshoot, and there were a few times i was restarting just to get the movement right.
Gornova, pdyxs, future players: Did you escape?

There are some reasons for the in-game level variety (the multiple levels are very much the same flavour -- no need to pad out the game with very similar levels, but can replay to do them puzzles again) as well as for the fact that you must play through the game in a strictly linear order.
But really. LD's theme is escape; did you?

so i tried to escape multiple times but after multiple levels of being hunted would eventually get caught.  if there's supposed to be more to it, i didn't really have the patience to sit through to find it.  i tried playing different sequel games with the same results.  i give up!
All the 'sequels' are the same game. Look at the links, they all link to the same page. I also noticed you could escape in the first level that you could.

I escaped, but got caught. And it then just resetted to beginning. Is that it? Anyway, it's an ok game though not very innovative, the ending was a bit abrupt. Controls could use some work, like pdyxs, I had trouble overshooting things.

Neat, and once I figured the mechanics out (:D) it was fun and straightforward. A bit more variety and a bunch of other levels or etc, or perhaps some measure of success like Gornova said could make it a good arcadey game. If that's what you're aiming for

This is a really nifty varian of sokoban, and I enjoyed playing it. I did escape... at least I think I did. They way you talk about "the theme is here, find it" makes me think maybe you had some other secret kind of escape in mind, and you had me superstitiously pressing ESC instead of SPACE when I advanced levels. Also I was totally confused by the four different versions. Still, I enjoyed it. Good job!
James, James, James. The escape you're looking for is not so superficial :)

description:
- Follow the instructions to free the Escapist from the water tank.
- Use the mouse to locate the hidden key in the water, and use it on the lock.
This is my first entry to LD! Thanks for playing!
To report any problems, please use the comments below.
author: Jorjon
title: .: The Escapist :.
comments: Ran fine, but after I drowned it just beeped at me :)  Still fun though.
Short but totally awesome. I escaped and felt like I'd achieved. Good job!
Hahaha... I enjoyed the crowds measured, rational reactions.
I like it a lot! Add scores at the end!
Good fun. Made harder by the fact my keyboard has no characters printed on it.
Liked that the key was random each time.
Just rather plain and short I'm afraid.
Perhaps if there were several tricks that needed to be performed.
Simple, but fun! The audio really added to the gameplay. Nice :)

I found that if you spam the tap buttons too fast, it doesn't work that well. I wanted to spam click as fast as possible and that's what lost me the first time around, but I won on the second attempt. :)
The anti-mashing mechanics is interesting but there's still too much mashing (and not enough varied gameplay).
The anti buttonspamming measures are interesting.
Once the key has been obtained, clicking on the lock doesn't seem to always work.
Too bad there's not more. It's too short even for LD entry.
Pretty good, I enjoyed it. however the key didn't seem to work?
I won on my first go, but had another to see what happens when you die...
I'm glad I did, heh. Also, I like drambles idea about tricks to preform.
I loved the crowd response in the ending.

description:
Your goal is to control the pellet object to the bottom of the frame were it will drop outside. To get there you can change colors and then pass through that corresponding color. Pickup powerups for a score boost.
To Play:
Unzip the files to a location you prefer, and run Untitled.exe
Canvas.cap is the source file, you will need Construct (0.99.97) in the Construct Classic series. You will also need the Path Movement addon.
The Controls:
Move Left: A
Move Right: D
Jump: Spacebar
Color Red: 1
Color Blue: 2
Color Yellow: 3
Color Green: 4
No color: Q
Restart/Regenerate level: Escape key
Scoring:
You start with 4000 points, changing colors will cost you, changing to red will cost you 5 points, yellow will cost you 3, blue and green will each cost you 2 points. Getting a pickup will give you 10 points. Your time in seconds is also removed from your score.
Known Issues:
Sometimes the sound starts out bugged, as a really deep feedback sound, rather than a beep. I have noticed that restarting will eventually fix the problem.
author: Sandcrawler
title: Untitled
comments: Wine says "Failed to load plugin 4.csx" and then the program crashes :(
Neat concept, nice to discover the score box at the end.  The controls could have been thought out more and I'm not sure where the 'escape' comes in.
@ JohanAR Sorry no clue. I'm not much of a programmer, and didn't write any actual code for the entry, it was all made within Construct.

@ jplur I agree that the controls have some issues, I've been thinking of alternatives, and a few other additions I want to make. The best new controls I can think of are to change it to a toggle, to you would be able to toggle forward, back, and clear it.

The "escape" theme is more conceptual, and I don't expect it to click for everyone. Basically I took the though of playing a Abstract Painting, and the fact that Abstract paintings are designed in a way that continually draw you back in, and meshed the two together. There are many different times and experiences when I have seen people stair at an abstract piece, attempting to come to a conclusion, when the piece more than likely has no logical conclusion, abstract art just is. So maybe they were playing some kind of game instead?
Cute little game. Would be nice to visibly show what colors 1, 2, 3 and 4 map to, but otherwise I feel it does what it set out to do.
While the idea was nice, this could have had so many things done to polish it a little. It does stand out from the others for mostly good reasons.

I really liked this, though it does feel like the scoring should be communicated better in the game. The first time I played it I was wondering where the challenge was, and it wasn't till I came back and read your description that I realised there was a bit more to it than simply picking up the dots and making your way to the bottom.
Scored 3936. I like that it's different and thinks outside the box of 2D platformers.

Put some icons on the screen showing the keys and colors, it would help. It would also help to have something else to do just slowly faze down and pick some score points - there are several games with the exact same idea of color phasing (but you're still going to have points for innovation) and they're usually better executed.

It's innovative but it just wasn't engaging me. When I saw how the scoring worked I didn't feel like paying that much attention, especially since I'd have to memorize the color costs or keep checking this page.

description:
Got like a minute left so linked to the swf
**update***
just found the edit entry so yeah, the version i had by the upload time doesn't have focus on a few screens when on the web, so start game click the screen then use the arrow keys to  accelerate. Didn't get the retry function bug free in time so the game just ends instead.
author: lartens
title: Twister
comments: ok so that was a mess, i forgot when its on the web the movieclips don't have focus, each screen needs to be clicked on before the keyboard event handler picks up the keyboard, sorry, rooky mistake, i also couldn't iron out the restart bugs in time so it just ends and needs a manual restart. I know super lame
and the source files as they were just before the upload < a href="http://www.grigorig.com/files/Twister.src.zip">http://www.grigorig.com/files/Twister.src.zip
I would just note that fixed version are at http://www.grigorig.com/files/Twister2.swf  http://www.grigorig.com/files/Twister2.html  and http://www.grigorig.com/files/Twister2.src.zip
its amazing how quick things get fixed after a little sleep
I really like the music, but the game play was not what I would call deep.
is it possible to get more than ca 700 points? even if I stay against the right screen border the tornado runs me over :(

thanks for playing, yeah, you can't actually escape, so its not quite to the theme, i've had something like 1400 points though, but i have a responsive bouncy macbook keyboard, there's also nothing in the rules about not using both hands, which seems to yield better results, the points and speed are optimised when there's a key press -> key release -> other key press -> key release.
Um, the controls aren't what I would expect to move a car.  Also, I couldn't escape...
The graphics are lovely in their simplicity.

description:
Hey everyone, it's pythong!
I really have to say, I needed this. Haven't been programming this effectively in a looooooong time, slept about 6 hours in this compo, and now I feel alive again! And still 4hours+ to go! THIS IS WHY I LOVE PROGRAMMING
What I used:
* Flash
* flixel: easy to make fast platformers, and easy to understand too
* GraphicsGale: Used it for the first time, and it's a lot better than what I did before: Photoshop and making my SpriteSheets on my own
* cfxr and wolframtones for sound
Was kinda hard though, because I couldn't debug for reasons unknown :P. My code didn't connect to the debugger somehow (so not even a trace()). Oh well...
To the game: Didn't had a good idea from the start, so it became a platformer, which explained why I used flixel.
----------------------------------------------------------
----------------------------------------------------------
You are an archeologist! Finding secrets and treasures is your job, your task, your fulfilling! One day, You find an ancient tomb mask. But can you just take it? It's being protected! Oh no! Escape the grasp of its protectors or you will never see the light again! And your soul will be trapped forever......
KEYS:
LEFT, RIGHT
SPACE to jump
X for interaction (just lift and throw actually)
Also, you won't reach the next level if you don't have the gold with you. So you can't escape. In which case you'll die. Horribly. Slowly. Or fast when you hear that sound ;)
Have fun everyone!
author: pythong
title: TREASURES
comments: This is the part where I go through every category.

Innovation... well, you have a somewhat clever boss fight, which automatically gets you an extra star from the base 2 stars of doing a platformer. It would be nice if you could use the treasure to kill enemies but oh well.
Fun... it helps that this game is short. The (somewhat thin but likable) plot keeps this game intact.
Graphics... nice job. Stuff's animated, and I'm not trying to rip my eyes out.

Audio... I must say, it definitely works, and the music's actually alright. The noise in level 2 could gradually get louder (it tends to drown stuff out), but other than that, just about everything makes noise. It could be good having the ghosts booing / bats flapping, but those sounds are a bit risky (they could sound quite annoying).
Humour... not much but there's a humourous ring in the plot. It's not bad, too.
Overall, there are a few rough edges (protip: try not to make the player start at level 1), but there's a game, it's got a nice thin plot, and it actually looks and sounds good.
Community... well, you've given us quite a few details of your progress. That's good. I suggest giving out alphas/betas if possible, they can help.
It feels like the camera follows your character a bit too closely. Nice graphics though. I didn't quite understand the ending (is the bell a treasure too?).
Really good art but the game design and coding seemed to be lacking. Ran in to a number of issues.
Having to restart from the very beginning is annoying.  Graphic and music wise the game was good.
Thanks for all the comments, especially GreaseMonkey :D. In like 5 LDs I never had anyone commenting this much on one of my entries
I made the player only have a single life because the game was very easy on its own with only 3 levels. I should have made alot more, but there was no time left unfortunately :(
and yes, I decided to make the bell a treasure too^^. So the player stelas all the treasure AND steals the bell in the end as well :D
Basic idea is good, but theres a few issues with the design:

description:
Perhaps bit off a bit more than I could chew, but this is a challenge after all.
The idea is a BattleStar Galactica Sim; aliens have destroyed your civilization and you have to escape their fleets that are hunting you around the galaxy.
That's the idea at any rate, at this point it's still extraordinarily bare-bones. So, I'm not expecting high ratings (don't be too mean tho!) instead I just wanted to get something in so I could point to it and say, "I did that!".
UPDATE: Yes, I'm aware that I neglected to tell anyone what is supposed to happen in this game; I had meant to post an update with some fixes but day_job() has been running somewhat constantly. So here's a brief rundown on what is happening.
The red dots are planets. Move along, nothing to see here, yet.
The Blue dots are enemy fleets. Don't worry, they don't attack you right now..
The green dot is your fleet. You can't see it, but there's 41 ships in there, and they all consume food, water and fuel each time you "jump". You jump by clicking a spot in space that's within jump range of the fleet (yeah, I know, can't see it right?) and then hit end of turn.
Woo, tonnes of fun right? Yeah, it's a prototype, not really a game, but I like the idea so PostCompo revs might have some interesting revisions.
author: CoffeeOnimal
title: The Remnants
comments: you have to explain controls and put source code!
I have no idea what to do. I just click "End Turn" at the top and some dots change position. Can't figure it out :/
You should explain the controls, if any.  As it stands, I don't think there is any game here.  Anyway, I hope you gained some experience for the next LD!
@Gornova: Since CoffeeOnimal participated in the Jam (not compo) s/he doesn't have to publish source code.

And no, to be honest there really isn't much of a game. At least some of the critical components are missing; the alien fleets don't attack, and there's no win/lose conditions, among other things. I also completely forgot to display all the critical information; food, water and fuel consumption. Not to mention letting anyone know what is what and what you are supposed to do.
So, lessons learned for next LD, and thank you for the feedback, it does help.
Is there anything else but randomly moving blue dots of enemy fleets and sometimes jumping of my green dot if i click close enough before click end turn?
Not sure why you uploaded / what you expect from comments otherwise. This doesn't count not even as a prototype.

description:
You are a bank robber, traveling through small border towns and pulling heists. The alarm sounds, the cops are coming.
Find the one way out of town that leads to the state line, and your ESCAPE from the law.
Instructions are in the ReadMe.txt in the ZIP file.
Windows Version - Uploaded
Mac OSX Version - coming tonight
author: KISTech
title: The Getaway Car
comments: Nice idea. I love the handling of the car.
The game is fun when you're at full health, but as soon as you drop bellow green you go to slow for it to be fun. Also, the sirens are annoying.
I tried to keep the sirens to a minimum, and I cut their volume by half, but yeah, they do get annoying. They would be a little less annoying if I had the talent to add some music to it. :)
Sirens are very annoying... Longer siren might fix it?
I never found the bank (or the exit), so I was just driving around running from the cops.  It would have been nice if there was traffic. :3
I concur, the sirents are annoying.  I managed to get to the state line on the first try.  It wasn't particularly hard and I felt that everything went a little too slow.
The car seems to have a lot of health; had hard time losing! The controls are great, I really like how the steering works.
The first level is supposed to be easy. With each level you manage to escape, another police car is added to the chase. So it does get progressively harder.
Nobody in my house has managed to get past level 5. :)

Cool neat game. I dislike how slowly the car moves after getting hit. And I'd like to be able to disable police cars (by ramming them, or making them go into traffic). Also, moving traffic would be a plus =)

description:
Java/Swing game (jar)
Press enter to start
Press the space bar to talk
Hold the arrow keys to move
author: syrup
title: Rooms
comments: took me a while to realize u needed to press Enter to start...
What an interesting little game. Good job on the graphics. I would have liked more story to it, but it works as is.
The art is nice, but other than that it seemed pretty bland. If there was more story, this could be cool.
It is too linear, not really challenging. i'd love to see more userinteraction and more rooms. good job on it though!
has a lot of potential, for sure. more rooms with different characters and it would be cool!

description:
(so tired...)
(EDIT: The links now include a fixed-up multiplayer version. It's still not superb, but at least makes it a fair bit playable (if you reset the server often).)
Alright! So this is my little game called "Right 31". As of the compo, it includes a fully working singleplayer version and a very buggy multiplayer version. (I will try to fix multiplayer for the Jam!)
CONTROLS:
Left/Right - move
Up/X/Enter - jump
Down/Z/Space - pickup block / throw block
GOAL:
Throw BLOCKS on ENEMIES!
(for multiplayer, to host your own server, run it with the "server" parameter. And to use a different server IP, run it with the IP as a parameter.)
(for singleplayer, it runs out of the box.)
author: Kouta
title: Right 31
comments: Good fun throwing the blocks on the bugs. Wish there was some sort of goal? At least I couldn't figure out the end goal..
The end goal? What end goal? You're supposed to escape from bugs in your code, but as you know, you never really can...
Awesome community involvement, but try to not be at your grandmas next time. ;)
The Asus EEE Pad Transformer is great for Ludum Dare! 16-hour battery, Linux/Android, touchscreen, touchpad, good keyboard, etc...
Next time I'll make sure to bring an USB mouse, though. Really.

You get a 5 from me for your community work, sir, but I'm afraid the game was too buggy and/or open-ended for me to enjoy it all too much. Good work for the trouble it seems you went through to create it, though :)
jonnopon3000: It's not that buggy in the postmortem! The singleplayer isn't buggy at all, even
Needs a goal, but kudos on going for multiplayer in the 48 hours.

description:
In this game you control small blue dot, which should run through the maze and escape from the lava flow. To win the game you must complete 5 random levels. Control - arrows or WASD.
2011/09/09 Suddenly my primary hosting is down, so I changed the links.
author: RadicalEd
title: Maze Escape
comments: Very cool! I kept having trouble on the corners.
Oh, those corners! My friends told me the same, but I have no time to deal with it.
You can "stick" to walls with no speed loose, this can do the job :)
I'm sorry, I'm too busy being mesmerized by the title screen slowly generating the mazes then filling them with lava! Tell me you are turning that into a screensaver!
Maybe I will! Just for $0.99 xD
cool stuff! i like how the lava forces you to go through it quickly, check the path in advance. finally making a mazegame challenging and skillful :D

I've seen similar done before, but you balanced the speed of the lava quite nicely to keep one moving but not domed if they pause for a millisecond on the corner.  Five stages is pretty short, but works well enough to give some slight difficulty curve (I notice the lava gets a bit faster each time) without becoming completely impossible or anything.
I'mma call this a job well done.

Nicely done.  Well executed idea with a solid mechanic.  I have to echo the complaints about the corners, though I did find it easier once I started holding down the keys of whatever direction I was going to move in next.  Well done :)
The lava's speed seems to be pretty well balanced - it was about 1 square behind me on the last level. I like how it kind of helps to show you the path.
I really like this game, very fun :)
Make the lava a tiny bit slower, but not much.
This game was very fun, quick and dirty, the controls were sometimes lacking especially going around corners... I got stuck ALOT. XD

Fun and relaxing. Could be interesting to take it further by perhaps making mazes that are locked off in various points, and providing the player with a couple of explosive charges to blow holes in strategic places. Making a hole in the wrong spot would create a shortcut for the lava and put you at greater risk. Maybe the bombs would actually be placed throughout the maze for you to pick up. Obviously with such a change the flow would have to be delayed or slowed down to make it all playable.
Sweet game. One level was enough for me though.

Cool. The only real suggestion I have for it is different generation algorithms, which might have made it harder / more appealing, more novel, etc. So that you could play it over and over and over and have a little more variance than with just this.
Very good gameplay mechanic. It becomes very fun to play after mastering the wall sticking technique.
I'm very glad that most of you have found this game interesting :)
Big thanks to all, I hope I'll continue to participate in LD, and I hope I can create more interesting and exciting games.
The loading and exit screens are almost hypnotic. The maze is nicely generated and the flow of lava has just about the right pace to it. Great work.
I have to agree with everyone else; the game over screen is really, really cool.
I got caught a little on some of the corners, but it probably doesn't help that I don't have an Up key haha

I played this over and over on the train home today and made many notes about how much fun I was having. The lava filling up the screen on the intro/game over screen has a mesmerizing effect. A lot like winning a game of Solitare on Windows. :D

It wasn't very hard, but it was enjoyable. I had to micromanage my player position while scouting ahead for the viable route. I found that the red lava was a nice contrast and gave me enough information via peripheral vision so that I knew where it was walling things off and it ended up helping guide me home.
Well done! Super polished and super fun. :) I like how the lava sped up. I barely made it!
I wish you had time to add some music and sound effects, though. That would have been the icing on the cake.
Cool twist on maze game! I had the same "corner" problem with everyone else. It will be interesting to see the basic idea being expanded.

description:
Based off of the original LodeRunner game.  Get the key, then get to the exit door.  Full source is included in package, so if you have Linux/Mac just install Python2.7, PyGame, and SDL (that's all that's required) and you should be good to go.
If you're on windows, just extract the zip, and double click on AAA GAME.exe
Controls:
W -> Move up ladder
A -> Move left
S -> Move right
D -> Move down ladder
E -> Dig a hole in front of the player
Q -> Place a trap in front of the player (have to give it a second to set before the enemies come)
Wish I had known they were having an LD compo earlier.  Had no preparation, so I had to learn PyGame really fast, and I hadn't touched Python in a while.  Also have a 3 three year old son I had to take care of throughout.  Came out okay, though.  Sad that I had to cut the sound out at the end because of deployment issues with Py2exe :<
author: Finity
title: LoDerunner
comments: Q -> Place trap in front of the player (sorry about that ^_^)
Pushing the left arrow key once for each tile I want to move is so painful.
Yeah, I lost a lot of time reimplementing things :<  My first LD48, though, so I'll have something better to offer next time ^_^
Pressing keys once and in game restart would have been great. But the basic game works okay.
Maybe I'll fix it in the source by myself ;). Yay for pygame!
It is somewhat frustrating.  Having to tap the key to move is not very nice, and I died in a lot of silly ways because the traps kept on killing me as well.

description:
You wake up in a strange place.  Smooth, alien surfaces all around you, a voice commands you forward to be tested.  You are a rat in an elaborate maze, and something is watching you, trying to learn something from your futile instinct to escape.
Huescape is a (very) short first-person puzzle platformer.  Use the traditional WASD/mouse controls to move around.  You'll figure out the rest.
Written with Unity 3 using some of the included standard assets (primarily the FPS character controller and the noise post-processing shader), starting about noon Saturday (EST) and submitted for the Jam Sunday about midnight (a couple hours after the competition closed).
Postmorten and details writeup are forthcoming - have fun, and thanks for playing :)
NOTE:  I've changed the web URL from DropBox to my own host so that I can see how many people are playing :)  They're the same files though, no post-jam changes.
author: mtthwcmpbll
title: Huescape
comments: Cool mechanic!  I wish you moved a little faster.
Cool idea but controls lack something. Continue the project after?
Cute, if short, puzzle platformer, and that mechanic has a lot of potential. Nice job with the fuzzy filter over the graphics; it gave the game a neat feel.
Thanks for the comments folks - I'm really trying to get some time away to write up more details here on the entry page as well as a detailed postmortem (I promise!).
Vrai neat! I feel lost in it.
Good prototype for what could be a really good game.
The huge text in the game was nice, I can see that concept used in a bigger game for the narrative.
The controls were really awkward though, it was hard to press 1-3 while moving with WSAD.
Nice mechanic and use of the basic functions!
This is an awesome start and I'd love to see where you take this with more time!
Nice idea, although I've seen almost exactly same mechanic in 4 entries already. It's a bit more interesting in 3d, could be used for some "portal" style puzzle fps.
Love the colour change mechanic! Really cool idea. Wish there was some nice music to go along with it.

description:
This is my first Ludum Dare entry, made with FlashPunk and the As3sfxr library for embedding sfxr-generated sound effects.
Press M during any level to toggle the music.  It's off by default because I wasn't entirely happy with it. :)
EDIT: August 22nd
I'd like to thank everybody for their comments so far.  It's clear that nobody likes the "run really fast" solution to Level 3, so I'll make sure to replace it with something more fun post-judging. :)
author: Basilios
title: Gaol Break
comments: An interesting concept for a puzzle game. I've beaten level 5 too!
It's that block-pushing game, but with a twist.
That game was already too hard for me, but with a crazy cop after me, it's impossible.
The music was good too, don't be insecure about it!
Very good submission, congratulations on your first time!
I quite like it. I gave up on level 3 because it required perfect timing, and I had to wait for the guard to finish his round every single time I failed.

I good idea for a puzzle game! I really like the whole concept. What you need to work on is your audio for one. I also think the graphics need to make more sence (I didnt get the block thing). Its an awesome first submit tho! Good luck in the future and I hope you do well!

I think level 3 was a bit brutal in terms of timing too, but I think the concept was elegant and well executed. The minimal graphics worked, would be interesting to see the various different tiles you tend to see in these games (slippery floor, switches that open gates, etc). I also REALLY wanted to trap the cop to detain him, so any new levels that did that would be a plus :)
Usually i beat block pushing games in a heartbeat (Lolo trained me well), but the "sneaking" mechanics added a lot of depth to the gameplay, congratulations :-)
Great game, loved the footprint feature! :)

description:
NOOOOOOOOO!!!!! The cubes are taking their revenge!!!!!!!
Use the awesome power of moving left and right and looking to avoid a painful death in a glowing pit of doom, or at the hands of a seizure inducing cube.
Only had about 8 hrs free this weekend so a very simple game, try to beat my amazing high score of 1000!
Eddie Cameron | @eddiecameron | grapefruitgames.com
author: EddieCameron
title: FUCKING RUN!!!
comments: Nice game!! Add audio a tecno music and could be a nice running game!!
Looking back is what kills me, every time. Got a score of nearly 700.
Aw, no Unity web player for Linux :(
Yeah, ran out of time for sound...But yes, this may be one of the few times that techno has a use
actually looking back could save you, but it doesnt help much, if you're next to wall, death pit ahead, and block is behind you one step away from the wall. these kind of traps happen all the time.
I think the core gameplay would be much better with a wider track. Impossible situations arise very often with only 3 tiles.
No bugs and interesting 'look back idea'. This is still a very decent entry, especially for only 8 hours of work.
An interesting idea, if I completely understood it.

description:
My second Ludum Dare game: Forever Running. Made with HTML5, Javascript and the Canvas element, so you probably need a browser which is up to date. Works best with Google Chrome.
Use A and D or the arrow keys to move. Press SPACE to jump. It's possible to double jump by pressing SPACE twice.
Avoid contact with enemies and run fast enough to reach the end of the level. Follow the green signs!
Due to the fact, that the canvas element is still a very young standard, there could be some browser dependend bugs. If this occurs (canvas is frozen, does not repaint, etc.) try reloading the page or use a different browser.
Have fun!
author: Fenmar
title: Forever Running
comments: The hit boxes could be a little more forgiving. Pretty intense game!
OH MY GOD A KITTEN DISPENSER!

I gave up on the square level; it was hard. I don't like how things can kill you when you're not really that close to them, and I don't like having to click to restart the level (I'd like to be able to hit spacebar since my hand is already there.)
But I thought the first two levels were very creative and funny. The kitten dispenser and the pit of kittens were great.
I like the fast pace of the game. But gave up on the first level because I got killed a lot due to weird hit detection.
Agreed on the hitboxes, deeply unforgiving.  Also the insta-death combined with lack of precognition makes this brutally hard to players that aren't also the designer.
However, despite all that I found a lot about this charming.  Especially the enemies :)

A bit too repetitive, and the collision detection seemed off a little (I couldn't jump up and over a wall if I was already pressed against the side of it, not to mention everything seemed to just use strict bounding-box based collisions). But for 48 hours, it's decent.

Pretty hard. Hitboxes feel enormous (like the corners of the bounding boxes of boulders are sticking waaaay out. Also relies on some elements of precognition. Sadly couldn't play much further due to the fact level 1 seems so impossibly difficult, and I am pretty terrible at these sorts of games altogether unfortunately. Still, from the screenshots it looks like you got a lot done in the 48 hours, so kudos!
Cute constantly moving platformer. Good game, but the controls and hitboxes could be less than accurate at times.

description:
Phew, it's been a long weekend. I hope this entry kicks some interest for you guys, enjoy it! Special Thanks goes to Erron Flaherty for teaching me how to code more fluently for this contest, thanks man!
--'ZOUNDS! The great Master Thief and Dashing Rogue, Blue Midnight, has been back-stabbed! Betrayed by an old colleague of his, he has been thrown into one of the Dungeon Cells and will be sold off to the French Authorities if he can not escape in time! Will our cunning Italian Gentleman Thief escape in time, or will he succumb to this challenge? It's up to you to find the pieces of the Treasure Map, gather up Food for stowing away and commodities to sell off for capital to finance the Expedition!
Can YOU save Blue Midnight, in his Dark Hour?
Controls
--Enter progresses dialogue--
--Arrow Keys move--
--C jumps--
--X held down runs--
Escape within 15 minutes with as much loot as you can! Avoid traps and pitfalls set by Leong to thwart your efforts! Good Luck!
author: Neonlare
title: Escape from Leong Mansion
comments: Very nice graphics and music! The dialogue was a bit hard to read due to the background being so bright. Also I had serious problems with the movement; it was very slow and slidey, and combined with a curiously high jump made dodging traps a chore. Really nice overall.
Great graphics, I absolutely love the death animations!

Graphics and music were excellent, and it had a nice retro feel. However, the controls were just really fiddly at times, and it could be a bit frustrating. With some work and polish, it could be great.
Thanks for the comments guys. Remember, if you Hold down X you move faster, this should help for those difficult jumps that you've been experiencing.

Updated the file, there was some kind of compression error that resulted in a part of the map crashing, nothing to do with the actual game content itself but I must have messed up the zip somehow. Should be fixed now (was making the game un-winnable).
some of the best graphics i've seen in the competition! great stuff. i agree with the earlier comment about the dialogue being hard to read though, some tweaks for later i guess!

Very good gfx (just the intro text really blended into background and was hard to read) and excellent audio. This is definitely one of the better platformers entered into compo this, although I gave up after a while.
Very cool. There do seem to be some buggy areas. I got stuck in an area where the obvious way to proceed wouldn't work (you'd immediately die by a trap you couldn't see from the previous room).
The music is great and so are the graphics.  The dying animations are a nice touch, but I saw them too many times as the controls could be improved a little more.  Overall, very good game.

description:
Controls: Arrows of WASD
Escape, run and escape again!! Exit from dungeon full of monsters before bomb explode.. you have only 60 seconds!!
RUN!!
Avoid close combat with enemies, you have limited health!
author: Gornova
title: Escape in 60 seconds
comments: cool it works :D Your time? How many moves?
Keys didn't seem to respond quick enough. Simple and well executed concept though.

It had a good challenge level despite the simple mechanics. The controls worked well and it was easy to tell what was going on. I would have liked slightly more variety of gameplay. Maybe let you collect clocks to increase your time as well as health. Overall good job!
Not bad, though the level design seems haphazard and random, and the AI is completely unpredictable.  Cool mix of dungeon-crawler and frantic-race though
Kind of bland, the sound got annoying. The movement scheme was also annoying.

I didn't like it.  Smooth up the movement (Legend of Zelda like would be perfect), add a gameplay mechanic (like bomberman, or turrets, or bullet time, or stealth or something) and you'd have something special.  You're almost there, it just needs more work.
Its a good idea but I didnt like the movement of the player. Also the sounds got really annoying. If you worked on it im sure you could get it a lot better! Good luck in the future!
Pretty good. I think maybe it would be better if there was time limit on level, not on all game. Or if you could extend timer somehow.
Decent game, but the sound was delayed by 1 second... Also for a long time I thought those red botles are keys I had to collect in every room.

A good idea, with okay execution. I found the sound and controls left a bit to be desired, but the game was still fun and functional, and it was a nice challenge. Could have done with more variety. With some graphical work and some polish and variety, it could take quick steps up in quality.
kinda fun little real-time roguelike! I had no idea I was being timed though so losing because of that was a bit of a shock

51 seconds 219 moves :). I noticed that after winning I'd win again in zero moves until I reloaded the page (on kongregate). I didn't like the audio and the graphics are a little bland but it's complete and it's fun!
Highscore bug is simple to fix, but after rating period here on Ludum Dare, I don't want to change my game before end :D
- movements: I'm planning to change square-by-square movements, using tweens for a more smooth movement
- other monsters: I'd like to add more monsters, maybe with different kind of power than hurt you (for example: frooze you)
- bonuses: clock bonus is reasonable, I like this idea,
- sounds&music: I will change it, promise :D

description:
I have written a short post mortem on the whole thing.
http://www.ludumdare.com/compo/2011/08/22/escape-deletion-post-mortem/
My start and end screens were unfinished, so directions are - use the arrow keys to move, esc to exit from the game, spacebar after you die. Don't touch anything. Don't let anything touch you. Get to the end of each level.
-- Fixed the missing libraries. Back to ruby 1.9.2. Going to move the source up to github today-ish.
-- Uploaded Mac version
-- Uploaded source code
author: siebharinn
title: Escape Deletion
comments: I like the whole computer feel of the game, especially how the minimal text contributes to it. It didn't feel like I was escaping but I did get the feeling when I was chased by the red enemies.
great audio work. however, it ran a bit slowly, the player hit box felt very unfair, and each level seemed to have the exact same wall layout.
It was great, cool audio! The collision was not very clear.

"Tron" feel is nice, but it was kinda boring (and later maybe too tough). BTW for some reason audio doesn't work for me (WinXP), so i listened to the menu tune manually (nice one :). And your level format is genius :D
Sorry, can't really rate on community. Somehow the link to your journal is broken?
Cool little game. Although it is kinda slow and gets boring real quick, the audio is quite nice. And yeah, the collision boxes are really unfair.
Did not have the patience to try to finish it, but with some polish it could become a cool little game. The feel for speed would be kinda nice.
Nice theme, graphics and sound, but definitely needs more time spent on the gameplay.

description:
*Note: If your resolution is too small to fit the game, press S.*
Windows: Run main.exe.
You are the greatest escape artist alive! Kill people with your dead bodies, loot gold from your vicious (but stupid) captors, and teleport like crazy.
But most importantly, escape!
author: johnfn
title: Escape Artist
comments: Great idea to teleport to the other side of the screen :)
Awesome game. And a lot of levels/screens as well. Fun, well balanced and a really nice concept!
Woow, excellent! It started out pretty interesting, and just as it was starting to get boring you introduced new concepts which kept it fun the whole way through. :D
Loved the puzzles with the dead bodies!
My screen is 768 tall and game 828 tall :(
Really creative mechanic, well done on the stage design!

@Almost: I've tossed in a feature just for you. Press 's' in game to make the game Smaller - 400x400. (I feel like this revision is valid since I feel that not fitting inside a computer's resolution is a game killing bug. Let me know if you disagree.) If you're on a mac, unfortunately I won't have the feature out for you until tomorrow, but it's up on the windows version. Let me know how this works for you :)

I really liked the idea, screen size was kind of a bad choice (I know you can make it smaller, but that was way too small) I dunno about the dead bodies, I couldn't make it that far, is there some tip to get past the first screen with the 3 enemies?

@nuria: The trick to get past the enemies is to wait until they start to turn before you jump over them, because their line of sight is diminished for a little bit. If you think it would be better, I can make the screen size 1.5x - just let me know. It's really important to get to the dead body dropping, since that's the best part! :D
Teleporting idea puts this among better games in the compo. It got pretty hard quite fast, but I enjoyed it.

Neat mechanic which I enjoyed. I got a glitch where some gold blocks would pass to the next screen and were unobtainable however. It did get quite tough and there seems to be a few "pointless" screens (the guard down the bottom... is there anything to do in there except avoid?) but that might just be me.

Hey @Dogbomb: the gold thing is actually not a glitch - it's a visual indicator of how much gold you have on the heads up display (like health).
