author: Cell
title: Relic Run
comments: Please give Critical Feedback, i may make a Commercial/another version with my Game Dev Team.

Solid fun gameplay and it's the type of game you can play for a minute or two when you are waiting. The smaller details like skins and the different difficulty settings helped add to the game's polish.
I see a folder called Source but it doesn't look like it has source code, only two binaries (Lua.dll and LD21.gmk) and an icon file. Maybe it's the wrong archive?

It was an engaging gameplay, i enjoyed it a lot. One thing that could add a lot are the graphics. I know that the pixel aesthetic can sumn to a game but in a massive shooting game like this that make the things indistinguishable. I would change the graphics a little, maybe the background color. The importatn thing is that objects should contrast. My two cents. Very good on-the-bus-going-to-work game. With unockable content could transform in desktop game.

Very fun! Seems very solid, but it is kinda hard at the beginning and very easy later on. Also, I thought I could escape, but I got 361 score and still didn't escape :P If you plan to make a second version, I'd like to have more weapon types, and local multiplayer. Best entry I played so far, congratulations!
quite challenging and hectic, but nice gameplay. love the art style.
very cool! frantic at times but i loved the simple graphics.
I found this fairly boring, since there was little reason not to just constantly fire directly in front of the character. I had no reason to learn what the different boxes meant either.
@Lilserf Then you're playing the game just for winning, not for having fun :S

I liked the destructible environment and the particle effects.  Enhancing the graphics would be nice, but be careful not to overdo it and saturate it, as it's already a very hectic game.  As for sound, the music seemed okay, but I found the sound effects annoying.

It becomes hectic very fast with many moving black objects. Destructables are a plus. Then again I might need to stop shooting everything. Sometimes I'm not sure why I died. It's challenging even on easy. Slower gameplay mechanic and object introduction is needed. Bonus points for character customization, although for 48h game that time may have better been spend elsewhere. Graphics have potential to be cute if they get variety, but I also prefer fewer more polished objects than a whole lot of black ones. Liek the "particle" effects though. It can be fun to be hectic, but it needs to be more forgiving. I suggest polishing the core mechanics and keeping back feature-creep. I did end up firing just in front in the end.

Easy was harder than insane. I guess I got unlucky there. Too hard early on to get a handle on what is going on, trying to avoid releasing spikes while at the same time killing dangerous things, and all of a sudden you're stuck on some hurtful enemy that drains your energy in a second. Would be nice if there were levels or stages where one element got introduced at a time so the player has a chance of learning and familiarizing before being slaughtered. Feels like it has a lot of content though, so it could be an involving game if balanced better.
This is a great, polished and finished bit of work. I am looking forward to seeing this go further... WITH MULTIPLAYER!!! Hell yeah! I'd love to shoot some real life arses with this.
Really good, although insanely difficuly. Well done!

Particles seem a bit overdone, honestly.  There's a lot of them at all times and until I played survival I didn't even realize enemies could fire at me.  Aside from that, getting hung up on little guys that run at you as your health rapidly drains is why I die, consistently, and the fact they basically trap you so you can't evade honestly ticks me off a lot.  The basic concept is decent and there's a lot of variety and small touches here that help keep things interesting, and I spent more time with it than most any of the other things on here so far, so there's that, but it certainly has some flaws.
so many bits, so so many bits.  fun, could see it doing well on a tablet on the train to work
There was a bit too much on the screen and the best tactics was just to run straight ahead and shoot. Fun for a while, but too frantic for my taste.

-   Are there bullets stuck on the edge of the screen auto-destroying everything? I'm confused why everything just breaks/appears even when I don't shoot. This seems to break the strategy aspect of "shoot some things, don't shoot other things"

description:
This game has been made by a team of three peoples called the Uchuu Sentai Pastagaga.
This is our first participation to Ludum Dare Jam so be gentle :)
In this shoot em up game you cannot shoot, you can just avoid the bullet. So let's name it an "avoid them all" game.
The more you avoid bullets, the more you score. Each bullet that goes out of the screen makes you earn 1 point.
Your score fulfil a power gauge which allow you to active one of your 4 powers :
1- Shield: glass shields block the bullets
2- Nova: generate a nova circle around your ship and destroy all the bullets in it
3- Mirror ball: makes the entire screen go BOOM and empty it
4- Score x2: all bullets that go out of the screen make you earn 2 points !
The idea behind the game is not just to "escape" the bullets. It is to "escape" reality. Firstly through the universe of the game and secondly because in the real world you will never just avoid the bullets without shooting.
As you will see the game needs some improvements, balancing and lack from real musics and SFX. But don't worry ! This is just the first version. Updates will come soon :)
We hope you'll like the game in this first release. Do not hesitate to drop a word, feedback, comments, anything will be appreciate. See you for another Jam :)
Gameplay video : http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ze7iF8JWjUs

Very nice art, but not really a lot of gameplay other than "avoid" bullets.

stylish shooter :) Since you dont have to shoot ennemies maybe you should have add some mecanics like ikaruga ( 2x bullets color + 2 shield types )

description:
Find jailed.exe in the unzipped folder and run.
Everything necessary is explained in the game. Try to beat "Insane" difficulty.
Written with python2.6 and pygame - if you want to try out the source with Linux/Mac please give me some feedback.
** Additional Update: If you are on Mac/Linux and run the game use 'jailed.py'!! 'escape.py' is an outdated version of the game (Saturday of LD).

* Insane isn't really that hard to beat because I messed up the level generator (check the journal link below the screenshots for an explanation). Postcompo will get an improved generator.
author: tcstyle
title: Jailed by the Ministry of Project Management
comments: It works fine on Linux. Nicely done, although it could use keyboard shortcuts for movement.
Insane is perfectly winnable (done 3 times now) but seems to be much more based on luck. I think you should get more information (of some sort) on higher levels.

Very interesting game. Took me only 5 minutes to beat all levels though, so I think you should try find some better algorithm that randomizes the world to make it harder to find one path that takes less energy to walk.
Hey, this is a very good idea, congrats!

It's a bit lacking on the tactical side, as you can't see everything from the beginning and getting new food is too random ... but I played it several times, which tells something. (I also beat the "Insane" mode, which wasn't much harder than the other modes.)

The only thing I didn't like was the graphics, or better, the choice of colours. The music is cheap, but sets the atmosphere perfectly ... but the bright ground just doesn't fit. If you would fix that + more interactivity / tactical gameplay, it would become a nice little coffe break game. :-)
Also, don't use "any key" for continuing. Make buttons or make it spacebar-only. I used my volume keys and the game just skipped the intro, which is annoying.
It gets a bit hit and miss since you don't really know what's out there. But I guess that's part of the point, one needs courage and luck to get away from the ministry of project management.
It runs fine in Linux - first I tried running Escape.py, and I thought that I played the game then - but I feel it didn't behave the same way as jailed.py did.
@Kvisle: Escape.py is an old version from saturday of LD (if I remember correctly). Thanks for pointing out. I will add some hint on this page.
Unsure of how to know where the rooms are?  Sometimes I go right, and go to the end of the screen, sometimes I hit a dozen rooms.

description:
Totally incomplete (~12 hours work) but thought I'd at least submit it :)
In-browser racing game (all HTML5, JS & CSS 3D transforms).
Safari or iPad (landscape) ONLY. Chrome has rendering bug.
Controls:
- Safari: Arrow keys
- iPad: Onscreen controls
Have fun driving in circles :) See if you can "escape".
author: fenn
title: Incomplete Escape Racer!
comments: Love to see an HTML5 game that actually runs pretty well!
I'd love to see this finished. Or at least maybe fixed for other browsers. (Terrain texture vanishes in chrome)
Maybe at least you could, count laps and made a time limit.. "finish 3 laps to escape before world ends" or something..
Nice to see a web game in HTML5, but it got boring after about 10 seconds. You did say it was incomplete :).
doesnt work at all in FF6 (well, the sky scrolls ok)
Doesn't work in Firefox either (it actually works in chrome for few seconds, Firefox doesn't do transformations at all).

description:
Written from scratch over the last 72 hours.  The story:
"A wizard has trapped you in a piece of non-Euclidean geometry!  Use the mouse to roll past dangerous hazards to escape the confines of your warped prison!"
Controls: Arrow keys navigate menus, mouse moves the ball around
Tools used: Linux, g++, GNU Make, OpenGL, GLFW, Eigen, SDLAudio and a bunch of calculus
Authors: Mikola Lysenko, Matt Watkins
Thanks to Wallacoloo for help with the windows port!
author: mikolalysenko
title: Help!  I'm trapped in a compact 2D Riemannian manifold!
comments: Haha, I can tell what theme you voted for! ;-) I really liked the originality of this game. It was fun to play mostly because it was just so different from most other games on the 'net. I think some subtle background music could help set a good mood for this.
This has great level-design. Every area is quite different to the last.
Cool, very interesting stuff!  I liked how it only used the mouse to control but I have to admit I struggled a bit with the controls.

KilledByAPixel:  Thanks!  Glad you liked it!  As a protip, try using shorter gestures to move the ball around instead of clicking and holding (kind of like rolling a trackball).  Also, on the donut level the frosting is very slippery, so you can try rolling on the cake part of the donut to keep the ball under better control.

Very nice looking levels for being procedurally generated. Sorry but I could not get a hang of the controls. :( I'd also suggest making the collision on the ESCAPE a bit more generous - I would get really close then roll right through, and reversing is near impossible.
Very interesting but quite disorienting. Often the ball seemed to move in the opposite direction of the mouse. Very different and original.
Really impressive use of the maths! :)
Visually interesting, and I always love abstract stuff like this.  The controls were surprisingly tight for something done in such a short time.
Really, really cool. Tricky as hell to control though!

I ragequit in the second level. Visually it's nice, I like and use fractals, name for the game is excellent, but the controls killed it for me, and I mean like totally. Although I understood how it's supposed to work (I think), I had incredibly hard times with controlling it whatever I've tried from small clicks to dragging the mouse - it wouldn't have been that hard if the camera wasn't switching so wildly, but I struggled just to get where I wanted, without being hunted.
@Shigor It has nothing to do with fractals. Read the description - it's just that, non-Euclidean geometry. :)

This is like the most innovative game I've seen in years. I truly admire you guys for the execution of this idea - I mean, a good idea is one thing, but trying to make a playable game out of this - crazy, bold and awesome. The controls aren't that bad, but more control over the ball could make this a much better experience. This is especially true in levels with holes, where camera movement can confuse the hell out of anyone. Also, the camera tends to sometimes rotate 180 degrees, which can be frustrating.

description:
You're a survivor that had the unfortunate event of being quarantined inside a city with a bunch of zombies!  Luckily you did get to contact help, but they won't be able to help you escape for 2 weeks.
The game is open-world and basically you're stuck inside a sectioned off part of the city.  There are buildings to explore and items and weapons to get.  I would suggest to constantly be on the look out for item boxes (which you can search for items in, but you can only get 1 item per item box per day (respawns at 8:00am)).
Anyways your goal is to survive for 2 weeks in the zombie infested area, so help can reach you to escape.  Controls can be found on the title screen.
Don't forget to check out the time lapse video!
author: GameNacho
title: Fierce Undead
comments: Right click as a main function in a web app is not the smartest move, dude.  :/  In this case, it renders the game pretty much unplayable.
Yeah I forgot about that... It's only for using an item though so hopefully it won't be too much of a hassle.  I'll make sure to remember this for next time.
Ok I fixed the right click problem.  You can now press "e" to use items instead.

i didnt get it, i got the pistol but couldnt attack with space or left click, time is also passes way too slowly, 2 weeks!! thats like an hour or so from what i could tell. doesnt really fit the theme too well its more survival than escape
You need pistol ammo in order to use the pistol, and it's significantly less than an hour although you're right that it may be slow.
Anyways thanks for the feedback so far, I'm definitely learning a lot from the comments and my mistakes.
I noticed the zombies were pretty good at finding their way to you, which is usually a feature -- but half way through I was wishing I could get them stuck on walls :)

Also nice that the zombies "gave up" after awhile, but I ended up spending a lot of time "herding" zombies just so that I could get them all to rest in a corner while I searched buildings.  In future games, you may want to make it a little easier for the player to disengage from combat.

description:
Help the sausages escape.
Tested to work with windows 7, vista, xp
Mac version coming later in the week, or grab the sourcecode and install python 2.6, pygame, and pymunk
*Note, if your computer is too slow, some levels may be impossible to beat before the timer runs out, in which case wait for the post compo version*
! Use both the arrow keys and wasd, they each control an end.  Also 'r' will restart the level.
author: jplur
title: Escausage
comments: Fun game - I liked it a ton. Some parts can get a teeny frustrating if you know what I mean.
I love the avatar and the character control. It reminds me QWOP in a certain way.
It's hard to master and funny to play!
this is so stupid I love it :D
Funny, but overall just ended up being a mashing of the up and to the right keys. The engine also seemed like it was quite buggy.
I liked the concept very much and it was also fun to play. The physics are very basic, though and sometimes I ended up button mashing to get to the exit.
With a little extra work this could really become a good game. Keep it up! :)
The controls take some getting used to, and time tends to be a little short but it's pretty fun.
I like them struggling around to get somewhere and suddenly they fly... :) Hot dogs! Nom nom nom...

Fun, very silly, but I found it often ended like a fight against the game rather than against the challenge the game posed, if you know what I mean. Still, a great contender, and something that deserves even more fleshing out.
Yay for pygame. Funniest game I've played so far!
nice and fun, but the controls were often unpredictable, which made it a little frustrating.
Excellent work! I like original off the wall ideas and you pulled it off! :-)
This idea is great! It also gives off a great qwop-vibe.
Flying sausages! Extra funny idea. Controls are very hard though, half the time I'm just randomly mashing up and right. I also didn't get you use both wasd and arrows at first.

incredible sausage physics !!! This game really need a slice-effect with sausage particles on the exit square collision. I also think that the multisausage is more fun with level like the hole than in the classic one-path level ( you always end up focusing only on one sausage at a time )
Very funny and ridiculous. Sort of fun, but is was I think way too difficult for the amount of limited control you had.
If I weren't so full right now this game would have made me hungry. ;-) Nice game idea, but at some point too frustrating / uncontrollable so I ragequit.
how this idea came to your mind ? really fun lol

description: Escape!
author: JGames
title: Escape!
comments: Clever ! I was almost proud of myself when I found the anwser xD
Ha, funny, that was the first thing that popped to my mind when the theme was announced. Didn't think anyone would actually go through with it.
Kind of lame, more a joke than an actual game.
Well... I'll give you a star for humor :)
Not much of a game, and there are others that did the same.  However, I rated high in humor :-)
Hahaha I figured it out! I'm so happy for myself. =)

There are quite a few entries in this LD using exactly the same idea, yet trying to be more involving, or with interesting graphics, even a background story and so on. I understand that this is a joke, but it didn't make me laugh that much and other entries of this particular 'genre' seemed much better. :]

description:
Quite simple, you are the world renound super-spy, Derick. And you need to escape from a maze set up by Dr. Evilface. Sounds easy on paper, huh? IF IT NOT FOR THE RABID SHEEP!!!
Side Note: Chrome seems to be have some problems running the game
author: Blayzeing
title: Escape from Dr. Evilface's Maze
comments: 2605. After about6 attempts, that's my success score, can you guys beat it?
those are some pretty tough sheep!
Interesting game, but you should let the player use WASD as well as the arrow keys because the mouse is used also.

Controls are insanely awkward and shooting doesn't even work for me. And after already sitting through all the dumb screens twice (which I can't click through), I really don't feel like sitting through them yet again just to have the game still not work for me. =/
I also had difficulty with this game, it seems like the gun didn't work? Was ammo required?
I managed to get up to 205 though just by running around.
those were cool animations at the beginning though.

btw guys, thanks for the feedback, I've already altered my code for WASD. AS with regards to the breaking with the mouse, I believe that that is a problem with chrome running AS2, as it seems to be having adverse affects on some games.

Very pretty graphics, slick presentation, broken gameplay. :-( As many have said the controls are awkward, and on top of that my gun wouldn't shoot. Mac OS X in Safari. Also avoid using the Ctrl Key + Arrow keys on Mac, as it causes an OS-level feature that makes gameplay difficult.

Clunky controls (HOLD mouse for shooting?! WHY?!) and long intro sequence (which is funny once, for the second time is annoying and I had no nerves to try for the third time) is killing it. A little bigger view would also help. I found no way to restart other than reload page.

Nice art and music (so I won't be completely negative), but next time keep the intro for the last (and make it skippable, or at least give us possibility to restart without forcing us to watch it) and concentrate more on the game.

description:
Should be self explanatory now that I added the tutorial.  Say away from the walls, and see if you can escape the tunnel!
Tools Used:
Visual Studio 2010 Express
Inkscape
Paint.net
author: BlackBird
title: Escape
comments: Nice take on  the runner-genre. The vector-graphics also seem quite effectively used.
The graphics and gameplay are simple, yet addictive. More games need to be like this. Building solid core gameplay, instead of frivolous things that get in the way.
Simple, but it works. Music and some effects would've been a great touch, but I can't really complain. Nice work!

I agree, music and sound effects would have went a long ways; as it was, I didn't quite pull of what I originally set off to do - and the "music" I created actually took away from the feel so I didn't leave it in.

The vector graphics would look a lot slicker if the lines were more similar in their fidelity and/or size, methinks.  The blue lines end up looking very tiny compared to the level, and the red and green lines look fuzzy in comparison.

I feel like this would really benefit from a wide screen perspective.  The physics make a big difference for this game compared to others of the genre, but things got moving fast quickly enough that the difference seemed nigh unnoticeable fairly quickly.

It's a good idea, though!  Maybe just work on the level and player vision so it makes the user think about and use the unique physics rather than just hope that the next bend's randomly going to be big enough to survive.

It should be noted that you can play this in whatever screen resolution you want via editing userdata/config.  The blue lines on the plane, and words were actually sprites - and the plane was to be replaced (I spent my time on other hangups though).  I'm not sure the size/thickness of the lines is what caused the slight difference you see - I'd bet it was sprite saved 'blurry' lines, vs my glowing line renderer.  The level was not meant to be a tunnel, but I didn't see much choice otherwise for the way the physics turned out and time crunch.
Pretty nice game. I think it would benefit from having the camera more zoomed out, so that you can see more of what's coming. It was very hard to react in time in some parts.
Seems to be influenced by Helicopter, one of my favorite games! With a little polish, sound effects, etc, this could be super addicting.

description:
Es' Cape
Welcome one and all to Es' Cape.
A game about one cube's love for his cape and his attempt at
escaping the clutches of evil.
Will You Help Him??
If you dont already have XNA - you will need the XNA Redistributable
And here is the link:
http://www.microsoft.com/downloads/en/details.aspx?FamilyID=53867a2a-e249-4560-8011-98eb3e799ef2
This will allow you to run the exe if you dont have XNA
If you do, then dont worry :D
Es REALLY REALLY likes highscores - Don't let him down!
I hope you all really enjoy the game and I hope to hear your thoughts in the future.
Connor MacKenzie
Apperception Games
author: EncryptedShadow
title: Es' Cape
comments: I pressed '1' and it just sort-of... sat there. Didn't load, sadly.
It does work, I have gotten others to get it to work

It isn't the most challenging game ever, and the menu system could probably use some work, but I did like the meat of the game; past around 15 points it gets pretty fun. There's no way to restart the game after death, though.

I love the boggley eyes. +1 for humor. Not sure about the depth of gameplay though, it would have been good if there were multiple layers to stand on. Nice twist on the theme - es's cape rather than escape. This is stretching it a bit but at least you think outside the box, (unlike your characters, who are all boxes).
Umm numpad? That's an interesting choice. There is not a lot of gameplay, and jumps are too gravity-deprived. Some enemy actions would go a long way.

I was at work most of the weekend, so 48 hours turned into just short of 11. Atleast I tried, going to work on it and improve it for the future though, like the restart feature and mutiple levels and more for the enemies to do.

Nice little game, but even it was made in only 11 hours I'd like to see some more stuff (e.g., animated eyes or a moving landscape). Please change the keys for the introduction, I hate having the Num key activated. ;-)

description:
In 2001 people in the United States were terrified. Something terrible had happened. Something that frightened even the bravest ones. Enrique Iglesias released a new album in English: Escape.
There was more. Enrique decided to make surprise appearences around the States. In shopping malls. It was said that listening to his new songs would blow your mind. Literally.
In the game you are a shopping mall security guard. You should protect visitors from him. You should find Enrique Iglesias among the visitors and click on him. Then, people could escape from Enrique.
But fail and people would listen to him.
author: Elgriego
title: Enrique Iglesias' deadly a capella performance in a mall
comments: A port to either Windows or Linux would be appreciated.
Indeed; most users can't really play this as of now.
Some friends will port it to Flash, improve some graphics and sound and then I will write a post mortem with links. Î�Î½Ï�Î¯Î¿!
Bonkers! Good sense of humour ( i'm assuming you googled escape and this was one of the top hits? )

Eeeehhhhh.... The idea made me chuckle but the gameplay is really dull. You are just mash clicking, there is no strategy or anything, this is 100% luck. Also, you broke the rules by using photos of this guy, although I don't know if that is against the rules in the jam. Honestly I'd say to scrap this and make something more original and interesting.
I don't have access to an OS X and can't rate this game.

description:
DEATH BOULDER JONES
You are thousands of years old, and most of that time has passed quite boringly. Usually you spend your time making beautiful rainbows appear, because it's about all a benevolent temple spirit has to do these days.
In the past few hundred years or so, you've noticed people with leather hats and bull whips have started coming into your temple looking for treasure, only to be slaughtered by the many traps.
Well that just won't do. You've finally started to feel excitement in watching them try to achieve their dreams, only to have it dashed away when they explode in a fiery death.
A new adventurer has come in, and his name is "Jones." He appears to be very stupid, as he simply runs forward unless a wall appears in his way... or a rainbow. It's up to your rainbow-making powers to lead Jones safely out of the temple and onto an early retirement!
- Draw walls with the mouse!
- Lead a hapless adventurer to fortune and a death from old age!
- Deflect arrows, block off lava pools, intercept crushing walls of death!
- Watch somebody else collect treasure, treasure, treasure!
- Help Jones run very, very, fast from a giant fiery death boulder!
- Use your spirit powers to view the world in slow-motion so you can better defend Jones!
author: demonpants
title: Death Boulder Jones
comments: The idea is pretty good, but the game is too hard from the beginning. It should be easier in the beginning i frustrated quickly. Great anyways!
Very difficult! Feels a bit like trial and error.
Fantastic game! I need checkpoints though... XD
I COULD NOT BEAT IT!!! lol very nice! Very funny, good sfx and music, hilarious concept, and great gfx for 14 hours work.
Yeah, it definitely needs checkpoints or lives or something to make it a bit easier. I also found the walls obstructing my view at times, which was annoying. But the concept is great!
Good idea and presentation, but either tone down the difficulty or use checkpoints, otherwise it gets too frustrating very quickly.

Very cool idea, and I was impressed by the opening, but Jones' movements are kind of crazy. He'll turn in crazy directions or just stop at a wall. Would have been nice if he always moved up, but would turn away from walls, then continue going up after he walked away from the walls.
Definitely a solid looking concept though, good work.
Really hard, but shows a ton of potential that I hope is developed. My favorite part: audio goes slower when you slow down time. Awesome touch!

description:
My first Ludum Dare! I changed my game idea on the 2nd day of Ludum Dare, so I had to throw this together in just over a day! My main gripe is the terrible main character sprite, but I just ran out of time to fix it. The difficulty ramps up fairly quickly after the first level, too.
In the future, I'm planning to add way more levels, crumbly blocks that fall away beneath you (or on you!), spikes, perhaps bad guys, more treasure to collect, scores, and ideally an 'infinite' mode that generates infinitely long levels on the fly. For now, though, you'll have to put up with this 3 level taster.
author: jwfrosty
title: Daring Do!
comments: Really good level design on those last two. I would enjoy a game where you go in to various temples as long as there was different types of things you need to escape from.
Great work for just 1 day. I hope you do put more time in to it!
I liked it enough to get to level 3
The level design was really cool; and this is awesome for one day's work. I got quite frustrated on level 3, but that was because it was hard and I'm not good with hard games :P
The only gripe I have is that the level shake at the beginning really throws my concentration off.
Really really enjoyed this. I had to stifle quite a bit of swearing while playing this at work! Good difficulty level for me
I like the level design, but it seems a bit less frantic than it should. The scene that you are covering here made it seem like indy was barely in control. Otherwise a nice start!

jonbro: I know what you mean. I think the latter two levels are a bit more frantic, but the first one is a bit of a stroll in the park. I want to add more gameplay elements (more traps), perhaps alternative routes through the level, etc, which I think should help. I think the lack of sound effects for the main character's footsteps and the rolling boulder leave a big gap, too - I'm going to add these in in the update I'm working on. In particular, I think it'd be neat if the boulder is louder the closer it is to you.

Well done, this was much fun. I actually checked this out because you had the exact same idea I did when I heard the word "escape." My game plays completely differently, but I also have a guy with a hat running from a giant boulder and avoiding traps in a temple. Cool! Anyway, this overall is just great. Playable, good balance, good feel. Well done.

jwfrosty: I think what makes it not feel frantic to me is the speed of the character. Like when I get hit by an arrow it isn't my bad reaction time, it is my perception of how fast video game characters move, and this guy just isn't moving quite fast enough. It would probably take a few tweaks to get everything faster, but I think it might be good.
er, I mean, it would make an already great game better... sorry, I should proofread for possible misconstruism.
OSOM entry for your first LD!
Good game. Could use a little variety in temples. The arrows are a bit unforgiving. Every game like this brings me a little closer to a new keyboard purchase >_<

description:
Use your wits and some hardware to hack your way out of the compound!
Find hacking keys and use the terminal in each section to bypass obstacles.
Instructions:
---------------------------
Left or A - Move left
Right or D - Move right
Up or W - Interact with item
Space - Jump
P - Pause
Use the mouse to hack while at a terminal
Notes:
----------------------------
**NB - I've fixed the font issues on the title and ending screens. I know it's a minor cosmetic change, but as not to bugger with the rules, please rate based on the "Web" version.
This was not nearly as complete in terms of gameplay as I would've liked. At the moment, it's more of a simple prototype for what I think is a nifty concept. More puzzles would be welcome, but I'm still extremely proud of this.
Enjoy!
author: Jimjam
title: Cells
comments: I didn't managed to use the red elevator of the first level...I think I havent understaood, I tried to interact with everything...Is it a bug or is it me ? Because I would like to go further, I love the graphics
When you use the hacking terminal (the octopus computer thing) you can click different objects to try to hack them.
I really like the level design of the second level.
Aaah! Now I understand! Thanks Thonk. And now, it's a pretty cool game! I would like to see more levels of course!

I got confused and couldn't beat the second level. I actually wasn't able to progress past the first room because I was playing on a laptop and it wasn't immediately obvious as to how to hack using the mouse. Explanation of this would have gone a long way. :)

Thanks for your thoughts guys! I agree, a decent explanation of the hacking mechanic is missing, but I did want it to have a sort of escape the room feel, leaving the player to look carefully at each "cell" and work out what to hack.

In an updated version, I'd like to see a menu popup when you try to hack a room. This could have many options, like kill lights, blow power, open door, move conveyer belt, etc., so that the game would have much more a puzzly feel. Right now, you just sort of have to wing it to get through the levels.

Oh, another explanation on how the keys work: The number of keys you need to reach a room is based on jumping from the current room (with the terminal) either horizontally or vertically. Each "jump" takes a key. You can't jump diagonally. I wanted to show this visually but didn't get around to it.
In the second level, btw, you can *OMG SPOILER ALERT* hack the room above the terminal. :)
I like it and I felt a pang of disappointment when It finished which can only be a good sign.
Really good game! I think a few more levels and a little help with the hacking.
Thanks guys, that's really great to hear :)
I'm definitely keen to update this one!
Innovation: New idea, and it worked pretty well.
Theme: It fits the theme perfectly, although it isn't exactly the most imaginative interpretation.
Graphics: Beautiful. I wish I could make stuff like this for my long projects.
Fun: I felt like I had accomplished something at the end of every level, but the levels were all simple linear puzzles. Explore this concept more! I'm sure you can come up with greater things.
Overall: I would just improve the level design and you have a solid, fun game you would find a flash portal.
Interesting concept. I managed to escape, but was left feeling as if I wasnt really challenged by it. Maybe this is because I'm a 1337 h4xx0r or maybe because it was too easy.
Nice graphics. I like the lights. I also laughed when I blew the fuse on level 2. With a bit of work this could become a puzzle game, as it is there is always one clear path through.

description:
DESCRIPTION
Your buddy is making a break for it, but unfortunately he's not too fast or bright. Luckily he has a friendly sniper to help him out, you! Shoot goons, take out spotlights, and direct your friend to safety!
CONTROLS
Mouse to aim, left-click to shoot. Click on your friend to toggle his movement (stop/move). Click above him to jump.
OTHER NOTES
The game is just two levels so it's not a complete title honestly. Think of it like a bare prototype. :)
Made using Flashpunk, some bits from Flixel, FlashDeveloper, Photoshop (graphics), sfxr (sound).
author: mklee
title: AWAYGET
comments: Seems good, but it's not very clear you are meant to shoot out the lights.

Really enjoyed this. Love shooting the lights out. Slightly irritating that baddies can spawn right on top of the escapee sometimes, and very annoying that you have to replay level 1 every time you fail level 2. Wouldn't mind so much
Nice idea! Need more level and others gameplay elements but it's a good start!
Restarting level 1 is a bit annoying. Its also not clear when a goon will spawn from a building.
But overall, it was an enjoyable game.
I do not get the lights, I liked shooting them regardless. Nicely put together.
Bravo, nice game! Wish it would become faster over the time, and there would be some background music, but as a whole a nice and complete game!
Very nice, like the art style.
Cool little game, nice little graphics, has some good potential! A little too easy, but with some work and variety this could be very cool
Cool idea for a game and neat gameplay, but I wasn't a fan of how the second level's super hard just because of enemies spawning out of the building at (so far as I can tell) unpredictable times.
I can see this concept being expanded on pretty effectively.  More hazards/objects to shoot, reasons to jump, etc.  Nice work.
Short and sweet.  Suggestions for "full" version: shooting the moon and the car as Easter eggs, maybe they blow up or something.
Enjoyed this one a lot. Glad you didnt put big signs up saying shoot the lights. Only annoyance was enemies spawning into the escapee, couldnt work out a way to stop that from happening with my gun
Nice work! Reminds of the classic terminator-2-shooter.
Good concept, but I agree with foobaz about having to restart at level 1 all the time. Particularly since the goons can spawn right on top of your friend's path in level 2.

I started to write a comment about bug with buddy stuck in the light and then I noticed first comment... It's morning, I'm just drinking my first coffee so my brain doesn't work much yet, but anyway this really needs to be told to player.
Goons spawning on top of your friend ruinned the game for me.

description: The first game I have ever made to completion.
author: Arron Fowler
title: Anti Puck
comments: Controls seem a bit sluggish, but it's a very nice concept and well executed.
Interesting concept but, I find it really hard to play. I'm struggling to control the turret thingy.

Had problems with the controls on the Original file on Kongregate. I have fixed it. There are power ups that make the gameplay easier as you go on. They are random so the gameplay changes quite dramatically for each time you play.
I liked the concept as well as the neat tron graphics but I found the game very hard to play.
So the basic thing here is that it's good to have deceleration faster than acceleration, especially when acceleration is large (otherwise the player just loses control too quickly).
The question then is how you do this, when the player's velocity is in a completely different (and arbitrary) direction to the force the player controller is applying.

description:
They've been experimenting on you! You feel...strange.
Evil Government(tm); are trying to wipe you off the face of the earth. You need to escape!
Get your blood pumping, the adrenaline might unlock your sinister new potential....
author: TheGrieve
title: When I Was Human
comments: Wow I really love the dna unlocking system. The music is great too and I can't wait for Story Mode.

One complaint would be that whether the game is impossibly hard or ridiculously easy seems to be entirely up to the random level generator. Also super speed actually makes the parts of the game that require precise jumping *harder*.
In any case, really cool game, and I love the atmosphere of the whole thing. Looking forward to the post-compo edition.
Awesome game, well worth a go! Certainly distinct from most of the other entries!
Very nice. The ability unlocking is a nice feature. The odd difficulty/impossibility spike but I think it adds to it.
Not sure I've ever seen checkpoints in a survival mode, not sure that it works though either.

Interesting, seems to demonstrate there's a lot you can do with the canabalt concept that hasn't been explored that I've seen. I liked how there seemed to be explicit "puzzles" here and that some of the power ups (like cheetah mode) hurt more than helped you.

Small things: The fact distance could kill you was not well telegraphed, the checkpoints remembering that you've lost health seems a little mean, it seems odd the game seems to go out of its way to give you "easy" stretches to build up distance but then as soon as you die you seem to lose all your distance?

My intention with the power-ups is story-bound, in that whatever modifications have been made to the player character might not all be for their benefit. (Thus cheetah mode being a double edged sword)
Also, you only lose life when hit by the bombs, the intention here being that pitfalls only serve to bring you back to the checkpoint - closer to the bombs.
Your comments are much appreciated and definitely will help me with my post-comp updates. Thanks again!

I think mixing health and checkpoints like that is a bit weird. health should refil when respawning- I don't know why I should get a game over when running out of hearts vs just respawning for falling off a building.. it makes falling off preferable to being hit, which I think is the wrong way round. anyway, it was pretty good fun :)
oh, on a small note: I think putting a hole right after the speedup powerup is pretty cruel!
It's weird how right after the player gets a speed boost, the level design becomes more about nimble jumps. Luckily there were some wide open spaces to run in after that.

The level generation runs off three sets of level segments, initially all segments are pulled from set 1, levels designed for slow methodical play. Once you unlock Frog, levels are pulled from the set 1 and set 2 pools, with set 2 containing larger jumps only possible with Frog.

description:
You are an adventurer who had the bad idea to plunder a cursed temple.
The wall begins to close on you. You have to escape... But even in this situation, you want to satisfy your greed an take as much treasure as you can!
Good Luck =)
Edit : I just realized that you need an effect to open the .cap
it's here http://dl.dropbox.com/u/23551572/LD21/Textured%20Lerp%20Tinting.fx
Code Construct Classic
Sound Design : Sfxr & Audacity
Music : freeplaymusic.com
author: Yann
title: Walls of Darkness
comments: Interesting, but VERY short. I like the music!
Also it seems like changing the difficulty doesnt make much of a difference.
Yep, I didn't have time to make other levels. I wanted to make the game look pretty.

Changing  difficulty change the timing between the start of each raw of walls. In this regard the gap between too easy and unbeatable is really narrow (if you try to get all the treasures). Maybe I should use another parameter hmmmmmm...
I like the concept, but the controls felt oddly stiff and fiddly, which made the last 'room' with holes feel very frustrating. The graphics and audio are nice :)

Yeah I used the default grid movement behavior of construct classic, next time I'll code my own movement 'cause indeed, this movement is too sensible (one quick touch may move the character for two grid square instead of one) and pressing two keys at the same time stop the movement.
I got used to it but it's not that good anyway.
Graphics and audio are great. I like how the music conveys a sense of urgency. The pits were to hard to distinguish from the walls though.
Aside from stopping when you try to go diagonally, it's a solid entry!

description:
READ POST MORTEM HERE FOR DETAILS :
http://www.ludumdare.com/compo/2011/08/22/untitled-escape-semi-post-mortem/
Arrows/WASD to move and jump
Space to allow walking during text
E/Right Ctrl to USE items or signs
Left Click - Place D.I.S.C
Right Click - Relocate to D.I.S.C
R - Reset position if you get stuck
This entry is not complete, but has tutorial levels. I took my time and aimed for personal goals instead and I am pretty happy with the results.
I plan to finish some levels and submit a jam version as well, but I figured I would leave the working gameplay + mechanics here as a peg of progress that I did finish in the 48 hours.
NOTE - If it crashes on startup, it has a problem with the audio. Plugging in a MIC usually fixes it. I will fix this asap.
author: FuzzYspo0N
title: Untitled Escape
comments: Dark on foreground tiles on a dark background? Not a good mix. Pity the controls aren't great - I really liked the D.I.S.C. mechanic.
There are some cloud layers of parallax and skylines that never made it into this version. There was also day time skies but yea the dark on dark was noted..
The controls are obviously a mess, something i plan to fix first anyway.
Crashes on startup, with no warning whatsoever.
Hempuli, I added a note about the crashing. please try that while i attempt a quick fix!
I'm digging the concept here, and see it working as more fully-developed game.  Nice job!

description:
A JavaScript/HTML5 adventure.
Move with ARROW-KEYS. There's NO other keys needed to solve the game. Just "touch things" to interact.
If you get STUCK in the first room, I have a small hint @
http://ippa.se/webgames/the_escape/spoiler.txt - It's not hard to figure out though :).
Works in all major browsers -
Chrome 12+, Safari 5+, FireFox 6 (and down to 4.0 I think) and IE9.
Do you make/love low-fi/pixel/retro games too? Add me https://plus.google.com/114411714248998389818/posts
author: ippa
title: The Escape
comments: Didn't get anywhere - but it plays nicely!

enjoyed this a lot! I think it's a great plan to have a very simple game mechanic and spend your effort creating a big and diverse play area like this to explore. the silouette gives you enough of an idea about the level and what things are, but it's nice and easy to create too. very clever
I managed to finish it :-D (I loved the outro tune).
The graphics were really clever, tho I would have worked on the color palette choice a little more.
What really impressed me was the sound design, it's known that HTML5 audio support is crappy at best, yet you made it so i tought i was playing a flash game. Simple but simply amazing.
I just adore games like this.
Good gameplay and feel and the music adds a nice ambiance.
My biggest criticism is that some of the jumps are pretty brutal to make and others where you have to just guess right or fall into a pit of lava.
I didn't manage to finish, but I did enjoy this game. Especially nice since it was made in JS and I don't like that many JS games.
The music and one color background helped create an effectively creepy ambience.
The jumping puzzles were tough but fun. I really felt like a mountain climber trying to find the next position for my foot.

I felt like if it had been done in flash it might have been a bit smoother and maybe some lighting and smoking effects for the background could have been added which probably wasn't really feasible with JS.
@Daniel X. Moore: there actually is a way of Not having to guess ... :].
@sfernald: JS is crazy fast nowadays, I could have done more. But first day was lost due to a servercash, so I basically did this in 10 hours. I also kind of like the minimalism of the gfx :).
What FPS did you get? It's very smooth here in Chrome.
Good fun :) I enjoyed the jumping puzzles, I thought they were quite fair. I really liked how you solve the first room, too, very tactile, felt like I was properly breaking out.

My FPS were very high, FYI. @ ippa: I could be wrong, but I think you do need to guess with the REALLY big jump/fall. Haha, I guess I could look at the map PNG? I can't imagine that's what you meant...? Anyway, I really enjoyed it, although I agree that the jumps can be pretty brutal. But the controls are good enough so it's not unfair.
Awesome, I'm really jealous of your level design skills!
I really like the design and music. Congrats!

Awesome stuff, I like the pixel-perfect platform physics, they were used really well, and the no-nonsense monochrome graphics makes for an interesting visual style mixed with a very tight platform challenge.
Twitchy pixel jumping, but still much easier than I would have thought. Really nice atmospheric music, great imaginative level design. Reminds me of Knytt a bit. :)

description: I really need to sleep now, have fun :)
author: khahem
title: Squirrel's Life
comments: I don't even think that life of a squirrel is so complicated!
Being chased by other squirrels is awesome. It needed some sound to complement it.

I would've liked to have seen the ability to move up and down, high scores (even if just local) so I can compete, or even just showing the score when you die, a simple death animation (it took me a while to figure out what was killing me). On the plus side, it was really easy to figure out what the keys were. The UI was nice.
269.5 This is a nice and simple game. I like it!
Good god, the death-messages are depressing. It's now just "you are dead" but "you died MISERABLY".

I needed a few tries before understanding the "obstacles", and I did not get the point, but after a while it was fun to get the whole line of squirrels trying to follow me. I'm still not sure what the point is, but who cares :)

description:
You are a small, poorly animated spaceship moving through poorly drawn space. You have been trapped in a grid of forcefields. You have but one option. ESCAPE.
Use the arrow keys or WASD to move. Once moving, you will not stop until you hit a forcefield. Press ESC or P to pause. Good Luck.
author: jacquies
title: Space Escape
comments: I like the simple idea. Adding some sounds would be fine, but the puzzles are entertaining without them anyway! :)
I gave up at level 9. What johnfn said, too. And we liked it :)
It was quite fun. And the puzzles were intelligently designed.
Pretty good fun. A nice remake of a classic sort of puzzle. I got to level 13 before I stopped playing. Would be nice to see some innovation here.
Good puzzle designs.   Butt Ugly, but fun.
Simple but clever puzzles.  I missed some music and sounds.
Would have loved some low-fi sounds with this one. :) I got stuck on level 13.

description:
You are trapped at the North end of a mysterious complex of connected rooms. Everywhere are mindless savages with a taste for violence and loot. You have only one last hope: Southward lies escape.
Coded with Flixel, arted with GIMP, sounded with bfxr + a mic, musicked with FL Studio and Kontakt.
Controls
Arrow keys: Movement
Space: Interact with doors and loot
Escape: Proceed from menu screens
M: Mute/Unmute
(There was an element of UK riot inspiration in the initial concept, but I lost my shot at high brow when I started barking like a dog into a microphone.)
author: PaulSB
title: Southward Lies Escape
comments: Gets a little repetitive; more variety and a minimap would have been awesome.
It is a clear goal and really easy if you are into games where you avoid obstacles.
Most people are telling me it's too hard so that's good to hear :)
Very cool atmosphere. The music really added to the creepiness. The pitch black rooms were especially good :p
I enjoyed the audio and graphics style, gave a scary atmosphere. Thee rooms looked too similar for me to go and visit all of them.
This game has a great dark atmosphere, but is a little too repetitive. I didn't really feel like I was progressing until I suddenly won. It's still pretty nice, with great graphical style.
The background music is awesome! I would like to have a minimap.

Has a very nice and creepy atmosphere. Although when I played it I didn't know it I was progressing or not. Throughout my playthrough I was asking myself if I should just stop playing as there were no clear indication if I was doing good or not.
Very cool graphics and sound. The whole experience was vaguely upsetting, which is to say I enjoyed it greatly :)
I like the asthetics, they're quite unique.

description:
:3
four hours.
press z,
and also another super-secret button.
author: skankparty2
title: Skank
comments: lol, I can't figure out what is happening!
What is meant to be going on here?
Wasn't quite sure what to do in this. Button mashing occasionally made the white guy fling something red to the dog thing. But I couldn't get more than that. Sorry. :(
Nooo! Descending bunny slippers from the heavens!!! I repent!!
I always like a nice cup of WTF! :-)

description:
Z = jump, X = fire
I coded this on a friend's computer, so if there's a weird @author comment in a source file I've overlooked, that's why. All assets and code are my own.
author: NMcCoy
title: Planetary Mission
comments: Not bad! Smooth gameplay and I finished at just the right timing, so your pacing is good.

I was confused with the startup that it puts you on that screen, and don't really understand the story or why I have the end time that I did. Or the artifact rating. I guess it's a parody of MegaMan or something? :P
Fantastically solid platformer, nice to play thought the hit box for the player seemed a bit off.
Notionally, this is the very last segment (i.e., post-last-boss escape sequence) of a fictitious NES-era Metroid knockoff, being played on an emulator.
Awesome, I love the idea behind this one. Great fun too!
Physics are a little slippery. I kept falling off the platforms.
Wow, this is a good game. The graphics and audio were great given the time constraint.
That was awesome! A great bite-sized little game!
The intro was great, at first I thought you had accidentally uploaded a partially completed debug build or something. After the game, I understood the tongue-in-cheek stats screen. ;)

Audio was excellent, gameplay was solid, I finished with LITERALLY one second left so the timing was obviously very well tuned. My only complaint is that controlling the player in mid-air was a bit uncomfortable, and made some platforming sections frustrating. I got used to it though, and it didn't detract from gameplay.
Haha, nice little parody. Strange, but fun and functional. Controls were kind of floaty.
When you land you seem to slide a block in whatever direction you were moving in (unless you're pressing to move the other way), making it hard to accurately land on the smaller platforms.

Awesome all-around - I had trouble getting used to the slippery controls though, I felt like I was sliding off platforms and taking forever to stop on the ground.  Other than that, I loved the chain reaction effect and the music and visuals made for a fun escape sequence.  I was also confused about the startup screen, but I see that explained here in the comments and I like the idea a lot.  Nice job!
Nicely done! The artefact rating confused the hell out of me, but the basic gameplay was awesome!

description:
Come on, come all! Witness MANGORE, the MAGNIFICENT! A Death-defying stunt!
Secured by iron locks and put in a watery container! Failure means a CERTAIN DROWNING DEATH!
How to play:
Use the keyboard buttons to escape.
Credits:
Art: junkboy
Code: Mammy
SFX & Music: surasshu
author: Fountain
title: Mangore
comments: really nice presentation but i'm totally mystified about how to escape.
You had me eluded for a while...not anymore! I am the great escape master :)
After escaping it crashes chrome. But it is plain awesome.
This is the best presentation of this joke that I've seen on the site.
I also got the crash on chrome, but well done.
I noticed that keyboard keys have some effect. What other active keys are there?
Looks great and rates high on humor, I'm not too sure I would really call it a game though.
Same Firefox crash. Oh man, that was funny though.
Couldn't really get it to work in firefox or I didn't get it. pressing the keys didn't seem to do anything and then it kinda crashed.  Tried refreshing but it that didn't help.

description:
Sadly I ran into some technical problems right when I thought it was finished. I didn't have time to fix them. There is a chance it might lag horribly for no reason. I hope this doesn't affect too many PCs.
Run it by double-clicking run.bat
author: Hook Jones
title: Grappling
comments: First time I ran it I spawned inside the ground XD A fun game - good platform movement. But I died when I ran into what I think was the lag problem you mentioned - a sudden slow down and then speed up as if it was catching up with itself

Oddly fun! The hint that the boulder would kill me made me laugh. Also it looked a bit like a giant cookie, but the game crashed when I tried to eat it. I'd have liked to have seen a score (distance traveled) as well as the difficulty getting progressively harder (perhaps the terrain gets more uneven as you go on? Starting out mostly flat?) Graphics weren't bad. If you made the main character a bit cuter or gave him some personality that would add a lot to the theme of the game. i.e. a fedora. Fun game! My son also enjoyed it.

Not that bad. But it's a real shame that the game has no progress in difficulty. I died once or twice - a pity the game just stops, btw - before I had the controls figured out, and once I did, it wasn't that hard to keep in front of the boulder.
The grapple hook line was a wee bit too flexible reducing it's  usefulness.
Not a bad proof of concept. Completely random terrain isn't very exciting though. Need difficulty ramping and variety.
About the game, it was a bit funny bit there was no challenge at all, I kept jump pressed and always escaped from the big rock, also nothing new happened.

About the distribution, the game didn't worked by running run.bat nor jones.jar but after copying native files to the same folder where jones.jar is, it worked. Also, why didn't you released a linux version if you were using java and lwjgl? I tell you that because I use mainly ubuntu and have to restart to windows to test your game to discover it could be played on linux if you put the natives for lwjgl there.
Heh, + humor points for "The boulder will kill you!" Aww, really? I thought we could be friends. :)

description:
It's time to leave your planet -- it's being bombarded by meteors.  You have to escape into space, overcoming your planet's gravitational field by climbing up the piles of meteorites.  The goal is to achieve escape velocity, which gets easier the higher you climb.
You'll need a pretty hefty machine to run this, as it's quite physics intensive.  Also, I only tested this on 64-bit OS X.  More releases to come, though!
P.S. I'm half an hour late, but I started an hour late, I swear!
author: maackle
title: Fall Into Space
comments: Looks interesting, waiting for Windows or Linux port
I'll wait for the windows port, but for the time being i gave you community rating.
I can't get seem to get this to work - unzipping the archives leaves me with a folder with a 'runme' shortcut, but that doesn't seem to do anything.
Same problem as mtthwcmpbll. A Windows port would be nice anyway, though.
Also waiting on a windows port :)
I can't test it because I use 32bit OS X and the binary you've built is x86_64 only.

I really liked this, felt quite etherial (music helped). Gravity getting weaker as you get higher (so your jump getting higher) was cool, but a little frustrating having to wait so long to fall back to the ground again so you can jump). Is there an actual end? I Got into space then it went blue, but nothing happened.

description:
Done in 48 hours.  Simple, too many mini games, so none of them are as high quality as I would like.
OS X: tested on my OS X Lion machine, I don't have a pristine machine to test on, nor an older machine, so I'm only saying it works on Lion.  It _should_ work w/out installing pygame.
Linux: you must have python-pygame previously installed (debian/ubuntu: "apt-get install python-pygame").  you can download the source and run 'python escape_from_the_frame.py' or you can feed the url to 'pip install' and run 'escape'
author: vitae
title: Escape from the Frame
comments: Bubble bursting was kind of annoying. Only got to fourth level each time. Sorry but it crashed twice on me with relatively similar errors.

description:
So I made a one button roguelike. You play as a brave warrior trapped in the dreadful dungeons of dread and have to escape.
Made in XNA 4.0.
author: Momeka_
title: Escape from the Dungeons of Dread
comments: Godd job, great game! The one key system was kind weird and annoying. If it was not for that i would play it for hours. I also wish there was some music.
I agree, single-key control made it feel rather slow-paced. Nice entry anyways :)
Couldn't really see the inspiration behind the one button gameplay, made it much more frustrating. Other than that, I loved everything about it. Very cute submission.
Very fun game, but I agree that the one-button system was an odd choice.  Very good job, though!

Certainly innovative, but not sure how fun it is to wait for the right direction. It can get annoying/boring fast, because a game can have so much depth with 1 button unless it is action packed. Levels are basic and lack more variety. I'm afraid I didn't see it to the end (assuming it's not infinite).
Good game, but would have been much better without the annoying movement controls. I got to level 6.
Also, I would recommend not using installers for LD games as it makes it more difficult to run. Especially when the start menu shortcut is called 'MyGame'. :)
I can't run games that use the "HiDef" XNA profile :( Switch it to "reach" and I'll be able to play it.
Unfortunately, I don't have a video card that supports the "HiDef" profile :'(

description:
Last, Ludum Dare I used only the most basic of canvas operations and things went quite well.  This time I decided to push things a bit by utilising things as if Canvas rendering worked in all respects.
Consequently, The game has issues on browsers.  I'd much rather hit these sort of problems on a Ludum Dare than in a project that my income depended upon.
FireFox 6 on Windows works fine if you have enough memory free.   I have had reports of FireFox 6 on Linux freezing X.  My own Linux box needs to be rebooted if I try this page in Chrome.
Under Windows, Chrome and Opera ran but rendered incorrectly.
As for the game itself,  I had a lot of fun making the time-to-beat runs.  It has quite a difficulty curve. The last level I have not successfully completed.
You can use cursor keys or wasd.  Space to restart if you crash.
author: Lerc
title: Escape from Browser Stability
comments: Fun game, the graphics are pretty amazing.
It works great in the webkit based browser named surf. The game is kind of resource hungry though.
Absolutely fantastic game. Well done! (also, how on Earth did you do the first level in 19 seconds!).

Decent game but this is why Canvas/JS isn't ready for primetime. Flash gives consistent performance over different browsers. When Canvas/JS can do these (which may be never considering the history of standards compliance)
Good implementation. Graphics are pretty cool. Needs some innovation though to differentiate from all the other "floaty ship maze" games.
Interesting graphics, could do with something more to keep it interesting though.
The framerate seems very choppy in chrome.

description:
This is my entry, it's called "Dream Path". Go play! :)
The concept of the game is that the protagonist is locked in her nightmares and needs to find a path out. Simple as that. It contains 16 puzzle levels, should take maybe 30 minutes to solve them all.
The game looks quite bad in the screenshots, but I'm pretty happy how it looks "live" once it's animated. Also, the whole atmosphere I think is what went well this time.
On the gameplay side itself, it turned out to be a really easy game, and I had a hard time building puzzles that aren't obvious. And I'm not at all happy with monster gameplay. It would be interesting to know if some better level designer could pull better levels out of the mechanics. So all in all, the gameplay side this time is a bit of a dissapointment.
Overall I'm happy with what I came up with this time, considering I had such a hard time with it on the first day. Happily it all came together on the second day (altough the game is no where near what the original concept was).
Programmed with Flash Develop, graphics drawn in Photoshop with Wacom and sounds done with Audacity + microphone + sample library.
Source is a bit of a mess, but it's available if anyone cares.
author: gimblll
title: Dream Path
comments: Nice idea, the way to move from one to another is a little non-obvious. I'd give the player a trail on the first level to give them a hint, as it also looks a little like it could be a loading screen. Might also want to speed up player movement a tad. Well made, looks good, fun to play. Makes you think a little bit, but not hard.

Very cool idea, but as the person said below, the controls are not obvious. This might turn away a few people because they won't know how to play the game. I managed to figure it out by clicking the screen haphazardly. Anyway, I really liked the concept and overall feel of the game. How did you make the soundtrack?

Yeah, the controls could've been more obvious. It's vague on purpose, that you have to find out what to do yourself but the biggest mistake I made in hindsight is that holding down your mouse button on the dots don't give you any feeback. That would've probably made it more obvious. But what can you do, it's too late now. :)

The soundtrack was made by mixing all kinds of weird sounds in Audacity, slowing them down and using some random filters. The idle soundtrack has at least rain, nails scratching on things, breathing, some kind of a faint chorus type of track and heart beat mixed together. The moving sound has some more brighter bells and such. That's about it.
I really wish I could have "drawn" the whole level path in one go in addition to moving one space at at time. Atmospherically it's very charming.
Faster draw would be nice... also I had some problems on the second level when there were two paths I could take (either correct) and it would only let me take one... the atmosphere is great.

I voted nearly 20 games so long and this has been the most engaging and complete game. Very simple but very good graphics and audio combination and a good amount of levels. Very well balanced. Congratulations! Maybe a little hint on how to pay at the beginning could add.
Cool graphics, and the puzzles were quite difficult but not frustrating. Really liked the atmosphere. Good job!
Not my type of game but it looks really polished. Nice graphics, audio and atmosphere..
Absolutely loved it. The art, sound and puzzle designs were great. Really really enjoyed this.

Neat! The animated sprites look great, and I liked how the game basically taught me how to play. My only complaint is the  constant crackling and static in the soundtrack. Kind of gave me a headache. Otherwise: well done!

description:
Step into the shoes of an amateur escapologist and master two illusions!
Directional keys to attempt Escape during Illusions.
M to Mute/unMute audio.
Escape for Help during Illusions.
Still burning a candle for Harry (1874-1926)
author: Dark Acre Jack
title: Dark Acre Jack's "Escapology"
comments: See the 'Web' link for OSX/Win standalone builds and source.  Thanks.

It's a nice idea, theme-wise. It's pretty fun, despite it's simple gameplay, but it's really short (although pretty much all Ludum Dare games suffer from that). You can replay it, but it gets boring after a few tries. It could really have used difficulty settings and whatnot, for a bigger challenge.
The graphics, being 3D and animated, were obviously pretty elaborate for a 48-hour competition. The Audio was pretty satisfactory. Good work, overall.
The theme and execution are quite unique. The only other time anything came close to this was in Spliter cell 2 :-)

Very original idea for the escape theme. Good looking game too. If only there were more scenarios! Great thinking though, definitely one of the more original games I've seen. Just needs more scenarios and gameplay devices.
Great idea, but slightly disappointing minigames. Excellent presentation though, very polished!
Hah! I had fun. Loved the intros and outros. I'd have benefited from a way to review the instructions; both times I forgot what I was supposed to be doing due to poor reading comprehension.

Thank you everyone for the feedback thus far!  I completely agree that a dozen more escape tricks would make this at least 11 times better, and by the time the deadline loomed I knew that, at best, the result would be more a demo of a much larger game.
Oh, and if you do miss the instructions ESCAPE during an Illusion attempt will pause and bring them back ;) Cheers!

I'm an amateur magician and I adored this. I'd atually love to see this develop into a fully fledged "magic act" game. Link those rings, pull that rabbit from the hat, saw that woman. This fits the theme of the competition though and was fun as heck.

description:
You wake up somewhere without knowing what happened. (Not original, but it works.)
Make with Ren'Py - Python framework for Visual Novels.
author: SusanTheCat
title: CRS Escape!
comments: I always forget to give credits:
That was neat, and I think I won, but is there a better ending?
Thanks for playing! Only one good ending.  Bad endings: Drowning, Asphyxiating, Imploding

I think you did a good job with this. The graphics were really good, and the mood and tone were very well-executed, but I felt like I was a rat in a maze. It was a bit disorienting to move around the facility. Clicking on the map would be a lot easier.

It felt like an old sierra game where I couldn't figure out the correct solution without dieing a bunch. When I finally got the correct answer I felt like I was climbing over the corpses of my previous attempts.
Interesting but it was hard mentally mapping the locations to the map without any directional cues
Thanks for the input.  I think you're right -- clicking on the map would have been better.

I haven't played a ton of visual novels (although I like interactive fiction, a la Inform/Zork/etc.) but this was fun. The art had a nice hand-drawn look and I enjoyed wandering around the zones wondering where I was and what had happened. Figured out how to escape after a few tries.

It would have been nice to have a few more zones, and maybe for things to be a little bit less symmetrical. I am still curious who "the woman" was. It might be interesting to have the Raccoon be able to read some things for instance. Some of the audio was much louder/harsher than the music, so maybe it could be normalized a little bit?

I originally was going to have the lab be bigger, but then common sense took over and told me to make it something smaller that I could actually draw all the backgrounds for and not have to worry about all my maps links. :)
Currently all the rooms are hand coded.  But I think making a "level editor" for renpy could be doable.
I was thinking of having video surveillance that the raccoon could access so that the player would get more background as to what happened.

description:
*Updated to correct version! You can ignore my comment below.*
*There were problems with the google docs download, so I also uploaded it to MediaFire. The dl link has changed to reflect the new upload.*
*If you have issues running the game, and have not ever played an XNA game before, use this link to dl the framework: http://www.microsoft.com/download/en/details.aspx?id=20914
WASD to move, left mouse to fire both turrets, z and x to fire them individually.
GUI is pretty self explanatory. Black hole kills you, but get close to it for an energy recharge bonus. At 300 energy you are able to jump to lightspeed and win the game by escaping the black hole. Drones kill you. Moving and shooting use energy.
Press m to mute the music while playing.
TimeLapse: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zvGRF3jEGgU
1814 lines of code, for those of you who care. :D
author: Bloodyaugust
title: Black Hole
comments: DON'T DOWNLOAD YET! THIS SUBMISSION WAS SCREWED UP BY THE SYSTEM.

The idea of trying to conserve power, but doing anything uses it is a good idea, but I felt there was a lack of balance. Shooting and getting hit used waaaay too much energy compared to what I was getting from the black hole. After about 10 tries, I couldn't find a strategy that worked. The graphics left some ambiguity as to what the front of the ship was, and the enemies didn't really look like ships, more like boxes.

It's a really good idea, but the execution was lacking. I would definitely say keep working at it beyond the 48 hours though. Maybe add in some kind of upgrade system, and try to make the game progressively harder, as opposed to being as hard as it is upfront.

I'm glad you liked that, it was my main concept from the get go. And yes, I'm getting ready to write a post-mortem actually, with all the things I've done since the compo ended and the things that I plan to do.

Also: I agree completely with your assessment of the difficulty. I ended up half-implementing a scaling difficulty system, but trashed later on. It is kind of telling that I have yet to manage to beat my own game...
As for the graphics, the ship was a definite brain-fart. The enemy ships were supposed to be akin to Borg, I called them Drones.
Upgrades and power-ups are also in the works.
The download link leads me to a google docs zip, and I don't want to download every file individually. Is there a better way? Could you upload to mediafire maybe?
Click file, then download. It makes everything dl at one time.
However, I did add a mediafire upload. :D
I will try to come back to this game, but it didn't seem like it would be easy to get it working under Mono/WINE on Linux. Too bad, looks neat :(
That's very unfortunate! :( I'm working on a port to Unity, so I'll let you know when that happens.

Tough old game. Could definitely do with some polish and work on ramping up the difficulty in stages. A greater variety of enemies, powerups and a nice "sucking" black hole effect and I could see this being rather popular. Nifty.

description:
Help the poor yellow ball escape the prison guarded by evil mean guards!
It's a top down 2D-turned-to-pseudo-3D game in which you control a little yellow ball through a complex filled with bad guys. You can only see things that aren't blocked by other things, so you can't see past walls. A compass tells you the general direction to move to.
There are 4 difficulty modes. The fourth mode, plague bearer, changes the game a little bit. As a plague bearer, if you touch an enemy that is not aware of you, then he will die. Make it to the end as a plague bearer and you will earn a virtual cookie for being awesome because I haven't finish it yet that way!
I've committed so many sins while writing this game. It's unbelievable. Beware of the source code.
Enjoy!
author: Frib
title: Abstraball
comments: The music was great, but more the color chosen than the graphics ruined any atmosphere. Good game, i wish the graphics motivated me a little more.

yeah I didn't focus at all on the graphics. Part of it because of how I built the LOS effect, which I should've built differently for a much better effect with more freedom to slap textures on it. I learned my lesson with that. Thanks for the feedback though, and I'm glad you like the music :D
If you had to choose the colors, which would you have chosen?
Actually, the colors were fine. The visuals were spot on since blur a blind corner with the wall was the most innovative part of the game.
It made the game feel like a real escape as opposed to some of the other entries. Good work here.

I would have chosen any color but with more constrast between them or some outlines maybe. But that is just my personal taste. I just hink the plain graphics influenced.. Good work on that ilummination effect!

Interesting concept with stealth game potential. It's not very fun gameplay-wise though to sit in a corner listening for footsteps. Then again it is miles more realistic this way, and creates unique atmosphere. I have mixed feelings :P The guards are not real enough to feel emotional threat as opposed to just colliding and getting fail game state. LoS implementation is cool, but polish and actual texturing beneath it could make this much more.

I think this game is a great exploration of what kind of gameplay is possible in this style. Better graphics would help tremendously, but in 48 hours you have to prioritize, and I think you focused on the right things. This concept is definitely worth pursuing further.
Sadly I couldn't play it, it fails for some reason and xna installer says I have it already installed so I dunno what could be happening.

description:
Follow Trevor, the lead singer of Hedge Social, as he makes his way through a hipster's worst nightmare - vintage clothing shops, coffee parlors, used record stores have all closed forever! Oh and there's a zombie apocalypse too, but the coffee parlors!!
[FOR WINDOWS USERS: just download the zip, and run escape.exe]
author: 8bitmuse
title: I was  a teenage Hipster!
comments: So, Linux version coming later? Escape.exe crashes :(
I used py2exe to convert these from their original python files, I'll see if it supports Linux as well. Either way I'm hoping to port it to Linux/Mac asap :)
Fatal Python error: (pygame parachute) Segmentation Fault
This application has requested the Runtime to terminate it in an unusual way.
Please contact the application's support team for more information."
Hey summaky, it's most-likely due to a missing dll, I went through and added any dll's which could be critical. Are you running linux?
Looks fun, but can't get it to run on OSX.

Decently done, but controls take ages to get used to for isometric viewpoint. Levels get repetitive quick, lacks more mechanics/variety. Power pills also always happen to be right on the way to the exit and not a challenge to get. Besides score, not much motivation to get all the pills. I like the "heads" as characters. Music for a "zombie" game could have been a little heavier, but it's still good.
Seems to almost work on linux if I just download both source and windows asset (I already have pygame). I had to comment out

description:
Moved to jam because it's been updated kinda heavily content wise and I'd rather you look at that than what I had <24 hours ago.
Still no sound, hahah.
Made a lot of tweaks to the editor and UI in general. An about page might be nice later I guess.
Tutorial still isn't a tutorial, I got sidetracked making the editor more bearable and including instructions in-game because everyone ignores readmes. I'll add some instructions to the tutorial later on if I get time for some postcompo work.
Again:
Arrows To Move.
Down To Use Keys.
--------------- ORIGINAL NOTES ----------------
Going to call it a night. There isn't a level progression there as I've run out of time, but I'm pleased with what is there.
Arrows To Move.
Down To Use Keys.
ReadMe for everything else ;)
author: Geti
title: Beam Runner
comments: It's kind of fun, a neat concept, although the level design needs a bit of work (and obviously longer). I can skip most of the level sometimes by just jumping over stuff. Also, for some reason the new game button only plays the first three levels and the play button plays the next three. I was almost ready to quit before I tried the play button. Also, there are some major bugs when you load an invalid level (you get stuck and have to refresh) and a minor one when you open a door that a laser has already hit above (it doesn't extend). I also don't see the point of collectibles. Still, quite nice, and I like the style.

Yeah, I was sad at the length, but the engine is solid (which is more than I can say for what I scraped together) and the graphics are eye-catching. VDO and I seem to share an idea of what looks interesting.
