These are the kinds of games LD is about. Short but sweet. I could play like 50 levels of this, so I'm glad there's a level editor.
@Everyone: updated with content and a less shitty editor, haha. Cheers for the feedback.
VDO: the collectibles give you points.
Feels polished, an addictive execution of a straightforward concept. The level editor is a big plus since the game is so short.
very nice concept! love the feeling and graphics. sadly no sound!
Cool game, though it's pretty conventional.  Also, pretty tiny :(

Fun game and a very awesome graphic style that I can't get enough of.  Decent gameplay, short but the editor makes up for it.  Only criticism I can think of is perhaps the lack of any sort of reward for progression or score; levels are not played in a linear fashion and there's no ending (at least not that I encountered).  Overall, all the flaws are made up for with the graphical style and smooth enough gameplay.

I fell in love with your pixel art, just amazing (oddly reminded me of the nes castlevania). And the animation was very well done. I can see where you were heading with it and although it wasn't finished it was going in a solid direction. Only critiques would be that it was difficult for me to see a sense of continuity between the screens. Oftentimes it would feel disorienting to have the game cut from one screen to the next without any sense or what your goal or direction was. Beyond that I love it :D

on of the best art styles in the compo.. really friggin cool to look at. My only gripe is sometimes telling the difference in a hurry between mines and switches is tricky (and you really don't want to make that mistake!). I'd have made switches bright green or something
I like the beams that come down, especially as they blow stuff up.  Nice touch!
Real strong visual feedback. Made up for no audio i think.
Nice one. I like the good-looking, consistent retro graphics, and the controls feel really nice and precise.
Fun. c:  Fast-paced and an editor is a really nice touch given the time-frame.  No real complaints here.
I love the graphics and the gameplay. There's so much you can do, dropping mines, destroying terminals with mines, etc. It's great, and I'd love to see some complex maps.
My only complaint would be the lack of music/sound effects, mainly because I'm a sucker for audio.

Daah! I made two levels and lost them both due to getting confused about the current editor state and hitting Q to go back to the menu. There should definitely be a confirm question there, or ideally store the edited level in memory so you can go back and edit it again from the menu. Not sure if the data string would paste well into a web page though, with that whitespace.

Very charming game though. I could easily sit around and make 20 levels if I trusted myself not to erase them before they were done. The editor could also benefit from better tile selection. Maybe hitting space to bring up a grid of all tiles so you can quickly click to select one.
The graphics are good, the gameplay is solid, and there's plenty of room to expand.

description:
Help a swarm of blobby slimes ESCAPE from the death factory!
Split them apart, join them back together! Jump! Dodge! Die! Infinite fun!
*Update!*
Uploaded a new version, only change being that it's compiled for the 'reach' XNA profile, which allow it to work on most every system. Should have done that before I even started!
Built from the ground up with C#, XNA, and the Farseer Physics Engine.
You'll need the XNA 4.0 Redistributable, you can grab it here: http://www.microsoft.com/download/en/details.aspx?id=20914
This is my first compo, wow what a blast! I am well and truly drained. Lots of fun, though!
Let me know what you think!
- Joe
jvsola@gmail.com
author: tgijsola
title: Slimes!
comments: Really, really challenging. Very pretty, very clever. Good job.
If you get a crash at startup, install the XNA 4.0 redistributable... that should fix it!
Turns out, you might also need the .NET 4.0 redistributable. :shakes fist angrily at microsoft:
It's a bit hard. I'm also stealing your XNA/.NET links :P
hard, but in a challenging way, platformer with a lot of slimes is excellent :)
Looks awesome, sorry I can't play on Linux (it doesn't work in WINE).

I like where you were going with it, but control and collision problems are killing it for me. It seems that the slimes will randomly stop moving on me, refuse to jump, or that the little bullets will kill guys before it actually touches them :(
Just a little too hard for me (bullets are a pain), but hey, controlling many slimes at the same time? Awesome idea! Besides, they're sooo cuuute! :D Good game!
Ha! this is great. And cute. Nice work!
Couldn't get it to work here.
Umm.. did you copy me? You even added the "!" to your games name.
As I explained in email, no. Your game is two years old and completely different from mine in gameplay and style. We share a name, but that's about it!

description:
Sprites made by me in ms paint, game made in game maker 8.
I know I won't win , but just for competition ;)
author: Bogdan
title: Stupid Escape game
comments: funny, but it really felt more like a platformer than a escape game
:D thank you for "funny" hope you like it
Well, it's nothing fancy, but you finished. Congrats! The game definitely could use some polish though.
got it running easily, thats a big plus!
Hmm, feels more like joke game with advertisement for your EpicWorld site ...
Nonetheless, the collision with walls needs works, but I like how forgiving the game is when you die. Overall it could be much harder, the last level doesn't even have enemies. :-?

description:
Hi, this is my first ever Ludum Dare entry, I didn't get as much time as I hoped to work on it but it was good fun. My game is a simple platformer made using XNA, so you'll need XNA 4.0 (http://www.microsoft.com/download/en/details.aspx?id=23714) and .NET (http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/bb203916.aspx).
Apologies if you have to install a bunch of stuff to run the game, if you're unable to play it I've uploaded a video at http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xoRTSst3n3U so you can at least see it in action. Also sorry about my terrible programmer art, the game plays better than it looks!
Controls are:
A and D - move
SPACE - jump
Left mouse - shoot
Tools used:
Visual Studio for code
Photoshop for "graphics"
sfxr and Soundforge for audio
Famitracker for music
author: Mahtiti
title: (No) Escape
comments: I like this, it's a lot better than the screenshot looks. The controls are nice and smooth, although a little buggy when something lands on you. That should probably kill you, because the game is way too easy right now with no noticeable difficulty curve. The gun also seems a bit overpowered, and it feels wrong to have the falling blocks NOT fall when you shoot out the bottoms of them. The music is nice and the game is fun, and I also really like the little tree patterns the block tower makes.
Super sweet! At first I thought the blocks would kill you, so I just started shooting straight up. Then I noticed the lava. Very nice.
I agree with VDO, was expecting blocks to either fall after shooting their support, or something, it does lose its appeal after you get on a good branch.
The best part about this game was without doubt the music, it went along fantastic with the game. Is there some way I can get the music?
I love the "hectic" feel in this. The shaky camera and the music are a big factor. Delightful how the music evolves as you climb.
The responsive controls make the eventual failure feel fair, and that's what makes this game addictive.
Great game, needs to polish a little bit tho.

@Sanguine - The music is included in the source download, but it's split into separate tracks that are faded in as you climb. I've done a quick mixdown of all the tracks though, you can get it at http://www.mediafire.com/?ocg5ec1f9mpcxrt
The mediafire link is giving a 404!
@Shot - Just got a Dropbox link setup, try these:

description:
You must escape from this place
This is a puzzle game. I think it's best if I don't say any more!
Controls:
WSAD/Arrow keys: Move character
Left mouse button: grab and hold the yellow-ish blocks
m: mute sound
r: restart level (this is probably needed on one level)
And only if you are really stumped:
-: previous level
=: next level
Tools used:
Unity (indie version)
Blender
BFXR (http://www.bfxr.net/)
Photoshop
Audacity (to loop a sound from bfxr, this was probably useless as I can do that in unity too)
Warning: I have no idea if the mac version works as I do not have a machine to test it on... Please let me know how it goes.
author: Terra
title: We'd like it if you Stay
comments: I somehow managed to beat the first three levels without using the mouse at all. Not sure if that's intended ^_^.  I liked the visuals though, and I couldn't escape one of the levels at all :(
Heh, not intended, but I can see how it is possible.
Which level did you get stuck on? You can use the '=' key to skip, if you wanted to see the rest, anyway.
Thanks for giving it a go :D

Not too bad.  Good idea, plays okay, graphics all work together well enough.  Objects move a bit weird when dragging them around, which made one level more difficult than it had to be (push the block to push your guy to beat the gate shutting).  Sound got a bit annoying pretty quick.
Yes, improving the dragging(more immediate?) would be one thing I would improve if I ever go back to this game. It is the main mechanic, after all.
I kind of liked that the object movement wasn`t fixed like most sliding puzzles, but the acceleration was slow and made things a bit tedious. I didn`t like the sound.

Ooh, eerie. I liked how you can move stuff both by yourself and with the mouse - that's a neat mechanic. The game was actually pretty creepy, especially since I was playing near midnight in a totally dark room. :) Couldn't quite figure out what happened at the end - some dark scary stuff came and then boom gameover. Still neat!
Mac version works. I got totally stuck on level 3 however and could only get by with the = trick...

Overall it was very neat, actually the concept you came up with turns out to be very similar to the one from my entry. It was interesting to see how the different choices you made from that similar starting point lead to a different game... I liked that you were able to get a story and some "events" in, the moments with the "four blocks" were surprisingly tense given how simple the presentation was and my heart was actually pounding after the game end.

description:
Hi there. Far from my first LD but things did not go so smoothly. Had some other things to do these two days but still managed to sit some 20 hours behind computer.
Sadly only something like 10 were productive.
So, theme was too broad for my taste so I just started working on something I wanted to try for a while, to make a 2D Toribash like ragdoll toy. And I did. Had bunch of ideas how to make it in to an escape game afterwards. In the end went with zero gravity escape as with gravity its probably even more complex to control it then in Toribash lol :D
Used Flash and Box2D . No time and motivation left to do graphics and sounds so pure code only ;/ But it has its own charm, will work more on graphics later :)
<Rant alert>
So it was my worst LD ever ;( Firstly got stuck with some angle calculations(well usual stuff) but then...
- Then my mouse broke ;(
- Then second mouse broke in same way which made me wonder if it is my notebook?!?!
- So I was finishing it in frustration with broken mouse and a touch pad. Considering that mouse is main input method here it was horrible.
- So those 10 hours of trying to figure out what happened with mouse and trying to achieve at least something with touchpad were hours reserved for sounds, graphics and normal level went in to ;/
- Anyways it seems it is biggest LudumDare yet, so I was stuck trying to upload at 4Am until my own internet went down completely 0_o, just to add to problems and frustrations. So its actually good that submission was extended 12 hours because of site problems :)
</Rand alert>
So, some strong speech and frustration for me here, but ah well, at least played with things I wanted :D Hope when frustration will goes away will experiment with this more. It should be a fun template for various types of games.
Update:
Added a video to YouTube with me passing this game http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YvdpZ4PiAO0 hope it will help people who never played Toribash to figure some things out, few advices:
- Use space to pause the game and issue many commands at once
- Remember about center of mass when you try to push
- Relaxed parts absorb shocks, stiff ones bounce, so its a good idea to be relaxed when you don't want to bounce, or stiff all parts when you want to push with maximal force
- And it is space, if you are flying in right direction just relax and wait, no need to go crazy and ruin your right direction :)
author: wonderwhy
title: Zero Gravity Escape
comments: Harder than QWOP, Extremely hard to control they guy, I kept accidentally starting a drag box instead of clicking on the joint.
I couldn't figure out how to make any progress in this game world because the controls felt, to me, very chaotic.  Maybe I just failed, but the learning curve seems pretty vertical.
I enjoyed the idea and I thought it was quite original. I found it extremely hard to use the controls as intended however, it almost always tried to drag a box, even when just clicking.
I kept getting stuck in the air without touching anything to help propel myself with. Interesting concept but the learning curve is a bit of a cliff. Could be solved with some easier tutorial levels.
Very interesting concept, I had fun doing flying kicks at boxes, but I didn't manage to beat the level. I think it has a lot of potential though! Very nice ragdoll physics =)
Extremely hard (and the dragbox if you don't click exactly on the joint is annoying), but it's one of the most innovative entries - too bad you hadn't time to polish it up :)

Very original!  I was able to get around 1 corner, but it really took a lot of work - very steep learning curve.  Fewer joints to control and keyboard shortcuts for different joints would have really enhanced gameplay I think.
Wow, that was really hard. There should probably be a less steep learning curve and then it could be really fun

Interesting tech-demo, but not really a game, as it lacks significant gameplay. Didn't make much progress I'm afraid with such difficulty for a 48h game. Controls should certainly be made easier. Realistic join system is fun as a concept, but not really fun to control. After all, we walk without thinking about every muscle :)

description: There is no escape! Escape the hoarding colored boxes and pickup gray spheres for even more score. Click the left mouse button to dash towards the cursor and F4 for fullscreen.
author: sirGustav
title: You can't escape the colors!
comments: Can't hear audio. I played this on wine.

Gets repetitive quick. The red one is a bit over-powered. There is also no way to kill the colors off, you just end up with them all dragging after you. I sort of like the clicking mechanic as opposed to just following the mouse.
3640 ! I like it, the control system is fun... You need skills to avoid those red boxes :-/
Nice concept, and pretty tight controls.  Good work.
really funny but some times it started to run really slow :S
Um, not much "escape" but "avoid" the colors, it seems.  Had trouble adapting to moving by clicking.

description:
Arrow keys to move - avoid hitting things to keep your speed up and stop the lava catching up with you.
NOTE: there's a bug which sometimes causes the game to crash when quitting.
author: Frimkron
title: Volcanowned!
comments: Would be nice if the game wasn't so impossible, One hit and you are dead.
A bit too tough, but the idea escaping on the rocket is nice (also nice title screen:D)
Very intense! I think it would benefit from a long vertical aspect ratio so you can see the lava and rocks and have more time to react.
Keeps you on your toes. I've seen a couple of games with this idea before, but your graphics are really nice, also the increased difficulty helps.

It's very hard and I didn't finish. I did enjoy it though; after several attempts I had one run where I got into "the flow" and felt like my fingers were moving before my brain told them to. That was fun - although I still hit a rock long before the end.
It was really very hard.... and the ending wasn't very rewarding either. But it was fun, in a frustrating way.

description: A game about that magical kind of escape that starts up this time every year, made using the O.H.R. R.P.G. C.E., source code is in .hss format and easily readable with any text editor.
author: GozerGomez
title: Virtual School 2
comments: Not something you usually see as a LD entry. I didn't manage to find endings 2 and 3 though...
Ending 1 was really a surprise. I didn't find the other too, though. :(
I guess it would be hopeless to search the internet for a walkthrough. ^^
But the game is definitely interesting.
Ending 1 of 3? The Cake is a lie! à² _à²

description: Made in Unity by @tompritcharduk
author: TomPritchard
title: You've got the money: Escape
comments: This looks nice, it could have done with some music to create an atmosphere, or even if there was just something chasing you. As it stands it doesn't feel so much like you're escaping because the only indication of a challenge is the countdown clock ticking away.
It works very smoothly and the controls are nice. I'd have loved something in the way of sound effects or music, but eh.
Fun, but not much of a sense of urgency.  Maybe the challenge is to find the way out, but I felt like I was wandering in the dark, but I found where to go with 1 second left!

There's not much challenge, or anything really. It's literally trial and error, without even anything to do in-between, nor even any reason one would have to escape (no cop chase?). Just aimlessly walking along 15 seconds of intersections followed by walking upon an arbitrary square. Seeing as I'm assuming "fun" stands for gameplay, I'll give you a higher rating because at least the controls worked. Even rudimentary sound would have sufficed; even if it was atrocious I could have muted it, and it would have distracted me from the dull, repetitive (and glitchy, what was up with that shadow?) graphics. Sorry if it's all rated so low, but I'm simply telling you how the game played out for me, and the answer is "not very well at all."

Good graphics, kinda repetitive, not enough information is conveyed to the user to help them figure things out. For instance I didn't know if the goal was a goal or some object I should not touch, yellow is not a good colour for conveying that.
Some music would have been nice.
The game itself played smoothly on my computer the driving mechanic had good controls for a top down perspective driving game.
With some luck I ran against a square. Than i was escaped. didnt know that that was the place where to go :P but it is a nice game.
The bright white 'Escape with the stolen money!' message is attention-grabbing and makes it look like something exciting is about to happen.
It would be great if the rest of the game world was also filled with interesting objects and messages.

description: Nowhere near finished, but a worthy first game and entrance. There'll probably be a jam one as well. Just keep heading right. Also, you may occasionly get stuck in the terrain, in which case simply press R or N.
author: Ria
title: VT74: Escape from EEPROM
comments: Liked the style of the game, but sadly I fell through the ground on almost every level, which made it quite unplayable :(
Little bit sluggish, and there are a few places I kept dropping through. Could do with some extra hazards. Quite like  the blue on grey vector aesthetic though!
So, I unfortunately couldn't really beat any of the levels, because I kept disappearing off the map. I think it's a really cool start and could be great, but as of now just isn't complete.
Wow, very nice concept here.  If polished this could do very well as a fun diversion.
I did not quite get it at first. It stated to press F? Though pressing W did way more.
Well not finished at all, but it could work out with a lot of polish and finishing. Sadly no timelapse.
Not very deep gameplay; all I had to do is keep pressing W to move forward.  I was expecting some kind of hazard, and I was disappointed.

description:
Unfortunately, game is not 100% complete.. So it's just a massive zombie survival =)
Controls: Mouse.
author: keenblaze
title: ZOMBEE FLOOD
comments: Fantastic way to make lettering. The game play itself was lacking, but I was really impressed with the saw blade action.
I really like the flocking to spell words.  I think you should keep working on it to get it playable.  MORE ZOMBIES THAN DEAD RISING.
Yeah, cool effects for the lettering, but on replays, it'd be nice to be able to accelerate or skip those.  Fun though.  Best part was the sawblades.
Haha, fantastic startup! The actual game is very tedious, but man the visuals make up for it!
Thanks to all! I know that this is not actually complete game - saws with player control should be a part of gameplay :)
Yeah, the lettering effect is awesome. The game is a little tough though, I survived for maybe 10 seconds - beat that!

The lettering is cool but I think it might work better if the zombies _started_ milling about where they were going to end up and then marched to their destinations... took a while for the letters to resolve which made reloading a little slow. Great 8bit zombies!

That lettering was awesome.  I'm also impressed at how many zombies you managed to get on the screen at once chasing the player. I don't usually like avoider games, but I could see myself playing this if it had more content in it for quite awhile =)
The lettering took a bit too long to get formed, and I couldn't find a way to skip it to get to the actual game.
The crowd lettering was really cool. Unfortunately There wasn't enough gameplay to satisfy me.
LOL @ epic intro. Although I'd prefer more gameplay to the "cutscene". Those saws looked so promising.
I love how the little zombies look and how they all move together. Very clever.  Zombie flocking was cool - especially having them spell out letters.
Just like the others, I like the letters effect. Other than that, there isn't much to see. It would be fun if this was explored further.

author: freeplay4c
title: Wallazoo: Path to Freedom
comments: The link to the game seems to be broken, could you please provide a working link?
Not bad idea, but it doesn't work very well. Especially annoying were characters getting misaligned with the cells after direction switch.

Decent idea for a game but the execution could use work. The 10 second switching with no countdown or anything to signify when it was going to happen made planning hard. Despite everything being laid out grid based, the npc's would sometimes get between blocks, especially if a wall closed on one.
Other than things being stuck between blocks they would sometimes get stuck inside blocks when the intangible walls became solid again. With a little more work it would be quite a game.

Although I like the idea, your implementation isn't very polished nor fun.  I had problems with wallazoos getting stuck in walls and I didn't know how much time was left before the direction switch, which was somewhat frustrating.

description:
YOU have stolen the new prototype VECTOR SHIP from right under the noses of the VECTROX fleet. Pilot your new ship and escape from the VECTROX mothership.
Gameplay Video:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=z060OSbtYVg
Timelapse Video:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YGJxIojWCBA
Requires XNA Runtime.
Includes source & media
Comes with Full Screen & Windowed version. Windowed version runs at 720.
author: black_mage_andy
title: Vector Dash
comments: Not quite varied enough to stay interesting all the way.
A fun, well-designed, but short game. The turrets could be more accurate to add a tactics element to the gameplay.
I like the way it forces me to be stealthy.

The tweaky controls were a little annoying when combined with the ability for one small bullet to obliterate me. Although the leveling and design of the levels and turrets was good enough that it was challenging yet still possible after several very careful tries.
the controls make it quite difficult to navigate accurately :(
Good game, but as seems to be a recurring theme this LudumDare, controls were frustrating.

I suck at this kind of games. Got only to lv 5. I could only reach the last turret of the level a couple of times before dying. It becomes frustrating pretty fast but I really enjoyed those moments of epic win. Overall a really nice game.
I never actually played the game, but I watched a video about it.
The controls are very sensitive and lack strafe-shifting. Inertia is too high too. Otherwise, nice little shmup.

Nicely balanced for an LD entry. Nice smooth controls. Liked the aesthetic, could have used some more varied sound, but most importantly I'd like to see pixel perfect collision detection added/fixed :)
Reminds me of Gravitron. :-) Nice work.

A nice game. Liked the back story. Controls were responsive, but hated them. Thate because the ship controls are Asteroid-like, and I dislike them. Graphically is good, had fun (and rage) while playing it. Audio is a little meh, but gets the job done. Overall a good game =)
This game would be so rad if I had a trackball and could use it like the original classic Asteroids arcade machines had.

I gave up in sixth level after about dozen or so attempts... it was just too hard for me. Otherwise it's quite functional, art code and sounds, but simple (and also probably second most used concept after typical platformer in competition :(
THe game shouldn't be judged on the fact that other people have done something similar. It is simple, but functional rather than complicated and buggy.

Fun little game, I like the clean vector look.  I for one actually enjoy the asteroids like controls, though the acceleration was perhaps a little too quick.  Nice that you were forgiving on the ship collision, but I think I would have preferred if it was actually to the ship shape.
Yea, sorry about that. The forgiving nature of the collisions was not intentional, i just had to approximate as best I could :)

description: Try to escape! That's the only way out...
author: BurnZeZ
title: The Power of Escape
comments: Allright... took me some time before I realized what kind of escape you have on your mind....
I found it surprisingly rewarding :). The music is awesome; you made it with FL studio? In the two-hour time period you mentioned?
I figured it out right away :D
That's some pretty good music too!
That's the second time a game requires me to push the magic key and I couldn't find it. Can't believe I fell for it again!
Ah, actually, the songs were made outside those 2 hours. It took about an hour to make them. Yes. FL Studio. :)
Ohh, tricky. I also like the music and walls :-)
What i liked the most was the mortal combat style music :-)
Loved the music. The title is a bit too revealing though. Nice entry nonetheless.

description: The game is barely playable, but in essence you must gather resources from a planet surrounded by flying electrons that attack you, in order to build a spaceship to escape. When you reach 10000 ore, you win. If your base dies, you lose. Buildings require power in order to be constructed. Deflectors DO NOT WORK.
author: Erik McClure
title: The Cloud of Very Angry Electrons
comments: Interesting approach, but I didn't get who was the attackers. I just placed a mine on top of other, because they don't take space. Fixing that, it would make a great game.
I never got building collision to work, sadly. It's a little more fun if you pretend you can't place buildings on top of each other, but alas, things did not go well.

It's really innovative gameplay; it's a shame it's not more complete. I thought the attackers were too small and random to really dodge them. I liked moving a planet though :). On the whole, the game just didn't feel very interactive. You have no feedback on the power system (that I could see) and there wasn't much room for strategy that I saw. The attackers seemed to bother me the least when I just spun the planet in one direction.

I'm thinking of adapting some of the gameplay elements for a more complete game sometime in the future. I wanted to put in a line that designated what a building was receiving power from, but never had time. For that matter your relays can get blown up and the buildings will still function despite technically not being powered.
Seems like it could be a cool idea if developed further, but I'm not sure it's complete enough to be able to tell.
It's a shame the game is unfinished.  As is it now, I just placed the mines and waited until I reached 10,000 ore.  I had no idea that I could move the planet until I read the comments.

description:
You must escape each blueprint by completing the mission objectives which can be found on the blueprint itself. Avoid letting the guards see you or they will give chase. If they catch you, you will die.  You can backstab guards when they are facing the SAME direction as you. Crack open safes and steal the goodies inside. Once you have completed all objectives, make your way to the extraction point where you will escape to the next blueprint.
Controls: Arrow keys
author: recursor
title: The Blueprints
comments: Nice music! I think the game could've benefitted from a few more hazards; currently the game gets a bit tedious quite quickly.
Love the art style, and the guard's noises :p Not sure why the safes are still unlocked after I've died, but it was still difficult nonetheless! Nice work.
Game looks cool, sadly I have Linux here so I won't be able to play and rate it (no Unity available).
Liked the blueprint themeing.  Had issues with the stealth mechanics, it was never really clear why sometimes I failed to kill a guard and sometimes succeeded.  Voice acting was amusing/impressive.
Nice MGS-vibe! (too much text at the beginning however)

So, I actually played this on a friend's OSX computer. Great job! The sounds and voice-overs are good, the blueprint graphics theme is really nice. Some music would have been good I think. Also, it might be good to emphasize the escape part a bit more. Right now it feels like I'm breaking IN, not breaking OUT :) Overall, great job!
Go timelapse. And really great art style and game concept.
Reminded me of The sting. Loved it very much.

Yeah it was tedious at first, but when I got the gist of it, yeah I did not read the txt, it was cool. Liked that the states were kept when dying. Otherwise it would have been nearly impossible for me to get to second level.
Hard, but once I got it, I got it.  Could benefit from a slightly more gentle introduction but I understand how the time constraints wear on the overall scope.
Solid entry, and something to tide me over until Schatz releases Monaco ;)

Hey, I love stealth games! Although I wish the AI would be a tiny bit better - after being discovered all you have to do is running behind a wall. After being back to normal guards don't do anything. But of course this way it's good casual stealth gameplay (even killing the guards works fine!), because you don't start right from the beginning after being hitten.

description:
Incomplete, and the only thing I started with before the start of this event was a Tile class. Also i did use some engine code (game loop) from an old project.
Anyway, only one map, and unbalanced. The idea is you're supposed to stop the 'prisoners'(triangles) from escaping.
Controls:
Menu will pop out of the right, and you just click the tower you want. You can't highlight towers unfortunately and you can't see their range.
Gray Triangles are normal, Yellow are fast and weak, Red are slow but strong, and green are 'bosses'.
After Wave 5, the entities just stop updating, but I'd be amazed if you even bothered.
author: Valeour
title: Prison Break
comments: Even if it's a good development performance, towers and mobs are too classic... And the game is too much unbalanced.
You should had a gameplay mechanism linked to your theme (prison break). For example, the player could have to light up  the level in order to allow the towers to shot the deserters.

The original plan was to make everything dark, and the mobs be invisible unless they got into range of the tower, but I never got that far in the end. And I'm aware it's really unbalanced, and I'm really sorry. I just couldn't be bothered anymore.
Thank you for the feedback though, moocho appreciatedo.
Runs at about 1FPS on my Windows 7 machine, the side bar menu takes about 5 seconds to come out, so it's unplayable for me.
Runs fine here. What we have here is basically a skeleton of a TD, but the engine is solid and works well. Played to the end, too.

description:
Poor Ball is the story of a little girl with dark thoughts, Ball, who tries to put an end to her suffering... It's a game where you have to be reactive and prevent Ball, a small ball, from leaving her house. Ball runs faster and faster and you have to place obstacles which she will bounce off.
Language: C++
Libraries: SFML2, FMOD
author: Fififox
title: Poor Ball
comments: Sad sad ball... it made me laugh a lot when I saw it
This is a nive idea, although somewhat hard.
I like the blurring-effect. Subtle, but effective.

A very innovative but challenging little game. Prevent the ball from escaping by placing blocks. You would need quick reflexes to keep this up for long. My highest record was a paltry fifteen seconds after ten or so tries.
I get the concept and the execution technically worked but it just doesn't speak to me at all.
Alas my mouse aiming reflexes are not that sharp, and I could only keep ball in the house for 30 sec. Still it was a very interesting game.
This would even be really hard to play with a lower ball. Couldn't get pass 10 seconds.
Nice game, although it doesn't motivate very long.
Perhaps you could try some variations, like a ball with gravity, or drawing lines instead of just placing boxes.

Interesting concept, but I'm not sure it can survive on mouse-clicking reflexes alone. A target trajectory for a short distance might help. Some feedback of when a placed brick disappears would help. I also like the drawing lines idea.

The game is cool. I just wanna hug that ball... Maybe marry her, and have kids (wait what?)... Moving on... The wait the ball bounces off the blocks doesn't feel quite right to me... I like the idea, but it should be worked out more. The tunes are well fit by the way =)

description:
WARNING: LOTS OF COLOURS AND FLASHING LIGHTS.
Let me take the time to invite you to escape reality for a while, sit back, be mesmerised, and allow you to guide the music along it's path to creation - with visuals intensifying to match. My experiment for this LD was Procedural Music.
To guide the music, you must avoid the red blobs, but attempt to collect the blue and green blobs. One will increase the chord complexity, and the other the progression complexity.
Controls are WASD to move, Esc will exit, and F1 will reset the game.
This is my second entry using my own engine, Psybrus. All engine code used is based on what was located at https://github.com/neilogd/Psybrus at the start of LD.
All game code is written in GameMonkey (http://www.somedude.net/gamemonkey/). See the .gm files in "Dist" for all the game code. For some idiotic reason I decided to lump everything very hackly into "game.gm". There you will find some horrific game code, along with the music generator. Hopefully I will get the time to clean this up, and improve upon it as there are so many avenues of music generation I wanted to explore, but didn't have the time to :(
author: neilogd
title: Lost Psyche
comments: I like the idea and the music, but due to the 2d objects in 3d space thing going on it's really hard to accurately judge depth and to hit the right colors for that reason. Still, cool concept for 48 hours.
Very hard to play. Couldn't get the hang of it.

I love procedural audio generation, this was quite a cool idea. I agree with the previous poster, it was very difficult to judge where I was at. Eventually I figured out that there was a crosshair, but even with that everything moved too quickly to really get into the groove.
Great concept, and good execution on the music generation!

I was balancing this game to make it playable with pretty heavy sleep deprivation...and it became quite easy to me. I guess that's what I get for spending the last couple of hours tweaking gameplay in the competition :( Totally needs some improving, and possibly slowing down the graphics a touch to give you more time to respond.

Really like that you're experimenting with procedural music, and the visuals are totally trippy (in a good jeff minter esq way). however, i had real trouble judging the note directions which kind of got in the way of my enjoyment of the game.
Nice idea, but it is quite hard to play.
The triangle doesn't centre on the screen and it's hard to judge depth. A good idea, but needs some touching up.
Cool stuff! Looks like Audiosurf! It's kind of hard tho and needs a seizure warning :P
Trippy, but hard to play. Kind of stretching the theme a bit aren't ya? ;)
Primitive and abstract. I liked it but most people would expect more. I know a VJ Toy when I see one! Nice effort. :-)

description:
+-------------------------7
/  Mission: Earth Escape  /
/-------------------------+
- History
In the future earth is overrun with pollution. It was the bad kind of pollution! Something had to happen for mankind to survive!
Scientists quickly discovered the solution. Humans had to move to other planets.
To do so surveying is needed, and most likely terraforming to make the environment suit the fragile human.
- Mission: The Earth Escape!
- You
You are the spaceship pilot! Haven't you always wanted to captain a terraforming delivery rocket?
Your main job is to avoid crashing into planets, and also keeping tabs on fuel economy
- Missions
Recog: Fly around planets to gather data. The closer you get the more detailed info you can get, which means more money! When you can't get more, press escape or crash.
Terraforming: Slam your spaceship(you included) into the planet marked with a white rectangle. The faster the more material you'll displace, which means more money!
- Controls
Mouse wheel controls zoom level.
G toggles gravitational field visibility.
WASD controls spaceship
Green gauge shows fuel level
Red/orange gauge shows grav. force
- Technology
Code: Object Pascal
(FreePascal Compiler)
Using ZenGL as a framework
Sound: None. There's no sound in
space... :)
GFX: Paint.Net
Dependencies: OpenGL+GLU(It should most likely work straight away if compiled on Linux or OSx)
author: Laksen
title: Mission: Earth Escape
comments: Entertaining game, i like the basic concept and the look of it. To bad there is no sound. A bit short as well unless i've missed something. Can you upgrade everything to level 10 after the first mission?
Nice concept! You have to get insanely close to those planets to keep your money up.
The uppermost item on every menu is missing for some reason (maybe it's just me?), but the game was still perfectly playable. :]

The concept is certainly interesting, but some things don't make sense; like why do I have to pay for engines and brakes again? Surely I should only have to pay for fuel and upgrades? With some tweaking it could be way more fun.
When I saw the screenshots and read the title I panicked a bit thinking we had the same thing going. In a way our games tell two sides of the same story.

Oh wow, Pascal! Love the concept. Simple, and even graphics are cute. Not sure how exactly upgrade works and why I even get money for flying close to planets/stars. Also lol @ "There's no sound in space... :)"
Very interesting. One of my original ideas for this contest was tentatively called "Escape from Earth" and was somewhat similar to this :)

Flying around the planets was pretty fun, but I thought it was a little confusing how you're supposed to "end" your missions (having ESC say "Mission accomplished!" was the most confusing). Great idea, though!
Annoying how running out of juice leaves you going straight with no option but to hit 'ESC'.  I enjoyed the gravity physics, however, as I've been attempting gravity in my own games.

description:
The game is a rogue like adventure game where a dwarf is lost in the mines and tries to escape without dying. You have to find the exit, dig for water to survive and collect as much gold nuggets as possible on the way.
gameplay tips:
- if water is near you will hear it.
- the harder rocks inherit more water and nuggets
- the exit can be anywhere not just in a room
Its my first LD and  I am satisfied with the result in terms of what I have got done in the time. Even though the gameplay could be more fun.. ;)
Use WASD or cursor keys. Sound is necessary for the full game experience.
author: JoeCool
title: Lost In the Shadows
comments: The first time I played In got into a second cave fairly quickly (with water and gold) but then found nothing else. The second time I played I never even found that much.
So map generation needs some balancing.

You are right, the item distribution needs more balancing. To find more items look for granite, the darkest of the rock types. It will often reveal water or gold. And if you hear water than its not far away just dig around till you get it.
Couldn't really get into it. Died a lot mostly due to pure luck and never figured out an effective way to find the exit.
Thanks for the feedback. My next version will be more fun to play. :)

I found the exit!!! good game, I like the dwarf dialogs while you are playing. Not sure how balanced it is but don't like so much each movement thought an empty block consumes so much of my health and hours.
it needs some balancing, but I'm looking forward to the next version :-)
Hey guys, thanks for the positive feedback :). I will work on the game in a few days. Have to finish my current project first.

The graphics and sound are great--especially considering this was done in 48 hours! The gameplay is moderately fun, but I feel like I couldn't realy come up with a compelling strategy. My only other criticism is that the controls felt very sluggish on my machine (it felt like there was a half-second delay between a key press and something actually happening).
On the whole though, very impressive. You should be proud!
Thanks for your kind words Deraj. To be honest, its hard to be really proud of it, when seeing all those other great LD entries.
I will work on a new version soon, with improved balancing, gameplay mechanics and better controls.

Randomness is killing it - unless you're lucky you just won't find the water (sound cue is a good idea). You'd have to change the generation of the level for it to be fun (now it really depends more on how lucky you are). I'd suggest generating water on the fly - if player is already thirsty, generate water nearby on not yet visited (inlcuding the detection radius) tile.
Shigor, thanks for the cool feedback. Greatly appreciated! :)

author: chrisc97
title: iQ
comments: Crashes instantly when I play it. I'm running Windows 7, if that helps.
This is one that I actually regret playing. The first riddle is programmed backwards so the right answer gets you scolded then having to retry the room.
This put me off to trying doors at random until escaping. The red door was a decent touch but there is nothing here that could have been accomplished in two to three hours.

Not a bad idea, but presentation could be better. Not sure how this is central to the theme though. Also for a 48h compo, I may not have enough patience to read and solve them all. Also not sure what wally2069 means, because first riddle answer is also the right door...
Sigh... why did you made the player to move so slowly when answering the riddles?
Overall... few simple riddles you have to answer by moving slowly to the right door, with some story and a bit better ending (where you could move a bit faster).

description:
Finally, after 28 and a half hours of game development (I mean 28 and a half hours of straight work), I am proud to present my creation :D. It is a top down shooter where your goal is to escape from a military base of an oppressive, poor government. I had lots of fun doing this and I hope all of you did too! Cheers! =)
Also, I was getting very, very tired towards the end, so a lot of my later features are hard coded rather than systematically programmed :S
I really wish I had time to implement a story line, but I'm not the most creative person in the world. I implemented a dialogue system, but never ended up getting to use it :( But I will definitely build on this game!
author: PaperCutDoom
title: Impossible Escape
comments: UPDATE: Game is exactly the same, but I changed the content system to make adding content much easier.
Couldn't quite figure out how to control the rovers... cool game otherwise!

Oh, I apologize for not making that clearer in the help menu. I probably should've made them left click to select. But anyways, it's right click to select a rover, then right click again to move it around. Also all the buttons and inventory are right click, so right click the use button to use the rover's item/weapon. Inventory is Drag 'n' drop with the right mouse button as well.
Nice little escape shmup. Can be a little unforgiving when guards start shooting right after you notice them. Collisions are a bit wonky. Crashed when I tried moving inventory.

Thanks for the constructive criticisms =), I fixed the inventory crash, I didn't upload it yet, I have to go to school in a few minutes. And yeah, I didn't want to spend too much time fiddling with the collisions during the compo. The AI definitely needs work hahaha.
Oops, disregard my previous comment; wrong tab.  This game is good, but too hard for me.
Bulett Hell! I really sucked at this. The music is nice, the weapon sound rather annoying.

description:
I Predict a Riot is not as funny as my usual LD entries, however similar to all my previous entries, it's not very much fun.
You are a high ranking prisoner in a prison, and its the night of the jailbreak.
The other prisoners have put you in charge of distracting the guards whilst the other escape.
No failure state, no real winning state. Just a concept really, I quite like it, but its taken me 72 hours and now I want rid of it!
I noticed there was a bug in level 2 where the prisoners do not count as escaping, I'm looking into this.
Unfortunately please be aware that the tutorial runs at a shocking framerate, however it improves there after, I am looking into optimising the tutorial.
Made with Game Maker 8 and tested on Windows 7, I went a bit crazy with the screen size and its resolution is 1024,480.
Apologies, didn't add www. to entry link, can now download!
author: cptalbertwesker
title: I Predict a Riot
comments: Is there a link to this game?
Interesting concept, you already noted level 1 was lagging , which was the same for me.
The delay on the first level is way too long. Just jump right into explaining things and people will get the hang of it. Otherwise a great job.

Unfortunately the only reason the delay was so long was because of the lag, otherwise it would have been as quick as the other levels, thanks for the advice though, I'm just used to games giving me the instruction in one lump then throwing you in, and getting confused, thought I'd pace it out. I'll just stick to instruction pages for the next LD :)
I couldn't figure out any controls. Clicking the mouse did nothing, and I could not find any keyboard keys that did anything.
The tutorial limits what you can do at the start, it tells you how to play.

Interesting concept which fits the theme as well... But to work it as a game you'd have to make it bit more complicated or provide very good levels and probably use some more goals then escaping (like distracting guards continuously while one escaped convict goes to open doors for others etc..)

The demo was agonizingly slow, but the rest of the game was much better. You should really look into that! Also, my general strategy was just to plant 1 peaceful protest and win, which seemed to work fine for me. Maybe you could make the gameplay more complex somehow?

description:
Alright, this is my first Ludum Dare entry and everything went smoothly.
The game is in XNA Reach, so any computer that has windows should be able to run it (at the very least it works on  3 year old netbooks). Just download the .zip and run the .exe You may need to extract it the contents of the .zip, though the .exe usually works straight out of the .zip. On older versions of windows you'll be asked to extract before running.
If you encounter any kind of error, it's because you don't have one or both of the .Net 4.0 or XNA frameworks (must be installed in that order). If you've ever played an XNA game before, this one should work fine.
.NET 4.0 web installer: http://www.microsoft.com/downloads/en/details.aspx?FamilyID=9CFB2D51-5FF4-4491-B0E5-B386F32C0992
XNA 4.0 redist: http://www.microsoft.com/downloads/en/details.aspx?FamilyID=a88c6dec-aeae-42cd-a108-d35c013c3b97
Followed is a story driven puzzle game about a man who is being followed. I like to think the story has some interesting undertones. The game is 12 levels long. Short of that, I can't really say too much.
It's worth noting that absolutely anything coming out of your speakers while playing this game was done by myself on a cello.
Tools used:
C# XNA 4.0
Paint.Net
Logic Pro 9
Have fun!
NOTE: Because of the high quantity of text files filed with random numbers, the .zip file trips the alert on some anti-virus system. For what it's worth, I assure you there is no virus.
author: Pvaiun
title: Followed
comments: Brilliant! The theme... The story... The music... Pureky brilliant!
If only it were a little bit longer. This was a lot of fun, great music and great puzzles. Was the abrupt way the music stopped at the end intentional?

Well initially the plan was for the last "level" to be automatic and the music was going to end perfectly with when the end screen showed up. However, I realized the ending felt much more dramatic when the player was controlling it and I didn't have the time nor the know how to mesh the music with what the player was doing. It's not perfect, but 48 hours isn't a long time ;)
Thanks for posting the instructions about XNA.  It's amazing how many games I haven't run because I didn't know that.
I had a lot of fun, very interesting puzzles and great texts! The music really inmersed me in the game despite of graphics. Note: the source link is not working.
Thanks everyone, the source link is now fixed. Sorry about that.
Great Monologue! Great cello playing! although i am kinda getting depressed playing this :(

Fun puzzle game, with an awesome narrative (I was thinking that only 4-5 lines into the game:)).  Good use of the theme, too.  Oh yeah, and that cello music?  Good stuff.  I just read that you played it yourself, nice.  I had read before playing of Logic Pro, so I thought it was just a (good) arrangement.
I like the characterization that was applied to this mechanic.  Well done, and very good execution on the tone.
Cool! Gets frustrating in places, but never quite too much so. Neat way of weaving a lot of tension and drama into a very simple gameplay rule.

description:
You will need .NET\XNA 4.0 to run this (download here http://www.microsoft.com/download/en/details.aspx?id=23714).
This game was made using the reach profile so should run fine on older hardware.
Also, thank you for taking the time to play my entry :)
author: DivideByZero
title: Escape!
comments: Neat idea, but I think you could have stretched a little further.  It's Memory, with all the inherent benefits and flaws as such -- the challenge mechanic really isn't there.  Next time I hope you can dive a little deeper :)
It's a good start but would have been more fun if you added in new mechanics and symbols as the player progresses.
A non-installation version would be nice.
a) don't use installer next time
b) intro screen with the text hanging too long, i was already getting ready to kill the process (this is really ridiculous)
c) gameplay is primitive variation on memory
d) you're generating positions randomly and you're not ensuring that they don't overlap, which might complicate the game / render it unplayable

description:
This is created in Game Maker 8. It's my first Ludum Dare. I could really have used another day, but oh well..
The objective of the game is to escape the game, so you kinda don't have any options to exit, without completing it.. Just Task Kill it if you get bored.
The source is REALLY messed up.. if you find some sprites in a map called sheep.. well, I kinda thought I'd use them, but then had another idea, and just kept them there for future games.
author: TheChriskage
title: Escape the game!
comments: Great! I enjoyed it very much. The last level was quite tricky, but I got it, Good job!
Yay, four games in a row. All of them nothing new, but nicely done. I enjoyed this one. The idea with the exit code is nice, even though I would have done it with more overall story.
To be honest I thought it was a bit frustrating to play because level 2 and 4 are way too hard and because there's very little feedback on your actions in all of the levels.
I love the idea of escaping the game and it's great that there are four games to play though. It's a good take on the theme.
What is this now? Now I have to play 602 games... Sorta fun though :)
The graphics were a mixed bag. Would have liked some kind of sound. Four mini games each only related by being part of the same program.

description: Updated: I put again the version I submitted yesterday (within 48 hours). New version was against the rules, so it's not available. Sorry for that!
author: the roguesque adventure
title: Demonout
comments: LOVE everything about this. Just letting you know though, if you max out one stat at the beginning of the game. You kill everything in one shot. You are the invincible evil overlord.
Some more humor (and story) could help, btw, nice game (add audio!!)
Great game! The particle effects and lighting are a nice touch. I assume it ends at floor 16? There's no more downward stairs.
It was supposed to get to floor 0, but I uploaded a wrong level data file without that missing stairs. Is that the kind of thing it is illegal to correct now?
Way too easy so I got bored pretty quickly by just walking and killing everything with few hits and constant Level Up messages. Otherwise nice, with some polish it could be quite nice game.
I have to agree with Shigor in that the game was way too easy. I became bored after the first few levels, but I continued because I was interested in what the ending might be.
Unfortunately, I discovered a bug on floors 16/17 where I could only cycle between the two floors.

My goodness you set yourself a mammoth challenge trying to do a complete dungeon crawler with so many elemtns within the 48 hours. You didn't quite succeed, but with a bit of polish this could be going somewhere.
Enjoyed it, because I'm a crawler-nerd... but definitely needs more work.

I think you bit more than you could chew. It's pretty long for an LD game, but it still feels like there was next to no content in a way. Not enough challenge, not enough variation between stats or enemies.

description:
****I FIXED SOME IMPORTANT BUG THAT PREVENTS THE GAME FROM STARTING****
As a result of this I had to remove all audio, so the files are significantly smaller than before. If you still get problems please say so in comments. Since I can only have 5 links I removed the HiDef download link of the old build.
You can still download it here: Windows - HiDef http://www.mediafire.com/?hybb4pjxib9wpxs
Dare To Escape is a bullet-hell platformer.
You need XNA/.NET 4 to play the game.
I am sorry for this! Never had to distribute an XNA game before. Thought they would work out of the box.
It's my first time participating in LD and the first "serious" game I did by myself.
Sadly there is not much content due to huge time problems.
In exchange the difficulty curve is insane in the two levels it has.
If the HiDef-version doesnt work for you, try out the Reach-version! If the Reach version doesn't work pls specify the error you get.
I didn't include the uncompressed audio files in the source as they take 300mb of space. If you want to compile it you have to remove all occurences where the AudioManager or AudioHelper is used.
The music was generated using http://tones.wolfram.com/generate/ . I hope this is allowed seeing how programs such as bfxr are allowed to generate sound effects.
There is currently a bug in that bosses sometimes dont spawn if you play the game in one session. If you find a blue orb without there being a boss you should restart the game. You can use the resume feature afterwards to start at your last checkpoint and the boss should be there this time (if you didnt save after picking up the blue orb).
I might expand upon this game in the future. If you're interested to see more content and better mechanics etc. feel free to visit my blog: http://projectblackdragon.blogspot.com/
author: xNidhogg
title: Dare To Escape
comments: Sorry chap, for some reason the Reach version doesn't seem to work.
Good stuff, quick addicting in my opinion! I'm sure the second level would have been easier had there been more time for levels! :D
Very nice idea, a bullet-hell platformer. I'd have loved some more content.
You should probably say that you're using XNA 4, because it would crash for people without it (and people without visual studio debugger won't know why)

just put up new downloads. Should be allowed as per twitter-feed as this was a bug that prevented the game from starting. As a result all sound got removed. Included original source on submission and new source

"Windows - Reach (bugged)" works for me, then again I have all the XNA stuff. Nice concept platformer. Turrets are a bit overpowered, and takes trial-error rather than skill to pass most. Bullets that follow you are too hard to avoid in narrow places. Then again those two might be the point of the game. Nice touch on the tutorial screen.
Brilliant! Very hard though... Maybe make the collision box smaller? Thanks for making this.
Fun and hard, just the way I like them. Some turrets could have been placed better but I realize time didn't allow for fine tuning and balancing.

Very hard. I could not pass the two boss turrets at the end. Since their pattern is random, I felt it was more luck than skill for this (most of the time, it felt impossible to get through ; there is not enough space to run or jump). I tried for a couple of minutes then I quit. This kind of extreme platforming is very tough to balance. Just looking at VVVVVV and SMB, I do not want to start thinking about how hard that must have been.

description:
Enter the Crime Zone. Move it, Move it. Catch the perps. You are drawn to a mysterious hotel. You are repeatedly drawn to this mysterious hotel. Protect And Serve. It's just another day in the Crime Zone.
Made in Adventure Game Studio 3.0.
author: thecatamites
title: Crime Zone
comments: excellent P.I.S.S. and C.R.I.M.E. physics engine... very good game!

I think I didn't understood anything...but I loved it! Each time I play one of your game I think "What shitty graphics!" and "What a shity idea!" But at the end, each part of the game looks wonderful to me. What is the secret ?
Very interesting game :).  It feels like a visual novel though I'm not sure taking any other paths would explain anything (not that I'd want to understand).  Could use some sound though!
I didn't understand a thing from this game...  However, it was kind of fun :-)
Now I need to take a piss.
Wow that's a lot of content for 48h game, awesome ! And I like the lynch-esque story :)

This was great, I started giggling within a few seconds of starting and continued nonstop basically until I finished. Afterward I tried it another couple times to check for branches I missed, it took me until my third try to realize there doesn't seem to be a way to quit except by winning :O

I thought at very first this was just going to be an endless chain, Officer A looks in the puddle, Officer B attempts to arrest Officer A for public urination, Officer C attempts to arrest officer B for assaulting Officer A, and so on... what is actually happening though is much more clever. IT ALL FITS TOGETHER.

description:
This is my first entry for Ludum Dare and I'm fairly happy with how it turned out.
I wanted to focus on an escape attempt against impossible odds, which turned out pretty well. It's essentially a frantic game of attrition, getting quicker and quicker until The Runner ultimately dies. With any luck, you'll get more and more panicked as your Light starts to dwindle and more and more enemies start to spawn.
The controls and instructions are in-game, but let me know if anything needs explaining.
The graphical style ended up looking really cool in action, but there are a few things I would change if I did it again (most of them involving getting more sleep and ingesting less caffeine in some way).
One major note that I forgot to put into the instructions is that powerups have a chance to drop from enemies when they die. Light+ boosts The Guide's Light radius (which has a hard limit) and Move+ permanently increases The Guide's movement speed.
More than anything else in the game, I didn't like the fact that your ability to generate Light is based entirely on luck. I've toyed with the idea of being able to regenerate light by being near a lantern (and the people who playtested it mentioned it too), but I couldn't get it implemented in a way in which it doesn't break the balance of the game.
Hints and Tips:
- Don't pick up too many Speed+ powerups! More control is often needed.
- Use the Lanterns to your advantage. Although they're not the best shield, they'll do in a pinch if you're low on Light.
- Don't kill every Flyer you see. They always release a Red Bullet when they die. Sometimes you're better off leaving them.
- When your COMBO hits 20/40/60/..., if you're not on full ammo for your right-click weapon, you'll get 1 ammo.
- Only use your right-click weapon when it's essential. It resets your COMBO and significantly hinders your score.
Let me know what you think of it and what score you get, my highest is 122460!
Tools used:
Game Maker
bfxr
author: Nihilate
title: BlackWhiteRed
comments: Awesome, I like how you're in control of the guardian and not the victim for a change. But the bullets only seem to reach the runner between lamp posts
love the artstyle and gameplay idea,
I'm seeing it upside down and mirrored o_O
It is some sort of bug?
i liked this one a lot! Good job!

description:
You were locked in the asylum because you belived you could breathe fire.
To excape from this madhouse you will have to kill nurses, janitors, and fellow psychopaths to find the key to the exit.
The farthest left bar is your health meter. If you run out of health, you lose.
The next bar is your rage meter. Keep it 1/2 red and 1/2 yellow to maximize attack damage.
If your rage meter fills all the way up, you lose what is left of your mind. You lose the game.
If your rage meter goes down to zero you become complacent and lose your will to escape. You lose the game.
The furthest right bar is your Magic meter. Maybe it does somthing.
Use the arrow keys to navigate the map. Walk into the same square as an enemy to do battle.
author: Amadeus
title: Asylum Escape
comments: I got the hang of it, I think. But I couldn't figure out if it was winnable, as the balance seemed a little off. The graphics were functional, but kind of hard on the eyes. And while the RPG system worked pretty well, the damage from enemies seemed a little unpredictable.

The game is winnable but it's very hard if you don't know where the key is (it isn't random). The idea is nurses attacks lower your rage/janitors attacks raise your rage/ and psychopaths are easy fights so you want to fight a psychopath if you are trying to recover. A janitor if your rage is low, and a nurse if your rage is high. Also, enemy move damage is always the same for each move. Noramlly 15-25% of your health(I definitely need to lower it). I will update the game after the competition with a boss battle, working text display and slightly better graphics. I really appreciate you taking the time to play it.
OK figured it out, very interesting mechanic and quite inventive. The graphics make my eyes burn though lol and you had no sound. Still it was an interesting idea, you scored high on innovation.

The art really burned my eyes out :) Attempt to create interesting and bit innovative fight mechanic is a definite plus and as a certified (almost, but I escaped) madman I have to approve, because I could almost feel I'm roleplaying myself.

description:
Note: The html on the page occasionally isn't loading the Flash for some reason.  If you get a blank page after clicking the game link, refresh the page and it should be fine.
I made a couple entries on my blog (linked above) while the LD site was down (in addition to a couple entries here).
As always, I wanted to do something way outside of how I thought most people would interpret the theme.  I ended up doing something very different than anything I've done before.
I went with the idea of psychological escape mechanisms, and avoiding difficult or painful thoughts.  The game (more of a playable story) has the player feeding the difficult thoughts to Anthony, a man tormented by painful memories.  The player must persist with the thought until Anthony accepts and comes to terms with it.
I discovered that conveying a meaningful story through a first-person thought fragment narrative was very difficult.  I spent several hours developing a story, and ended up scrapping it and creating a much shorter, more workable one (that went in a very different direction) in the last couple hours.  The final result came together at the end.
I created the game in the Flex 4 framework (with Flashdevelop) and Flashpunk.  The one piece of "art" was created in Photoshop, and the music in Reason.
I kept the story pretty short, so it shouldn't take more than a couple minutes to play through it.
author: Martoon
title: Anthony's Psyche: Escape
comments: a haunting but very interesting game. reminded me a little of Today I Die. nice little play, and an interesting take on the theme! i'm a huge fan of portraying stories in interesting and meaningful ways like this, and you did a good job of it!
I liked the idea, the concept was interesting, but it got boring pretty fast. The music was nice, but that got old fast as well.
This is the kind of game that can oly come out of Ludum Dare. I applaud you.
Like the concept. I only did it all to the end just to see all the story. Some obstacles and a way to lose would benefit the game =) But good work!
Interesting, but mechanics lost their meaning after the first couple phrases.

I'm sure that may will disagree but this has captured the theme of escape better than anything I've seen so far. While most things have you running from something scary thins makes you face said something.
I can't but wonder, would Anthony have lived if I wouldn't have completed the game?

Awesome. I really liked this, but felt that once the drop (*spoilers* figuring out that the guy had killed his wife) happened, the story should have ended quicker. Maybe make it so the words come more quickly/are easier to move around? (this could be a good way of building/relieving tension as well).

I liked the music and the mechanic of revealing the story a bit at a time. Reminded me a bit of Today I Die also (http://www.ludomancy.com/games/today.php if you haven't seen it). I agree that the mechanic of following the figure with the text to uncover it got repetitive. I can easily imagine a situation where you show a scene (e.g. a room) and have to move different words/phrases to different areas to reveal them. Maybe that could replace the main figure?

I think the biggest change I would make to the story would be to reduce the number of statements that hint at a violent end. Ideally with a game like this it would be one of the very last sentences that completely changes the player's view. I could even imagine having the music change a few times through the game, from sad, to fond memories, and finally to a sinister conclusion.

description:
My name is Max, i have been programming for 7 months now, this is my second game ever and my first Ludum Dare entry! I am happy about succeding this challenge, i am learning a lot and this is an awesome community.
A memory is about someone who is trapped metaphorically inside his head and cannot escape his past, it is some experimental idea i tried to print on this game.
You have to explore "your mind" with the arrow keys looking for the 10 keys necessary to go through a portal that supposedly will take you out from there. Meanwhile, you can read the characterÃ�Â´s thoughts in the screen.
I hope you like it,or at least feel something while playing through the game :)
On development:
I wrote the game in C++ using OpenGL, and a few helper libraries(FreeType & ZLib for fonts, DevIL for PNGs)
The images were done with GIMP, some of them are just edited photographs i took. I could not make it in time for the music because i did not manage to get OpenAL working on time for the submission.
Again, hope you like it and i will be very pleased to answer any question about the game.
Cheers!
Max
author: maxx
title: A memory
comments: this needs some serious bug-fixes, otherwise good job
thanks for playing! yes, i was rushing and when uploaded i noticed the bugs, stupid bugs really. anyway, i wish i could keep updating the game, but that is not possible
Very pretty, moody graphics and setting.
Great job on the graphics, they are amazing for a 48-hour game! I would have prefered fewer ads/less wait time for the download, though :)
Thanks! GIMP filters and some imagination can get the job done quick enough. Wait-less download next time.
This is a very nice game. Hard but fun
Very pretty game. Would have loved some nice music to go with it :)
An exceptionally good looking game! It just sort of lacks direction. How many keys do I need? What do they do? Is it okay to collect the same one over and over?
I did make it to the swirly bit after collecting 10 or so keys, but it just returned me to the main menu. Is that winning?
Like I said though, gorgeous game. Good work.

Yeah, i changed the idea over and over in the 48 hours, luckily a could deliver something "finished". So i involuntarily concentrated more in the graphics part, not too much time to code something fun. Tough, i learned a lot this time, which i will hopefully apply on my next LD. Thanks for playing and sorry for forgetting the "game-with-objetive" part!

description:
You are the warden of a psychiatric ward.  Your job is to take care of the best lunatics and crazies society can produce.  You must make sure they do not escape the premise.  This can prove difficult because they damage everything they get their hands on.
Arrow keys to run.  Hold Shift key to walk.
Repair walls and other constructions by walking (or running) up to them.
Source code is included.  The software is built using C++ and OpenGL 2.1.  It also uses the following libraries:
- boost
- SFML 2
- Eigen
- DevIL
- Box2D
author: Trancelucid
title: Warden's Burden
comments: You may need the MS Visual C++ 2010 redistributable DLLs, available here:
Also, on some computers the game will look "paused".  There's a problem with the physics in that velocity is always zero, so nothing moves.  Sorry!  Next time I'll ask more friends for play-testing.
Its a nice idea to start with

Nice idea, but way too unpredictable and hard to keep under control. Also it's a bit weird that there's seemingly one way out (through the yard), but the patients can apparently escape through any border.
Can't rate because of the "paused" problem.

description: A point and click game about saving people. JUST KIDDING. It's about escaping from a big mansion, or villa if you will. I'm really happy with how it turned out! Aaaw yeah.
author: EricTheCoolDude
title: The Villainous Villa
comments: Haha, this is great! Really funny, adorable art style, and wow the music. I'm surprised and impressed that you made a separate, really terrific track for the battle sequence that normally takes 5 seconds to go through. I did a second playthrough so I could hear the whole track!
Pretty short and obviously not very challenging, but seeing as both were likely intentional, I think this is a fantastic effort, especially seeing how early you submitted it. Nice work, man!
Very funny, very enjoyable game. The only thing I didn't like was not getting to see the room of evil. ;)
Really lovely.  So much done with so little in the way of code heavy mechanics is really inspiring.  Really quite amusing too.  Good work.
Loads of fun... music was superb!
Freedom!!! Hey this is funny stuff! Next time we want to see the room of evil too. :) Good music. Thanks!
Could probably have used a *little* more challenge, and im a bit annoyed i didnt get to see into the room of evil...

Felt more like an interactive movie than a game, but the killer soundtrack, stunning graphics/animation, and tongue-in-cheek humor made up for that. I enjoyed your timelapses as well, especially the "mom made pancakes" comment. :D
Pretty great!  Not enough classic adventure in these compos.

Cool, excellent sound... But what the hell should I do at the window? It seems there's bug because even if I take the pillow, I can't use it in anyway, place where it was is still active and if I jump, I splash...
This is great! The soundtrack is magnifiecient too. What tools did you use for that?
I don't usually like games like this, but this one was fun!
Not very challenging, obviously, but has nice visuals and music, and is good and funny!
I burst out laughing at the very start with the bars bit :D Very funny, nicely done. Not very long, and gameplay is crude. Music's great though.
LOVED the music. cool game, loved the battle towards the end.
Lovely game. Well done. Arguably the best point and click adventure I have played.

description:
"Still Dreaming" is a short adventure into an abstract landscape. The player is faced with a variety of puzzles and hopefully will get a bit of laugh out of trying to escape this weird dream.
The main goal was to create a game with a specific atmosphere that guides the player through a short story giving a glance into a different world.
This is distributed as an executable jar. So all you'll need is JAVA to run this. This works on Windows/Mac. Make sure you turn on the speakers, there are some eerie sounds.
UPDATE: Enhanced post compo version added. I mainly fixed up some visual things and few glitches. More content will be added later.
I'll be porting this over to Android!
Tools used:
- GIMP for all graphics
- REAPER.FM for audio
- LIBGDX as a graphics framework
- ECLIPSE IDE
author: bach
title: Still Dreaming
comments: Beautiful game. I'm stuck on the first level though, lol.
I felt like a brainiac after solving the tree puzzle...
Awesome game man, keep on deving this one!
The particle effects and the ambient atmosphere created by the music and sfx are amazing! Great experience for such a short game. Cheers!
Gorgeous. Plays really well. The audio and the graphics gel together really well.
It's short, but made of epic winnage.
Great entry, I really liked it. :)
I really don't get this. Where is the puzzle? I don't want to spoiler this, but I didn't need to think even for a sec...
And also you don't know when is autopilot and when the controls are yours...no fun here.
Quite the experience, puzzles hit just the right level of difficulty for me. Good job.
What seems to be a beautiful game (seeing from the screen shots) doesn't run on Linux =(
@N0_Named_Guy: Unfortunately I couldn't test it on Linux :( I'm working on uploading an applet so that should hopefully work through your browser.
I had to download the source as well and run the jar from stilldreaming-desktop so it could get assets. But I still couldn't get it to work on Linux. Here's the error in case it helps you debug.

Caused by: java.lang.UnsatisfiedLinkError: /tmp/libgdx/733885368/liblwjgl.so: /usr/lib/jvm/java-6-sun-1.6.0.17/jre/lib/i386/libjawt.so: symbol awt_FreeDrawingSurface, version SUNWprivate_1.1 not defined in file libmawt.so with link time reference

description:
Would like to make another level or two, it's a bit short. But here is as it stands at the 48 hour mark.
The more quickly you move, the more readily you'll be detected, so sneak if you plan on coming from behind.
edit: another note, the enemies' vision cones is primarily an indicator of their facing direction, not the range at which they can see you. They can see much further than that.
author: Xion
title: Space Pirates Suck!
comments: Neat, and functional. Although I don't really see why you wouldn't want to be sneaking all time time, unless you screw up. Love the vision range displays, although enemies sometimes saw me from way beyond them if I was straight ahead of them.
I liked it, tho I missed some ambient sound, this game was asking for spacey wooooshes and computer noises on the background.
nice job! Digging your pixel art and animation
Oh my god, this is totally sweet.
I like the graphics, but the game is kind of frustrating since you can't attack once the space pirates have noticed you. I keep dying too quickly =/
I was dying for an option to beat on the aliens, but I'm violent like that.
Nicely done. Cure art, though in need of variety or polish. Camera shifting is cool, but when moving about many corners, it becomes too shakey.

Excellent entry, functional, interesting gameplay (so much like old metal gear :) polished, no bugs I've seen. Difficulty seems about right for me, not to hard, not to easy. Audio is about the only thing which could really use some improvement.
As for the length of the game, I think it's pretty sufficient for 48 hours compo.
Nice game, but really unforgiving! Noobs like me need checkpoints every 2 seconds.
The game was quite hard, I think it would be appropriate to have some sort of tutorial.

The graphics were great and the mechanics were pretty solid as well. The difficultly needed to be turned down or have some checkpoints somewhere. Too much backtracking. Also the pirates viewable distance should get turned down a bit.

description:
I worked solo so I did not had time to make models this time so I bended the rules by using models and animations from other projects. Also I drank too much energy drink cos it was free at our event LUDUMDARE KAJAANI (http://ldkajaani.blogspot.com/) and could not made all the great gameplay elements I was planning due the lack of sleep.
Also to save time I decided to remove (almost) all colors from the scene and got this nice Twin Peaks / Sin City feel for the game. The low visibility makes it more challenching to play and adds more mood even thought it might not be everybodies "cup of tea"
author: Ataverti
title: Road to Escape
