sorry, I didn't realize you had to put the "http://" in, so the links didn't show up :/ Fixed!
(That'll teach me to upload without checking late at night!)
I didn't make it to the shoe :(
Innovation: This genre is done quite a bit, and I didn't see anything new.
Theme: The theme wasn't really explained in-game. The theme explanation felt like an excuse to fit the game after making what you wanted to.
Graphics: Things resembled what they were meant to be, which is good. I'm not sure if I quite liked the cursor sprite or the wall sprite, which didn't fit in with the rest of the art style.
Audio: The music was 8 looping measures, which could definitely be expanded into something worthwhile. The sounds themselves were okay, but a little uninteresting.

Fun: I was a bit irritated by the level design, mostly because the rooms just seemed to cut off right at the borders, which looked a little odd. The level design also did some weird things that ended in awkward maneuvers to shoot at enemies. The boss' hitbox is, well, a box, and you can get hurt while walljumping on the above platforms. Also, you never explained that you can walljump.

Overall: I don't want to be rude, but this game needs work in all departments before I consider it worthwhile. I can see the effort, but I don't know just how well it turned out in the end. Maybe use this advice to make a better game next Ludum Dare, or practice on your own time! You can only improve from here.
I won with 830 and took about 10 minutes.

description:
Ruin Runner
This game is about escaping ruins. There are a lot of obstacles, but you can jump over them, or walk over them with the shield or without the shield.
Controls:
ENTER - Start level
UP - Jump
RIGHT - Go forward
LEFT - Go back
Q, W, E, R - Shields
It's our first jam game and we haven't got enough time to complete it, so it has some bugs. It was written in Ubuntu 10.10, C and SDL.
In case, you want to run it on Linux, you will have to have packages: libsdl, libsdl_image and libsdl_ttf.
We hope, you'll enjoy it. Team InfinityLeaks.
author: InfinityLeaks
title: Ruin Runner
comments: The level where you have to swim down ended being too hard for me to make it through, the scroll speed just kept overtaking me and squishing me. fun game though!
I couldn't get it to run. I'm on Ubuntu linux, got the libraries you mentioned. I just see a black screen and have to kill the process of with signal 9 to get the window to close.
doesn't run on my Windows Vista Machine
It ran just fine on Win 7 x64

The black screen is one of the serious problems. We have concentrated on the boss levels (unfortunately we haven't made them), but we haven't done the music or menu. Just try to press ENTER to continue. The sixth level (I'm counting it with tutorial) has no end, because it has to be a boss level.
I'm afraid this thing crashes my machine (sorry :-) )

Tested on different computers with different performance and with different OS. No crashes. The black screen is caused by waiting loop on ENTER, there has to be some sign like "Press ENTER to continue".

Runs of winxp. Never got through the third level with water (the one on the last screenshot) whatever I did even if I think I've done everything all right. Black screen on the start waiting for enter, troubles with quiting the application are just few of problems. Tutorial texts without possibility to skip them are annoying. Different shield mechanics might be nice addition, but that's about everything. Weak one, especially for a team entry, you'll have to do more next time :)

I also found the part with the water you have to go through impossible. I'm not sure what I'm missing. I thought the mechanics were not a bad idea, but maybe you could have eased into it by just having 1 or 2 kinds of shields on the first few levels. Actually I use a Dvorak keyboard and the keyboard switcher didn't work when I ran your game, so the shields were almost impossible for me to activate in time. Why not let us use 1/2/3/4 as well? Fortunately you can beat the levels I beat with almost no shields, only by jumping!
Yeah I just got the unclose-able black window (Windows XP).

author: notabotanist
title: Pod Absconder
comments: Wow I'm awful at this haha.  Fun and challenging!
Vector graphics in retro style FTW! I like the game very much - it's hard in a good way, its fun, and it feels complete. Congrats!

description:
Escape from the mansion by avoiding the killer ghosts!
Arrow Keys Up, Down, Left and Right to move. Touching a ghost will kill you, if you fall into their line of sight they will chase you until you can loose them.
author: cjke.7777
title: Haunted Escape
comments: This game slightly overstayed its welcome given how simplistic the gameplay was, and the audio loop grated a little by the end. It did, however, come together to create a good, spooky atmosphere, albeit one that wasn't built on much (just a little backstory hidden along the path would have helped here).
The music was setted the proper mood, but was a little repetitive.  Getting stuck on walls was also somewhat frustrating sometimes...
Ah-Yhoogly-boogly-boo-hoo-hoo! Boo-hoo-glee-ee, What-are-you? What are you?
i got the 'didn't find out what happened' ending, was there any more?
Wow, very nice! I found that the number of ghosts is absolutely right. It was neither unbeatable nor too easy.
This concept could develop a fun narative game if it was expanded. And the first ghost to chase me actually gave me a scare!

In my first playthrough I only encountered one locked door before I found the key for it. I played through a second time checking more doors before grabbing the keys, and found a second locked door. It'd be nice to see where the locked doors are, or have some indication about when a key is used. I don't know if I did use all 3 keys, or if there was a secret area I never found.

description:
Plot:
You are the captain of an alien vessel that was transporting humans across the galaxy to be probed. The humans revolted and managed to explosively decompress themselves into space (wearing space suits). You were travelling so fast that they're spread out across several solar systems. Round up as many as you can. Don't let them escape.
How to play:
Click behind the ship to thrust it forward. You are pulled by the planets gravity. When all the humans in that system are collected, a portal to the next solar system will open. Fly into it to progress.
Goal:
Collect as many humans as possible. High scores game. High scores aren't saved to disk. You have 5 lives. Good Luck.
Technical Details:
Written in Python (www.python.org). Requires Pyglet (http://code.google.com/p/pyglet/). Graphics were created in Pixelmator. Sounds were created in as3sfxr. The logo font is Pirulin by Typodermic. Free for commercial use.
It should run on Linux if you have python and pyglet installed, but I haven't had a chance to test it recently. Apologies if it doesn't work for you. Assets are included with the source distribution.
author: dave84
title: Harvest
comments: The game may be great for the fans of this genre, but I had no fun while playing =X I don't like to click around to move the ship. Awkward controls ruined what could be a good game. =(
The controls weren't too good. . . A smoother control setup would have made the game a lot, lot better.

I agree the controls are not intuitive, especially when trying to navigate while the ship is at the edge of the board, maybe a frame around the game board could be used as an additional input area to account for this, I lost most of the time by loosing focus of the window. This could also be improved by an auto-pause feature.
I had some fun, and the gravity mechanic worked great.
Might make for an interesting iPhone or other touch platform game if it were spiced up a bit. Not sure how it relates to the theme really.
Controls are really killing it in a big way...
I didn't like the controls, and the game doesn't seem to fit the theme well, but I loved the art and the gravity mechanic. A good game with some potentially very bad problems.
Looks like I dropped the ball on the controls.

If any of you have suggestions for a control scheme you'd like, let me know. At the moment I've a build where the ship is attracted by the cursor instead of repulsed, but I don't know if the mouse is the problem in general or just the repulsion.
As for the theme not fitting, I tried not to be too obvious, having the humans be escaped rather than the player escaping from somewhere.
Not to beat a dead horse, but the controls feels like playing Catherine after the Butt monster reverses your directional controls :P
Maybe some turret style controls would be an improvement.

I love the controls. I found you from your tweet and I thought I would check it out. Yes they are not what I was ready for. Yes I died quite quickly to start with. After a while I found the controls made for some "seat of my pants" game play. This is exactly what I like. Too many games do not challenge you to become skilled at using them. This one does and for that I beg you not to change the controls. I think your game is suffering from the fact that with so many entries it is difficult to invest time into any one game. I am keeping your file on my mac and plan to play it once this judging is all over. Please think about extending it I would be interested in beta testing. Please check out my equally difficult to control game "Anti Puck" good luck

description: Help save the world of Glissaria in an action packed mix of tower defense, match3, and rpg elements!
author: arkeus
title: Glissaria
comments: Your first screen looks like an ad, other than that, I really liked the game play and graphics. Sound was a bit annoying after a couple of minutes, but it was better than silence.
I really liked this game. I hope you continue working on it because it has lots of potential.
-At first I had no clue what was going on, I basically had to read the tutorial image to figure out what to do.
-One suggestion would be maybe you could start out with enough wood to make a tower.

I agree with the below that the first screen looks like an ad. I found the game bewildering at first, and navigating between the areas was difficult. I also was not aware of how close I was to losing at any point, so it shocked me whenever I did.
An interesting concept to say the least. Although I do feel that there's too much going on for what amounts to a relatively simple game.

Huge props for trying something TOTALLY different to anything I've seen in this LD (or in gaming in general actually) and I feel that if the game was less time-based, I would have enjoyed it a lot more. Unfortunately this feels like playing chess while dancing the macerena.
If you decide to build on this game, may I suggest making it turn-based, it's awkward to be puzzling for resources while keeping an eye on the battle to the right.
Nice idea and optics, but it remains quite hard to understand.
Wow, quite ambitious idea you had there, and very well executed for this short timeframe.
Sadly I did not get what this has to do with "Escape"

It took me a while to really figure out how the mechanics fit together, and resource collection (specifically having to drag the locked blocks off the playing field) seemed a bit fussy. Other than that, it's a very fun gave and innovative to the max. Very impressive for 48 hours :)
I really like the concept here. The only problem is that there's so much going on that I feel completely disoriented. It's pretty tough too. Well done!

description:
You are a prisoner of your own conscience.
Gather 10 keys to escape!
author: madflame991
title: Gather 10 keys to escape
comments: Very repetitive, no sound, and I didn't understand the concept.
This is the most boring game I ever seen

I ended up getting murdered by some sort of hand thing and there wasn't much I could do. I caught onto the concept after about 10 rounds or so. I'd have loved to see the choices have a bit more meaning behind them, like instead of the unicats making you stronger, maybe opt to turn them into a key? Not sure if that's the right solution.
Anyway, it was an interesting little experience.
Repetitive. I wasn't quite sure what was going on or why. My son liked it however. More choices would have made it more fun -- I felt like I wasn't much in control.
Haha, interesting idea. I cannot get past the cube head, he's too tough to beat. :D

The enemies were really neat - I died when I got to the rectangle with fingers. I had enough keys, too. It does need more game variety, however. Once you figure out if kicking high or low is the better option, there's literally nothing to the combat.

Total randomness is completely killing it. Sometimes there's dozen of mushrooms in the line, sometimes dozen (well maybe less but anyway) monsters... With some polish, more reasonable choices (and MORE of them) it could be quite good. This way there's almost no reason to play (unless you're the type who just loves pure random chance)
The biggest problem for me was that it was trivial to have almost perfect play, which didn't actually mean you wouldn't die. That was unfortunate I think.
This might have potential for a simple clickidy game, but there isn't much gameplay here. I like the variety, and some of the ideas. It's a little too random though, this may be a good thing though.
Quite repititive. With some variation, decisions that make a bigger difference and sound it would be a far better game.

description:
Escape from prison planet Kajak in this simple space shooter. Espace is made using Qt framework in C++ and so far I've ported it to Windows and OSX. Linux port might be coming, but not within the Jam limits.
There's some reports of background music not working on Windows, but it works on my machine so I'm unable to locate the bug, but it seems like there's some kind of issue between Phonon and Directshow filters.
The OSX version is not fully tested as a release package, so please let us know if there's any problems with that.
Have fun.. and don't forget your towel!
Team:
Code, sfx, music - eimink
Graphics - Hasis
author: eimink
title: espace
comments: I wish I could fire that weapon farther!

Ran on Linux with wine (but I would prefer a native binary =) ) and had fun! Liked the "Shift" mechanic you made. Allowed me to play suicidally :P Also, I wish the ship could move a bit faster (it is hard do avoid the "homing" ships). Good work!

It is a shame that the background music doesn't work for me.  I also felt that the explosion thing was a bit annoying for my taste.  The rest of the graphics were OK and the game was definitively playable and good.
It needs some polish in terms of controls (need to be tighter) and some balancing in terms of difficulty but beyond that not bad!
Everything worked fine (Win7 64bit), but the game does need some polish. I mean, why WSAD controls when not using mouse in any way? I'd much prefer arrows.

description:
Do you have what it takes to save enough cash so you can escape the rat race, go solo and create a runaway-success indie game, setting yourself up for life in the process?  Now you can find out...
This game was made in Scirra Construct Classic.  This means that you will need DirectX 9c and the Visual C++ 2005 redistributable installed in order for it to work.  Both can easily be found via a Google search if required.
The 'source' I have included is simply the Construct .cap file for anyone who's interested.
author: mrbungle
title: Escaping the Rat Race
comments: I like both two games :D Nice idea!! The rat race is too slow, cause not so much fun, but I like overall idea! Well done!

Thanks for your kind words Gornova.  Yeah, I actually made the rat race intentionally slow and frustrating with horrible, annoying music so it better represented the drudgery and maddening elements of going to work for someone else every day of your life.
The transition from rat race to indie-dream world feels great. I want to spend more time in that world!

What an interesting game. I hate the rat-race part, but that's clearly the point. And the indie section is so much more enjoyable because the rat race is so painful. Really interesting idea and well executed.
Interesting concept with the switching between games and all. Second time I got in the indie section the countdown bugged and I could get guaranteed success without much problem.

Quite clever combination of games! As previous posters said you really hate the rat game, but with intended reason. My only gripe is that both the games could need some more polish. I would put up with the rat race more if the indie game was better.
Great concept, and the contrast between the rat race and the indie development is very powerful.
It's also great that indie development feels wonderful but you're also painfully aware of the money running out :)
I would like a little more air control or just somehow easier controls in the indie world to emphasise the difference even more.

I definitely like the idea, and could be taken much further. Not sure I'm a fan of the implementation though, and the maze is very tedious. I know it's intentionally annoying, but "intentionally annoying is still annoying" (Yahtzee). The contrast is great, but I would prefer it to be a contrast in atmosphere, not controls/tedium.

description:
Recommend to play the web version because of the small file size(less than 400KB, Unity3D Webplayer required).
Game Control: Mouse move to control the runner moving Left/Right.
author: Spotlightor
title: Escape the Normal Life
comments: Love, and I mean love the art style. Fun game, the flying at the end really added to the "let your dreams take flight" vibe. However, the atmosphere would have benefited tremendously from some sound.
Yeah, really beautiful minimalist (procedurally generated?) graphics. Fun game, too!
This desperately needs an online high score mode with an infinite path that keeps on going faster and faster. Also, how about something to do with the left mouse button, such as jumping?
Liking the art style a lot. I get the feeling you spent most of your time on the graphics and missed out on some features you would've wanted to implement.
Nice concept, but not much depth do the actual gameplay.
No sound or music. Graphics were OK, i like the ghostly nature of the "normal people", it would have been better if they had sapped your energy or something.

The gameplay is quite lacking, but, I love the style... title, visuals, running animation... everything fits perfectly together. And it's unique too. Better than empty "skilled art" in my opinion. Set to some good music and a little more gameplay interaction and this could become a medium to get lost in.

The game is pretty fun, but quite unforgiving. A mistake gets you way back, but I like that. If only I could do something with my mouse cursor (Win7 keeps showing other windows when the cursor happens to hover over them). Good game!

This was pretty cool, and just about the right difficulty. I fell off once near the end, but never had too many problems. There's more gameplay than some entries I've played, but slightly more variation in the level wouldn't have hurt.
The style is coming together, but some things (the strange character model, the colour green for the path) didn't seem to fit with the grey buildings, black ground thing, and ghostly people.
Well done, though, for thinking a little outside the box and trying something different.

My system is pretty terrible and so the framerate was choppy, but I liked the art style and the gameplay seemed pretty solid. Shame I can't actually make it to the end because the framerate makes it pretty much unplayable.
I like the graphics and that when you die you don't have to start from the beginning again.
It would benefit from some sound and the mouse sensitivity seems a bit low.
Nice job... this didn't start off as a game for a different theme, did it? ;-)

description:
my First Ludum Dare entry and my 3rd game ever. It's am little game where you try to escape different coloured dots and make them explode by steering into each other. You try to escape them until to many of them crashed into you, then you lose and you can write down your score.
The Best thing about this game is the fun I had while making it in this competition.
-Game made with Visual Studio C# 2010 Express edtion and
Xna Game Studio 4
-sound made with "sfxr - sound effect generator by DrPetter"
-graphics made with paint.net
Site note:
Before you start the game make sure you have .net Framework 4 and xna version 4 installed.
If not there are installers for both of these are included in the Package.
author: PeerM
title: Escape the Dots
comments: Congrats on finishing your third game ever and first LD submission.
Very nice third game and Ludum Dare entry! It's really simple and fun, that's always a nice way to go. :) Also, it's worth noting that the effect it plays when you are hit is really neat. Good job!
Well the theme application was kind of weird and the game was just dodge getting shot at by homing bullets. These kind of endless games just do not resonate well with me.
Scored 710 on my first go, not sure if it's good or bad.
Very dynamic and controls are tight. But gameplay lacks depth, gets repetitive quick. Graphics are simple, and not sure anything more is needed really.
Surprisingly fun, for as sparse as it is. Controls feel great, too. With a huge swarm of dots behind me, it feels a bit like geometry wars.
More "avoid" the dots than escape, but nonetheless I had fun trying :-D

description:
My game is about a rabbit trapped in a sort of castle full of wolves. I originally planned it to be more complex, with having the wolves chase you around, finding other rabbits and some other things. If it weren't for the 12-hour extension, this game would have a really small test room instead of a proper level and no sounds, so THANK YOU WEBSITE CRASH!
The game is sort of a dungeon crawler. It should really have more levels, but it was hard enough to make a single one and I don't have any more time. You run through a maze, find things blocking your path, and find things to unblock your path. The game's biggest feature is the turn-based fighting system I managed to put together, which I think is pretty cool for a 48-hour game. It's also pretty fun. I hope you enjoy playing it as much as I enjoyed making it!
EDIT: In response to the comments, the game did always feature a rabbit. I didn't really think about it, the only time it seemed weird was when I was making the bow-holding sprite, but even then it still seemed strangely natural.
author: Petzi
title: Escape from the Wolf Castle
comments: As someone else whose entry hinges on the inclusion of a bunny, I salute you. Also, the game was quite good.
Great! A Bunny using a bow, wtf. I loved the game, too short though but it is a 48h competition. Good job!

I like the exploration style, and it fits the theme well. I wonder if the game originally had a bunny as the protagonist, as you're opening chests, using keys and doors, and wielding a bow! Battle system was super slow and the game crashed immediately on one of my computers. Otherwise it was a good game!
The twelve hours extension was just for uploading, so not going to rate unless you put it as jam. Otherwise, not bad, nice idea for fighting, but it's really too short.
I suck at this battle system.  The game is good though.  However, I am of the same opinion as Shigor that this should be in the "jam" category.  So I rated it a bit lower.
Was pretty bizarre, I did get the fighting system and did feel it was kinda uncomfortable. I like off the wall
Nice old school adventure game. For me the reaction based fighting felt quite difficult so I didn't get that far.

description:
This is a "Game" in which you're in a "Castle" that you have to "Escape" from which is actually "Endless" because it's in your "Dreams" that are full of lag "on purpose" to simulate the "true" "experience". " "
Arrow keys to move, and try not to get stuck inside a wall while on the "magical" lift-y things.
EDIT: The game runs the size of your browser due to the way it's embedded on the page. If you want the game to run faster just make your browser size smaller (Try and keep a working resolution though)
author: Blackduck
title: Endless Castle
comments: Short platformer with no real challenge. Mixed bag with strong innovation but lacking any fun. No fulfillment, purpose or reason to keep playing.
The ending made me chuckle a bit.
the guy looks cute. gameplay is rather boring though :(
i like how the world is distorted though :)
It's too boring, there's really is no gameplay to speak of.

description:
You are the only one left on earth, and there is a meteorite that is going to hit the earth in 10 minutes.. you have to ESCAPE THE EARTH!!! You can do this if you will find all the rocket parts needed to build a rocket.
Controls:
action    - space
movement  - arrows
exit game - escape -> you won't escape by just pressing this button
When you win the game you get your 'time left', post it in the comments!!
I put 3 executable there - big/medium/small for different sizes of the window
P.S when you get stacked just reenter the room..
P.SS - the game map and objects are saved in the data folder, there is no build in editor but you can edit it your self with Photoshop/GIMP + notepad ;) so it's a cool game engine for puzzle games!! maybe I should build a map editor?..
author: Vladp995
title: Earth Escape
comments: got out with 3:22 left, quite a fun game.
Nice game, very solid. But the intro is hideous, perhaps text-only would have been better ... ;)
The semi-scrolling level however don't work. They seem to scroll 1 or 2 tiles, which leaves me wondering wheter the levels are supposed to scroll or be completely immobile.

They are movable and at first you could only seen 15 tile of 20, but before the final I've decided to change it because it was a little pain in the eyes to look at it, and since the code worked with odd numbers, instead of changing it I put it to 19 of 20, so they are scrolling but the room are to small for you to see.
This was cool! The time pressure kinda killed the exploration sense I was starting to enjoy. Game with more levels (screens) so far :)

Good implementation. Levels are big and you get lost quickly. Like the mazes are way too big. No real gameplay reward, except rocket part. Like the variety though. Stone pathways look like walls though. Timer ticking is a little annoying. It's supposed to create the sense of urgency, but I'm not that attached to the character to mourn him too much. :) Had two parts, but I still escaped?

description: Its not a lot, I know. But its something.
author: Game Engine
title: Castle
comments: This is interesting! It was fun to mess around with - putting an actual game in there would just sweeten the deal.
Please continue developing this. The world needs more realtime roguelikes/dungeoncrawlers :)
I can't really wait for you to add more to this game.  Shooting the arrows and swinging the swords was surprisingly entertaining.
It seems to be just a tech demo right now, but definitely keep working on it!
I am interested on the effects the different colored spheres have on the actual gameplay.  If you ever finish the game, please let us know.

description:
Prison Planet Trench Escape!  Escape from the prison planet in a stolen ship while in hot persuit by the bladed THRESHER, the end of many would-be escapees.  Avoid obstacles and shots from defense drones.  Only the Thresher can destroy your craft, but any hits you take will slow you down.  The game is a vertical scrolling game played with the arrow keys or WASD.
Engine: Unity3D
Programming: C#
Modeling: Blender
Art/Textures: Paint.Net, Photoshop
Sound: Audacity, Bfxr
Music: Audacity, Otomata, (ClubCreate) Electro-House Blender
The game meets most all of the requirements for the main competition, but is entered into the Jam because I wanted to work with a partner.  Actually, I'm not entirely sure if mixing software like the electro-house blender is specifically allowed by the rules.  I think it is since the loops are legally usable, but I dunno!
Credits:
Programming: Dan 'Doddler' McNeill
Art: Mike Paulson
author: Doddler
title: Prison Planet Trench Escape
comments: The presentation is nicely done. I like the drawings in the intro. The gameplay is straightforward and easy to grasp. I think it would have been nice to give the player a bit more room, because it gets pretty crammed with just a few enemies.
Nice job getting your friend to help out, cause the art makes this game feel really polished. Fun stuff!
Great art but I would have liked to see non-standard Unity buttons. Game was easy on easy and hard on hard and overall fun. Good job.
this was fun but i noticed it is possible to not die at all..
Good story, nice thresher graphic. I didn't like gaining momentum as I moved left and right.
i like how you fly out into space at the end- feels very serene.
Nice work - especially the evil machine of doom.

description:
A one-button-game (escape), try to escape the evil viking for as long as you can. But be aware of the traps in the castle!
It seems that the distance indicator doesnt work well in chrome for some reason.
author: Mstrp2ez
title: Castle Skate
comments: Cool, few bugs, really needs a preloader.

I liked it! Using "escape" as your primary key is cute (but predictable ;) The player animations were nice and I liked the jump,double-jump,sword and turbo mechanics implemented with the single button.

The first submission to make me laugh (Not at, with. At least I hope.) Not very polished though, the distance indicator didn't display right, the background didn't tile well, and animations could sometimes display weirdly.

description:
Well, I'll be damned! Looks like I can enter the compo after all! I gave up since the server was going so slowly! That said, it's not like I'm going to win or anything, since my random level generator broke for some reason (among other things), but oh well.
Anyway! You're a bubble.... and you jump... straight up! lol Enjoy!
Oh yeah, and originally, the idea was that you were escaping from a porcupine that's chasing you, but my weekend got all screwed up with distractions and I ended up with a half-assed product. =(
author: onefineline
title: Bubble Jump
comments: I gave you only community rating as I have no device to test your game on :-p
I tried to play it in Xcode iPhone Simulator but it seems to break it. I 'win' by doing nothing, as soon as I touch the ball veers off and I lose.
yeah, gave you community vote, sorry no device to play it on.
Not the most original of course, but it could still be a fun game if the bubbles weren't all in the center of the screen. Congrats on getting something in anyway!
I too only could give you community points because I don't own a iOS device.
I'll be damned! People actually tried playing my broken-ass game! Thanks!

description:
Use your mouse to guide birdie out of various buildings he's got himself stuck in. Do it under par to unlock harder levels.
Note: Due to there only being 5 levels(+1 super secret bonus), I made the difficulty quite high. All the levels are possible below par, just try to not hit everything.
author: Darkcoder
title: Beak Free
comments: Awesome concept! It was fun to play but it was too hard at some points. But the flapping sound almost made me vomit.
Wow, painful sounds! Implemented pretty nicely though.
sounds are indeed terrible, nice concept however :D
Having the bird flap at its own intervals made it soooo hard for me to control it. "Don't flap too much", the bird says. Why does the bird taunt me!!!
While frustrating, it's still pretty addictive :p
Cute little game. I think it's a little too punishing on the player to demand par or better on both flaps and hits though! It takes a lot of work to clear a stage.
Something felt wrong with the controls (or I didn't get it). Also the size is too big for my laptop's screen (768 height).
Nevertheless my daughter (just 2 years) really liked to watch my failure with the birdie.

Nice idea! I made it to level 4 but the game was pretty hard, mostly because I felt like my control over the bird was pretty laggy but I was expected to make pretty tight movements. I probably would have been able to play longer if it hadn't been for the flapping sound effect, which was quite anxiety-inducing. Clever idea though!
Shouldn't have locked down the levels the way you did, couldn't beat the first level so I never got to see the rest.
Interesting concept, but too frustratingly hard, requiring lots of patience. I found the sounds quite comical, but I can see how they would annoy me by level 5.
What a great game! Interesting idea, likeable character, the crash noise was a little harsh. I had to play the first level about ten times before I finally got through.
Interesting idea. Although the game is damn hard. Maybe you could have let the bird flap only when the user clicks. Couldn't beat lv. 2, lol. I kept hitting everything on my way. Overall a nice game.
It felt like trying to thread a needle while wearing oven mitts. Remember not all of us had the benefit of playing it 100 times as it was being developed.

"Due to there only being 5 levels(+1 super secret bonus), I made the difficulty quite high" - you know, most of us would probably prefer bit lower difficulty and more enjoyment... for me it was more exercise in frustration then game:(
That's a really great start and an interesting idea, but it would have been even better if you had a few easy levels at the beginning for the player to get used to the controls.
OK, NOW I know how everyone else who played my entry felt! hamster_mk_4 nailed it. I really like the opening menu screen with it's animation and the bird following your cursor with its eyes.
This is a nnice idea, but I think the scoring goes in the wrong direction.

description:
I decided to do this last minute so kept it kind of secret. Didn't tweet or update, just got my head down and made it!
The story goes something like this :
You are a convict in an off world prison facility. A moment to escape rears its head, and you take it. Grabbing the nearby vehicle carelessly left unattended at the gate you make a run for it. Get as far away as you can from the prison before your inevitble capture.
Tools used :
Unity 3.4 Pro
VS 2010
Modo501
Cubase 4
Libraries used :
iTween
JCar
author: quickfingers
title: AWOL
comments: very good work. I am impressed. Its fun to play and looks awesome!
Nice work. Especially with the minimalist graphics.
Wah, nice graphics man, and sounds. And game is somewhat fun. Great work.

Great game, really fun, and it looks great too. Once you play it for a while you really start to get the flow and it actually has a lot of depth. There's nothing more satisfying than flying into the air, turning into a tank, shooting down an enemy plane, and then turning back into a plane... except  for when you do it while doing a backflip, hah :)
My highest score is 5900, but I bet I could pass 6000 or 7000 if I played a little bit more.
Beautiful, and it has great music as well. Most of all, it was fun!
WOW. I can't believe you made this in 48 hours all by yourself.
This one is TRULY great, I would play it on kong thinking it was just another great flash/unity game.
My only complains would be the lazors beam being the same color as the background sometimes, which makes it hard to notice who's shotting at who.
Also, I didn't see any heavy purpose or incentive on using the jet engine.
Great graphics, nice gameplay, good sound, overall a very good game. :)
Very nice.  This game is gorgeous, fun and plays well.
very nice. looks cool and it's even fun to play.
Looks great, plays great, is great.

Very very awesome! Love the atmosphere and physics.  The game is just quite fun to play. One of my favorite moments is transforming into flight mode and soaring over tanks only to drop down onto them and the running men once you fuel runs out. Great job!
I love how getting flipped upside down dosen't break the flow, as you can just turn into a jet and keep on going. Slick.
Nice looking game. Only bummer was that my tank flipped over on almost every soldier I ran over, which took out way too much speed out of the game :(

this game is awesome, particularly 'fly mode' which I almost missed! my only crit would be to add the velocity of the vehicle onto the bullet, cos if you get really fast you can almost outrun your own bullets! anyway, one of my favourites so far!
Presentation is great but I have some problems in control my tank/hovercraft :(
Wonderful. Great atmosphere, music, animation, art and balancing. I really can't fault it!

I was confused by the control scheme the first time I played(managed to skip the instructions by accident and expected left/right to be "accelerate"). The second time I "got it" although it ran sluggishly for me on this laptop.
Excellent video and audio, quite funny game
Fantastic little game. Love the atmosphere!! Controls are a little hard at times but overall top game.
Wow, best game I played so far, fantastic graphic, cool sounds, fun game play. Good work man.
Looks great, but gets repetitive quick. I love the high speed driving/flying, but wonky physics and short sight range somewhat spoil that.
I love it. It's the best game I played so far. Good work! :)
Sooooooo pretty. I'm so impressed by your graphical abilities, especially in 48 hours.

Cool game, awesome graphics and sound but the controls are pretty annoying. Every time I fell upside down I was stuck and every time I was entering the fly mode it automatically switched back after a couple seconds so I couldn't fly D: maybe I got something wrong...

Now I found out that there is a fuel and now it makes a lots of difference. The tank/plane idea is very coll and very fun but still too bad you can't shot forward because you're gonna hit your self. Overall one of the top games no doubt.
I love this game, great grafics and pretty adictive. well done!
My son is addicted to this game.

Really nice graphics and atmosphere! The first time I played I got upturned right away and it was very hard to recover from that. Second time I made it 3km. I would have liked it if there was some kind of end in sight other than losing all my health (a lot of injuries seemed random and hard to avoid), but a real polished game otherwise...

Great fun and excellent presentation. For some reason I really struggled with the fly mode though. Either my head is just not working, or it really wasn't taking off for me. It'd be nice if the craft lifted automatically from the ground a few CM to give the user the air-control... I was just dragging my sorry-ass along the ground.
Nice idea though. Reminded me a little of Spycatcher, with the vehicle changing... maybe add water/boats next? :D

description: Yay! My first Ludum Dare entry. No sound or music though, not enough time :(. You are escaping from... something along the lines of bloodthirsty sumo-wrestlers and soldiers. I had other ideas and level designs, so i guess i will make a post-LD version. Hope you enjoy!
author: blahoink
title: Asplosions!
comments: This was fun :) Certainly interested in a post-LD version!
nice man. I got stuck on the "build a tower to escape" level. Really good concept though!
Good fun! I completed it. I'm awesome.
Pretty cool, the building/destroying mechanic is good though I wish there were an auto-file.
Had a lot of fun with this. Collision was a bit frustrating at times due to the block size in relation to the character, but still played it to the end and enjoyed it.
Haha, major bug on the first sumo wrestler level, after each death they seem to double. Anyway, great game.
Wow I died a bunch against the sumowrestlers now they kill me as I spawn.
Really love this concept, kept getting killed by the sumo wresters though :(

Would have loved to see an auto-fire feature, as it was nearly impossible to play this without a mouse (using laptop touchpad). Level 3 kept murdering me! It feels like they kept spawning more the more I died.
Anyway, love the style and what you had going. I had fun. :D
I loved the idea. In the second level it got stuck dying because of infinite sumo-wrestlers. Funny graphics.
The sumo wrestler part was seemingly impossible and incredibly frustrating.  They spawn quickly and aiming the fireballs to make a big enough space to escape is too hard.
Love the game, especially his facial expressions and the introduction of new mechanics.
Thank you everyone for the support on my first LD! I wasn't aware of the spawn-killing bug after release, sorry. It t'was some data clearing issue, and i'm sure to fix it for the post-LD release!
Neat little game, I made it through once, though the second time I got stuck at the sumo level.  There seems to be a bug where if you die there, the sumos don't ever stop coming in.
Fun game & concept, although the sumo wrestlers seem way too difficult (on my trackpad anyways), and I haven't been able to get past 'em.
LIke the graphics, like the gameplay and the concept.
IF you die, the sumo's continue to spawn right on top of you making it too hard to continue. It was fun up to that point.
Graphics are nice, no sound though (or did my sound just not work)
I really liked it!, looking forward to more.
I loved this game so much. The humour is amazing, timing of pop-up messages is spot on and with a new element each level this is an amazingly solid entry into the competition. Astonishing work.

description:
This is my second game for Ludum Dare and it was so fun! I based my game off of my first game I've ever made :) heres my programs I used:
-Adobe Photoshop
-Mixcraft
-Flashdevelop
-FlashPunk
Just use your arrow keys to move and escape from the creatures of the deep. Pick up a coin for extra points. Submit your score and get achievements!
author: Dmurph
title: A Underwater Escape
comments: Totally fun and easy to play.  Nice music.  wish I could have done more than just move around - but, it's a neat package overall.  Nicely done.
Cool little game, did you make that music - it's pretty damn awesome :)
Ya I did make the music :) I love mixing together songs too! I used Mixcraft if ur interested. Lol And thanks for the comments!
Nice little avoider. Music is good and there are achievements :D
The issue I noticed is that the collision boxes are not easy to guess.
Ya i had that on my checkbox to do but i ran out of time :/
Seems a bit... 'static', but you made a 'complete package' game here, which is very admirable. Good job!
Nice - I fully expected disco lights to kick in after the music started. Love the shark graphics!
Haha ill add a disco ball next time. lol

Solid and simple. A little rough on collision detection and feedback (I would add a timer after death to show the actual result with lots of blood effects, but maybe that's just me :p ) but with the music, the achievements and all, it's a complete experience. Good job.
Dude needs to be more focused on where his body went than he does worrying about sharks and arrows. And yet there he is, the severed head smiling at me, taunting me, telling me to burn things.

description:
Use the "WASD" keys to move around.
Use the mouse to look around.
Use the left-mouse button to use a recall.
Turn on/off the flashlight using the "L" key.
Back to menu by pressing "ESCAPE".
Instructions
-Find the exit (Gap in the edge of the screen)
-You have 30 seconds each level.
-Levels become increasingly maze-like & complex. May require a few run-throughs to complete all levels (only 8).
-Use recalls to save boundary visibility. (not really too useful :P)
Created In:
-FlashDevelop Beta2
-sfxr
Libraries Used:
-None
author: DPbrad
title: .SHADOWS.
comments: Good challenge - I got to level 3, though.  It was tough keeping the flashlight going in the direction I wanted it to go.  Good idea, though.
Nice technology but found the game a bit slow. I didn't actually notice there were spinning things for a while. Cool look game though.

Cool idea, flashlight key should have been closer to WASD though.  The bad key placement ended up in the game going faster if i just blindly ran through rather than stopped moving and checked my surroundings with the flashlight.
Love it. Especially the 'frosting' effect of the flash light. Can you tell I'm hungry?
Interesting! Level 8 is pretty tricky, but I really like the visuals. It would have been nice if the graphics were matched by some atmospheric background music.
Cool game. I really like how the walls look.

Really like the feel and graphics. Had a good time. Somehow I didn't find the mouse to be very useful at aiming the flashlight--when my mouse left the game window it caused problems, but since the light is relative to the character you have to keep moving it to keep it in a certain direction. I almost think having the flashlight correspond to absolute position on the board (e.g. when the mouse is at "three o clock" it always points east) might have been better. Also, some tense music would have been great. Very original and cool feel though. Great first game!
I love the look and feel of the game, though can't work out what the 'recall walls' thing does.
It would be easier if the flashlight toggle was on 'F' rather than 'L' so it's nearer to WASD. Some sort of music that fits with the visuals would also be a good addition.

Thanks for the feedback guys! I understand the "L" key placement was a bad choice, and also the "recall walls" feature is largely useless for this game, but maybe for a larger game where you can proceed through a massive building, it could be helpful.

And I simply just did not have enough time to get the music done to a decent level, so decided to leave it out. I had just started doing sound effects (The only one there is the time countdown after 5 seconds).
This one nails the "lost in the dark"-motif that's been tried before. The flashlight-battery empties very fast, the flickering is awesome, and the reflecting walls work very well.
Great idea, but needed things to keep it fresh. The recall was a great idea, it would've been nice if you could make it more useful.

Idea of remembering walls is very nice, although mostly useless, but it could be used as one of the keystones for a specific gameplay. With some polish and some other features (currently it really is boring, I quit after third level) this could work quite well.

description:
This is Tools. A text-based prison escape game. You acquire items and you use them to craft tools which will help you in your escape. Of course, it is not that simple, because there are also people who will stand in your way.
Don't be afraid to experiment and find out all the crafting recipes. There is a total of 12 recipes and 17 items. (Some of which absurd!)
If everything is okay, all the bugs are eliminated. I thank you all for the support but I would like to specially thank Mjiig, Marach and Fififox for helping me out with the most annoying bug of my game.
I'd also like to thank the people behind Ludum Dare for making this all possible!
author: Sanguine
title: Tools
comments: This is pretty cool! I like the fact that you get many chances instead of loosing when you make a mistake.
In theory, you get 5 chances. But it almost never happens that you keep failing.
This is a beautiful game, maybe a little longer (50 days..) but I really like it.
You need to put some music in it, some graphic (I'm thinking like a rougelike game with a tileset) and will be a gret game.
p.s: add more prisoner with stabbing desire :D
Thanks. I'm thinking of adding more RPG-elements to the game and making it non-text based.
What a clever game ! My favorite so far ! The feeling of prisoner routine is here and you are right in the theme. Good work !
I very much want to try this out, but can't manage to get it to download.  Any help here?
I reuploaded it especially for you another time ;) http://www.mediafire.com/?ga9vjv7pl6bmk8w

On the first playthrough I got caught a lot and never crafted anything, found any teammates or anything. The second time I made a number of things, made trades, got a helicopter, and it was much more interesting!

Congratulation for trying (and quite suceeding) something different. After I've hacked your sources and removed the incredibly annoying pause between lines I played for a while, then I took a bit better look on sources what is and is not possible.

What is hurting your game is the total randomness which can make or break experience. For example trading would be much more useful if convicts offered you something for something you already have. It would be nice to have some more interaction possibilites like choosing whether you want to go to gym, or look for convict to recruit / trade, or hunt for items.

description:
My fabulous entry and also my first into Ludum Dare. Made using FlashDevelop, FlashPunk, PunkUI and Photoshop.
Those pesky sharks are up to no good yet again! They wait with their mouths wide open in anticipation of gobbling up some unbeknownst swimmers as they hurtle towards them.
You - Yes, you! - are their life ring wielding saviour! Move across the bridge using the arrow keys and throw life rings to help the swimmers avoid the nasty sharks. Z will throw a ring which will move swimmers to the left and X will throw a ring which will move swimmers to the right.
You're their only hope!
author: Psy
title: Sharks Are Evil
comments: Fun, little, addictive game. Only thing which I didn't like was the movement of the sharks, sometimes they just directly jumped into the people who were already past the bridge, eating up to 3 at once without me being able to do anything.
Sharks are crazy, unpredictable beasts! Also, evolution has granted them the power of teleportation.
I liked it.   Make it into an iphone game, polish it, and make some money.

I don't like how the sharks teleport randomly. If they shifted over a lane or two that might be better, but it just feels like I'm hopeless to save them and I'll do just as good if I let the people fall randomly.

It took until about the 5th wave for me to realize that the preservers shifted their lanes. In the description text, maybe make it more obvious as to their functionality? I thought I could just throw them and if they touch, they are saved.
At first I didn't know that the life rings just moved people around.  I though that just touching them was enough.
Also, the shark movements are so unpredictable that is very hard to save anyone.  When I think someone might be safe, a shark just moves to that lane and "noms noms"
fun game ! Try to add hints for the player so he can predict the next shark move
I didn't get what I should do, as whenever I tried to make the people move away from the sharks, the sharks would just teleport around and eat the people I moved nonetheless.
But overall, pretty slick game. Wish you have made some audio, at least recorded a "Nom nom nom" on your mic.
The shark movement's been already mentioned, and I have to agree, that could do with some fine tuning.

description:
A prison break has occurred and Custody Carl is the specialist police officer who will recapture the escaped convicts.
This is my second LD48 entry. Again, using SFML and C++. The art was done in paint.net.
Unfortunately, the game didn't progress as far as I had hoped, but enjoy it for what it is! Have a happy day and thank you for checking out my entry.
author: feyleaf
title: Return to Custody
comments: It would've been a lot more interesting if there was some sort of conflict - maybe some of the prisoners would try and attack Carl or something of the sort. The game's not overly bad, you applied the theme well and the graphics are pretty well-made, (albeit at times a wee bit glitchy) but the whole "lact of clinflict" thing really got to me, sadly. I would have easily rated this a 3 overall if there was something to worry about, maybe a 4 if it had some audio thrown into it too (and it was well-done.)
Cool concept, but AI is very simple and don't really pose a threat or can escape. There are also collision bugs. The rope is very long :) With variety, this could be taken further.
Demonstrates the idea and shows that with more time, you could make an interesting game out of it!

The graphics are not bad, idea is fine and catching mechanic seems to work well. Other than that, I must agree with others that the game needs some more variety. Maybe the prisoners could escape after some time of being tied up, or could hurt the main character when touching him? Nice entry and it does have some potential - worth working some more on it.
@panzermancer @Rudy @ExciteMike @marudziik Thank you for the feedback. All of your comments are well taken into consideration. I shall make something even better for the next LD competition.

description:
Misspelled title, I know. Oh well
Phew I'm glad I got this done. This is a dungeon crawler I programmed from scratch in C, using SDL for rendering. Coded my own TGA loader so only SDL is required. Enjoy. :)
For Windows - Just extract the zip and run the EXE to play, no installation needed!
Massive thanks to vede for compiling it for Linux!
Please visit my blog at ryanpridgeon.net :)
Gameplay vid; http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PoGLc3_WJKU
-Ryan
author: RyanPridgeon
title: Ryan's Labrynth
comments: good that you got a game done is such a short time :) nice work buddy

Impressive work considering how much you put in to the back end stuff. The game initially felt fun, but as it went on, began to get frustrating. Enemies were placed right outside of doorways, and since there was no damage cooldown, you could be killed in an instant walking through a doorway and not knowing what was behind it. Dying was also really frustrating, because while the graphics were fine, everything kind of looked the same. It was hard to get back to where you were.

If there was more variety, maybe items to pick up or more enemies, it would have been more exciting to continue, to see what was next. Without anything more to find though, I didn't feel a need to finish.
You definitely have something here, you just needed more time for balancing and content.
As stated on IRC, more speed please =)

Thanks for the comments :)  I agree wbobeirne, the last stretch was kind of a rush and there was loads more I planned to do; more distinguishing tiles & level design, more enemy types, checkpoints, etc... but it was quite a rush; I only started yesterday :)

I absolutely loved the shooting component you added to the game. Lacks some kind of story. I just wish there was more speed, and that the collision was a displayed circle in the center. Keep developing it, i would play it!
I played this this morning, but didn't finish for two reasons.
1) The character moved so slow! It felt like he could be sped up 2 or even 3 times and it'd feel a lot better.
2) No health pickups (that I encountered). Death seemed inevitable after a few minutes in, so it was frustrating to crawl back and forth to the location you died.
The collision felt a bit off, as well. How was the hitbox done? It feels like is isn't pixel perfect and I was hit by shots I felt like I had dodged.
Either way, it ran smoothly and I had fun trudging around while I did. Speed would have helped out immensely here, though. :)

description:
Well, I made this game, it's not very good, but I hope you guys like it.
You will need XNA, Content folder is all of the images I used, the LudumDareEntry folder is all of the source code.
Extract both the content folder and the rescape.exe to a folder, and run rescape.exe to start the game.
Thanks for playing.
author: Staneh
title: Rescape
comments: It's a good start :).  I've tried XNA in a game jam before and I know that it's a bold choice in engine.  This game could really use some sound as well as a little more polish (like the main character still being around in the end screen :/)

Sadly there's not much to like here... first level is simple "adventure" (knife in the sink in the prison cell, sigh...), combat scene in second level isn't combat at all... There are worse games entered in the Ludum Dare, but not much of them. Better luck next time.

Intro cutscene is far too long, the game is too short and easy. It's not a bad start in game programming, but using XNA seems like wasting resources (though it really depends on how familiar are you with coding, etc. - hard to tell since you didn't write _anything_ in your journal). You could do a lot better, but I will assume you did your best. There are worse games in the compo.
I can't play it.  I start the game, but I don't see anything, not even a window.  In the task manager, I can see the rescape.exe process one or two seconds and then it ends without any error message.

description:
by SLiV, Joszs and Ever121
Your vessel's shields are about to give way, your ammunition is depleted and you're about to throw yourself headlong into a room filled with hostile turrets and explosives.
If only you hadn't been so reckless in the past.
In Left, you control a small craft on its way to escape from a dangerous facility. You start out with fully charged shields, loads of rounds and even a couple of rockets. However, they'll have to last pretty long if you're planning to get out.
Luckily, you can revisit the past and master your challenges to perfection, granting you more room to spare in the present.
This topdown action/agility game was made in less than 72 hours. Tested to work on Windows 7 and XP.
author: SLiV
title: Left
comments: This one was brutal to beat. Revisiting levels in order to help on future stages was good until I realized that future events had consequences in the past as well. Like having lower health on past stages because of screwing up on future ones.
A really deep and well thought out game.
Dammit, when I finally beat it it crashed =(
Nice game, but the controls were a bit difficult because the ship takes a while to stop.

description:
Windows version patched to fix illegal resolution bug.
All versions are wrapped in an installer. I had no real way of circumventing this without having you install the full ~120MB panda3d SDK and python so please dont hate me too much.*
Game is far too easy at the moment. Needs some balancing
Linux/Mac will need to make do with source only for the moment as I can't get packpanda to work on Ubuntu. Anyone with panda3d can run this with
$ python infall.py
*so it turns out I can package the game as a standalone executable but it will download the runtime at launch and thats probably worse than the current installer method so I guess I'm stuck with installers for now. Thanks for understanding
author: voxel
title: INFALL
comments: I have to be honest, I don't REALLY understand what I'm doing. Am I meant to be getting out of orbit? The boosters didn't seem to do a lot, I was just kinda left floating around.
Very pretty, though. I liked having a chair...
'What to do' is on the big monitor on the left wall of the cabin. Guess it could be clearer. Thanks for playing Zed

It took me a while to figure out I was supposed to mouselook around the cabin to see those side screens. I know the instructions screen told me I could look around, but I didn't see a reason to look anywhere other than out the front window at first.
can't get the Linux64 version running.. it installed panda3d and then fails on "no module named datetime"..
I have python-egenix-mxdatetime and python-dateutil installed
None survive. Nice game, slingshotted myself around the planet. Audio loop gets repetitive quick. Looking around in the cabin was probably too distracting.
It seems panda's definitely not right choice for an engine to use on ludum dare :) hundred megabytes of dlls almost scared me out of my sanity.

As for the game... there's not much of it, after I understood what I'm supposed to do it was just a matter of aiming a bit on the right and hit the thrusters. About the only thing I liked was music, simple, but it's enough. Better luck next time.

description:
My game is called "Globular Prisonbreak". It's an action-puzzler about speed, precision, space, and color. A Blob creature, known as Bloopie, makes its escape from a Gnomish prison. There are 27 short levels in this frantic tetris-meets-frogger arcade.
The idea is to dodge globular bullets coming at you from all sides as you make your way to the top of the level. If you are hit, the glob attach to Bloopie, becoming an extension of its body. So just don't get hit right? Not so simple... Blocking your path are laser force field gates which must be disarmed by sacrificing an exposed glob of matching color from Bloopie's body. Don't have the right color handy? Just absorb it from the bullets. But here's where it gets fun--the glob bullets are initially all grey. An absorbed glob adopts the color of the floor tile where it was absorbed! Pay heed to next color you'll need... and get the bullet in the right spot! Stay thin or get stuck and crushed in the stone gateway exit.
What I used to make this game:
A netbook.
Flash Develop
Flex compiler
Flixel 2.55
A desktop with crash-a-lot hardware (for music/graphics).
Pxtone (ptVoice and ptCollage)
Now a few notes on my first experience with Ludum Dare:
I've been wanting to compete in ld48 or the jam for a few years now, but haven't had the time. I wasn't really prepared for this one either... I just stumbled here in the first several hours of competition and decided to join in. I'm so glad I did--it was a blast!
Unfortunately my first game could not be polished as well as I would have liked before presenting it. There are some bugs, although the whole thing is quite playable and enjoyable throughout. I never did beat it in development, although I have just now for the first time while writing this... so you can except it to get quite challenging. Some honest advice: The game will tend to hide its bugs if you don't mash keys. Keen sight and a little hesitance will escape through the final 10 levels.
I'm especially proud of the idea this game presents. I plan to improve on it in the future, starting with some fixes and features that didn't make the 7pm (PST) contest deadline.
And last but not least.. I'm VERY MUCH looking forward to trying out YOUR games over the next few weeks!
author: Edsploration
title: Globular Prisonbreak!
comments: nice concept but the game itself could use work. Also I could just rotate myself past most of the goals.

A great concept, but unfortunately just devolves to me brute forcing and rotating like a mad man. Could use some work on making the strategy of making colors a better option than just mashing Z and X.

Thanks for the comments! They Match my thoughts on it so far. Actually I tried last minute to fix the brute forcing past barriers but ended up breaking rotation further.. changed it back and resulted in more bugs overall. This was my first ludum dare so I'm happy regardless of the initial result. :D

interesting concept, i got really confused tho in level4 i think it was or 3, where i was getting hit and the colour didnt turn into the same as what was under it, restarted and it gave me a different set of barriers and i got past tho
Not really challenging.  Sometimes, I could simply rotate and move past the lasers.
Interesting concept but I got overwhelmed and confused.
Quite creative. I think it would benefit from a tutorial or something because it can be confusing at first. Liked it though.
The game is cool for a first LD entry and you should continue working on it.

Especially because this is a very original idea. The first time I started it (without reading the manual), I thought it's some kind of Tetris/DrMario/etc. kind of game (of course, I didn't know what to do, e.g. that I have to escape through the hole in the north). But after reading the description I saw that there is more to it.

description:
My first Ludum Dare and the shortest amount of time I've had to produce a game.
Controls:
WASD or arrows to move
spacebar to interact
P to start game
escape to quit game
Escapism is a game about the joy of games and the struggle to find balance in a life that is anything but exciting, where there is no escape.
author: dramble
title: Escapism
comments: Cool idea man. Looks like you didn't finish it. But playing the game within the game was pretty cool.
Escape the Zombies is arguably the hardest game...ever. It seems like there should be some sort of strategy but I just keep dying over and over. It was kinda addicting though.
A neat concept, but I wasn't sure if there was a point to it (or maybe that IS the point and I'm not getting it).
Mucho likey! Could benefit from some fail conditions (for running out of money or energy). I really got into escape the zombies (I think I got about 1,300,000 in the end)

This feels likes it's right on the cusp of being a good art-game experience if it were fleshed out more. I think the main thing that is missing is a feeling of consequence. "Escaping" into the zombie game doesn't have any real effect on the rest of the game world - similarly, letting your money and energy go to 0 also do nothing. Introducing some dynamic that adds some tension and choice between the escapism and the "real" world could do a lot for the game and its meaning.

description:
The game revolves around escaping a collapsing facility of some sort in your rocket. It has quite a retro feel to it, with a good measure of pixel art and 8-bit music. The oncoming blocks and background are procedurally generated, so each play will always be different.
Note, the controls are touchy; this is so you're able to dodge large obstacles effectively.
Page on my website: http://nova-fusion.com/games/facilitated-escape/
Time-lapse video: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1mFjpDqBEPE
Gameplay video: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IZhfP9omp_w
Enjoy!
Update: The 1.0 (post-compo) version of this game has been released. You can check it out on my website with the first link above.
author: BlackBulletIV
title: Facilitated Escape
comments: Very funky, can I have a mobile version please?
@kevglass Thanks! That's a good idea. I'd have to learn some more about iOS and get a developer account though.
Cute game, makes me dizzy/sick to play it though, something to do with the player's fixed y-position and the scrolling.

Player's collision area might work better if it was a bit more generous (sometimes I died by accidentally just nicking a wall with the back of my ship, when I meant to ninja-ishly scoot around the back of it, and felt cheated).
@ChevyRay Thanks. You're right about the collision, it should be more generous, at least on the top and bottom.
I had some frame rate issues, but the graphics and game play were solid.

@hamster_mk_4 Thanks. I did have some minor issues as well, but for me it was caused by having too many other applications rendering at the same. Minimise those and I could get it over 600 FPS. It might also be related to drivers, or just something in Love2D; not sure really.
I like it.  Rock on for using Love 2D.

Regarding collisions, I'd like if I couldn't crash into the sides of oncoming blocks.  It sucks to try to switch tracks too early and wipe out.  Course, I'm kind of drunk, so maybe it's user error.  STILL, I liked the music, reminded me of games in my youth.
Space theme and shaking screen were cool too.  I appreciated those touches.

It's probably a good idea, but I'd only want that effect if the user only lightly hit the sides. Realistically, if you slammed a rocket into the side of a wall, it'd blow up. (And yeah, being drunk wouldn't help, lol.)
This one is hard. the rocket moves a bit fast so I fly myself to the sides of the blocks. But very nice game.
Wow, I really liked this game! I had a lot of fun, and the audio is great. The procedural generation makes the game - it's got a lot of replay value.
@cornedor Thanks. And yeah, it is pretty hard; takes some practice. But of course, since it's procedurally generated, there's no "end" to get to.
@jonnopon3000 Thanks a lot! I agree, it would hardly be as much fun without the procedural generation (just like Canabalt).

Nice little game with nice little polished graphics. Nice overall :) My only problem was that it seemed like I would occasionally run into situations that were simply inescapable, for no problem of my own. Maybe be a little more generous? I mean, I'm going to die anyways... :-)

@johnfn Thanks! You're correct in what you say, there's some impossible situations generated by this version of the game. I am however continuing to develop the game, and thanks to feedback of others it's now (in my opinion) quite a bit fairer than what was submitted.
It says my computer doesn't support framebuffer and can't play.
@summaky Yeah, unfortunately framebuffers (OpenGL 3+, I think) are a requirement at this stage. I'm going to try using SpriteBatches, which is supported by OpenGL 1.something and higher.

description:
Worked on this about 12 hours.. the other 36 were filled with sweet sleep, bbq and getting drunk with friends.
I wanted to do something space-related first, but couldn't think of anything cool.. so I took the coolest thing from space (black holes) and made them into a weapon (:
The gameplay is pretty straightforward: use the gravitational pull of the black holes to get to the end and escape the facility.
Don't expect nice graphics or audio.. (:
Should work in recent versions of Chrome, Opera and Firefox. Probably not in IE.
(hihi, now there are three games with that name)
author: Murphy
title: Escape Velocity
comments: Aaaarrrgh... that S-shaped room (in the screenshot) is a killer. Couldn't get past it...Good fun though!
I also went with "Escape Velocity" as the name ... so I had to come scope out the competition ;)

A few bugs, but I could see what you were going for, and a few good moments of flinging myself about. I kind of wish placing one would kill the last one, although that might be integral to expanding the puzzles later. Didn't really feel like I was in complete control of where i was firing.
I didn't get very far, but I like the concept. Not bad!
Already the 3rd web-based game that doesn't work for me, must be something wrong with my flash =/
There really are a lot of things I wanted to tweak more (e.g. the direction of the shot currently is not accurate), but had no time ): Maybe I'll revise the whole thing soon.
@puffi: Huh, that's weird.. what Browser (& Version) did you use? There's no flash in there, it's all Javascript. (:
I was using FF 3.6.20 ( seems like I updated to 6 only on my laptop) which should explain a lot.
Runs fine on Chromium so I'll get around rating it.

I should know better than to steal a black hole gun. ;)  Riding an event horizon is hard, and this little guy can whiz through a dozen of them!  Fun game, if rather buggy.  The first time around I reached the end level without knowing it, I was just stuck in a blank grey level.
Nice idea, too bad you hadn't spent more time on it and less on getting drunk :)
great idea, i just couldn't play it very well :) would be good to polish up the gameplay

description:
You're an indentured pilot, working for EscaCorp interstellar delivery company.
Your father was also a pilot but he crashed the company's ship, leaving you with his debt.
Your boss gives you so little fuel for each trip, you're lucky not to slam into a planet or be lost careening into deep space! You have no choice though; you're just a few deliveries away from earning your freedom!
You have to use the gravity of stars and planets to slingshot your way to the delivery zone!
Use the arrow keys to accelerate but watch your fuel! (METER ON THE LEFT)
F5 resets the game. I said F5 RESETS THE GAME!
Pause pauses :)
Note: The delivery zone is always to your right somewhere.
Thanks for playing! :)
By the way, this is my first Ludum Dare entry. I really appreciate every comment that lets me know someone has played it and REALLY appreciate the great feedback I've been getting!
Post-compo EDITS:
I now have 3 executables in my .zip. See readme.txt and take your pick! Extra-crispy is the latest and greatest and by far the tastiest but is VERY post-compo [latest is v1.2].
New Features Added:
Multiple ships (extra lives).
Menu with multiple difficulties.
Target zone indicator.
Animation and more.
The compo executable is there too (EV_Gross_Compo.exe) and none of it's original assets have been fiddled with.
I now have a linux executable and source! THANKS JohanAR!
author: Jedi
title: Escape Velocity
comments: The gravity is buggy and often flung me out of the level. Good job finishing though!
Thanks for the comment. There are some bugs i.e. involving moving the window or if your frame rate drops really low it might mess up.
I wonder if what you're describing isn't what I would call "featurey" though ;). I worked hard to tweak the Star-Trek-(go-back-in-time)-slingshot-feel of the gravity and I like it for the gameplay.
Oh yeah, occasionally going out of the level was something I just decided to live with. It's WAY easier than, say, tiling the level.

I guess I can't edit my own comments here? (Or don't know how). Anyway, thanks again, Jacic. I tried opening a few instances and it's definitely a frame-rate dependence thing :*(. I tried to code for independence as much as I could. I think it's only the big skips that screw everything up. No clue what kind of system requirements I have but they shouldn't be TOO strenuous! Up Next? Physics in a thread with a set step interval. Didn't think I'd really need it. *harumph*
I think it's much more about luck than maneuvering... There's far too much speed and so little control to your ship. It was fun attempting the first level for a while, but I never finished it...
The idea is fun, but the implementation is bad. Keep working on it! Hint: make it slower, in general.

Thanks for the feedback! I'll say more in my postmortem but after watching a friend play, I think a big problem was my "growing up" with the mechanic of the game and knowing how to play it as I went (and not playtesting sooner).
For the record, BlueShaman, it's definitely not down to luck! (Unless you're seeing a bug, which is quite possible) I can beat the 1st level w/ over 90% fuel left about 90% of the time.
Thanks again everyone! If this game sucked before, please give it another go!
I've (hopefully) fixed it so it's framerate independent and at least rocks or sucks the same on most every pc.

It was a small change: I was updating the physics every frame feeding it the amount of time passed, now I update the physics with a set stepping (1/200th of a second), updating it multiple times if necessary.
I made this change so the game would play for everyone but RIGHT away I noticed the playability on my pc went up about 150%! I said, "Yup. That was it." ;)
I left the physics otherwise alone. I can now beat my own game about 25% of the time and, at least for me, it's always fun :). Keep the comments coming, please!
It's more fun than I would have thought, my greatest issue with it is that when you crash you're taken all the way back to the first level.

It is too hard (postcompo version being slightly better) unless you really spend a lot of time learning it all over again with trial and error. Good idea, but to be it really funny you'd have to slow it down a bit and give player some warning (at least direction to the target would be nice). This way you have to try and try and try (took me about ten tries just to locate the exit in the second level)
The game itself is neat. I liked it although the little control you have over the ship was a bit frustrating.

I didn't see the escape theme at all, but it's a nice entry. Try balancing a little bit the game, by either reducing the speed or giving the player more fuel and perhaps a way to slow down or stop (that may consume fuel too). Overall quite interesting. Hope you finish it someday.

The "original" version has fake difficulty caused by having to restart from the start after dying. I'm glad you've tried to respond to complaints by making improved versions; that's why I gave you a high community rating. "Escape velocity" is also a distinctive take on the theme.

description: So this is our entry into the competition.  Unfortunately it didn't go as planned at first due to technical issues, but luckily we found a plan B and made do with the time we had left.  It's not as complete as we wanted, but we will update it routinely outside of the competition.  Which will increase the interactivity substantially.  Thank you all for checking us out.
author: Dookington
title: Escape to the Stars
comments: Awesome game, well-made and amusing. But what's the deal with the icon?
Im not going to sign up to a website to download your file
There's no need to sign up, GigaClon, just click on "Slow Download" and you'll be able to get it.
Sweet! I thought this was so cool, art was awesome, music was great and humour too, feels like you've got a framework here for something cool in the long term

Err, you don't have to sign up to download it, but you do have to scroll down to the bottom and then wait around. I'll mirror it here so nobody else has to go through that: https://s3.amazonaws.com/excitemike/misc/Escape+to+Stars+1.0-win32.zip
(you might want to change the link at the top to point to the new mirror, Dookington!)
Short and sweet. Really funny. Great art and great music. I liked it!
I re-routed to the new mirror since some people seemed to have some trouble
@Marach - the icon is something we just forgot to change.
Thanks everyone for your comments, we do plan to extend the game to a longer amount.
Entertaining, if a bit brief.  "Boring Girl = Boring Ending!" made me a smidgen sad, tho. >_>
The art, both graphics and music, is fantastic.  It is a shame that the story is (understandably) so short...

description:
You've just completed a mission deep in the heart of Berlin.
* Make your escape via the heavily-guarded Autobahn.
* Keep your speed up to confuse the German machine-guns.
* Watch out for the tar-traps and blockades.
Control scheme is a little involved, but it's not a racer. Try jumping!
No sound/music sorry. Ran out of time.
The source is a Unity project. Extract it to a folder and open that folder in Unity if you need to look at the source.
author: hakearok
title: Escape Kraut
comments: I like the idea, it reminds of the Need For Speed quarter mile races.
Also, took me a while to figure out how to accelerate. That instruction needs to be bigger :-)
Good game. I especially liked it because most of the other games were 2-D platformers. Reminds me of Crazy Taxi, but with a twist. Bravo!
Awesome work. My only complaints would be not being able to control your jump mid-air and that the machinegunners were a bit cheap.
Aside that, very very good work here!
After I finally noticed that you can accelerate with W it was really fun. ^^
Liked the general idea of the gameplay. Jumping motorcycles ftw :)
Audio would have been great. It took me some time to get that the reason I died was because of a machine gun :)

description:
Escape the black chomper.
(hint: this is an endless game. it took me FOREVER to test it.)
Please report all bugs to me.
author: thatshelby
title: Escape Infinity
comments: I liked this a lot. Some of the enemies were a bit hard to deal with, but the concept was very fun and the health made it fairly forgiving, if not too much ("Oh I took too much damage early on maybe I should just kill myself"). Loved the menu style
Haha, nice game. Love the big black chompy thing and your (small) humor style. Showing health by bullet color was also clever. I liked that almost everything was destructible too. Solid LD game!
