Solid, fun, a little punishing at times, but some nice work all the same. I found the controls a bit fiddly at times, but that may have been my computer.
mys best is 4850 ! The game was fun... The control and escape feeling would be easier if you could slide on the block and not only freeze when you are near an entrance

6800 on my first attempt, which was ended with green health due to getting tangled up on a wall. Less on my second. Tweaks could include slightly faster ship movement and sliding on walls, like Ben said. Maybe also a charge shot that gets built up while you don't fire, so you can save up for a large single-hit bullet instead of firing continuously all the time. Could add an extra sense of skill and elegance to playing, basically ducking forward between oncoming bullets and delivering a well-placed punch to kill the opponent.

Pretty fun little shmuppy thing.  Solid gameplay, nice clean visuals.  The small window meant there was lots of opportunity to click outside it, but that didn't seem to be an issue since I keep the mouse button held down all the time.  My only complaint is that the enemy shots moved so fast that avoiding them often felt like more luck than skill.

author: Games_1
title: ESCAPE FROM troll CASTLE
comments: Would also have worked with the big and small theme :) One disadvantage with being small and slow is that the levels felt a little empty, and I spent what felt like a long time waiting for platforms to move back and forth. I like the humor though
Oh the wait and wait and wait before I move somewhere or until the platform rides to me... :( it really kills the mood
hehe good humour! The scale was messed up but I liked the cute running of the small character :)
The scale seemed completely off which made the rooms seem a lot bigger than they were.
Got stuck in a wall when a platform pushed me into it and couldn't continue.
Could really use a better indicator of the area your attack covers and how the enemies are hittable. Their hitboxes did not seem to match the graphics.
Got stuck on the ceiling as the platform pushed me too.
The character is too slow, just walking back and forth becomes boring because of that.
I really liked the audio tough.

description:
This game is somewhat of an adaptation of Flatland, by Edwin A. Abbot, though that wasn't really my intention going in.
My intention, instead, was to use the Facebook API and social network to create an asynchonous co-operative experience, where players worked together to complete the game and the story.
I've done this to the extent that the game is quite possibly impossible to finish alone, and still very hard to finish when working with others (note: the social aspect is hidden at first, but becomes consequential once you get to the later levels, and hopefully will become apparent).
This is pretty much an experiment, partly in story and partly in social media. I'd love to hear your takes on it.
(please note that for the social aspect to work at all, it requires you and one of your facebook friends to play. It also only really kicks in after you're both at level 10. This is something that the game would ideally flag more, but I didn't get around to it...).
More notes can be found on the webpage.
(for those looking at the source - note that I took the php files off the source viewer as they were being executed rather than viewed for some reason. They'll still be in the zip, with database info stripped out, of course)
UPDATE: Added commentary on youtube.
MORE UPDATE: Postmortem!
author: pdyxs
title: Escape from Flatland: an Adventure of Two Dimensions
comments: How do I get the social part to work? Does it write something on my wall or what?
Wow, that's really great! I'm a big fan of Flatland and this is both true to the book and fun to play!
@tnelsond - this is probably where it falls down a bit - the social part requires you and one of your facebook friends to play, and only really kicks in if you're both at level 10.
Neat idea! A bit frustrating at times due to the controls being a bit touchy, but very fun.
I really like what you have done here. My favourite so far. Simple look hides the depth of the subtle gameplay. Really pleased to have played it.

Liked the game. Didn't test the social part, so I am not evaluating it... (And I know first hand that it is a pain in the arse to develop for the Facebook API =P) Cool story, couldn't get pass the level where there were all those lines... That was to be expected... [I have no friends who like this kind of stuff *cries*]. So, great game! Hope you publish it as a Facebook app, and build a user base from that =) Only one complaint: slippery controls... The triangle rotates way too fast, and moves slowly (in relation to the rotation speed).

This was an aamzing game! I managed to escape, but then got stuck not having a partner. The idea was really smart, the controls and breaking were cool, the plot and story were really fun. Minor criticism--it seemed like the other shapes could move/rotate in any direction whereas the protagonist can only "thrust" forward, which is a big disadvantage. Maybe I was just imagining that? Overall amazing game, great job!
Wow - thanks for all the awesome feedback guys, glad you all liked it.

@N0_Named_Guy - yeah, the controls were done right at the start and I didn't really tweak them. I'm really confused as to how to publish it as a facebook app, it keeps asking me for different urls and then not telling me how to give it a name etc... do you know of any good guides?

@d_m Hmm - woulda been cool to allow you to go forward in any direction, but the controls'd get a little complex. You'll notice that the regular shapes are able to thrust in any direction, but isosceles triangles don't (as they have one, much pointier edge they always attack with).
I liked the breaking mechanic, gave it a real sense of strategy. But the lines.. oooh the lines.
-Have the triangle always face the mouse
-When holding down LMB, they advance toward the mouse.
-When holding space, they retreat away from the mouse.
@Andrew - yeah, the lines are pretty hard to kill...

@panzermancer - Yeah, mouse control would've been a good thing to implement (tbh i'd have probably made it a choice, as i mostly play games on my laptop and get annoyed when there's no keyboard only option :P)

Very cool idea and story fits great with the theme. Controls are too responsive. Nice geometry/collision/slicing, but the triangle tends to "stick" and slide on walls. Also tiny hits cause insta-slicing. I can see potential. Not sure I'm into the whole "social" thing.
I was sad when the music stopped.  I really enjoyed the music. (And the game!)

This was a fantastic idea, and for the most part a fantastic implementation, but even though me and a friend were signed in and i was well ahead of him, he never got an ally. We were both playing at the same time, is that the problem?

description:
This is written in C (Standard 89) and uses SDL and SDL_ttf.
I didn't quite finish as well as I wanted, but it's playable. It runs well on both Linux and Windows.
To play, type in a command followed by a space.
The commands are usually pretty basic stuff like "run" or "sprint".
(Those aren't real commands in the game, if I told you what the commands were that would spoil the fun.)
Just remember commands are separated by spaces which means when you type a space the command starts over.
This is a simple game which hones your typing skills, so any key that isn't a letter or a space will just send gobbley gook to the program.
Keep typing and you can help Esca (The purple rectangle) escape from illiteracy.
EDIT: If anyone can beat this please let me know. As for right now it's probably too hard. (I made the level in the last couple minutes before the compo ended) :D.
People who have finished the game:
-Tnelsond (ofcourse :))
-Shadow
-the31 (editted the mapfile)
-LegacyCrono
-jwfrosty
author: tnelsond
title: Esca
comments: I loved the way you controlled the character. It would be nice to be able to stack commands like code though :)
You can kinda "stack" commands by typing commands really fast.
All you have to do is type a command, then a space, then another command.
Or do you mean like create new commands?
Or do you mean stack commands like "walk 5"?
Didn't get past the flap command, but interesting control mechanic. It would be nice if it would automatically press enter after every successful command.
I considered not requiring the space between the commands, but then I figured it wouldn't help people's typing skills as much.
Yeah, I should probably polish and simplify it and make the learning curve easier, I'm the only one I know who actually beat it.

For a post compo version I'm envisioning two lines of text, one for running, another for jumping. If you type the text from the first line then your character moves, and if you type stuff from the second line your character jumps. And as you progress through the game you'd have to type more and more to "escape" bad guys chasing you or something like that.

Loved the command-based mechanics, although i would have appreciated to end simple commands with ENTER. I know later in the game you need to input them fast but having ENTER as an optional delimiter would've been great.
Sometimes the 'hints' are a bit misleading because when you find them you just go and try to input the command and sometimes the result is instant death. LOL.
It kinda feels good once youn manage to finish.
Very cool concept! The character could move slower, or it gets too hard.
The flapping eventually got me, but it's a very interesting approach to typing games, I'd like to see it expanded upon (preferably with less flapping)
That was some entertainment tnelsond thanks! :-)
I would love the ability to list the things I want done then see them done (i.e., "jump flap flap flap flap flap<enter>" but then it wouldn't really be a typing game would it.

description:
http://jakexyz.com/ld21/
Everything is at the site. If it doesn't work on a non-Windows computer, I'll try switching up the natives!
Resources Used:
LWJGL
Slick
sfxr
author: naxum
title: Dude Running From an Explosion
comments: Innovation: Your basic run-and jump. I liked the addition of the ability to block bullets.
Theme: While it fits the theme, there are so many games in this contest exactly like this one, and you may as well be entering for the Advancing Wall of Doom LD.
Graphics: Basic, but they work. I commend you for not using a square character.
Audio: Same as above: It works, but could be better.

Fun: Pretty frustrating to play. There were little things like disappearing platforms disappearing too quickly to actually run across, and disappearing platforms not disappearing when on a ladder, which usually ended in a swift, unfair death. I'm sure these would probably be sorted out if you had another 24 hours, or a play-testing group before release, but I'm here to judge the game you submitted.
Overall: Kinda-imaginative, kinda working, but definitely flawed. It's good as is, but tinker with different elements and I'm sure you can make a better game.
I'm re-posting this to get proper spacing, so sorry for the double post. Won't happen again!
Innovation: Your basic run-and jump. I liked the addition of the ability to block bullets.
Theme: While it fits the theme, there are so many games in this contest exactly like this one, and you may as well be entering for the Advancing Wall of Doom LD.

description:
Windows, OpenGL. Arrow keys to run and jump. Hint at the end of this message if you're confused.
I skipped Saturday in favor of double-feature movie night, and didn't do much on Sunday either... Basic mechanics working that night, and level+gameplay added on Monday to make a rather bleak Jam entry. As usual it's mostly a technical experiment rather than a game.
Hint: There are switches you should step on. Will need to get creative with gravity to reach them. Make sure down is the right way.
author: DrPetter
title: DrPetterLD21
comments: Love the mechanic! I like how the button is so in-your-face but is definitely trickier to get to than meets the eye. Would love to see this kind of platforming explored more.
Agree with Chevy, would like to see this expanded upon. Got a little disorienting after staring for a bit (not in a bad way though). Loved the player sprite and how jiggly it was.
I always liked games with gravity change, and this one is no exception. A shame there is no sound.
Very fine prototype. It made me feel a bit sick after a while but I enjoyed it nonetheless.
A lot of possibility in this! And it's smooth and functional. So keep at this one!
Interesting idea, took me some time to pusth the damn button :)
That mechanic you have there is a way cool!
Nice.  Like the gravity changes and the scaling effects of the creature.
Cool mechanic! I think this is a prototype for a good crazy game. Kinda made me dizzy and/or sick though.
That was really fun, quite disorientating, but got used to it rather quickly. Took me a few tries, but the mechanics felt rather solid and fun.

description:
Authors - Alejandro Valenzuela, Isaias Rodriguez, Ricardo Lopez Salazar
DROWN-
You are on an island which is about to get completely flooded, Your only way out?, a boat, somewhat far from you, you may think you've earned your survival, well think twice 'cuz you are not alone, there is someone else on the island and he'll do whatever it takes to stop you to get his ticket to salvation.
In this game you compete with other player for survival using plants you can take shortcuts or block the path of your rival to make it to the safety boat, while running away from the comming flood.
author: alejandrov
title: Drown
comments: INSTRUCTIONS: This is a 2-player, turn-based game. Use the left mouse button to select where you'll move your character, then press ENTER.
The other player then decides where to move his character in the same manner on his map.

After a certain number of turns you get seeds which you can use to grow plants either in your own map (which gives you a movement boost) or in the opponent's map (which makes him lose a turn). You can place these seeds by pressing the right mouse button on either map.
Every certain number of turns the darker parts of the map will begin to get flooded. Be careful not to be caught in it! You win by moving your character to the boat.

Originally the game was going to be played over a network but we didn't manage to get the network functionality implemented, so instead players take turns. Please consider "Local player" to be the player in the left-hand map, and "Remote player" to be the player in the right-hand map. Thanks!

description:
Here be my third Ludum Dare entry.
Take control of our locked away hero using the arrow or W, A, S, D keys.
By harnessing the power of his electromagnet bracelet and pressing the "X" or "CTRL" keys you may move pesky blocks barricading our friend from his escape.
With thought and care he can traverse the level and open a pathway to the goal, the teleporter. Entering this teleporter shall transport our hero to a new location and a new challenge.
Should a challenge become too difficult or terrifying to confront, press the "R" key to reset the level and try once more.
author: Zemmi
title: D.T.R.J
comments: i like the spaceman. he looks like george takei.
I got stuck on level 9 :( I loved the two-block puzzle concept. The Escape theme wasn't really represented, I think.

I like this concept quite a bit!  I have only two complaints:  First, the music got a bit repetitive after awhile.  Second, some of the puzzles seemed to be somewhat ill constrained; I felt like I solved them by cheating/using a particularly inelegant solution.  Of course I think that it is quite difficult to make levels for this kind of game, so hats off to you for creating as much as you did in the time limit!
Finished it (829 steps/307 switches). Quite a nice mechanic - didn't get too hard, as some box-shifting puzzle games often do

description:
The concept was Escaping from Dunkirk, but it evolved into the full BEF (British Expeditionary Force) mission, with 'Real' physics!
Honest play it and find out!
Note it is hosted on Kongregate!
author: Arowx
title: BEF
comments: It's so tedious to move one unit at a time. I wasn't sure exactly what to do either. Do I just move all the troops to the other side?
Sorry yes that is the first part of it, Yes, you can use the 3rd man to push the two in front.
The physics of this game is just... wow. Like when my tank flew off the boat and landed on my troops. :)

I'm afraid I couldn't work out how to control this properly or really what I was supposed to be doing. I like the graphical style, though, and the minimap at the bottom is a really neat mechanic - just needs a bit more time on gameplay, I think!
I've updated the instructions for the game does that help?
Basically you can only move your forces forwards and backwards, slow or fast, stop them and get them to Dig In (down arrow) that's as complex as it gets!
It could do with a layer of polish, I managed to push my soldiers and a tank into the enemy, then they disappeared(I assume they got killed)
Yes they just disappear at the moment I'm going to work on some polish and an updated version next week will post on LD and on Kongregate.

description:
System requirements: Java, mouse
Made by Sara Kapli
Created using Processing, Photoshop,
Inkscape and Audacity
--------------------------------------
Escape. Most people have had dreams,
or nightmares, where one is being
chased, usually by someone who has
no name nor face. In my dreams, I
also cannot get anywhere, my feet
just aren't moving regardless of how
I try. It's like I'm in quicksand,
the more I try, the more I cannot move.
I cannot even breath. The only way to
get out of the suffocating horror is
by waking up. And if I do wake up in
the middle of the night, chase will
continue if I manage to get sleep again.
After this nightmare my head is heavy
and my thoughts are cloudy the whole day.
When it comes next evening, I go to sleep
and nightmare will start all over again.
There is no escape.
author: stRana
title: This is your dream
comments: Despite this being so simple I played it over and over until I got to the "next morning." It was frustrating to find the hotspots yet at the same time it felt accurate for the "dream world" idea.
Oof, 47 meg download :( I would recommend splitting the .zip up into three separate ones, one for each platform. 15 megs is a lot more manageable!

As for the game itself, I like the art, and wanted to keep playing to see all of it, but it became too frustrating to continue on. Excellent feeling of tension, it was quite nightmare-ish, so you nailed that aspect of it!
The heavy breathing really had me scrambling to find the hot spots, which was a neat effect. =] But it was really tedious to find all of the hot spots especially when they got really small.
Wow.  It is a very simple game yet I couldn't stop until I got the the next morning.  Very well done!
Yikes! Made me realize how crappy zip can be. The large size is due to three identical 15 MB files that get compressed and stored independently inside the archive.

Anyway, game is a bit simplistic maybe, but also very easy to play and relatively rewarding due to that fact. No introduction or learning curve needed. Could have been fun with some other dream-like effects like illusions and distractions while trying to find the clickies.

Tense! It looks like the hotspots are pre-set not randomized (thank goodness!), so I can quickly get back to the bit where I just start to see what I guess is some body of water, but after like six attempts with over ten seconds on that screen each and STILL not finding the hotspot, it gets too tedious to continue. Until that killed it, it was a very cool experience!

description:
The Man Who Sold The World
A bit of a less-literal, more metaphorical interpretation of the theme. Help define the destiny of humanity...
At first I didn't think music was gonna make it, but then I managed to make sure the audio content was implemented bug-free with the extra 12 hours - you guys rock!
>> Disclaimer (Aug 23rd) - I did not use the extra 12 hours to generate new content or update existing content. I simply ensured the music was working as I didn't have time to test it beforehand. Rate this infringement as you will, but I kindly ask that if you demerit the game for it, please only discount the "Audio" rating, as the rest of the game was complete at submission time. <<
File is 8.8mb, may take awhile to load - there's no preloader, but I assure you - it IS loading! ^_^
Game built in Adobe Flash CS5.5 using AS3, Flash Professional IDE.
Character art and animations built in Adobe Photoshop CS5.
Audio constructed in Sony ACID Music Studio 8.0.
Any questions, contact me here or at nick@kranggames.com
Enjoy <3
I used the following external libraries and reference materials:
AS3 CASA Lib
http://casalib.org/
Troy Gilbert's Pixel-Perfect Collision Detection Class
http://troygilbert.com/2007/06/pixel-perfect-collision-detection-in-actionscript3/
Reference Picture of Cessna 208 (3-View)
http://www.aviastar.org/air/usa/cessna_208.php
Reference for Running Animation, 8-Frame Run Cycle by Indigo
http://z3.invisionfree.com/TeejCreations/ar/t99.htm
Reference for Climbing Animation (Crono from Chrono Trigger)
http://www.spriters-resource.com/snes/chronotrigger/crono.png
Reference for Swimming Animation
http://www.virtual-swim.com/3d_mv/top_btn/free/2006wc_200/2006wc_200_q.html
AS3 Sound Manager v1.4
http://evolve.reintroducing.com/2011/01/06/as3/as3-soundmanager-v1-4/
TweenMax by GreenSock
http://www.greensock.com/tweenmax/
author: krangGAMES
title: The Man Who Sold The World
comments: At the end I didn't make a choice, was that making a choice?
The character animation and art was well done, found myself wishing I could interact with the environment a tiny bit more, at least with some of the NPCs.
Awesome game! though not very related to the theme in my opinion. The game was very engaging and the music was pretty good. Congratulations, very good job!
I followed you through this build and i tell you what, this is just wonderful. None of the music gets annoying. However, some of the jumping does. But hey, great game :)
You weren't meant to use the 12 hour extension to improve your game. I'm unsure how to rate this, given your claimed infringement. Perhaps you should change it to a Jam entry...

That aside, the game was quite lovely. Interesting to play a game of practically zero risk or challenge for a change. The environments, and moving across them, did have a beauty to it. On the other hand, I don't find the game's theme and choices resonate with me; I feel humanity is more than what can be boiled down to a single adjective, unless perhaps that adjective is 'varied'...
Very impressive game. Amazing animations, pretty graphics, and  a thought-provoking story! Excellent!
Very nice game. The story line is interesting, the music is nice, especially the stuff that plays outside earth, and the platforming can be interesting as well.
I'm not quite sure how it relates escaping. Is it that there's no escape for the human race?
Also, how do you choose wisdom in the final stage?
Very nice! I like the little intro. "Go to Earth to find Love!"
Don't have to tell me twice. X)
Very, very, VERY pretty. Atmospheric and lovely. Didn't see much 'challenge', but it was a nice experience.

Not going to rate it because of the 12 hours supposed to be safeguard against problems with upload, not for finishing the game (especially as music is one of the biggest +) - you should change this to jam entry.

But although the gameplay is very simple platformer you managed to make something interesting and captivating - story and music made it one of the best entries I've yet seen. But I kinda don't see the theme in here much.
Great atmosphere, the storytelling was really nice and the music was very good! It somewhat lacked on gameplay though. Some challenge would really improve the experience...
I like it bur don't match the theme for me :(
Great work :) Loved the story. Loved the atmosphere. Controls were tight and the level design was good.

Very nice! Controls are excellent, music really adds, gameplay was simple but enjoyable with some solid platformer level design, and I find very little here to take fault with. The length of the game is about perfect. An amazing entry.
I liked the music! It could definitely have used something more going on gameplay-wise, since it is about as basic as a platformer gets, but that didn't stop it from being entertaining.

It's a pleasant and calming experience, but I think it relies too much on the story and not enough on the game-play. It's not very challenging, and it's very very linear. It's not really a good idea to make a game that revolves around a story for a 48-hour game, since games usually need to be short, so there's no room/time to elaborate. The graphics and the music were really pleasant, though. And you did manage to keep me playing through the whole thing, so good job. I think you should have made use of those nice platforming mechanics, though.
Well that left me confused. I did knock down an audio point for the deadline editing, but honesty prevented it from being a flat out one.
The music and story carried the entire game. Good luck.

description:
RTS style game where you lead a group to rebuild their ship and escape the horrors of The Island.
Made with LWJGL and Java, might work on MacOS and Linux but has not been fully tested on those platforms.
author: balorian
title: The Island
comments: Really fun little game. RTS gameplay is well implemented and the game itself is a nice challenge. Nothing beats MONKEYS!
Great game! A little too hard at the beginning, though. How did you create the applet? I have an application written with slick that I would like to applet up.
Maybe I just suck, but I found this waaaay too hard, couldn't really achieve anything.  Decent scope for a weekend, but I think you'd have benefited from less mechanics and more polish.
eggplantanimation: LWJGL has a tutorial on this here: http://lwjgl.org/wiki/index.php?title=Deploying_with_the_LWJGL_Applet_Loader_-_Introduction

The game probably is a bit too hard at the moment, I made a few last minute tweaks to it that I most likely shouldn't have, and didn't have enough time to implement a difficulty setting option. I might continue to develop it further though.
Nice game. Was hard to see which guy you had selected though
This is a neat idea! (but in need of balancing. This is incredibly hard)
I also like the mumbled voices (remind of Blendo-games). How do you create those?
Good game, although as was already said, too hard. Quick switching between sailors via numeric keys would help a lot. One of the better I've seen so far, congratulation.
I totally lost. Very fun approach but the interface should be much improved.

Very ambitious for a 48 hour compo.  I have a similar project so I know how tough it is to complete this.  I found it slow and confusing in the beginning, but the graphics were really clear and functional, and I like the feedback on the AI state of the sailors.

description: NOTE: I'm getting a few people saying mouse doesn't work, I think it might be its just not obvious what to do first: you're injured so need to click on the medical cabinet. Hope it's just that and not a bug :)
author: RichMakeGame
title: Stratus
comments: Love the art style - however left-mouse isn't working for me, for some reason. I can't interact with anything :(
That was awesome, I want more !
Remind me Laputa by Miyazaki, and Skies of Arcadia (Dreamcast RPG)

Beautiful, yeah. The interaction needs refinement, though. The instructions at the bottom right are unclear and you'll end up trying to click everything. Use text rather than images - you could even tell a story (describe the events) while you're at it.
It ends right when it's started, but that's only to be expected from 48h games. I'm hoping you'll develop this further on your own time.
A promising and visually impressive entry that feels like a tech demo for a larger project rather than a game in itself.
Great idea for and escape game, need refirments.. Why didn't you add some text ? You could tell a nice story!

thanks for commenting! yeah I guess a consequence of focusing on atmosphere and art, the game length and mechanics suffered somewhat.. I think this would have been better for a week long project, but I really wanted to try it anyway :). cr, I'm really sorry that's a terrible bug :(. the first thing you're supposed to do is click on the medicine cabinet- does nothing happen when you try that?
I love the stylized graphics and the way you directed what needed to be done with the icons.  This would make a really fun full game. Fantastic job!

This is wonderful! I love the environment/mood of the game. I was a bit surprised by the abrupt ending, but that is to be expected for a game in a competition like this. I see potential for a very deep storyline here too. If you were to further develop this, I think it could be a hit!
It looks really nice, and the atmosphere was solid. I actually think text would've worsened it somewhat.
I disagree about adding text, I like this icon-based gameplay, I can really see this expanded into a nice absurd lo-fi steampunk story about flying fortresses.
I've looked at quite a few entries and this is my favourite by far so far
best game evar! these graphics! awesomsauce!!!
The graphics is awesome. What minecraft would have been if it were scifi. :D Was I suppose to put the bomb in the engine because that killed me.

awesome graphics! i too disagree with those naying the text. but i didn't know what to do at first and it took me a while to figure out what to click. i think the problem was that i didn't notice the blood on the ground--you could start it with the player getting hit or coughing up blood or something and then the bandage objective image could appear and then it would be pretty clear.
Absolutely loved the graphics and feeling. There's something magical about walking along on a ship.

The game itself was pretty neat, but I think some more helpful pointers would have been useful. I didn't really understand how to play at first. The first "task" wasn't obvious until I read the comments.
Working on Quest3D for more than 2 years, I can't believe this is done in that engine! Really cool graphics and a short but interesting gameplay. Congrats!
Lovely lovely 3d pixels made into a fun little puzzle game. I really want more of this!
Amazing work! I really like how the story is told through game-play instead of narrative. Well done!
Please don't forget about other keyboards !
I don't know for the others by I can't switch QWSD to ZQSD so it's really difficult to play this game :(
Very good graphics, i loved it. I had fun.

The game itself wasn't the best thing, but the graphics and engine were phenomenal, so I can see why there wasn't a whole lot of time to flesh out the game. Still, quite a wonderful concept, and briliant visuals.
This one will be in the top I'm sure, awesome graphics style!
Great graphics and I like the puzzle-y nature of it. Yup, I was wanting more but I love what you did.
Best game I've played for this LD so far.
Holy shit, that was amazing. The feeling of a story evolving so quickly is something awe inspiring. Just left me wanting so much more! My favourite so far :)
Would've loved to see a little more work on the presentation and story, but great technical feat for the 48 hour challenge. Exceptionally well done.
Hey, did the main character burn his wife before the start of the level!?
Excellent 8-bitish art, nice setting, there's only one thing I find annoying... it's too short. I'd love to see the whole game :)

The art is amazing and even though, as you said yourself, this is more of a tech-demo than a game, it was still a lot of fun to play just because of how stunning it looks. I agree with others that it could have been clearer as to what you were supposed to do, initially. I thought left-click was broken, but it turned out that I just hadn't been clicking the medicine cabinet, the only clickable object at the start.
If this was expanded into a fully-fledged game, perhaps with a storyline, you could sell loads of them.
Yea after the ludimdare you should expand this game. This would be the a.k.a. demo. you could make money selling it off steam. omg I would totally buy this.

blown away by the comments, thanks so much guys :) taking all the crits on board too, I totally agree the icons could be clearer. I'm not so keen on text (i quite like making my games multi-language, without need for translation) but things could be made more obvious through other means. As for expanding the game.. I'm in two minds! well, of course I'd love to, but I'm already working on a game called Pineapple Smash Crew . Hmmm!
I just wish it was longer. Great work! Love the "story", as short as it is.
I can't use the left mouse button, so I can't technically play, but damn this is beautiful!

This was very cool, although I'm not sure if I won or lost. I put the last item (the bomb) in the engine and it told me "thanks for playing". I'm going to assume the ship blew up and I died, it makes for a more complete story-arc :).
Legogo has a very good comment. I use dvorak, and so it's a right pain to play. I compromised by running sideways everywhere, but can't help feeling the arrow keys would have been a better choice.

I like the 8-bit style. Although it's terribly overused, it makes sense for LudumDare, and your colorscheme was wonderful. I didn't have any problems with the instructions or icons. It felt really polished (except for the ending).
So much (as of yet unrealized) possibility. Very cool, good style, everything. PLEASE make more.
Hey I thought that thing on the first picture was a weapon. Full of win it is! I request more shooting!
Another fine entry for the competition. I would like to see this extended or continued somehow. A sequel perhaps. Also the text ending felt a little weak. Otherwise, great work.
The graphics are excellent, but the gameplay itself felt a little lacking as there isn't much to do. Definitely worth further work.
I just couldn't kill them all, how many of those flying things are there?

16 iirc! if you want a tip, their firing timer gets reset if they get hit (i know, there's no feedback for this at all) so if you feel there's others about to shoot you, spray a few bullets in their direction and then go back to your main target.

description:
Saharan Scurry
Created by Oliver "Tubbimora" Tun
Description
The Army are after you!
Escape from the Army by driving away in the conveniently placed jeep you found in the middle of the Saharan Desert!
Freedom is 10000m away!
But be careful, you'll have to drive through the emergency minefield placed by the Army and avoid the tanks chasing you!
Good luck!
Author's Notes
My first ever entry into Ludum Dare and one of my first ever completed games! Hooray! Entering this competition was a great experience to have and let me actually know what it was like working under a deadline. I had to cut a lot of ideas and fancy things from the final product in order to make it a functioning game, but I'm happy how it turned out even though there isn't much to it. I will most likely enter when the next LD comes around and hopefully be more experienced so I can create something more complex. Thanks to everyone who kept me going and Ludum Dare for an awesome 48 hours.
Tools Used
C# 2010 Express with XNA 4.0
Adobe Flash CS5
sfxr
SWFSheet
Paint.NET
author: Tubbimora
title: Saharan Scurry
comments: I wish bullets would kill tanks for extra awesome points :)
Oh wow, I never thought of doing that ._. That's a pretty awesome idea as well.
If I decide to do more work on this game I definitely will :D
Not working here for me. Here's what happens when I launch the exe : http://i.imgur.com/SV9mv.png
Those tanks sure are dumb!  They step on mines (but don't blow up).  And they're supposed to chase me but they go right past me while I wave at them and smile.
@agersant: You most likely don't have XNA 4.0 installed.  You can get it here:

description:
My first Ludum Dare entry! Only just made it in. It's a puzzle platformer about pushing blocks to climbs upwards and escape from a pit.
It has 15 levels, with a big new game mechanic introduced on level 11. The controls are;
Use the left and right arrow keys to move left and right. Press up to jump. If you have a gun press the space bar to use it. Press R to restart a level. Press H if you need help and help text will be added to the end of any text that is on screen. You can go forward or back a level using the < and > keys. If the game doesn't respond to key presses click on it to gain focus.
The game seems to grow rather hard early on so if you have to use the help option or even skip a level don't feel too bad. Make sure to get through all the levels one way or another so you can see the ending screen though.
Created in FlashDevelop with AS3. Bfxr was used for sounds.
author: SuperSausageDog
title: Robot Pit Escape
comments: That's some pretty cool game play, and the puzzles get very challenging after a while.
Shockingly innovative, mind-bogglingly challenging. You're onto something with this game idea, find a way to bring it to more people!
Thought the game way pretty neat.
some interesting puzzles, some felt a bit tedious. that ending screen surpassed my wildest expectations.
Very nice puzzle game, good job!
Cool concept and very solid execution. nice job!
Fantastic gameplay mechanics, I love it.  With some fancier graphics and controls, this would be very releaseable. My favorite game so far!
Nice puzzle game. Very fun and interesting level design. The font was a bit small though.
I found a bug (although not game breaking). You can push a block and shoot a laser at the same time (putting the block in an intermediate location).

Wow, I wasn't interested from the screenshots, but this is a seriously awesome game you have here, hilarious text too. Polish this sucker up with some better graphics, sound, and music, and you've got a serious game. Some amazing level design in here, if only a little too tough for a few. Definitely used the H key a few times.
Neat game play. Makes me think - I like it :)
The addictive qualities of tetris plus the addictive qualities of a platformer. Nicely done!
Neat mechanic. I also like hoe the levels ramp up in difficulty.

description:
My first game jam, and I heeded the wisdom of McFunkypants regarding the avoidance of noob mistakes, going with something very simple.
A 2-player game: get your lovely bees across to the other side of the screen, but stop the other player from getting their bees across. Bees sting each other when they meet and die shortly afterwards.
Would good games seem as good if there weren't bad ones to compare them too? Do my terrible graphics somehow benefit the community by providing a low-water reference point?
author: peterstock
title: Quean Bee
comments: Great start Peter. The link is broken - remove the www. to download. Game loads on my Linux box with WINE, however the controls don't work. I'll try later on with a real Windows machine. Don't forget that to enter the competition (not the jam) you need to include the source code.

Thanks for trying it out! I should have said, the controls might not be what you expect - you can only move the bees once you have created some to send across. So press Space and Enter first, then you can move up and down.
I didn't read the rules properly at the beginning, and didn't make my engine code publically available before the competition, so this is just a jam entry.
Wait, are you the guy who made Armadillo Run?

Cool idea, though it's not particularly intuitive.  It also kind of turns into a who-can-mash-the-keys-faster game after a while, since defending makes it a zero-sum game.  Would be nice if you got a bonus for shooting down an enemy bee somehow...
This became a whole lot more interesting at the point I discovered how this all works :)
Very simple gameplay. A tutorial/intro would have helped.
nice, simple gameplay. A great start.

description:
Short platformer fighting game based on running away, and getting trapped.
Made with Processing and Paint.Net. Music made using Audacity and Anvil Studio.
First LD competition that I've entered.
**Note!**
In one place, the space is only 1 tile tall. It's difficult to pass through! It's not supposed to be difficult, though, so step back to the bottom of the stairs and then jump at it if you're having trouble. Just keep trying and you'll get through.
author: BlueShaman
title: Mirror's Secret
comments: I got stuck at a bit where the path through was too narrow for my character to fit through (ceiling too low), as far as I could tell. Did I just miss something?
Hey. The game was rather fun but as happened with Devenger I got stuck the same way.
For people stuck, just jump a bunch from the bottom of the stairs.  I liked the arrows, but it was hard to tell when i was hitting him with my sword.
Step back and jump from a distance. I meant to remove all of those overly-short passages, but I didn't test one or two of the levels (that one being one).
This game feels really polished (apart from a few problems like that narrow hallways)! Excellent work.
I really like the atmosphere of the game.
For those that are stuck, try running a tiny bit before jumping.
Just in case you don't know this (you probably do though), you can easily make a web version of the game by using "Export Applet" in Processing.

The attack was very inventive. At first I couldn't figure out what the point of use the left mouse button was, but then I realized I seemed to be able to control the point of attack by moving the mouse. It was fun and reminded me a of jedi fight (or maybe sith).
Got stuck on narrow path but would have played for longer. I count that as a good sign. I like the realisation of the sword.

Good game. Got stuck on that narrow path. And it took me some time to figure out that I had to use the WASD keys. Another complaint is that after the game loses focus (on Linux), the WASD keys won't work =(
A bit hard to see what's going on at first.

description:
The level design is awful, I didn't really have time, but I was partly saved by GIMP's maze generating plugin :D
I wanted to write an "Escape the Maze", but with eye candy and some new features, like destructible walls, super-colliding-super-buttons and one-way walls. I pretty much succeeded, despite having completely changed what I was aiming for at the beginning of day 2. I'm much more pleased with this than my LD19 entry, despite less completion.
Written with Flex 4 and Flixel, on Ubuntu Linux ;)
author: RandomM00
title: Maze++
comments: It was a little tedious with all the dead ends. Otherwise a nice little game. The fog of war effect is cool, and helps you remember where you have been.
I'm no big fan of maze games, but the lighting effects in this one really makes it work.Good job!
Very nifty. Nice mechanics with the switches and bridges and such.
A pity there's only one level. :) I liked it! Nice lighting mechanics.
I agree with others, the lighting was really slick looking.  I also liked the humor/honesty on the ending :).  It could've used a less shrill beep noise, but nice work!

That was actually a lot better than I was expecting from the screenshots. I have to agree, the fog of war effect was really well done and made it fun to explore the map, and the explosions were cool too =)
Not much happening in the game but, I'm intrigue to keep playing anyway. And I finished it!
I agree that the fog of war is cool. This game will probably be better if more things is happening.

The graphics were simple but attractive. The controls were a bit weird at times but mostly fluid and nice. I agree the level design wasn't fantastic but I still enjoyed playing through it. If you want any pointers on maze/labyrinth generating algorithms I've spent some time thinking about them in the past.
Some music and better sounds would really help this game a lot! :)
Thanks for all the positive comments, I really appreciate it!

@d_m I spent a bit of time looking for maze gen alorithms, but the problem was making them work with the tile based (rather than wall based) maps, and having complex items in them, like one way walls. In the end, I decided to cobble something together with a mixture of the GIMP's maze render plugin and adding things by hand. If you have any better ideas, I would love to hear them, I'm hoping to improve and update Maze++ to put on Kongregate.
I thought the switches really made this game pretty playable. Without being told what anything does, it really felt like I was exploring (more than actually going through the maze did).
Love the fog of war.. Really cool!! :) Nice little game overall

description:
A game for iPad, hopefully will add in some builds for osx and windows shortly. If you have an iPad, you can sign up on test flight and I will send you a build.
Added an osx build, the controls for are:
red player: ASDF : Left, Right, Knife, Flip
blue player: JKL; : Left, Right, Knife, Flip
Leave the executable in the folder with the data folder.
author: jonbro
title: Martin vs Monty
comments: Fun- signing up for the beta
hey folks that signed up for the ios thing... please register an ipad if you have one, this is ipad only right now.
I don't have an iPad, so I can't test nor rate it.
there is now an osx download.
mac only? :( not going to rate
The screenshots look really nice, sadly I don't own a osx device :(

Played it on an iPad! Pretty fun! I did get confused for a sec when when I was first killed and there seemed to be two of me, and I thought it could some flash or something to draw your attention to where you just respawned, but that's minor stuff.
Fun stuff! I adore the art style, and the game was pretty amusing.
Little hard to play this single-player, but looks pretty solid. I like the art style.
Cirrial: I think I agree with you, totally hard to play this single player... I wonder if there is the pong racquet ball equivalent that I could figure out for this.

A pretty cool game. Unfortunately, because this game is obviously made for the iPad, it felt very awkward to play on the Mac because I had to use the mouse. However, it looks like it would be great on its intended device.

description:
~~~ WARNING: Causes Rage ~~~
- Post how far you got ^_^ -
Play the Java applet at:
www.zirconcode.com/ludumdare/index.html
--------------------------
|   The Land of Colors*	 |
--------------------------
*colours
About:
This is my first Ludum Dare (#21) entry, so be nice =)
I spent about 16 hours on the first day and 5 on the second.
Everything is written in Java, all from scratch.
How to Play:
Press spacebar to respawn and go through the story.
Press m to unmute/mute the awesome music. Music is muted at start.
Use the WASD keys to move the upper ship
Use the Arrow keys to move the lower ship
The ships may not touch black.
If the ships are not on the same color, your lifebar will drain rapidly.
Bright green signifies savepoints, white is the end of the level.
There are three levels, each one grows rapidly more difficult.
If anyone can complete all three without dying once they shall be proclaimed our hero.
Enjoy =)
author: ZirconCode
title: Land of Colors
comments: Hi, I really like the game, awesome idea, this asymetric gameplay is really hard, i've played alone, but it must be alot of fun with two people
I've only made it to the third level,
Also, the little introduction (especially the comment at the bottom) made me laugh so hard :D
The big flaw for me, wich is that important, is the art side, it's really basic, but great game :)
this was a very good game. i have never seen a game like this before. i made an account just to comment on this game. very nice. and i thought the music was funny.
(p.s. i completed the whole game by myself and ended up with a score of like -5720 or something XD)
The music was nice, but you should have cleaned it up (no coughing allowed!).
OK, the music made me laugh, and the two-ship gameplay was pretty neat. Of course, the music kept playing once I closed the tab, so as I write this, I'm hearing doom da doom da doom da doom.
Cool idea!  I like the tandem keyboard gameplay, though it's really tough to play alone.  Also, please cut the coughing out of your music next time ;)
haha, i actually liked the music. but the death sound is fucking horrible omg! i got to level 2 and just couldn't take it anymore lol
It's hard, but once you get the hang of it controlling the two ships at once is very enjoyable.
The screenshot looks really intruiging, I am having a lot of trouble getting it to run in the browser though (Chrome on mac). I will try to run it later on the command line...
One of the more original ideas, it's harder than it looks, which is always a good thing.
Wow the music continued after closing the window. Which isn't that bad cause I like the mouth made music, even with coughing.
The starting screens art is... you know. But in the game it's okay. I really like the unusual concept of the hame mechanics.
Very creative, but extra hard to play alone. Takes a while to get used to, and the map is rather unforgiving. "Music" made me lol.
A long time ago I built a game where you were controlling two separate things with WSAD and the arrow keys, so I love the concept.
I love the concept! It is great to do two things at the same time - I am pretty sure it's good for my brain. Good stuff. Thanks :)
What a cool concept!  A pretty fun game if you have two people!
This would make a great co-op game.

Really great game! Interesting concept. Controls are straightforward. My brain isn't used to think in two layers like that. Only possible recommendation might be to make it a top-down scroller instead of side scroller, because then the controls would map more readily to what's going on.

description:
Evil Llama escaping from the death festival in mexico.
How-to: press anything to jump.
Remember: Flowers are good, everything else is bad.
P.S: w/ small easteregg inside.
Will be very thankful for hosting web-version.

win64 version available here: http://db.tt/w3A3Tuw
sorry no more input fields available
author: degtyarev
title: Evil Llama: Escape from the death festival.
comments: Words cannot express how much I love the graphical style. <3
Once you include source, I'll give it a full rating.  If you want, you can include a web-copy in the same zip, and I'd be happy to host the web version for you.
Let me know! Thanks (P.S So far, I'm really digging the Win64 version, but I wouldn't want you to get DQ'd for not including source)
Solid iPhone game you've got here with a few tweaks. Theming is impeccable.
I can give you hosting for a few weeks at http://centigonal.com/random/llama/ if you like :)
MidKnight|Centigonal, Thanx! We'll update web version link!
Your game's a bunch of fun! I love the colors!
I encountered a couple of issues you may want to fix eventually:
- The music stops playing after 150 meters or so
- Sometimes flowers appear *inside* the ridiculous dia de los muertos paraphernalia that's supposed to trip you up
Most of the time you can still acquire the flower if you jumped before and touched it while landing, but it requires some luck and training.
I see you found some hosting.  Highest rated game so far!
I liked how the music increased in intensity the further you made it. Nice touch!
Very cool graphics!  Nice difficulty curve.  Good work!
I found the foreground distracting and often missed the small skull with the candle. Other thatn that, this is avery well realized game. The music realy compliments the DÃ­a de los Muertos graphics.
We'll release a new off-compo builds soon with this issues fixed
Love the art! LOVE LOVE LOVE! Best I've seen all competition. The audio was nice, too.
I got a bit dizzy with the amount of parallax going on. Anyone else? I think it was just the foreground layer, or all of the colors. :P

I felt like the player should have died once the llama was inside the crowd, but he doesn't die until he goes off the left-hand side of the screen it feels like. The first time I was close to them, I thought I was going to die, but once I realized I was still alive it wasn't as intense.
The style is incredible, but I wish you had time to replace the font with one of your own style. Everything jives so great except the font.
I died, but the game over screen said llama won? I don't understand. :P

description: A simple platformer.  Arrow keys to run.  Z to jump. Escape to exit.
author: pgil
title: Hotel Escape
comments: I got frustrated pretty early on, and found the game quite unoriginal, but then...
Sorry folks, I'm not going to spoil it for you guys YOU HAVE TO PLAY THIS!!!
Just when I couldn't stand it anymore... nice game. Enjoyed it very much!
I wasn't sure at first but when the real game started I was suitably impressed.
Maddening. Madly entertaining. Also, a technical achievement. Particularly loved the sound work.
Great! Where is your source code though?
Whoops. I knew I forgot something.  Source added!
It was very clever, congratulations. Impressive technically.
Hahaha, very clever, sir. I was just about to post to tell you that the game has a bizarre crash. You sure got me.
This was awesome! Great idea, and well done making this in 48 hours in Game Maker!!
you sir, deserve to win this time :D
forgot to say how satisfied i was when i finished the game :D congrats. now, wheres your twitter account? :)
Frustrating but I kept playing to the end.  It was pretty great to have spectators for.  Thanks for this :).
Fun twist delivered at the right moment - well done! Actual platforming could use some polish. :)
Very good, wasn't sure if it was a bug with WINE to begin with, then realised.

While technically innovative but in all the wrong ways. My patience for the ragequit mechanic is now at zero. Also simulating a fake crash that forcibly takes control of my screen resolution is a big no no.
Seriously missed the mark on this one.
Technically impressive and mind-boggingly cool visuals.
Took me a good 100 deaths to finish. :)
Everything that needs the be said has been said by other people before me. Good job!!
If it hadn't been for the comments here I would have hated it.

The first two times I ran the game I couldn't quit aside from killing the process, hah. It wouldn't recognize me pressing the ESC key until I did "run as administrator". So that was kinda painful. Once I read the comments here and figured out what was supposed to happen, I got it to work and then it was cool.
Hated controls a little... Hate when I do press a button but it does not react ;(
bloody game maker games not working in Wine :( looked nice
Very well done, innovative. Controls need polishing, sometimes jump doesn't register. Music is great.
My Escape key didn't work the first time, I had to force quit. Thanks to Matt Rix for the tip of running it as admin.

description:
You are in jail.
Try to escape.
Press A to use your face.
- game by DragonSix aka Benjamin Grauer
- http://twitter.com/Drag0nSix
Additionnal notes :
-It's an XNA game, so I've put the necessary installers in the zip file if you need it.

author: DragonSix
title: Faceless
comments: Can't play, can't rate =X Sorry... (Linux user here)
Nice concept, but I spend more time watching the face travel than playing the game, the face travel should take no more than 5 seconds maximum
This is the strangest game I've played yet.
LOL @ the ending! Very strange but interesting game but I agree with one of the commenters, face travel should be sped up.
Yep that was seriously odd! But in a good way

The atmosphere is pretty creepy, but with no strategy and more interaction involved, this is somewhat lacking. Nice graphics, although being able to skip the mask sequences would be a nice option. This could be very innovative when made into a longer and more feature-rich title.

When I first played this I double-checked to make sure I had eaten the right brownies from the fridge. Once I'd been assured that my party pies were indeed still in stock for the weekend, I continued to become engorged in this d'arte abstracte that challenged both my senses as well as fill me with a considerable sense of motion sickness.

I'll agree with the remarks that the face travels a bit too slowly - add to it that the constantly rotating camera (especially on long travels) really did make me sick :D I ended up looking in the opposite direction of my screen until the sounds ceased.

Regardless of these details (mere details, I tell you!), I think this could become a phenomenal "interactive art" piece. Add some truly queer random quotes throughout the movement and think this would become a profound piece kind of like the Path.
Nice concept! I did feel quite dizzy when the face moves though.
great atmhosphere. The face flying sequence are a bit too long and you can make some very long face-jump avoiding a part of the leveldesign. The ending is cool :)

Sorry man, couldn't play 'till to the end (now that I've managed to be on Windows). It is too noisy, I dislike the sound effect you use when the face is being used. Another thing that really gets my nerves is that everytime that I use my face I must sit and watch it go... A nice effect here and there, but man, EVERYTIME IT IS USED? That's too much for me. Enough with the hating =) I find this game quite an original one. I has a really nice idea, but poorly executed... I wish you the best =)

description:
It's an Oregon Trail-like game, made with the O.H.R.RPG.C.E.
I hope you enjoy it.
author: Spoonweaver
title: Escape the Zombie Horde
comments: I made a last minute fix. The game will end when everyone in the car dies now.
If you downloaded it before and were bothered by this please redownload.
This fix was made before the end of the time limit.
Wow!! Never imagine a game like this with this theme.

A very neat game, with some subtle humour. I think there are still a few cases where the game doesn't end if everyone dies (I kept repeatedly dying of thirst and starvation in one game) - but mostly it worked fine.

It would be useful to have some kind of counter or timer that showed how far you'd already driven or how far to the goal. I also found it very frustrating to play with one key. If I pressed the key each turn, it took ages to progress. If I held it down, then it would skip past all the dialogues before I could stop and read them. Maybe separate keys for this would be useful, or automatically drive through the stages where nothing happens.

I never did make it to the military base, but I played quite a few games and had a lot of fun with it. I think my party died in pretty much every way possible, so I'm holding my fingers that the zombies don't invade any time soon. I'll be the first victim for sure. Very well produced overall, congratulations :).
Oh, wow. Thanks for the comments guys.
Cool, though I think I've seen a similar flash game out there before.  Nice work for 48 hours.
Surprisingly fun with minimal game mechanics.

Interesting concept, but it severely lacks interaction. Having the player to make choices before the game even starts never is a good design choice, IMHO. Also, I can't see how much I bought the different items before the game starts. It just isn't very rewarding. :(
Other than that, I like the general idea, and somehow the atmosphere.
Great idea, but with no control on what's happening it's no so enjoable playing it!
My only complaint is that I can't see what I already have in the car on the load out screen. =[ Other than that, awesome game!
Awesome game :) Love the concept and gave me a good laugh!

description:
And here it is the all new exciting adventures of everyones favorite Psychic Trash Robot. His insane creator has put in him a gauntlet of (badly simulated :P) physics challenges and he must escape!
GOAL:
Getting from Left to Right!
CONTROLS:
Left/Right  = A/D
Jump        = SPACE
Telekinesis = Right Mouse Drag
Esc         = Exit
And by telekinesis I mean that you can drag any purple coloured objects around with the right mouse button :). As a further note the jumping can be done every 2 seconds even if you are not touching the ground.
As far as I am aware there are two ways by which you can break the puzzles. A toast to anyone who discovers them!
All of the Graphics and Physics engine have been written by myself in C++, so please be gentle if it is slightly buggy :3
To Linux Users:
This game requires 2 libraries that you get with the following commands,
sudo apt-get install libglfw
sudo apt-get install libdevil1c2
Well that is my submission to Ludum Dare 21. Hope you enjoy it!
EDIT:
Windows executable is now up! HUZZAH!
I had some problems getting it to work for god knows what reason. Feel free to let me know if it crashes on you or otherwise does mean things :)
EDIT EDIT:
I should probably have mentioned that both the Linux and Windows version is compiled for 64-bit. I will include a makefile with the source so you 32-bit Linux user can compile it.
EDIT EDIT EDIT:
Makefile is actually up now! oO
author: snesgaard
title: Escape of the Psychic Trash Robot
comments: Isn't the game compiled for Windows? You have to submit at least a windows executable :(

I tried to compile from source, but couldn't figure out which -dev packages I needed. I got libglfw-dev and glutg3-dev but I am not sure what package has IL/il.h

Core/GraphicsCore.hpp:20: fatal error: IL/il.h: No such file or directory
The reason it won't run on 32-bit is that the game is compiled on a 64-bit linux. And unfortunately I don't know to force gcc to compile 32-bit binaries :(
As far as I can see you will only need DevIL which you can get with the following command,
Hope you can get it to work!
Windows version is up now btw!
crash on windows version, not explanation btw :(
hmm strange, what version of windows are you using and is it 32-bit. What .dll files was included in the .rar archive?
Quite nice game. The textures of the robot were acting up, but everything else worked
Thanks, glad to hear someone got the game to work :)

The game works for me too, although I think I had trouble before. It's pretty good - congratulations on getting a game done. Some constructive criticism: the slidey controls make me kinda frustrated - it could have controlled a lot better, and sometimes I would fall realllly far down and have a long boring time getting back up. But still - the game is solid and kinda neat. Good work.
Crash on windows XP (32 bit) - access violation reading...

description:
You are a prisoner, imprisoned at the Satanic Mental Hospital. You must escape imprisonment at the Satanic Mental Hospital!
You can do it!
Built in Flixel, using Flashdevelop.
Photoshop for the tiles, GraphicsGale for the sprites.
Voices recorded in Audacity (mine + wifes).
Sound effects made in Increpare's lovely BFXR.
Music made with FL Studio.
Thank you for playing!!!!!
author: eli
title: Escape Imprisonment at the Satanic Mental Hospital
comments: Cute. I liked the music and sound effects and the amusingly unfinished player character graphics. :) I didn't seem to ever be able to punch nurses before they nursed me, but there was plenty of health around to make it to the exit pretty easily. And I escaped!
Gameplay is very decent. I thought the controls were a little sluggish though, it took my character a little too long to get moving and felt like I was ice skating.
The graphics are OK but incongruous, especially for the main character.
The music is very good but it's a bit too short and the beginning and end stand out too much.
Pretty good start.. one thing that would really help is having a longer reach, as I couldn't ever punch the bad guys without getting hurt myself.
The nurses did seem to hurt the player before they could get punched back. But the massive health drops made it more than fine. This is worth expanding on to make a full version.

description:
Explore the dangerous halls of XYZ in an homage to the metal gear solid gameboy game.
The game is finished from the mechanical standpoint. Sadly there aren't that many levels.
The controls are arrowkeys(or wasd) for movement and space for menu navigation. The rest will be explained ingame.
When the game runs to slow. Disable PostProcessing in Options.
For a better challenge.. disable enemy sight cone in options.
This game was written purely in java without external libraries.
made by SaiKai and Dero
author: SaiKai
title: Escape from XYZ
comments: The visual theme and level design are pretty neat!
Game is super slow. Levels are also pretty small for the map size, would have been nice to zoom in a little. Pretty good stealth game.
Felt very slow. This was kind of nice for giving it a bit of a creepier vibe, but the gameplay itself isn't really that creepy so after a while I was just annoyed at how slow it was.
Artistically, it has a great theme. The audio fits how the world looks, but I can't get over how slow it plays.
This is minor, but I wish that at the start of a new level, your energy level was at full so you can sprint right away. The movement is so slow that I try and sprint whenever I can.
The player's hitbox is much larger than the character sprite, which causes some frustrating moments where you are trying to move, but can't due to invisible collision.
All in all, great theme and was atmospheric, but it would have helped a ton to speed the player up and tighten his hitbox.

While I like the stealth game play you were going for, the speed of the character really ruins it for me. You added the run button, but its pointless when near guards so the player is forced to crawl through the level.

description:
Escape from Music Manor: A Rhythmic Roguelike!
Overview
Escape from Music Manor: A Rhythmic Roguelike! is a single-button game. You play an unfortunate guest trapped in Music Manor. You must press Escape in time with the beat to select the actions you will perform. Do your best to escape with your life!
Instructions
-Press the Escape key in time with the beat to select which movement you'll make.
-Take your time! Enemies and traps don't move until you do!
-Reach the yellow square to move to the next area.
-Try to escape the Music Manor!
Created by Zachary Lewis for Ludum Dare 21.
Copyright The Game Studio 2011. All rights reserved.
author: Zachary Lewis
title: Escape From Music Manor: A Rhythmic Roguelike!
comments: Totally cool, really original, loved this. Have to try to expand on this after the contest, it's brilliant!
@kevglass I'm expanding on it right now, actually. Keep an eye on the Kongregate link I posted above. :)
Yeah, the idea alone, roguelike plus a rhythm game, is awesome. Simple but with some strategy, and very original.
I feel like there should be some penalty for waiting too long, though. Other than that, I like this one very much!
+9000 innovation!! (tho the sound design was murdering my senses)
Cool concept! Graphics are obviously quite basic and the game could really do with more fun way to select moves. As it is now it feels to slow an uninteresting. I like the changes in the levels!
It's very innovative and original, fun and fits the theme. Audio is a little weak tho, and graphics are very simple (although nice :P). Overall, neat game!
With some more graphical and audio work, this could be really really great. As it is, it's pretty cool, original, and fun. Nice stuff!

description:
Run from the purple squares and collect coins as you go.
Buy upgrades to get further and submit you score to the leaderboard.
*** Note: The difficulty of the enemies are not reset when you die. Please refresh the page occasionally or they will get really hard!! ***
Also note: The leaderboard times out when loading sometimes.
Scores seem to get submitted properly though.
Also there's a bug making you restart with R if you write it in the highscore name box. Your best score is saved though, so just die and enter your name again. Copy and paste an r from somewhere. :P
Update: Apparently Playtomic leaderboards are disabled at the moment. Should be working soon.
Update: The leaderboard seems to be working now!
Update: Not yet. :(
Update: Mostly working now!
author: Danik
title: Coin Runner
comments: Wow, it's really hard to survive once you've upgraded everything since the enemies also get tougher.
Good! I made it a lot harder right before the deadline since I was afraid it was too easy.
Danik, you did a great job! I think it would be even better with some other audio and other graphics!
After playing it more, maybe they get a little too tough. :3

I like the upgrading mechanism, it was fun to replay the same levels when feeling more powerful. I don't think it's too tough - although it seems a little random whether jumping on an enemy will kill you or them. I got a high score of 702! Pity the leaderboards aren't working.
Upgrade mechanic = genius. So much fun getting more and more powerful, even if you're just a pink square. xD Great job.
This is my favorite game on LD21 so far. The upgrade thing makes this really addicting!
They come from behind in front and above, you really feel like it's personal sometimes
Thanks for the comments guys! I'm continuing to work on the game, if you have any criticism it's appreciated!
Pekuja: I see what you meant now, that is a bug! The enemies difficulty is not reset when you die.
This was a lot of fun, very Diamond Hollow-esque.  I'm always impressed by how well the die-then-level-up mechanics works in games like this.  Overall great job!
That would make a very good postcompo game. Add some nice sprites and check the jump controls. They somehow seemed quite unprecise. But the basic idea is fun even now.
Just great.  I actually played this for long enough that everything I look at is now moving sideways.
At first I found it a little odd that the only way to access the upgrade shop was by dying, but it grew on me.

The enemies became a lot tougher to avoid the more I played (often, enemies would spawn on the right hand side of the screen whilst I was trapped in a sort of tunnel) -- some way to avoid these, or to replenish lost health would have kept me playing this for much much longer.

Fun game, I didn't realize why the game got so hard after I died over and over again. There seemed to be some glitches/inconsistencies with how fast the screen moved. That said, collecting the coins and killing the enemy squares was definitely fun, and the controls were pretty smooth.
Wow... At first I was like... WTF ANOTHER STUPID PLATFORMER...
Then I played and played and played :)

description:
I didn't finish in time.. I'll upload my work and source mainly for learning purposes and in good sport.
The idea ... You travelled space for the past ten years in a spaceship that is now slowly falling apart. You need a new <Enter gizmo name> propulsion distributor, however your spaceship model is over two decades old and item is hardly found in stock anywhere, so it is highly expansive.
You get a message from an unknown contact:
"There is an abandoned space station facility nearby that was used as a custom weapons factory and spaceship salvaging depot by space pirates, the part you are looking for can probably be found there.
"Great! Maybe this is my lucky day." You head to the spacestation to search for the missing part.
The original idea isinspired by rouglikes, shmups and Robot wants, these are the features I wish to implement:
* procedurally generated space station (maze) levels.
* Upgradeable - ship + ship upgrade tree
* several types of enemies and traps
* Some boss fights.
* rare items/ unique upgrades
- Managed to write the code for procedural maze.
(Only the maze is ready)
You can use the map images in the source to win.
Thanks for saying hi:)
author: elbowroom
title: Astral Artifice
comments: I kept making very little progress, then getting stuck in walls. The game's main innovation was the color change, which would have helped me maintain a better idea of where I was if I didn't keep getting jammed into a wall. I gave up after the third time, stuck somewhere in green. :P
I like the concept of flying around free and overall has a what looks like a fair bi of polish. Although I did get lost in the end...
Not my kind of game, but I was definitely impressed by the graphics.  The timer counting down from 20+ minutes intimidated the hell out of me.  I wasn't going to play a giant maze for 20+ minutes.
I agree with Josh and mikelovesrobots3,
20+ minutes is scary, and I got stuck a few times. >_<

Problem with your idea is that that's way too ambitious for LD. The maze generation looks good, except there's too many long, long ways to go that have no reason to go that way, they just suck your time away. Collision was buggy, but the game did seem very much done in what you did finish.
I got stuck in a wall and couldn't continue.  Three times...  Other than that, a good game.
Not much to do unfortunately, I like the ship control mechanism if only it didn't get stuck in walls all the time.

description:
The invasion has begun! Get into the seat of a huge mechanical spider and let your robot rip through the bodies of the fleeing goblins/rabbits before they get to their ship. They DO fight back, at least for a few seconds.
Also. Walk LEFT, which makes sense since they are escaping.
CONTROLS
asd = control of the robot, walk to the left
mouse = fires and aims the gun
HARDWARE
opengl 3.1 (#140 shaders) - If it wont work, pleas try to update your drivers. If that wont work i'd be very happy if you could tell me what graphics card you are using. =)
THOUGHTS
I actually do feel pretty good about this, since the semi-disaster that was LD20.
What i especially like is:
- parallax scrolling
- Lua controlled bots
- Component based game architecture
- The spider, since i cant really draw/animate.
- That i rolled my own pretty much everything. =)
What i don't like is:
- That i did not test it on other systems, will see if i can scrap the 3.1 (got it down from 3.3) shader requirement.
- No crosshair, and various graphical glitches
- People walk right
- No animated ending
- No weapon upgrades
TIP
- press the right mouse button once for autofire
- if you cannot play, please watch the video! =)
author: nilstastic
title: And resistance was futile
comments: Unfortunately I can't play it. It crashes before anything even shows up, just give an instant "has stopped working" message. And my computer is new, has a good graphics card and I have onpenGL installed.
For what it's worth the videos look fun.
Is the graphics card and ATI or Nvidia? I've been having trouble with ati based cards. :/
This game brought out the psychopath in me. I like it, but at 826 kills there simply weren't any more things to kill :(
Good work, though. I like the graphics :)
Nice arts! I kind of feel bad for the little... things though :(
It does not work, I don't know why.
Same as last guy.  Would think nVidia would support open GL on a new card but ho well.  Interesting concept, at least, cool to see the escaping being done by someone other than the player for once.
On a new card NVidia supports opengl 3.x, a good place to check the status of your card is: http://www.realtech-vr.com/glview/download.html - there you can see what parts of opengl is supported.

But, i do feel bad that not everyone can play it and i will look into how much work it would be to make the renderer work on 2.1 hardware. The reason i went with 3.3 was because it was new and fun, but it's even less fun when people can't play my game. =)
And, if you'd like you can try again, i've rewritten it so i'll only need 3.1 support.

Works now, but there is something really weird with some sprites, like they're trying to resize to some weird size, use wrong depth sorting, or use wrong portion of the texture. Crashed after a while.
The movement and the mindless shooting was all good, but I really didn't know where I was going with this one... was there a point/endgame?
Worked fine on my system: NVidia GeForce GTX 460.
Geforce 8600GT on winxp, current drivers (open GL version 3.3 reported), crashes after startup.

description:
Lost in a cave, find your way out!
----------------------------------
I sort of ran out of time here. I dreamed too big! Thanks for checking out what I have so far though.
author: John Conrad
title: A Cave Escape
comments: The platforms in caves reminds me of Terraria :)  Too bad this didn't get further along.  The falling mechanic is difficult to work with, though, because you have no idea how far a fall is going to be before you jump.  I tried to hug the walls when falling, but sometimes I just picked the wrong side and died just from bad luck.
Really big cave system, though, would like to see more :)
Thanks for the feedback! Maybe in a future version I will add wall sliding to do controlled drops. To help with the blind falling and all. :P
Shame this didn't get further, looks like it'd be interesting game.. love the switching to rats mechanic. Good luck with continuing.
Controls are a bit iffy, and the bullet/rat collision detection is flawed. A lot of the time it looked like bullets were hitting a rat, but nothing happened. Still, a nice start.

Couldn't really get into this one, clunky controls and lack of in-game instruction/purpose.  I ran about for a while, and then died (i think) after falling too many times.  Looks like a cool game idea, but only if you had more game s:
A few people mentioned clunky controls. Can anyone elaborate on what felt off? Was it the responsiveness or the button choices or the physics or something else?
Again thanks all for the feedback so far.

I didn't use the body switch to reach the end of the level. There is a good idea which is not exploited... It's a bit sad. I think you could make an interesting game if you continue the development further (doing a better use of the switch mechanic)

description:
We live in a world dominated by television. You need to find something better and stop the counter.
Tech:
It's my first LD, also first project in Flash, FlashPunk, FlashDevelop and Box2D. Graphics and sounds created using Gimp, Paint and Bfxr.
author: Maskl
title: TVs Attack
comments: Just getting a screen with gray static when I start the game :\
I'm almost immediately stuck - 3 TVs blocking the bottom, 2 TVs blocking the lower path, and the insta-death on the top path.  What gives?
spoiler: move back when you hear an explosion (on the top path)
@JohanAR: there's no loading bar and the game has about 5MB. Maybe that's a problem.
I love that the pupil heals you, very nice detail.

Very nice. Graphics make nice atmosphere. Grenade sound is a bit bad though. Idea is also cool and I guess it fits the theme nicely. May be more story about TVs and their crappy influence would have helped.
Very very nice game. And it makes me laugh.

description:
You must escape from the Labyrinth, while dodging merciless monsters that will kill you without a second thought, solve riddles from mages that can kill you with the flick of a hand, and find items that you can use to defend yourself.
Note: This game has no battles in it.
author: Master K
title: The Labyrinth
comments: How do you play it? I downloaded the zip and it has a readme, hsi file and an rpg file.
What program is needed to play?
Please put the game.exe file in the archive so that those of us without the engine can play :)
i'm sorry but i can't play it, sorry i really wanted to try it because the name sounds cool
In order to play this game you need the O.H.R.RPG.C.E.
You can download it here for either WINDOW, MAC, or LINUX.
The game should work on all three.
