Thumbs up for music and for the riddles, thumbs down for forgeting to mention how to play it (thx spoonweaver)
With it being so easy to die, it would have been nice to have checkpoints, or at least a way to skip the intro (I couldn't find one).  I did like the riddles though.
The big open hallways are too big and open.

description:
The game uses Java, you need that installed to run. It's available as an applet (though Java applets on OSX arn't nice) and as a downloadable game.
You are Sidney, a convict wrongly banged up. Sidney has mutant powers - the ability to copy himself. Sidney must escape through a series of cells to be free of the prison.
Avoid the prison guards, they'll wake up if you get to close. Avoid traps and lazers. Press the switches to open the doors to the cells.
author: kevglass
title: The Cell
comments: Great job, man! One of my favorite! :)
Simply the best game of this compo
Best game I've seen in the compo yet.
Nice job. Loved the idea within the theme. :D
I'm see that you were expecting the "Self-Replication" theme to win. ;) Fun game.

That's a good game! The idea was interesting and has been well executed, the graphics are nice (toilets :D ) and the sounds are good, and there's even a background music! kevglass' journal is well filled, cool! That's an outstanding entry!
Just admit it, you started working on a self-replication game in advance, then changed the graphics when the theme turned out to be "escape" instead. :y
Really well thought out levels, challenging!
Devious puzzles! This is definitely one of my faves so far. And probably the one that's kept me playing longest.
One of the best I've tried so far...
It is clear that you were anticipating self replication as a theme, but it does work as a block pushing puzzle game to escape jail.
FWIW, I didn't read the themes or come up with the idea until the announcement of the final theme. I guess self replication was just on my mind having read the top few themes.

Great job! I played this a bit earlier but wanted to actually finish the game before I scored it. Definitely fits the theme, and is a nice balance of fun and challenging. It took me a moment to figure out the cloning ability, but once I did it was definitely great. Reminded me a bit of Lolo to be honest. Great game!
Great work with the game, nice graphics. Sadly I couldn't hear any sounds on Linux :(
Nice audio. Quite challenging. The character sprite doesn't really stand in middle of tile, which makes it weird when looking at tile lines.

Quite a few entries using this dual-avatar movement mechanism.  This one's had the best aesthetic so far, but I'm not sure if I prefer the static movement to the one where you can push the replicant around by bumping into walls.

description:
my first ludum dare entry and yes the first game i really completed.
!you need Microsoft Visual C++ 2010 Redistributable Package to get it working:
http://www.microsoft.com/download/en/details.aspx?id=5555
controls:
use A and latter D to build up speed
use W and S to avoid obstacles
the goal is to get as many points as possible.
be careful if you go to fast you might not see where you are going.
about me:
Hello everyone my name is Alexander Bladh aka Xobust. I'm 14 years old and live in Sweden just as @notch :P.
i've been developing for a while now, the dream of my life is to become a good developer and make all sorts of programs.
Enjoy ! :D
author: Xobust
title: Road Runner
comments: Doesn't start in Wine, possibly due to lack of that VC++ redist
It ran fine for me, but I don't understand why I had to hold down the D key at all times. If the player is going to be doing something all the time why not make it automatic?
sorry forgot to tell you... you cant use both a and d unless you got 7000 points, before that you only use a to build up speed....
hm thats weird i dont have to use the d key at all time to get the player to do something probably a bug in sdl duno.

yes and you can try to run VC++ redist on wine, probably i won't port it to linux cuz i don't know how to use any Linux complier. the libs i use are cross platform so feel free porting it to whatever platform

Controls feel very strange and make little sense to me. I kept losing until I realized you had to jump to keep up with the scrolling rate of the game. I'm also unsure why you packaged two EXE files in your entry, they appear to be the same.
Probably I didn't unsdertand the game.  I just had to press jump all the time to avoid the obstables and accumulate points.  The A, D, and S keys didn't make a difference to me.
I didn't like to always have to be tapping a key. Also, I found the color scheme off-putting.
I thought the warning sign was a cool mechanic that was very-well implemented.

description:
I was unable to make a complete entry this time around. Being still in high-school, my parents reserve the right to change my schedule at any time. So what I have finished is merely a concept with only 4 levels. Not much, but it's playable.
Use the arrow keys and the space bar to guide your character to the exit. Run from the advancing wall of doom.
After the competition, I added a few more levels and revamped the graphics and menus. you can play the post compo version here: http://dl.dropbox.com/u/2727127/Pressure/World1.swf
author: frr171
title: Pressure
comments: Same, had fun, more levels would be nice.
This could have been truly entertaining, if only it had been longer.
Jumping feels very floaty and awkward, especially since you can't half jump. Needs more levels.
The level design is smart (the last room has a nice timing =)) and the idea could make a good classic game but it's too short...
Nice job anyway. When I was your age, I was not able to do that in such a short time .
Do not be discouraged, and finish it! we want moar!
OH GOD THE PRESSURE! (coming from the sliding wall of doom :-) )
Nice idea. I like the scaling levels, and the "just enough" time to make it.

The spikes are a bit sensitive; I tried being a ninja, and I hit the hitbox of the spikes, but not the graphic of the spikes. It might work better if the hitbox of the spikes was shorter, or if you only died if you were moving downwards.

As others have said, the timing in this game is really well done. That's sometimes hard to get right, but you did a good job with it. Tell your parents that they're keeping you from valuable educational activities! (I'm not being sarcastic, I can't think of a much more educational experience than trying to jam out a working game in 48 hours)
Very short, but a OK proof of concept. There was not as MUCH pressure as I thought because the levels are very short. I do think this idea can be expanded.
It's a good prototype. The mechanics and increasing difficulty is working. With better graphics, sound and more levels this could make a fine game.
Simple idea - maybe not very innovative but very good timing (especially in 4th level) makes it really good. This could be a very good game if polished. I'd like to see more levels.

description:
3 Levels complete for this dare.  In the future I'd like to update the controls to behave more like the older 8 bit titles.
Mac build is Intel only.  Source is a UnityPackage.
author: paraboxstudios
title: Oh No, Lava!
comments: A nice 5 minutes of game, here - nice that it isn't too ruthless with dead ends and suchlike. Have you considered trying to expand this by making levels procedurally generated? It seems it would be suited to that.
Bit too simple for my taste
I like how it shows the power-ups scattered throughout the level before starting.  The lava looks more like fire to me.
Interesting. Although yeah, the lava looks more like fire. Despite being simple I find it to be nice enough. Good Job.
I actually found this quite enjoyable for it's simplicity, although it also felt a little too punishing.

The fact that getting killed only lost 1 coin adds a bit of strategy to the mix, in that if you can go to a dead end that gets you at least 2 coins, that is still a net gain.  I think with a little more variety, some better level design and slowing moving lava, this could be quite fun.
Also, the approaching wall of doom really did give me a strong feeling of escape.

author: Draknek
title: Not the Sharpest Sword in the Box
comments: Really great game! I have played this a bunch so far and love how fun and simple it is with a surprising amount of strange and funny gameplay that happens depending on sword distribution and how you have "arranged" the man.
Funny little game. Not sure how it fits the theme though...
I would love to have it on my iPod in the morning to waste some time in the train on my way to work :)
@Marach: you're escaping the swords ;) But true, it might be streaching the theme a little.
I also like the title, very clever.
Very very cool. Lovely implementation of a very original idea.
best game of the compo so far!
Very simple, straightforward, fun game! Can easily see this on an iPad or iPhone.
Interesting avoidance physics game with funny audio game over.
Love it. Should definitely bring this one out on the iphone...
OMG !!! This is so great ! I love it
I can imagine this being an escapist's nightmare, a box with neverending swords. Very original I must say.
Really liked this one. Simple but good. I like the vintage feel of the artwork and friendly sound. Good work.
This turned out very good indeed!
One of the best entry so far. Agree with the others, this should definitly do well on a portable device !
Just awesome. Simple and efficient idea! Nice job!
I guess this could have 5 stars for innovation. But, you cant really escape, can you? P.S. mochi highscores do no fit in stage.

description:
Mob Escape was an attempt at making a reverse tower defense game where you are the guys running through towers trying not to get killed. That idea evolved and eventually I ended up with this game. Basically you have 3 guys following you and you are running though corridors and rooms trying not to get hit. While making it there were several points where I wanted to quit because it just wasn't very fun, but I'm glad that I stuck it out and finished. There were a lot of things that I planned on adding (obvious by the inventory boxes on top that are never used), but not enough time. If I ever decide to do any more work on this you can find it at http://joedev.net
Controls
WASD or Arrows = Movement
Space = Pause
Left Click = Shoot
author: JoeDev_net
title: Mob Escape
comments: "Reverse tower defense" sounded promising, but it isn't quite what the player might expect. Gets a bit uninteresting quickly because of the lack of variation. Also, there's little payoff for fighting rather than running away - but I guess that just fits the theme, heh.
More level progression could've made this a gem. Don't introduce every enemy in level 1. Shorter levels, more new mechanics per level.

Fun little dungeon crawler! Would have liked to see some treasure, maybe a little character progression or powerups, and a little more variety in the levels. I liked controlling four dudes at once, occasionally using the lesser party members as meat shields :)
Interesting idea. I agree with the above comments on level progression.

I also found a strange quirk with your tile renderer. http://fireslash.net/~fireslash/images/ld21_reviews/ld21_joedev_net_1.png seems to happen randomly while running through the levels. Could be a floating point math issue?

Exactly! I agree that the game does become uninteresting quite quickly. That hit me about half way through developing and I almost ended up quitting, but I'm glad I kept going and finished. I made a mistake making the levels random hoping that they would be fun enough to play, but they weren't, so I would have been better off just creating a set of predefined levels. I probably would of had to time to add a semblance of a story line as well. Lesson learned.

description:
Use right click to go to this point.
Use left click to shoot a fire ball. Mind that there is "reload time" so you will not be able to shoot fast.
Edit: Update to properly handle mouse clicks!
author: Ingon
title: Magiscape
comments: The buggy controls make this game pretty much unplayable... :(
Mouse clicks are registered 20% of the time.
I did found out about this but it was already past the deadline. The problem is that I developed on mac laptop using the trackpad, where all click were properly registered.
Well, I didn't have any problems with the clicking. Seems like a decent base for a game, but needs more content!
Controls seems to be fine, even though I would have like your main dude to move a little faster. Loved the opening dialogue, so was disappointed that there was none at the end :P
Trying to play on Linux. I open with the Sun Java 6 runtime, and I get the title screen, and I can click "Start". Then I see the screen saying it is an LD21 game. Then I click and it just closes.
Couldn't play it. Running the .jar just opens a blank, gray window.

description: Spent a whole bunch of time sleeping this weekend, but managed to make something that resembles a game, so here it is. You are an outlaw running from the law with some loot on horseback. Jump over chasms and fire your gun at your assailants.
author: pekuja
title: Horseback Chase
comments: Nice, solid gameplay, even though I wished for constant fire! ;) Do you plan to extend it in the jam?
Good gameplay, just not very much depth to the game. Overall, good.
@ratking Didn't make a jam version, but I'll probably work on this more at some point. Add some real graphics, audio, some more kinds of obstacles, etc. The feedback so far has been pretty positive.
You laid the groundwork for a great game, but there's just not enough content. Would be good to see this fleshed out.
i like it. would be sweet with swapped out graphics and sound. and IMO, the bullet shouldn't should also shoot at the same Y coordinate whether you're jumping or not.
It's a fun little game. The shadow really helps to give you a sense of where you are. I think the collisions with the chasms are a bit unforgiving, some overlap should be allowed I think.
It's nice that it gets harder over time, with the wider chasms.

@excrulon The bullet "shouldn't should" shoot at the same Y coordinate? Umm, I'm not quite sure if you mean if it should or shouldn't shoot at the same Y coordinate, but of course the problem is that when you're jumping, the gun would naturally be higher. I could probably make it so that the bullet will go over everybody's head then unless they happen to jump when the bullet reaches them, but I figured this was easier, and doesn't look silly with bullets coming out from under the player if they're jumping.

@Danik Yeah, the chasms are unforgiving. During development the chasms were actually red, so they didn't actually look like chasms at all. Then when I changed them to actual holes, I didn't think to make them wider, which would have made more sense, but by that point I was already used to the hitbox so that little design flaw crept in there.

Nice and simple, if graphically too simple. Gets a little repetitive gameplay-wise and too hard with one hit kills. Some variety would help. Some art could make this a nice casual game if some pick-ups or terrain variety are added.
It was frustrating at first as there was no cue that you start moving, so I'd go right straight into a chasm.
That is the greenest... squarest horse... I think I've ever seen.
With some decent graphics swapped in and a little bit of sound, this could be killer. The mechanics are smooth enough, but those nice shiny bits being missing are letting it down quite badly.

Quite fun! Wish it had some simple sound effects and maybe some expanded gameplay elements for pickups/dodge items, but it was good for what it was. If you had time to add some art and animations, that would have made this much better. :)

description:
This is my game! Controls and stuff on the webpage! Play it down there!
----
Ludum Dare was fun and inspiring. I'll be sure to join next year as well.
----
DISCLAIMER:
Music made by Incompetech (Or however you spell it)
The source is ONE BIG FLA, so I hope that's okay.
author: dev_redant
title: Hamster Escape!
comments: Neat game. Cute graphics, but not much gameplay.
Neat little point and click game with good music.
Got stuck on Level 2 for a long time, but after I got through it the rest of the levels were relatively quick to complete.  I'm not quite sure I understand all of the solutions, though.

Cute game, but I often didn't understand why I won a level. I'm not asking for super mega HD graphics, but the visuals didn't really explain to me what it was I was clicking, so I just clicked at random. Music was adorable.
nice music, cute theme, very easy, but enjoyable :)

Nice atmosphere, but a little short on gameplay. I'm not quite sure 'simply drawn' graphics lend themselves for point 'n' click games - objects were so big that clicking and moving stuff solved all your problems before you know why.
While the graphics were cute, visual cues weren't so great as I wasn't even sure what I was doing.
Rarely knew what I was clicking on or how it worked, but I thought it was funny and cute. I won by just clicking on random things and progressing when I could. :3
It is a cute game, but I got stuck on level 7 when the ball started falling through the screen and looping.. then got glued to my cursor.
Unable to download - says account suspended
We all like the Music by Kevin MacLeod (Incompetech is the correct spelling), but I'm afraid for the 48h-compo EVERYTHING has to be created by yourself.
Hosting account suspended (both win and web links) so can't try it - anyway by using music not of your own you've broke the rules.
Yup, can't play with the account suspended.  And as matthias_zarzecki mentioned, you're not allowed to use any external art, music, etc. for the compo.
If you get your download working again, I'll check it out later but play with the sound off so I can legitimately rate it.
Aren't you supposed to make music yourself for 48h compo?
Buttons are a bit hard to click and I never really understood the way boxes fall. The graphics and the music complement each other very well.

Finally played: confusing pixel hunting requiring pixel precise clicking even on menu items. Got stuck on level two for a long time before I managed to click somewhere and something happened, then finished the rest quite fast (often don't understanding what I am doing). Sometimes item would stay stuck to my cursor.

description:
You're under attack by a Thargoid Invasion Fleet. Make good your escape while shooting down as many of the pesky blighters as you can.
Controls: Arrow keys to move, X to fire.
I had other plans this weekend and so I didn't originally plan to enter Ludum Dare. However, I had ideas for the three top-rated themes, and I knew I'd be spending three hours on a train, during which time I might as well be making games, so I decided to have a go at making a game for Ludum Dare on an extra-short schedule.
In the end I managed to spend about five hours on this game, but it wasn't really enough. It's a bullet hell game, but I didn't write code that's flexible enough to generate sufficiently interesting patterns. I had intended them to be fairly simple to fit the time constraint, but not this simple.
Since I'm not convinced this sloppy pile of code has any real potential, I haven't bothered to write scoring code or code to detect collisions against the player. It just loops endlessly without any possibility to win or lose, although it's moderately satisfying to shoot the Thargoids for a while.
For five hours I'm reasonably satisfied, but sorry it's no fun!
author: Dan C
title: Flight of the Cobra
comments: Nice effort. Too bad you didnt finish it, I bet if you had spent the whole weekend this could have felt more complete. :P
A bit bummed this isn't more fleshed out, seeing as it's the sort of thing I'm totally into.

If you decide to flesh it out more, might I suggest either slower movement or a Touhou-style "focus" button that slows the movement down for finer precision?  It's not a huge deal here, but if things carried on too long it could become one.
Also, bullets show up under the player...?  Can make it a bit hard to judge their relation to your little hit box.
But for five hours, not bad.
This would be quite tough if the bullet collision were implemented.
@zaron I was going to add a DoDonPachi-style button to fire a more powerful solid beam while also moving more slowly, but I didn't get that far :)
@zaron oh and yes, bullets should definitely appear above the player. Had I implemented collision detection I would have fixed that but as it is there didn't seem to be much point.

description:
Fires & Fights is a web-based (HTML / CSS / JS) two-player game about escaping a confined space. Player One controls the blue square (WASD to move, Q to open windows, E to put out fires) while Player Two controls the pink square (IJKL to move, U to open windows, O to put out fires). Work together, or you'll burn alone.
Two players are required. Sorry if that's a hassle. This is my gift to those of you with significant others who were neglected over the last 48 hours, bring him/her in to play with you. In my own playtesting, I found that the close proximity required to play with two people on one keyboard results in greater than average amounts of snuggling. Enjoy.
See the tutorial on the site for more specifics about gameplay. I wrote and tested the game using Chrome for OS X, and have tested it in Firefox as well, but besides those browsers...there be dragons.
I've written up a post-mortem about how the game came to be and the inspirations behind it, which you can read here: http://samuelfine.com/firesandfights/dc.php. If you want to learn more, follow me on Twitter @54mf.
Thanks for playing.
author: 54mf
title: Fires & Fights
comments: Since I am alone here, I had to play with myself. ):

I really liked the simple look of the game and the glow around the tiles, even though it started lagging when I had about half of the windows open. Might be just me though (Firefox 8 Aurora on Ubuntu 11.04).
Also a question, should anything happen when you opened all the windows? When I finished I could move around, but nothing else happened.

Thanks for playing! Unfortunately, I didn't get a chance to write that last "YOU WIN" bit, so nothing happens. Thanks to some stupid coding decisions, it would be somewhat tricky to determine when the board was completed, as there are a few different states: both sides are totally cleared, one side is cleared and the other is totally on fire, both sides are on fire and the players are dead. The dead state is easy (by checking player health), but the other two needed more time. It'll be there in the next version. ;)

Had to play it two-handed, but it's an interesting concept. I felt that fires were easy enough to contain- I did controlled burns to open windows on one side. Maybe if putting out fires had a cooldown they'd be more of a threat?
I'd be another two handed player, which was challenging.  Neat idea.

@whiletruefork - the fire-starting algorithm needs to be more agressive, for sure. I'm actually a little bummed that I didn't test it more before the final deadline, I had a few test games that spawned a ton of fires right away so I figured it would be tough enough. Subsequent testing has revealed more slow games than difficult ones.
Interesting game :) Wish I could test it with someone, as playing it by myself is too hard for me.. Ha!

description:
This doesn't fit the theme, and isn't complete enough to be a game. But it's what I spent the weekend on.
I've written a bit more about what I was trying to do with it on the Google+ blog post linked to above.
author: based Space Combat
title: Failed Turn
comments: Really cool idea, but there is no game :'(

Wow, I can see the potential... Put 20 ships of different types all fighting each other on the screen at a time like an epic Star Wars battle... although I'll admit at first I thought it was a submarine. Definitely has a lot of potential -- I've played a turn based space combat game in 3d but I think 2d would be more fun. Surprisingly fun just to fly around for a minute, but I crave to blow something up.
Yeah, totally see where you were going with this. Cool idea for sure!
Very nice concept and could serve as basis for a game. Unsure how distracting giving command would be without playing it. There is no theme here though.
Cool idea for a new way to control things in some kind of space RTS, SpaceWar, or Asteroids type thing!
Interesting basis. THis would make for some great ultra-strategic space-battles (Flotilla comes to mind).
Interesting idea.  I hope you find time to make a complete game.
there's an enemy ship in the picture! i played for a bit and all I did was float around space. how do you find enemies

description:
Made in FlashDevelop with Flixel. It's your average Breakout clone. Or is it?
This is not only my first ever Ludum Dare entry, but also my first game coded from scratch. I've previously used Stencyl to develop game prototypes. EscapeOut itself is more prototype than game: given time, I could improve it by adding sounds, a timer, powerups, and better visual cues. Still, I'm very proud of what I've produced. I hope you enjoy.
author: David S. Gallant
title: EscapeOut
comments: Brilliant idea! Gives the "uuuh" moment at the end. :)
Haha, this game is awesome. Great idea.
Please write at least one blog post or you can't receive Trophies! :(
Ha, very clever! I like how it's just a little twist on an old game, very nice!
Hahaha, I thought the game was broken for a sec.
Nice little "gotcha" there. At first I thought it was a bug. :)
I press 'w' and a message shows up: you escaped! is it supposed to do that?
I noticed at the beginning when I thought I'd lost that there is no way to lose...and it clicked in my head when the top layer turned out to be blocks. Very clever.
Ok, I almost why the hell you just made another generic breakout / arkanoid clone?... then I missed the ball... Good idea, points for innovation :)
This is the first game that actually made me smile. The "surprise" still feels weird to watch, it's breaking all the rules!
Hah!  I like it, very clever!
Ha, took me a while :) Love the idea though..
At first I was like, WTF? then I was like "Ooooohhh". Nice one!
Haha, funny idea, initially it is "huh, escape?" thoughts :D
Still waiting for a blog post...
Very clever, but it did take me a while to get what I'm supposed to do. :)
made me smile. great idea, took a tiny bit of working out (i was playing it like breakout) but an overall satisfying game.

description:
You play as a man trying to escape a collapsing building.
Use the arrow keys to move.
author: Armageddon
title: ESCAPE
comments: Got a lot easier when I realized I could infini-jump!
Also I love the art style! Simple, tiny, effective.

I agree that the minimal graphics are quite nice. A little bit of work (sound, music, plot exposition, in-game text) could go a long way. I'm not clear if the infinite jumping is a feature or a bug. But it's definitely playable! Good job :)

description:
Hey everyone, so here is my First LD entry, i plan to had so much more to it... the first day go pretty well but i lost myself in tweaking and not necessary stuff. BUT, I'm proud of this game as the first one i made myself and found it buggy but fun, I Hope you will enjoy it and have fun !
Note : I tried to make a progression on difficulty but the 3rd one is quite difficult but doable really quickly if you are good at Jumping.
author: dray
title: Esc. the Robot
comments: This is a quite good basis for a puzzler/platformer, although in need of some balancing and polish. The background is also quite nice :-)
Good controls, although the perspective makes it a little tough to tell where you're jumping sometimes. Fun!
Biggest gripe is that the level doesn't auto restart. Pretty good platformer and game though.

I know :/ actually you have 2 ways to restart : if you fall you reappear on the StartPoint( the idea was to put checkpoint in the level). Clicking the Restart level at the top-left corner. I think to upgrade the game after the comp, making easy to restart is on the list.

Nice graphics, the controls feel a little bit weird by moments (you can jump in the air after stepping on a red block, I'm not sure if that's wanted of not), and most of all the perspective makes it very difficult to tell if the next piece is below you or just further away on the same level.
Anyways a simple idea nicely implemented (and I really like the robot model!), I'm not seeing a lot of potential right now, but maybe with a bit of polish, who knows.

Thanks to the 3d perspective it can be extremely hard to guess where are you going to end. I've played few levels (good progression of the difficulty), but having to do a lot of attempts to find possible way and jumping in confusing 3d became too frustrating.

author: j_peeba
title: Dystopian Future Underground City
comments: Great graphics and audio, and the backstory-thingy made me chuckle: but I totally couldn't get a hang of the controls and get passed the first couple of levels :/ Perhaps a bit more of an easier start for people with 'suxxor skillz' like me - perhaps when I'm a bit more awake I'll try to persevere.

Really fun! I found the controls were hard but not necessarily in a bad way. I think if the environments were a little more open then it would be less frustrating to be constantly crashing due to momentum. The backstory is funny and the music awesome. The graphics are really nice too. Good job!
Fantastic graphics but the gameplay was incredibly frustrating. The slow turn radius of the ship plus the presence of gravity combine to make it really frustrating, in my opinion.
It also took quite a while for me to even tell exactly when I was colliding with stuff, because it's a weird "soft" collision that just steals some health, instead of the more common hard collision.
This makes every collision guaranteed to hurt a LOT, since you don't bounce off but continue to penetrate the building and hurt your ship more.
Nice work! I liek the graphics and the soundtrack.
The gameplay, however, is enragingly hard. On touch kills me in this clustered level, and the flying space-police-cars can just go through stuff?

Why are the cops flying in cars?? Oh well, I want to like the game, but there seems to be a bug that basically doubles gravity or heavily reduces my thrust once a level has been restarted - if I die once or complete a level, it's almost impossible to gain altitude afterwards. The second level seems almost impossible due to this. Apart from that, the game looks and sounds great. Movement is pretty good as well, assuming this is a bug and not some very evil feature.

description:
Your prisoners, the dwarves, are escaping! Move with the arrow keys. Press space to jump. Turrets cost $50 to place. Place them with the down button. They can be moved by standing in front of one, and pressing up. Press up again to drop it. After a few shots, the dwarves will fall. Pick them up by walking over them. Move them to the jail, and trap them. If you don't pick them up in time, they will get up. See how many of you 200 prisoners you can keep!
Concept: Joecool117/Pie
Programming: Pie, Art: JoeCool117.
Our first LD!
author: eggplantanimation
title: Dwarflings
comments: Well, I thought the game sucked, but then I found myself unable to stop playing it, haha
you should make a polished version of the general idea on Android, I love me some tower defense

Platformer based tower defense game is an interesting idea. It's something I've never played. That being said, I had some collision detection issues. I could jump from the bottom platform and I would fly all the way up to the top. Also, after I built two towers, nothing would ever get past. Does it ever get more difficult?

Thanks! I had never seen one, so that is why we made this game. The collision detection "problem" was sort of on purpose. The game did get harder after about 2-3 more minutes. A little bit after that, some platforms break, changing the course of the dwarves!
I really liked the graphics and the way the platform broke after a while. I think that should've happened sooner (with the game finishing sooner as well).

description:
Crystal Conduit
Ludum Dare 21 Entry (Aug 2011)
CONTROLS:
WASD or Arrow keys to move.
Avoid getting hit by stuff, collect the keys and find the exit.
The source code for this project is available. That code and
all graphics, music, and sound effects may be considered
in the public domain.
Created by Matt Shaffer
htt://matt-shaffer.com
http://pwna.net
Made possible by the following free software:
GIMP - image editing
LMMS - music
SFXR - sounds
ENIGMA with LateralGM - game creation
Utilizes OpenGL and OpenAL
http://gimp.org, http://lmms.sf.net, http://drpetter.se
http://enigma-dev.org, http://lateralgm.org
author: Daz
title: Crystal Conduit
comments: While the game seems interesting, the missiles are almost impossible to dodge and its extremely unclear where one is going, and mistakes are punished too harshly.

The best strategy is to go near a launcher and have it launch a missile into the wall, and you quickly run by after that. If not, the missiles also blow up on their own after about 4 seconds if you can run away that long.

this was really really hard. I couldn't beat it. I gave up because I kept having to redo a ton of level without so much payoff. Perhaps you could add checkpoints near the various challenges. (was that what the red balls were?)
Graphics wise, there was a ton there, the only feedback I could give is perhaps you could distinguish what is background and foreground a bit, things sometimes seemed to be walls that were not.
The challenge was too high being as no checkpoints existed. The music track either glicthed or was missing a few notes towards the end of the loop.
The circle of vision also added to the difficultly without any real explanation. I gave up after trying to pass the crushers with a dead end after it.

description:
This game will need internet-access for the full FUN! :-)
It will load the locations of the deaths of other players into your map!
You are a robot-scientist who is attacked by bugs in his lab.
You have a LASER weapon to defend yourself!
The number below the stairs indicate how many people went in there. (Not how many died there)
--- Want to know how i've done that? See here:
http://www.ludumdare.com/compo/?p=68738
author: Spunkmeyer
title: Another Escape From Self Replicating Bugs 2
comments: AEFSRB2 is an enjoyable game which misses a reliable gun (bugs do not always die when hit too rapidly) and a better difficulty curve (first levels easy and last really hard). Maybe the levels should have been linked with the map (they could therefore have been adapted to help the player when needed), nevertheless it's a good shooting game and the online scoreboard (quite empty at the moment) is something other games should have too ! The graphics/sounds aren't very good but that's enough for such a game; a background music/rythm would make the game more entertaining though. The author's journal is filled with comments and food, which we all appreciate. Cool LD entry, which might benefit from some more polish ! :P

I wasn't able to get this game to start. According to the log file, the game started, but I never saw a window pop up. There appeared to be some window when I hover over the icon on the taskbar, but I couldn't get the window to actually be visible on my desktop.

Nice little game. The lighting system and ray-tracing gun show you have some definite programming chops. (So too does the internet death displayer, but unfortunately I didn't see any - not sure why?). I question why there are 5 different levels though, since they all seem to be pretty much the same (except for the introduction of shooting bugs). Still, nice game.
@Deraj: Your resolution could be too low. It needs 1024 768 minimum!
@johnfn: The levels are just getting more diffucult. Beside that, your health-bar never increases. So the 5 levels are there to test how tough you are :-p
Letting us see each others corpses and scores is a really cool idea!
Before even seeing your entry, I was actually thinking how awesome it would be if someone released an easy-to-use library enabling internet scores in (LD48) games. *hint hint :P*

For the 1st two levels, I chose stairs w/o corpses (so I'd be more likely to survive :) ). Then I wanted to see corpses and went looking but didn't see any in levels 3 or 4 for some reason, despite there being 6-9 there.

description: Hey! Redditor from Sweden here. This is my first ludum dare game, and my first game ever completed(though I've made alot incomplete ones). I hope you enjoy!
author: itsarabbit
title: "Get to da choppa!"
comments: I got an error in the forest... also, I have no idea where to go.
Ahahaha this is great! I made it to the choppa :D
Mark: I feel the same way. The big empty 'field' was strange too.
Not bad. Fits the theme perfectly. The story made me chuckle. I enjoyed my time with it. However the large amounts of areas with no objects around was a down point for me.
Yeah, filling the empty space was a big problem for me. Everything practically had to be built in blocks and if I'd had it any smaller, it'd simply be too small.
I should've also made it clearer what the player should've done, and where to look.
haha sound was hilarious love the voiceover at the start
I managed to find my way out of the screen never to be seen again
Needs an arrow or a minimap, something to give da player an idea of how to get to da choppah. I also got lost in da areas with no features. I didn't manage to get to da choppah.

description:
Something has gone terribly wrong, fight and flight your way out of this place, before it gets you!
Turn down your lights, and turn up your speakers. etc.
Controls: Standard Mouse aim/shoot keys/AWSD movement
My first entry to LD, it's been a blast. Managed 26 hours of development. Built in Unity/C#, SFX with AS3SFXR online, Music made with Reason, 'Textures' made in Fireworks.
author: Jasper Stocker
title: Alpha Centuri
comments: Brilliant graphics and music. I really like the flashlight effect. The game was very atmospheric but I suddenly got overrun with waaay to many enemies to handle!
Fun and stylish gameplay.  The blood made a convenient marker for where I had been :P  I know darkness was kinda the point, but I could have use for a slightly brighter flashlight.
Didn't get very far, got swarmed by enemies. However, you've got some great graphics in this game!
Good looking game, but I couldn't get past getting swarmed by the little black things. Maybe I'm missing something? The flashlight and muzzle flash effect are very cool though.
There comes a lot of enemy's when you find the first guy.
Haha - sorry guys. Guess I made this a little too difficult! ^_^

You can get through though, I can do it (of course, I'm the bloody dev! haha). I've added a help link but basically, KEEP MOVING, burst fire, try to flank/avoid enemies when to opportunity arises (not often) shoot mostly ahead and at any ghost taking your soul!..
Good luck and thanks for playing/rating.
I have to agree that the music is great, and coupled with the limited field of vision provides immersion.
I escaped !!! :D Good game ... I was like " OMFG " when all that ghosts started attack :D ... good idea with flashlight ;)
Great job mate :) nice atmosphere throughout! Enemies swarmed me and it felt seriously tough
it was great, I was really hoping for aliens rather than ghosts mind :]. But great atmosphere, well done!
thanks guys :o) @RichMakeGame: they could be the ghosts of aliens... ;o)
Nice looking. I wanted to move faster. Light was great. Sound was good as well. Nice atmosphere

Very creepy. The 1st part of the game with nothing attacking you realy set up the mood. I thaught there would be a finite number of enemies So I bunkered down in a corner. Aparently this was not a good idea.
Nice immersion, and I also expected aliens... but the ghosts was a welcome twist. A brighter flashlight would be a decent addition, but give it a burnout time or battery run-out perhaps?

description:
My first entry!
Unlock is a easy puzzlegame (sadly I don't have the time to make complex levels)
I'll probably work on a post-mortem version with harder levels!
UP DOWN LEFT RIGHT SPACE
R to restart the level
enjoy!
(the sound don't work well on the web version I will work)
author: uuav
title: Unlock
comments: Neat little puzzle game. Nice music too. Good work!
Nice, could use few more levels. BTW R for restart didn't work for me :(
Great game. Really nice levels so far. Fits my desired difficulty in such a game.
@Shigor you played it on osx win or web? I did the restart update a bit on a rush at work, I might upload the wrong file.
Fun little game. Restart button doesn't work though.
I like it very much. Certainly a fantastic first entry. No real flaws!
I'll fix the missing button asap. Thanks for your comments guys!
Hop you got the fake ending ;)
Hope you got the fake ending ;)
Love the aesthetics of this. Fun too, though I wished the cursor would have moved faster.
The level-design scales nicely, the faux-crt-pixel-style is quite neat, and the soundtrack is fitting. Also, the instruction (up down ..) are brilliantly simple.

Pretty cool feel to it. Not much of a puzzle player, I had a bit of a tough time with some rooms. Eventually finished it (the real ending). You could maybe try mouse control instead of arrow keys to manipulate the level. Just click and drag pieces. That should be more fluid and perhaps more enjoyable. The pieces could even move with full pixel freedom and only lock into the tile grid (smoothly) when you let go of the button.
I've seen at least one other game with similar gameplay here already but the visuals are very nice. A hidden security camera type thing.
I REALLY like this game. The graphics are pretty awesome and the gameplay is unique and memorable.
Nice work. Liked the chunky graphics and T.V. static effect. Music was good. Well done! :-)

description:
Made in Game Maker: Text-Adventure... with a twist.
'Don't you hate it when words just escape you, on the tip of your tongue - so to speak.'
WASD to move.
Left clicky-click buttons with the mouse.
No sound - ran out of time ^^
Hosted at my website:
http://nizan.weebly.com/ludum-dare-21.html
My first Ludum Dare complete! :)
author: Nizan
title: Tongue, tip of the
comments: I can honestly say I've neither played a text adventure with platformer elements, nor a platformer with text adventure elements. Good job :)
Game was a bit confusing at first, I thought it was bugged before I realized I had to move the blob.
Interesting concept!  I like how it's not only the dialog choices that changes the game, but also that it's the gameplay that changes the dialog.
It would have been nice to get an introduction to the game mechanics at the start. but overall interesting concept.

Going to work on it some more outside of the competition, and actually explaining the controls is top priority ^^' Can't believe I forgot to... xD Glad people have enjoyed it though! Thanks for playing :)
That was an interesting mix of genres! =]
A very interesting and innovative idea. Liked it!
Interesting concept, yet quite confusing from the start. Only after I started to type Father I noticed I can move (I tried cursor keys to no avail, so I was looking for some other way...)
Excellent concept. The only bad thing I can say about it is that the whole screen would sometimes flicker.
Yeah the flicker thing I have no idea about at the moment, a few people have mentioned it, but then others not had a problem at all. Looking into it, but thanks for pointing it out :)
Bravo!! All you need now is some sound and to brush up the graphics. That was great! :)

description:
Not really finished, since there were a few physics problems ( still there).
It doesn't run on some computers for some reason... and on some computers, you have to press 1 in the main menu to get to the second level.
For Windows users: just unpack the zip file and start the exe.
For everyone else: install Love2D (http://www.love2d.org) and run the .love file.
Connection to escape: you should escape the facility through various rooms with a meaningful ending (sadly I didn't get around to finishing the ending, so much for that.
The source is included in the .love file, which can be unpacked as .zip archive with 7-zip ( or other archive tools)
author: RebelMoogle
title: The Life of Borgy
comments: Has potential, but hard to comment on it in its current state. I've love to see you keep working at this post jam :)
Good that you can now finish the level. I was really surprised when I could suddenly move the boxes and was free! :D 4*
This has neat portal-vibe, and the music is quite fitting. Unfortunately it's quite short, and the jumping is kinda flaky.
Wow thanks for the input. I'll try to continue working on it, although I might port it to another framework, as I had problems with Lua (maybe C++/some Library.)
Not a fan of the gameplay/controls.  Jumping from a standstill feels incredibly weak, and jumping while moving feels ridiculously overpowered.  Great music and I liked the signs/humor/vibe, though.
what were your problems with lua?

I really liked the background graphics, I think you could change the foreground to match them. Now that you have the first level of the game, I would like to see where you can go with the mechanics that you have setup.
The gravity was a little too moon-like for me but I otherwise liked the feel of the game, especially the way you could impulse-slam into walls and bounce off them a little :).

This would be more fun if you were escaping from something, say an enemy or rising water, etc. It seems pretty pointless when escaping the room I'm in just takes me to another (well, the same) room to escape (but you already said it's not done).
The graphics were cohesive and the background was really good. I really like the sad expression on the robot and his animation. Good choice of chip-tunes. Great entry for a fellow first-timer :).

description:
Super Kommandant Extreme is based around two main ideas, Light as a limited resource and Hogan's Heroes perspective on prison camp Kommandants, the idea being that while people were off fighting in the war the kommandants stayed home and lived the life of the party. The only real thing they feared was having their command taken away from them, so you better stop those prisoners or you'll be wearing snow boots on the eastern front!
At the start of the LD i had the option of doing nice or quick and dirty code, i chose the latter so if you look at my source be prepared for horror.
Programmed in Java, nothing else :P
Sound tools were Audacity and Sibelius!
Graphics were made by a little program called ArtIconsPro and the logo was created using OpenOffice.
Quick instructions for people who do not want to read the ingame ones:
WASD / left mouse grab and drag : navigate the map.
Moving the mouse : watch tower beams follow your curser.
Right mouse button : Fire machine gun.
Watch tower beams when the large part is held over a prisoner (they will stop moving) for long enough will cause them to vanish back to their barracks, do this!
Only shoot them if they get outside the fence! killing guys inside of the fence will cause you to lose very quickly!
author: Nothing Games
title: Super Kommandant Exteme
comments: Pretty cool game, but pretty hard too.
The wall of text in the intro made it a downer tough. I confess I didn't exactly read it, so on the first rounds my prisoners just escaped.
I only realized what I should be doing about 5 or 6 rounds in, when I discovered the right mouse button would shoot.
Even though, finding them prisoners was pretty hard, and killing them was unrewarding, so it was not very fun.
The music was pretty nice, but having it be interrupted every once in a while really broke the flow and made it annoying.
Apart from my douchebaggery, the game was really awesome, congrats!
I liked the premise but found the execution a little dull. Good entry though! Congrats!
Cool idea.  Could probably use some more gameplay depth as simply swiping the mouse back and forth isn't all that exciting.  Good job overall however!
I know that the core idea is to search for the prisoners, but how it was executed is somewhat dispirited.
Nevertheless the concept is great. Really liked it! Good Work.

Now this is what I am talking about. Using tools to prevent others from escaping. Shine the lights at prisoners trying to flee so they are noticed then captured. Shoot anyone outside the walls because they are too far away.

description:
Spiritual is a game about a mischievous Wisp who gets thrown into a world of swamp and mazes as a punishment for slacking off from his divine duties. Your mission is to guide him through the everchanging network of duckboards, collect the Wisplings he needs to reactivate the Seal he came through and take one step closer to the home. To be honest though, the level are procedurally generated and the difficulty increases indefinitely, so the road is quite long. Maybe we need a sequel to relieve the Wisp from his torment?
Controls are explained in-game, but we forgot a couple of details in the rush: You can skip to the opposite side of the maze by moving the Wisp outside the screen, providing that the block on the other side is accessible. Also if you stay still for a moment, the platforms directly under you will move. This is meant to prevent getting stuck so easily. The game can also be played with Xbox 360 controller if you have one hanging around.
Spiritual was made by Team Jolly Roger for 21st Ludum Dare, using XNA Game Studio 4.0. Feel free to give us feedback or suggestions at teamjollyroger.com, or check us out on Facebook. We hope you enjoy the game!
author: TeamJollyRoger
title: Spiritual
comments: Impressive game!! Atmosphere is unique, graphics is good, sound and music too!
For gameplay I prefer more direct control on sliding blocks.. well done :D

Loved the story, the intro art was very good, as well as the ambient and hypnotic audio. The mechanic got a little dull after several levels, and I ended up quitting after about 7 or 8 levels - it became an excercise in patience, something Ludum Dare game rating doesn't really allow for ;) Maybe just a few too many levels. A few powerups or something to break up the monotony would help immensely. Overall, enjoyed the game quite a bit, really enjoyed the mechanic! It was neat and oddly humbling to NOT be in control of my environment. :)
Thanks for the feedback, we appreciate it immensely! :) We already have several improvements in mind to enhance the gameplay, including powerups.

I don't know yet when we will actually have a change to put those ideas in good use, but I'm convinced that we will develop the game further in the coming months. If you're interested, we will post news of any progress to our brand new development blog. (http://www.tjrdev.blogspot.com/)
PS. We already ported the game to Windows Phone 7 for fun, works surprisingly well!
I agree, the "wait for the blocks to randomly move in a way you can use" mechanic gets old quickly. Having SOME way the user can affect that might help.

Looks and sounds amazing! However, the mechanic was a little problematic - because the sliding blocks were completely random, it was often more a matter of waiting for the right blocks to come than of actually making a good move. Maybe if you add some element of control to the player?

description:
You have to escape from the blowing spaceship.
Hadn't really time to finish this properly, and I didn't want to include it as Jam entry, so... Hey, at least it works! ;)
Arrow keys - movement
Z/Shift/Space - jump
Z/Shift/Space/Enter - make selection (in main menu)
X/Escape - cancel selection (in main menu)
You can resize the window to get bigger screen.
author: Wirtualnosc
title: Spaceship Crash
comments: Controls are a bit frustrating at times.. And some music would have definitely added to the atmosphere!
Quite interesting. The not-insta-death-spikes however don't work quite.
First try was on normal, which was just insane (developer difficulty ;). Some variation would have made the game a lot more interesting.

Grr! I really wanted to keep playing this, but was in the end just too frustrated by the difficulty of the jumps. There seems to be a slight input lag, or something, so lots of times I felt like I pressed "jump" while still standing on the ground, but fell down anyhow. :(

I played it a few times with the falling blocks but it was just way too hard-- without them (on "Very Easy") it's much more manageable. I think I made it until about the 6th room or so! Good job, just wish the jumping was a bit more forgiving (maybe code in an "air step" where you can still jump even after a frame or two off the edge of a block.) Level design seems quite solid, too!
Falling blocks a little too random and difficult to avoid by anything but sheer luck.  Overall good job however.

Nice little platformer. Controls feel strange... I guess I expected to jump higher. Exactly the same but shaded tiles for background as foreground is not a very good idea. I like that there's no insta-death, but then again getting more health means less and less danger.

Played on easy. You move so slow and the blocks fall so fast that it feels just random whether you are going to get hit :/ Too frustrating to go back and try again after failing to escape the first time.
Difficulty ramped up quickly. The falling bricks (set at normal) tended to be unavoidable and punishing. Nice little platformer.
There was no warning where blocks would fall and they fell too fast to be avoidable, and this was on normal. The difficulty of the jumps was a bit high as well but nothing outrageous :)

description: My first Ludum Dare competition. It's not a very long game but I hope you'll still enjoy it. "R" resets the game, "WASD" moves the character.
author: PaulWagener
title: Office Escape
comments: I like the clever use of stealth. Makes me want to watch Office Space again. I found myself 'dying' just to find out what people would say. Although I did get stuck when the crate guy backed me into the corner.
Great game! It`s a pitty that there is no sound effects.
+ finnaly someone who created ENDING ... in other unity games there is black screen or "YOU WON" somewhere on wall. ;) You definitely have my rating point. (sorry for bad english)
hm... :D Voting is only available to participants.
Great humor and use of the theme, I loved the dialogs. Difficulty was good too, neither too hard nor too easy. The blocky graphics and (lack of) sounds could use some post-compo love =)
I liked it. First game that made me chuckle :) and good use of your mechanic.
Pretty nice-- but I never could figure out how to get past the Presenter. That's probably because I suck, not a game flaw ;

haha nice! very cinematic I enjoyed that. My favorite thing you did was the atmosphere you portrayed throughout. As weird as it is, that reminded me a bit of Beyond Good and Evil for some reason, probably the 3d-sneaking mixed with cinematic elements. As far as critiques go, the graphics could've been more harmonious (that is, I felt that some more lo-fi graphics here would've been an asset) and some sound would've really added to the atmosphere. Plus the jitter on the characters walk cycle could've been reduced to make it smoother, other than that great job!
I like the text handling, the setting was good. Worth spending the time on it it would take to make it great I think.
The graphics are great and the setting wonderful.  I like the "boss run" :-D
Thanks for all the great feedback so far!
I like how their field of view is projected with light. Much better than my take on it (ahem)

description:
Our hardware hero is stuck again on planet Takutaki. Jump through magic warpgates to escape the pink threat!
* Arrow keys to move
* Move your BLUE hero to ESCAPE via the GREEN exits
* Avoid PINK. Seek CYAN.
FLASH VERSION DOESN'T HAVE AWESOME FOOTSTEPS?!?!!!111one (Due to no support for frequency changing at runtime).
** Made in 2 hours! **
Timelapse: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yyMCETPM0mo
author: Jigxor
title: NO ONE CAN STOP THE HARDWARE HERO
comments: Not terrible but nothing really special.
Guide blue guy to green exit while dodging pink squares. Run through presumably endless randomly generated levels to score points.
My top score was like 17250 or something when I realized you could collect to the cyan dots for more points.
Can't say this game is anything new, but it's still pretty fun. The fact that you did this in 2 hours is awesome.
Nice game, especially if it was done in less than two hours. Not too interesting, but fun.
Cool!  Though as the comments above me echo, it's not particularly innovative.  The cyan are also a little hard to see against the white background.  Wouldn't mind some better art too ;)
Nice for 2 hours! I actually thought of making a 2 hour one afterwards since the submission time was increased for the Jam, but then I was like nah I'm too worn out haha.
Thank you for the feedback everyone! I hope you all enjoyed it, if only briefly!
The graphics where simple, not bad but not good, same with the audio. Definitely a great game for the fact that it was made in two hours.
I wish the boxes flew in more directions.
A bit boring, but not a bad game.  Toward the later levels though it can get a bit random, since there doesn't seem to be any check to prevent one of the pink blocks from starting on top of your guy.
@mikolalysenko - I thought I fixed that glitch. Guess not! Sorry!
Nice work for 2 hours. Nothing new but, quite enjoyable. I think the sound effect really fits in.

description:
'Next Time I Won't Trust the Man in the White Van' is a top down challenge/puzzle game by Josh Coughran (Maple) and Rory Higgins (Spaceoff), set, rather unimaginitively, in a dungeon.  Everything about the story is what you make of it, so without further ado:
Controls:  Arrow keys to move, R key to restart the level, M to toggle mute.  The game saves the last level you were on, which can be accessed with the Load button at the menu.
Edit: Noticed too late there's a problem with the keeping of the deaths stat, beating a level will accumulate a death, so don't feel heartbroken if you got a seemingly perfect run with 26 deaths or so.
The artwork, music and some level design was by Maple, the rest was by Spaceoff.
If your not satisfied or wish to contact us, Maple can be contacted at twitter.com/@itsMaple or mapleisnot(at)gmail(dot)com, and Spaceoff can be contacted at spaceoffz(at)gmail(dot)com
author: Spaceoff
title: Next Time I Won't Trust the Man in the White Van
comments: If there are two things I love in this world, they are sliding block puzzles and good pixel art, and this game has both of them. Fantastic!
I like how you took the classic block pushing game and made it much more dynamic. It's great how you keep adding variation to the puzzles so nothing seems old.
I think you maybe a genius, that was great!
Liked the game. Shame it does run half the times on wine =(

Amazing game! I loved how you introduced the game mechanics piece by piece, and how you didn't need to say how each mechanic worked - you put the player in situations which allowed them to experiment and WORK OUT how a new mechanic played - amazingly "perfect" design!
I finished the game with these stats:

description:
My game is incomplete, hence the name Need For Code. Its a pistake of Need for Speed.
This is my first time hearing about Ludum Dare. It is also the first time I have ever made a game. If I wasn't watching Notch's stream I possibly would have finished.
I thank you guys for the inspiration to finally make games after years of making boring client websites and business apps.
author: K1NET1K
title: Need For Code : Escape
comments: I uploaded the game anyway. I'm pretty proud of what I did manage to get done, aside from spending 75% of the budget on art....
oh yeah, and i didnt do anything to the game in the extra 24hrs of jam period, i should have just uploaded it like it was in the comp.

The screencap looks cool, but all I see in the web version is a car driving on a pretty picture... (I run right over the cars) I love the speedometer thing, but it only appears when I drive in the blue out-of-bounds area :-)
hey i never said the cars were actually 'real'  :)
Car turns really slowly for a top-down racer.  Since that's the only thing to the game right now aside from what could of been, that leaves a lot to be desired.

You made a very common first timer mistake, art is not the prority. And yes, the movement does not feel like a car at all, but it feels slipery, maybe you could adapt that movement physics to a Zamboni Race Game :-D (Ice resurfacer: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ice_resurfacer).
The big ludum dare traps: chatting in IRC, watching Notch's livestream, and making too much art :)
Your cars look fantastic, I hope you come back to do some more work on this some time.

Yeah, next time start with boxes and work on the driving algorithm first. That said, I've tried driving algo's before and they took me a lot longer than 48 hours to get right, and that was for a tank, which is probably a lot easier. Good potential! I really wish you could run over the police (I'm a bad person) and damage the cars. Even just running over the police would have made it a lot more fun. Best of luck.
You definitely need to be careful about making too much art; it's definitely a nice thing (and can be pretty motivating) to have good art, but the priority is the game mechanic.
I hope to see you in the next LD.

Hi, I think you're up to a good start, especially if you've never made a game before :). The controls of the car needs to be tweaked. Feels like origo is to far down(?), and the turning is too fast. I hope you keep making games, and you might have the start for an engine you can use in the next LD =).

This is an awesome start for a first time attempt at writing a game, and I really hope you keep at it! I actually really liked the slippery controls and thought they were quite fun, although it felt more like a hovercraft than a car, haha.

Don't take any criticisms too hard, and consider this a lesson learned- some of the best games here are just circles and rectangles without any art at all. Art should be the last thing you worry about when you make a game, and that's an important lesson to learn, so your time wasn't wasted.
Just think- you've done more in 48 hours than most people who think about game programming ever do, so if you give yourself another month, what awesome things could you pull off?
thanks for all the positive responses guys. i am continuing to work on this game, and hope to have a playable version in the very near future.
Promising, but it looks like there was quite a bit of work left. Definitely run with this, though, it's a great start!

description:
Moustache chick is on her hunt of the mighty lady shaver. But somehow she got stuck in the mighty lava caverns of death.
Better help her to escape the ever filling lava floors and come out alive.
PS: Press P for getting some health as a cheat, if the game gets too hard
author: joekinley
title: Moustache Chick
comments: I found the controls rather dodgy, but otherwise the game is neat.  I really like the tune.
Collision was weird too, there were several points where I was like "Oh there was NO way that lava should have hit me!" I really like your lava fill mechanic though.
Controls felt *really* twitchy. Liked the little 'whee' when you jump :)
The mechanics were pretty interesting, but oh gah, arrrrg, the controls, OW!
The music is AWESOME! The game looks really nice, too.
As everyone else has said, the controls hurt it. There's a real sense of, "I KNOW I jumped early enough and held jump down, why doesn't she make it!?"

If the platforms weren't at such exacting heights, it would be OK. There also seems to be many times when you require the player to jump on a block directly above the one she's standing on. Trying to execute that little maneuver killed the fun more than anything else for me.

Partly because it's frustratingly difficult but I think I also felt what you were requiring of me was unreasonable. I.e. moving in midair gives you more control in a game but it's just one of those aberrations from reality that make it fun. REQUIRING me to change direction midair, however, takes me out of the "reality," of the game and just makes it silly.
Rage-quitting aside, still a solid entry!
Refine the jump controls und the collision boxes and you have a great game there! :)

While I love difficult platformers, I found a few of the jumps quite harsh. Not to mention the unpredictable lava things with their seemingly large hit boxes. Nonetheless, I loved the music and art style!

Well, there's a bunch of things that could be fixed to make this game better, like more predictable lava, more forgiving hitboxes, more realistic gravity for jumping. Also the "hit [a] for whip" thing confused me. I guess that doesn't work until later levels, which I never reached. I felt like hitting the lava was unavoidable a lot of the time due to the large hitboxes and the unpredictability of the lava. Also it would be nice if I could continue from the level I got to after dying. Having to play through the whole game again is way too severe a punishment for the player. Still, not a bad entry, but it could use some extra work.
The premise and title are quite brilliant.

Another platformer which is just killed by the difficulty combined with clunky controls. Sometimes crazy jumping combined with strange collision with lava, which hits you even if you're sure it won't... In second level only way I found to get up was to have a collision with falling lava and jump from it ... Thank you for the cheat, but even with it just wasn't able to get over the vertical climbing in level three I think (I really wanted to see the whip).
Excellent music, nice graphics (and quite funny backstory / character)

author: rom016
title: Many_Many_Spiders
comments: I would suggest not using such an annoying file host. People will be turned away by that.
I would also suggest not violating the competition rules and using premade assets.
Annoying, difficult and based almost entirely on luck.
Definitely move over to mediafire or something. This file host is really bad.

The game is a good start but just not fair! Why are spiders so much faster than me? And how come I can't do anything except be killed by them? I need to be able to get revenge somehow, or else it's just totally unsatisfying.
The game is clearly unbalanced, the spiders are too fast and too big and the hallways too narrow.  Wasn't able to get past the third level.  A flamethrower would be neat!
This is one of the most annoying file hosts I've seen (2 waits, and word verification).  I recommend you create a Dropbox account.

Sigh... next time use dropbox or anything else please, just not something which forces me to wait, click, wait and wait... and then fill damned captcha. And then wait more and more and more for just 1 and half meg file... containing very simple and almost unplayable game using asssets from GameMaker...
Sorry I did not know the file host was that bad.

description:
A game about propaganda production.
You can only use the escape key in this game.
Press it to move guards toward your searchlight.
Catch the Es when they try to escape!
(They need to get a cape first, and then go through a hole in
the fence.)
Survive for as long as you can!
The game is over when five Es escape!
(Needs the XNA 4.0 Redist to play - see README.txt for the link.)
author: rubzo
title: Laboured
comments: A pretty fun game with some strategy required. Good audio work! Would have been nice to have a win condition though, after about 20 e's, I no longer felt a reason to continue.
Pretty good. The controls were a bit clunky, but innovative. I guess that was by design.
Crash on startup, Win7 x64, I have all the imaginable redistr etc. as I'm doing XNA myself. As a Jam entry, can't recompile either.
Rudy - do you definitely have version 4.0 of the XNA Redist?
@rubzo: My game's in XNA, and I've played other XNA games, so yes, I'm 99% sure.

@rubzo: "Song playback failed. Please verify that the song is not DRM protected. DRM protected songs are not supported for creator games."   at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Media.MediaQueue.Play(Song song)

description:
A pretty standard platformer about a vampire whose home has been invaded by a floating orb of light. Get to the bottom of the disturbance so you can finally get some sleep.. and goodness don't we all need sleep after Ludum Dare?
Source is the .cap file (Construct Classic) in the zip.
Requires:
DirectX 9c. (Even if you have DirectX 11.)
Pixel Shader 2.0
author: MisfitBYTE
title: It Burns!
comments: I found the controls very frustrating :(
Not really fitting all that well. The explanations disappear too fast which makes it hard to understand what is going on. There was something cool here but the rules are hard to understand.
I had no idea how to control my guy so I kept dying.
The game felt kind of all over the place. Not much of the HUD was explained, and I wasn't sure how to kill enemies. Got stuck on the second level. Liked the music though.
There's a tip in the readme file that should make things a lot easier. What about the controls are confusing or difficult?
At first I was also somewhat confused by the controls.  Specially when I fell and the game didn't restart.  Using the wings is difficult because I don't know when they are going to worn off.
Thanks, I forgot to put that in the readme. I didn't auto-restart (press 'R') because you can scan the level left and right after a fall death.

description:
Here it is! Menu was a rush hackjob, and there is no sound.
Full disclosure, some code was hacked out of a platform engine I built previously, but had to be completely rewritten from the ground up anyway twice (if something is worth kludging it's worth double-kludging), so I am unconcerned.
FLASHY COLOURS, BLOCKS, AND SHOTGUN COLLARS ON CUTE LITTLE THINGS
EDIT: Given the longer entry period, I did a few bugfixes while bored, and re-upped.
author: Hangedman
title: I Think In A Minute Or So I Will Explode
comments: I always had a soft spot for these vertical climbing games. It is an interesting game dynamic you made here. Is there some algorithm that makes the game get harder the higher you get?
Just tricky enough for my tastes. Fun stuff, and a great name.
Yeah, the game does get difficult as you go up. Or, it did once I patched the damn thing. First build was missing the difficulty code XD
Enjoyed the game that I played it more than I intended.

2082 before I fell to my death. Was getting some weird issues with edge-grabbing, where he would grab on to the bottom of a block instead of the side of it. Other than that, really fun, addictive design and a great cohesive art style.
I had the same issues with grabbing the bottom of the blocks, but the game is solid and fun. I ended up playing it for aabout 30 minutes.
That was awesome, good gameplay balance and controls.
Nice and easy to get into. I like it.
I like it, wise to choose few colors!
Love the switching mechanic, and the gameplay/controls seem dead on.

Nice little game with a clever mechanic. I admit, my favorite part of this game is that you can cling onto the side of blocks. It's a great mechanic that makes the game feel a lot more solid, and more platformers need to have it :)
First climbing game Ive seen with this mechanic, I liked it even if it was a bit simple. Also the animations are well made!
Love that you can grab ledges SO MUCHHHHHHHHHHHHHHH!!!!!!!!!!!!
Very good game. Simple, yet with interesting mechanics. Controls are perfect.
The controls and jumping physics were deliciously smooth. A nice change from all the clunky platformers I have seen in this contest so far :)

Thanks for all the great input, folks :D Also, feel free to leave your best scores, as I'm trying to think about how I can make an improved version and I'd like to get an idea of the scaling of difficulty.
At the moment it gets harder at 1000 and 2000.

Awesome game, but it would have been nice if transitioning inside a block had a pixel or two of give room, just so you didn't have to be pixel perfect. Would love to see this expanded upon with some sound and some progression with an end. Great work.
Good game but I don't understand the link with the theme :\
The hanging-move is neat. The Mechanic is great, but sadly it isn't to much puzzle-effect.
I don't think you were supposed to use the extending submission time to make any changes to your game, but otherwise this is really nice work.
They weren't really changes, so much as a few fixes to broken code and bugs. But mea culpa.
I liked this.  The animations were entertaining and I am impressed with the wall cling.  Getting some sounds will make this feel really nice to play.

Really, really nice little game. Hit a a bug where the black/white display was reversed from the block logic, and some other weirdness, but overall controls felt good and smooth. Really liked the edge-hanging mechanic, and the core black/white swapping was super fun. Also liked that I could kill myself by being embedded in the rock.
Wished there were sounds and music! Let me know if you'd like me to compose some music for you (example music in my game).
Nice visual design with simple fun gameplay. A bit stressful at times with how easy it is to die from a shift or standing still. Love the ledge hanging and the tuck and roll falling.
This was one of my favorite games of the compo.  I'd buy it if it were a little more polished.

description:
A short game inspired by the older point and click games. Help someone escape from his imprisonment. Your only help is a direct audio feed with that person.
I intended to have a lot more content and features, but due to some bugs in my code I actually wanted to drop out half way through. Luckily I didn't! Enjoy!.
Made using Flashdevelop, Paint.net, SFXR and Flixel.
I just noticed the volume of the sound might be very low, you can adjust this by using + / -.
author: Jhelle
title: Hello??
comments: Pretty awesome game, I loved the idea that the guy had to describe what was in the room for you to see it.
Fantastic, really original! One of my favourite entries. :D
I liked the way the room changed as the person described it to you. However, I wonder if the game could have a bit more going on puzzle wise.
I really dig the style and the fact that objects appear as they are described. Could have a bit more of a challenge to it.

Very entertaining. i love how you interact with the character while talking to him. also, good idea to have the objects appear only when talked about. kind of reminds me of what happens in my head when i read a book :) good work!
(i hoped for a creeper boom in the end :P)
Fun game. The ending was great. I can't help but thinking it would have been funner though to figure out the commands and type them rather than punch a number.

Entertaining, and nice work on the audio. Kind of wish I had more control over what happened, rather than sort of waiting to be told what I could interact with next. Nevertheless, a real contender and a nice take on the theme
Choices do seem a bit limited, but I really liked the way you only showed game objects after they appeared in the description.
Just one thing, in the second room, telling the guy to move right makes him move left and visa-versa. :P
@Mikhail actually, it's left and right for the person standing there :)

description:
Version 2, now with sound and music.
Game is multiplayer. The first one to join plays the Queen. Recruit some friends to play it properly!
author: triplefox
title: Heartbreaker!
comments: A little bit buggy (objects moving back and forth, players dying at wrong times etc) but a nice idea. I like that you can just drop in and play with random people. Game mechanics could benefit from being a little bit more complex

Cool idea!  The ice queen is way too powerful though, it seems like your balance is way off for 1v1.  Especially being able to drop monsters right on top of people and then reactivate the ones they just killed...Otherwise it makes a neat sort of mazing game :)

Cool game! The asymmetrical multiplayer aspect is pretty interesting. But it seems really imbalanced when there's only one Mage. It's way too easy for the Ice Queen to keep up. I think the Ice Queen's powers should depend on the number of Mages. Or something.
I'm only able to drag blocks around.

Quite the intriguing game, albeit quite buggy. I honestly think, however, that it's great fun and you should extend upon this idea. Maybe add more elements. Hell, if you want, I can join you in designing additional content and such. Granted, I don't even know what language you did this in, but I can learn. This really seems like an idea that can go off, I'd love to join in adding to it.
Woah, multiplayer :) Sadly impossible to play alone no?

It's showing quite a promise, but since I wasn't able to force more people to play, I had to test it almost against myself so  I can't exactly rate it properly - it seems that the game mechanics need some serious tuning (especially for the number of the players). Movement of the mage is extremely erratic (might be big ping on your server, didn't test it) and I think it's not going to be big fun for mages. Audio and gfx is good, almost excellent (didn't like the monsters very much) and it shows a big promise, so I'm rating you quite high despite my problems with gameplay.

This is amazing. Played it with some friends. Hilarious, but also a bit cruel. Could do with some spawn area protection. Also, 1v1 is massively unfair in favour of the ice queen. Best multiplayer game I've seen yet.

I like it. The problem is that it's only fun for around 3 Red Mages, too few or too many makes it far to hard for one side. It would also have been nice to make the new ice queen random, rather than the person who first escapes. A little buggy, but mostly no problems.

I thought the game was awesome. Great idea, good implementation. It was a bit buggy though, and I'd have like to see those issues polished out a bit more. It's also REALLY imbalanced in 1vQueen or more than 3vQueen.
OK wow just posted this on a forum and got 8 or so people to play with me and this is FANTASTIC! It's fun to play, and I love the way it's "casually" / party line internet multiplayer.

description:
I didn't succeed in finishing it, and therefore the UI is very limited and there are no sound, and the game overall isn't balanced, and I don't intend to fix it.
There are some systems that somehow refuse to play the game. Try again later or on another computer if that happens
author: ahnimal
title: EscapeBot2
comments: Although you seem dissatisfied with it, I kinda enjoyed it. nice job with the randomly generated levels; I never encountered one that I couldn't beat. I was hoping for more of a resolution, though, but it's understandable that you didn't quite get there.
I can't play it =( Does not work on Firefox, on Linux...
I tried it on ubuntu with Chrome.
I dont get what im supposed to do the door never opened it just keeps me in a cube
I got stuck once and couldn'r open the door. The controls are a bit difficult especially if confronted with enemies.
