description: Instructions: WASD controls your velocity, but you have limited control due to the gravitational pull of the black hole you are closely orbiting. Use the mouse to shoot and kill 200 enemies!
author: CaseyR
title: Escape Velocity
comments: You should put up an executable too. Not everyone would prefer compiling it manually.
yeah, don't forget to include the http:// part of the link!
yes, please add an executable. I don't even know what platform the game is for?
No executable not going to rate
Uncompiled code and not even a link to prerequisite library is a very bad community support. Hoping to see an executable before the end of this.

I gotta agree with the others, Casey. I've been messing with the source for two hours now and the farthest I've gotten (after noticing the class naming conflict between your Game class and the abstract Game class in libgdx) is being told it can't start up a window.
I'm sorry, but I just won't spend more time trying to make this work.
The screenshot makes this game look interesting, but without any way to play, looks like this one's not going to see much love.
Why did you uploaded it at all? You say in your journal that your game is missing a game... you put up just your sources with comment that it can't compile...
Oh man, I'm really sorry guys!

The reason I submitted at all was because the 48 hour deadline was coming up (before I knew it was extended) and I was planning on coming back and submitting an executable. You're allowed additional time for porting... but I got busy with work and never got around to it. :\
Sorry for those of you that tried to compile the source, it's missing the art files. I only had the source there to prove it was done. I forgot to include the art assets. D'oh!

author: Redbone
title: Escape Work to get a Drink
comments: BSoDs were a nice touch. So small! I wish I could scale it up.

It's a very nice, simple game. The graphics are fun and cute. The sound does get a bit annoying after a bit. You did a really good job with the key collection puzzles, but I'd have liked to see some that were a bit more taxing on the puzzle end, instead of the action side. Overall it was pretty good.

So fun (and cute)! It's clear you put a lot of thought into level design - the challenge level was perfect, as well as the length of the game. Reminded me of old Windows puzzle games, Chip's Challenge, Kye, etc. :) Very nice. (Coincidentally, I was playing this at work. :P)

I was utterly annoyed by the teeny doorways. the character moves half a doorway with each step, so that if you aren't lined up perfectly with the doorway you can't align yourself to it. Ended up having to push against a nearby parallel surface every time I wanted to exit a room.

Purple dudes were aggravating beyond words, but otherwise this is pretty solid.  Rooms are well thought-out.  The fact keys don't reset when you die is the only thing that got me through it, though, thanks to the rebound shots just being infuriating.
Nice puzzle game. I like the look and sounds. Controls were annoying because you could get stuck on open doorways quite easily.

description:
Controls:
Arrows to move, Z to shoot, X to reload (uses 1 clip)
You wake up in a fortress in the middle of Russia, and must escape. Using a hidden pistol which uses completely different ammunition than everyone else's (I'm mean like that :D) you must travel through the maze. It's a system that allows for and rewards stealth killing. I didn't get any of the character sprites, or most of the tilesets that I wanted, done, but that's due to real life and procrastination getting in the way. I'm actually rather happy about this game, and plan on expanding it in the future.
author: Fenyx
title: Escape from the Wintry Fortress
comments: Nice little game. Took me two tries to win, mainly because the first time around I didn't realize my health came back. The game could benefit a lot from some variation in graphics (instead of the uniform white and brown) but on the other hand I liked the filtered effects and falling snow. The soundtrack, while pretty simplistic, was nice.
The narrow ways in which you can't see anyone make it unnecessary difficult.

A pity there's only one level. Btw. I could just pass by every guard without shooting up until the last one, which I gunned down. High walls make some enemies difficult to see. The game is unpolished, but not that bad, actually. Congrats!

description:
A little story game about a child being bullied.
Controls:
Arrow keys to move, X to jump and advance dialog during cutscenes
Tools Used:
Flixel
Bfxr
Musagi
GraphicsGale
...First ludum dare entry ever!!! I'm so proud of myself :o
Edit: Since there was still some time left in the jam submissions, I fixed some stuck bugs and hopefully a lag issue. Fingers crossed.
author: Klare
title: displaced
comments: This is great! And sweet and evil at the same time. Nice Work.
Also, the "eyes in the walls", followed by the "guy in the wall" are great :-)
Awesome graphics, especially effect-wise. I also like the content and simple-look approach. Story bits are cool and funny (the end is somewhat sad though). :D Game feels complete and polished.
Pretty swell.  Well made graphically, decent sound, overall pretty fun.  The gameplay isn't very explorative though.
haha nice easter egg at the beginning with the mum! That made me laugh out loud. Good minimalist style and solid platforming mechanics, well done
It was pretty entertaining up until I got stuck at one point.  Overall, pretty good!

I feel as though this game is the gem of this competition that is going to get outshone by the more popular/contemporary creations by the likes of Notch, for example. If you happen to stumble on this game out of the 500 or so submission, consider yourself lucky :)

Wow, excellent work with the theme. Definitely fits well. The game looked and sounded very well too, though I found I was having some pretty serious frame chopping. Maybe too many effects going at once.

Good work with such simple elements, the game does great job creating agonizing feeling towards the end, perfect for the theme. Great example of the fact that games can are very extensive form of expression.

I like a lot of the choices you made, like the implementation of the "health bar". The enemies looking just like the walls was a very cool choice. I felt like the mazes went on for too long with not enough variety to make it interesting. I wish I had gotten to jump on more heads.
Really nice, simple but with attention to details.
The blurring effect towards the end was very effective in conveying the character's feelings. I also liked the music.
I like the text that shows up when you, eg, jump on mom's head.  I got stuck, though, and couldn't continue, and I've never been fond of jumping puzzles.
A simple game, made wonderful by use of theme and mood.

description:
A physics-based platformer which does all it can to try and stop you escaping to safety.
Controls:
Left and Right arrow keys or A and D or Gamepad Joystick to move.
Esc to pause, change room and reset death count.
author: hayfield
title: Ballin' Basement
comments: Very impressive although I found it kind of hard!
Nice 3D but couldn't get very far - controls seem to be getting in the way.

Really well-done, you certainly put a lot more into 48 hours than most other people. I could only get so far as that part with the two mines, after the orange spinny thing. The bullets were weird to figure out at first, but then I got it and it was actually pretty cool. Good job.
Yeah I got to the part with the turret, pretty fun game.
Fun, but physics are a little weird. The ball is often go the the direction opposite of you would normally expect.
Physics feel awkward, but the idea is solid. I got to the part with two pointy things after the turret.
I agree with the other comments: very pretty, seems like a good concept, but is pretty much impossible because the controls don't make any sense. I couldn't beat the first level.

I too got stuck on the turret. One thing that might make it easier to see what's going on would be make some of the walls a bit thicker so you could see more of the conveyor belts and springs and things. Also music might be nice... the sounds get a bit tiring by themselves after awhile. But, great graphics, fun physics engine, interesting idea!
Good start, although like everybody else, it took me quite a while to get used to the physics and controls.
I couldn't really get used to the physics. It felt like everything was rotating around the center of the screen (rather than just gravity changing directions).
A pretty well made game otherwise. I wish there were no restrictions on the rotating angle throughout the game (like on the winning screen).
Thanks for all the comments so far.

It's supposed to be hard!  I do think, however, that it ended up a bit harder than it should have done - room 5 in particular is rather terribly balanced, while a couple of others are harder than I'd have liked to stop it being possible to pass through while simply rotating the world to a particular angle and leaving it there.

description:
A short platformer about a man who accidentally escapes from prison and has to find his way back and sneak into his own cell.
I used SunVox for all the music and sound, coded with AS3/FlashDevelop/Flixel and used DAME/Fireworks/GraphicsGale for the graphics and maps. Enjoy!
author: geckojsc
title: The Great Unescape
comments: Are you *kidding* me that's a difficult game :P
I liked how the enemy movements seemed timed to perfection for someone who didn't spend an unseemly amount of time making a jump :P The timing was good, my aim wasn't.

I had a slight difficulty with some of the colour choices. Most of the time there was a clear distinction between solid and not, but the bridge in the second level had me freaked for a moment (with no checkpoints I was being paranoid about touching stuff) among other things. Ignoring the palette, the feel of the graphics were quite delicious.

I'm hoping it was just my system, but the music seemed to mess up several times. I tried reloading the game but the invariance persisted. It's most notable right when the superhero teleports in. I don't know if this was intentional, but it also popped up in the second level's music at a late point of the track. Besides that little popup the tracks were actually delicious. Smooth, mellow; reminded me of a lot of music I heard from Cyrex in times past.
Nice minimalist graphics, all very slick but a bit hardcore. Could use some checkpoints...
Damn... I fell right on the first level... (By going to the left for lolz)
For a 15 yo kid, Not bad! Game is cool, music is cool, it is very polished. Could use checkpoints =) Also, I fell to oblivion on the first level, by moving straight left...

The no checkpoint system is a bit harsh for my taste, though. Mostly because some enemies seem to spawn at a random point, making it somewhat unpredictable. Playing the same level over and over again is somewhat tiring; I only played the first 2 levels.
But the great storyline, nice soundtrack (though with some hiccups), decent graphics - I agree with Tellus, the bridge was confusing - and fair gameplay all made this a definite five outa five.

Thanks for the feedback so far guys! I'm really not sure what's up with the music, I've played through several times and also tested with a Flash keyboard input app on an Android tablet, and I can't hear any audio hiccups. :S
Glad you're all enjoying it though, really encouraging!
Hey, you've got a great game here! Too bad it'*s too hard for me, the Checkpoint thing would be awesome. Sound problems here, too.
Very nice, but a little too hard without checkpoints.
BTW, I downloaded the source and compiled it myself, sounds is good there. Seems to be a browser thing. Perhaps you should add an index.html?
Okay, I put the game on a small web page now, and also created a standalone .exe version. I'm pretty sure the audio will work fine on the standalone download. :]
Nice game, I like the audio and graphics.
Normally I'm really into platformers but some choices you made got me grinding my teeth a little. Like all those blind drops into potential enemies and large collision boxes.

description:

author: MattRB
title: The Accidental Adventure of Jim
comments: The idea of playing a mini game in order to defeat an enemy is nice, but the game itself (Pong) is just too slow. Also, the ugly endboss(?) is unbeatable, more or less. Dunno, I stopped trying, sorry.
First I thought you have to escape the dungeon, but then the ugly guy said something about a princess, so I think you missed the theme. ;)
Fazit: It would have been nice if you had some more polish in it, it just feels incomplete as a whole. Which is said, because I like Dungeon Crawlers. :)
Hey, no I really didn't miss the theme, I just didn't finish the dialogue/story :P

My plan was to do 2 more levels after this one, and Jim the titular main character was to be a random convict, misinterpreted as a hero come to save the princess. He just wanted to escape from prison, but was forced into a role, I never quite got to express this, though :P

description:
Left and Right arrows to move. Space to Jump. Space to release from crane. Didn't have time to put in "restart key" so if you get stuck you'll have to restart the app.
Scratchy Get Out! is an arcade game where you "Scratchy" have to figure out how to escape from the room. I kind of molded it in after classic arcade games like Mario Bros.
I should point out this is as much a puzzle game as it is an arcade game. It is pretty tricky but it is solvable. You will definitely have to use your brain to escape the room. You have to pick up items, operate machinery, etc to win.
WARNING:
The feedback coming in is that the game is way too hard. The level that I managed to build would normally be like the last level of a 20 level game. It has everything thrown in it and I made it as hard as possible. If I had had more time I could have made the tutorial levels necessary to make it not so frustrating for players. The one thing I really screwed up on was running out of time before I could build more levels. I had this wonderful toolbox ready and I could have easily built more levels (especially easier ones) if I had just had time. Oh well, I learned a lot with stencyl so next time my progress will be better.
Due to people having so many issues with making progress, here is the walkthrough:
SPOILER*******************
Jump over the growlers and get a boulder. Climb the rope and jump on the cannon. The boulder should load into the cannon (if you aren't standing on top of the cannon). Then the cannon should fire the boulder into the crane. Drop the boulder on the blue rock by controlling the crane. the rock should break if you hit it. By the way, due to a bug, always wait at least 10 seconds after loading the crane before dropping a boulder. Ok, now you have a way to get back down and get more boulders. Keep doing so and reloading the cannon and try to kill off as many of the obstacles (knifers and growlers) that you think you need to to make it easy to get more boulders. Once you feel safe, start dropping the boulders on all of the things above the exit. Once you have cleared a path to the exit, then this time load a boulder but stay on top of the boulder. This might take a few tries (you have to be on the boulder just right). But then if done correctly the boulder should shoot you up into the crane and you will be stuck in it. Now move the crane over to where the exit is and release down. You have escaped!
END SPOILER ***********************************
Used stencyl to program and generate flash swf. Will post more details later. Posted on Kongregate.
I am continuing to develop this game. Already I have a version that adds a cool indiana jones boulder dodging level and fixes some of the annoying bugs. Right now I'm providing the new version as an SWF. The best way to play is to download the SWF file and play in fullscreen mode. This is smoother and makes it seem more like an arcade game. You can download the SwF here:
http://dl.dropbox.com/u/5866491/Scratchy%20Get%20Out%21.swf
There are two known bugs (that manage to make the game even harder, not easier of course):
1. the "getting high" bug (if you get this you have to reload the game).
2. the "crumbling boulder" bug (the workaround here is to wait 10 seconds after loading the crane with a boulder before releasing it).
Here is a video walkthrough that might help you finish the game:
http://dl.dropbox.com/u/5866491/BeatScratchy/BeatScratchy.mp4
author: sfernald
title: Scratchy Get Out!
comments: I just couldn't figure out this game, and I died like 20 times. I got as far as sticking a boulder in the cannon, but it just seemed to disappear and not show up again. Maybe the game should clue you in if it notices you've died a lot or something. :)
Yeah, it's a little tricky. I would have put in some easy levels, but I ran out of time of course.
When you put the boulder in th cannon, it should shot into the crane. Then go from there.
Btw, the "crumbling boulder" issue can be avoid it you wait more than six seconds to release th boulder. Wait like 10 to be safe.
btw, don't be dismayed by dying in this game. You were meant to die maybe 200 times before solving the level.

Game based on continous dying and trying to touch this or that   and hoping it would do something isn't very intriguing. I gave up after few minutes (would gave up sooner, but I've read in comments what I'm supposed to do. In the end I managed to get up with the rock... and nothing happened
If you jump on the cannon thing below the crane, it should load the rock. The rock then should fire automatically out of the cannon. You should hear a sound too to confirm you did something correct.
Don't like games based on dying? That was the whole 80s man. I must be getting old. Sigh.
Ok, walkthrough added. I'm sorry I overlooked difficulty guys. Next time I will be more aware of it.
This seems like a good start, but as others have pointed out, it's too challenging, half from lack of direction and half from bugs.
Also, I don't know whether this is in your control, but I'd be willing to bet that a lot of people hit the "back" button when they saw the ad at the beginning of the game.

What ad? I never see ads? Hmm, maybe I need to stop using kongregate. I just use it to to get extra feedback. I don't make any money off this junk. I usually remove the games from congregate after a couple months anyway.
I think I'll reconsider using kongregate in the future. It's annoying cause fullscrren doesn't work Iin google chrome for me anyway.
Unplayable it it's current state due to issues others have mentioned. Good job making something for LD, I hope you take everyone's feedback to help focus on key principles in game design.
It's hard but not unplayable. Lots of people have beat it. The only bug that that I know of that hinders winning is that you have to wait 10 seconds before dropping a rock.
I'll do a video walkthrough to show how easy it actually is.
Ok, I've made a video walkthrough that should help:

description: RUN! RUN FROM THE VOID! ESCAPE SQUAREWORLD! GO!
author: lectvs
title: Roundman: Escape from Squareworld
comments: I like this game a lot (it is similar to my entry :) ), but I see many things that could be improved rather easily.
The movement feels too slippery, some air friction would help a lot when making precise jumps. As it is, you need to press the other direction to slow down, which is hard and somewhat frustrating.
The animations of the characters, and the way the tiles are sucked into the void are really nice. The music is pretty awesome too. There are a nice amount of enemies and the color powers are cool.

It would be nice to see more of what's in front of you, by having the camera more to the right, but since the "void" is stuck to the left side of the screen, that would make less room for error as you would be closer to it. One option would be to make it move independent of the camera, but that could make it less clear where it is, and if you are in danger. This was a problem for my game aswell.
I don't see why you couldn't have used the arrow keys for movement. A and D are a lot more akward, and might not work on all keyboard setups.
Lovely game! If this had online highscores, it would increase the replay value immensely... Nice work!

@Danik I'll add arrow key support and mess around with air friction. However, with the way we coded the level (including the void) it would be a lot of rewriting and experimenting for something that probably wouldn't work. The game would get easy if you could just outrun the void. We ran into that problem as well, so we settled on that so we'd have enough room for error, while not being able to see a lot of the upcoming level provides a bit more challenge.
Anyway, thanks for the nice comment and some constructive criticism, I'll definitely play around with the gameplay to see what works best!
Well, the game had floaty controls which made the basic running frustrating. However everything else was great I loved the color powerups, the musc and animations.
The controls were way too slippery for my taste. They were also awkward using the A & D keys. The bricks never gave me a power up.
You have something but it needs a lot of polish.
@wally2069 What do you mean by "slippery"? And the bricks aren't supposed to give you powerups, the colored ones are.
Crashes at intro. Win7 x64, I should have usual redistributables.
@Rudy Due to a bug that's been fixed after the compo, you must have an audio device plugged in.

I am not sure what you mean by "plugged in". Windows has to detect a plugged in audio input at some specific place? I'm with headphones "plugged in". Also I think you can update the file with game-crashing bugs like this post-compo. I tried misc device combinations to no avail.
@Rudy I'm not sure if I can update the actual compo entry, but you can get the most recent version (includes the audio fix and arrow key support) at http://vectorzero.net/ld48/roundman

This is fun, but I also found the controls rather slippery... I wish there was a bit more feedback upon killing a monster/hitting a block that I was gaining more score. A more defining "ting" or a pointvalue floating out of them or something.

description:
You're the amazing Perdigod, and must guide your people, the Perdiganawe tribe, to safety, before the raining season begins .
Why's the raining season so dangerous? well... it rains comets.
In order to escape certain death, every year the Perdiganawe must have a ritualistic peregrination to the Nose Totem, wich will protect them from the mighty rain.
Objectives :
- Get to a safe point with the minimum amount of Perdiganawes to finish the mission.
- If the Apocalipse bar is depleted ( top-most of the screen ) , the rain begins. you still have a chance to get to the end, but watch out for the comets!
Tips :
- Lots of things can be dangerous, even Bridges!
- Never get too close to the predator.
- Sometimes you just have to face dangers instead of avoiding them.
Controls :
In a Warcraft / Starcraft Style control, you may select your units by clicking and dragging a selection box over them.
Once selected, Right-Click will make them go to the appointed location.
Arrow Keys move the camera.
That's it! hope you enjoy!!
* The thiers brothers *

title: Perdiganawe

thanks a lot ! I recorded those with a friend of mine, was really fun to make xD

simple but fun :) I would have liked some quick indication of where the bullets were coming from at the top of the screen, just to aid dodging

Solid little game. It was tough at times, but with some more polish and finish, you could have a cool game there.

description:

Made with Flixel, Pixelmator & my voice.
author: qrunchmonkey
title: Henchmen, Attack!
comments: nice take on the runner-genre. The title is great, as is "League of Malevolence"
Also, do I spot traces of flixel and the canabalt-sourcecode? :-)
I found the sounds quite charming. Interesting take on a Canabalt type game. Perhaps it could either be a bit faster or have some sort of store based upgrade system between rounds.
Yes, I used the Flixel engine (I even said that in the description) but there's no trace of the Canabalt source in there - I don't believe the the flash version open source, is it?
(Though I will admit I took a peak at canabalt-ios to see how they did the gradual acceleration, and then did it in a similar way.)
I guess it's just Flixel then (the similar font and placement of icons convinced me).
And the code of Canabalt is actually now open source (which is great), but not the art assets of it.
I like the take on the runner genre you've gone for with this game. Reminds me of Cannabalt, and I love that game :D

description:
El Dorado wasn't anything like what the brochures made you believe. For one thing it was packed with native americans that didn't appreciate a settler walking in from nowhere.
Fuck El Dorado! Let's get the hell outta here!!1
Arrows to move left/right. Space to jump.
Avoid the spears. Have fun!
Written in around 15 hours. No Native Americans were harmed during the making of this game.
Edit: You cannot win, because that's how things roll in El Dorado!
author: deps
title: Fuck El Dorado! Let's get the hell outta here!!1
comments: you and your fancy three-dimensional computer graphics .. I'll play this later ;).
awesome graphics, way to continue a series of games. Love the little messages at the bottom of the screen as well.
Nice to see 3D, though very odd looking ground vs objects in this. Game play is good and funny :)

Very simple, but very good nonetheless. Good looking graphics, though I have to ask, why was everything floating above the ground? Gave it an odd look. Also, I don't know if there was a win condition or not, I never got to it. Would have been nice to indicate that.
The ground doesn't really moves, just the texture. :) It was late, I was in a hurry. Let's just pretend that you're driving so fast that it's an optical illusion. ;)
Oh, and the only end is when you die. Time ran out...
No, unless you count burning to a crisp as winning... But that's how they roll in El Dorado! ;)
Loved the Oregon Trail style text that came up when you got hit. Especially, "Your grandma fell off" and "You are about to die from corrugated ankles." LOL!

Not bad for few hours, but in the end it's just a simple dodging (in 3d, but with unity it's not that hard, with flying boulders and cacti and funny donkey/horse/something.) About the only thing I liked were the funny messages when you got hit, so you're going to be one of the few games I rated with some humor :)

description:
This one didn't go quite as planned, took forever to come up with an idea. I also cut most of the stuff I actually spent lots of time on, since the gameplay wound up too complex. So it's pretty sparse, and very buggy, but whatever... it's playable-ish.
Goal:
Outrun (escape) the disintegrating level behind you.
Jump, duck, and rotate gravity to get through the obstacles.
You'll gain speed the longer you run without hitting obstacles. Also note that crouching for longer than a moment will slow you down as well.
The green/grey rectangles at the bottom of the screen represent your speed.
Controls:
Mouse: look
Left click: jump
Right click: crouch
A: Rotate gravity left
D: Rotate gravity right
ESC: Exit
NOTE: You may need to install the Visual Studio 10 redist.
author: Riley Adams
title: Fragmentation
comments: Wow, des level is quite cool.

Alas, I think this game has "feature-overload". It's not only first-person mouse-controlled, but also a runner-game, and has the gravity-switch-feature. Together with the 3-sec introduction (during which you can' move or do anything) the first plays are very confusing.

I found this game most fun before I realized you could use the mouse as well. Once you start combining them it becomes mentally awkward and hard to work out obvious solutions. When you just use the keys there are simple patterns you can use to solve most situations.
Would have given more on "Overall" if I wouldn't fall out of the level at the end ... looks broken, sorry.
I thought this was a lot of fun, maybe would have been better without jump and duck, to make the most of the gravity shifting.

I thought the level deconstructing itself was very cool, but there are too many different control schemes and the idea get boring very quickly. I feel like it would have been much more interesting if you kept the level falling apart idea, but turned it into an exploration game instead.
Wow. This is awesome. Only problem is that there are lots of glitches- I repeatedly lost by falling through the ground.

I liked the aesthetic, and as the game went on the controls and switching and etc became more useful. Once I got the rhythm it was kind of straightforward. Nicely functional, if a little repetitive. Also, the visual feedback of the world collapsing, though neat, didn't really give you any warning or chance to get back your speed/evade or etc.
Neat, and nice graphics, but a few little problems that could be ironed out.
Very nice idea, congratz. Music's too repetetive and i could use some more challenges, but as a simple AND quite original concept game you've suceeded very well.

I didn't think the controls were overly complex - I got to grips with them pretty much straight away. Also, I assumed the whole "falling out of the level" thing was a feature meaning the destruction had caught up with you.. maybe I'm wrong!
Anyway I thought it was pretty awesome and once you get a high speed going its pretty intense!

description: In most RPGs, you are encouraged to fight every enemy, but in this one, you are encouraged to run away instead! Guide Scrawny, an untrained treasure hunter, out of Strong Castle while running away frrom the monsters surrounding this 20-floor stronghold.
author: jcenterprises
title: Escape from Strong Castle
comments: I played through some floors, but the black and white grid was killing me. It didn't have sufficient chests and the speed of the hero was rather slow. A good idea but not good implemented.
I can't say much about the game, but I like the concept of an adventurer's only option is cowardice.

The idea of coward running from fight could be interesting, but I just couldn't stand more then few minutes of eyesearing black and white grid with totaly monotonous music with gameplay consisting mostly of hoping that I'll escape from the fight quickly enough without getting hit...
Very impressive RPG engine for a 48-hour competition, but holding escape whenever going into a battle wasn't the most fun, unfortunately.
My suggestion is to take the RPG engine and go make something bigger and better :)
The idea seemed interesting at first, but the floors were large and uneventful other than occasional 'fights'. This can be further explored to make a more complex game.

description: Made with Unity 3d, MonoDevelop, Blender, Gimp, and Audacity. The only thing that wasn't standard assets in unity or made by me was http://unity3d.com/support/documentation/ScriptReference/CharacterController.OnControllerColliderHit.html added onto the standard FPS controller.  Also this is my first attempt at Ludum Dare, had a lot of fun and learned a lot in a short time.  Changed the download links to mediafire, because I did not realize how much traffic this would get (3GBs of bandwidth used in two days! wow! I'm surprised in a good way!), the web version is still on my site though, and all versions have not been updated in any way.
author: AndyBrown
title: Escape from the Labyrinth
comments: With some better art, it could have been much more scary, but even at that state, it's really creepy, the guy popping up behind you is cool, but his design is just funny, that too bad
Love the thing behind you. Even when you know it's there and you keep seeing him, it still spooks you. Reckon on creepy music would ramp up the fear too...
Didn't realize the thing was behind me on my first play, super creepy when I saw it! Couldn't find the exit, needs balancing. I also made an imperfect creepy Unity game, by the way!
Would work much much better with some sound and a better sense of space.  As it was, I felt like I was lost the entire time, which meant I wasn't really engaged in the game.  Better luck next time :)
There is some sound.... breathing sounds from the monster and the torches make noise. I really should have implemented footstep sound though - and some other environmental sounds.

@mpc174 I'll have to check out your game too! Hum, the exit can be a bit hard to find, but it is there in each game... although it is easy to lose your bearings since there isn't much variation in the maze.
@Jasper Stocker Thanks, I have no experience with making music, but well placed music could definitely help with the mood of things.
@astrkl I'm not all that good at 3d modeling, or texturing, so it was the best I could do in the time I had, thanks though =)
I got captured, But it is pretty awesome :)

I had no idea anything was following me at all.  After exploring for like 5 minutes and finding a creepy picture, I just got a "you were captured" message. Kind of a bummer way to end after all that work. I didn't really know how to find the exit other than the standard follow-a-wall maze navigation.
Heh, liked that creeping guy, does have some atmosphere.

@lilserf sorry about that, a lot of people ended up not seeing him because of turning slowly - not checking their backs etc. If you don't have your sound up a bit to hear the breathing I guess there's no real way to tell that he's behind you, staring into your soul.  And yeah, sometimes finding the exit can be a rather hard.. as the mazes are random each time, sometimes it's really easy though =)
Creepy, nice work. I managed to escape! :)

This was pretty creepy actually. I was hoping for something more from the ending, but roaming the labyrinth had a cool creepy mood to it, although I guess there was no real threat there. I even found the portrait of the monster, but I didn't really understand the significance of that.

@pekuja Thanks! The portrait gives you extra time when you get close enough to it, 50 more seconds of the monster staring into your soul before it can capture you, but yes, there is no way for players to know that... I wasn't sure what to do to about that when making the game, it was actually one of the last minute things to get put into the game.
Nice atmosphere, but not a lot to do. I tried to spot the creepy guy other commenters mention, but couldn't see more than a brief 1-frame flash. I suspect my framerate may be too high?
Nice atmosphere for a while(thanks to the creepy breathing sound mostly), but in the end it's just a simple maze
I really like the scary Joe guy following you.
I've played Penumbra, and nothing scared me more than the guy popping up behind me...

description: Escape from Shimishland! (Instructions in Game)
author: CaptainLepidus
title: Escape from Shimishland

The text instructions were helpful but not very immersive.

We had planned for a story to be told with the text instructions, but again, we ran out of time.
I really liked the part where I ran over the enemies with the car - that was fun ^^

title: Escape from Room 32

description:
My first time trying this, I created a simple "chase to the border" game.  The objective is to make it to the edge of the map.
I used xna game studio 4, paint.net, and sfxr.  3D objects were created by just typing out the coordinates in code as they are all simple primitives.  Terrain is random seed based so each level is the same.
I took one peek at some old code for camera axis vector extraction, but other than that it was all done on the fly.
Plays well on netbooks, and controls with either keyboard or 360 gamepad.
REQUIREMENTS:
Windows XP, Windows Vista, or Windows 7
XNA Framework Redist:  http://www.microsoft.com/download/en/details.aspx?id=20914
.NET Framework 4.0 Redist:  http://www.microsoft.com/download/en/details.aspx?id=17851
author: Kharza
title: Escape from Cube Mountain
comments: The first level is so confusing, info about powerup could help, but i enjoy it, the game is more and more challenging, nice start.I played with keyboard too lazy to get my joypad.
Really cool. I could see it having some kind of cyberpunk 'Running Man' vibe if you expanded on it.
Could use some more obstacles or higher/lower terrain variations. I was surprised by how the sound makes those cubes so menacing.
It was frequently very to difficult to see myself as a cube would pop up from behind me and due to its size over shadow the player making it hard to see where I am going next.
Also the sound did make the cubes scarier than imaginable.
Loved the sound - really creepy. The map is pretty bland, a bit more variety there could make a real improvement.

Thanks for playing!  I had done some fractal terrain that is much better in the past, but I couldn't remember exactly how I did it, so I went with just randomized heights and 2 smoothing passes.  They vary per level, but are somewhat similar.  I had to be sure things weren't too steep so the camera didn't drift into the ground.
The sound makes this very creepy! Nice gameplay too, I was constantly escaping at the last second. Appreciated the XBox controller support.
I moved last weekend and shut off my net service.  Let me know if the links go bad and I'll try to move it elsewhere.  And thanks for the feedback!

description:
Version 1.0
Escape Flight Z-1387
Instructions:
Because airport security focused too much on checking bearded guys you are now trapped on a flight that is infested by the walking undead. Try to find a parachute and escape the plane!
Controls:
Cursor keys to walk
Left Mouse: attack
Right Mouse: throw item
-> Punch seats to detach them from the plane
-> Pick up stuff with your arm
Hints:
- Throwing stuff might be more effective than punching
- There might be some hidden items in bags
- The boss doesn't get along with cats very well...
Game by:
Clemens S
Clemens P
Julia S
Martin F
Michael F
Made for Ludum Dare 21
http://ludumdare.com/compo/
(Sorry for the big file - the intro movie took up way too much space because we couldn't get it to play an avi file without problems...)
title: Escape Flight Z
comments: I love the music! And the humor!

69Mb, voa! Very nice game, I see quite a lot of work went into this. Love the intro with check-in bags! Collision detection is very buggy. Nice sound effects. Boss fight was sort of creative, but a bit unguided without the hint.
Not to bad, but the collisions are unpleasant :\
Music is quite good anyway and I love the scenario =)
The death music piece made me chuckle.

description:
Short, pixely, and a little bit rushed, ESCAPE is a first-person point-and-click adventure game made entirely by me!
Sorry about the no sound deal. I'm not an audio guy : /
author: TerryDiF
title: ESCAPE
comments: Short but very fun.  As a Myst fan, I cant help but love this kind of game though.  Particularly love the graphical style too.
Amazing. This it really great in almost every way. All that is missing is some nice music and sound.
This one was tricky but cool. Sometimes the short distance for hotspotting objects faked me out(e.g. the lower drawer, the rug).
really cool so far... but I'm stuck at the mask ... dont really wanna try all combinations to find the right one... maybe I missed a hint somewhere

Usually I end up getting stuck on these kinds of games for 10 minutes and then quitting out of boredom. But that wasn't the case with this one. I find storylines help tremendously to make these kinds of games more interesting, but there was none in your game. Also, if you beat it and play it again, your inventory is not cleared. But overall, good graphics and it fit the theme.
Very cool! Missing music though. FYI, moving the invisible mouse off-screen causes it to defocus the game if I click "off screen" on multiple monitors (or while windowed).
Done!  I had trouble understanding how to read the arrows on the floor, but finally did! :-)

description:
Bug workaround
============
- If the screen is mostly black and you can only see small dots, simply wave your mouse cursor over the game and things will go back to normal. The bug is easy to fix but it went unnoticed until the deadline =(
- If you want to play an updated version with a few bugs squashed and the possibility to jump using the space key rather than the up arrow key, go here : http://www.bashecn.org/tmp/LD21/updated/ (DO NOT PLAY THIS VERSION FOR RATING)
Goodies
======
Soundtrack download : http://www.bashecn.org/tmp/LD21/Ernest%20the%20Plump%20Adventurer%20(in%20trouble)%20OST.zip
About the source
============
The source includes the current version of my personal framework (Bacchus). It's not ready for public release yet so if I were you I would not try using it.
Resources and tools I used
===================
HaXe
Bacchus Framework
FlashDevelop
Adobe Photoshop
Propellerhead's Reason
Lame Encoder
BFXR
Fonts MinstrelPosterWHG and 04b11
George Kilian's Irish Red (lots of it)
Special thanks to
============
The Ludum Dare staff and IRC Channel
Remy 'Sieben' Leone
Ernest Adams
author: agersant
title: Ernest the Plump Adventurer (in trouble)
comments: A solid entry. I feel the game's death penalty was just a little too punishing. It felt like slow super meat boy, only If I fell I had to watch a slow death. Areas like the balloon bonus round really showed the potential, but the majority of the game was just shy of that.
Still, good contender for some awards.
I didn't see the reason for every jump needing to be a double jump, but other than that it was a fun play, and I loved the music.

fantastic game, really fun and I loved the art! very stylish :). I got stuck on level 14 tho, after 6 tries I ended up giving up, sorry :/. There seems to be a jump which requires a leap of faith and missing it is instakill. At first I was really pleased to see the water was not instant death, and you could recover- however more and more in the later levels  it does become instant death. I love that you even coded a bonus level!
Solid game. I was having some slowdowns sometimes which made me fall from the moving ledges. Besides that, awesome music and graphics.
Great little platformer. Wonderful art, nice soundtrack, fun gameplay!
Really mature game. This should get some postcompo improvement love.
A polished hardcore platformer, just my type. LOVED the pixels and the music. Very well done !

Lovely pixelart and music ! Solid gameplay and nice level design too, interesting assets combination and presentation ("deceptively easy" ? eh :p) albeit quite hard  sometimes (damn level 8) but that's the oldschool charm :)
Plus, kudos for managing to pull everything off on your own in only 48h !
I love the level names. So far this is the most humerous entry I have played.
Controls were a bit unforgiving and I was often annoyed by the inability to jump onto a platform from directly below it. Just didn't feel right.
Water rising is a nice idea, makes for some nice challenges if you want to collect everything.
I liked the theme and the audio, but the gameplay mechanics could be a little more balanced. I had a lot of fun escaping the water, though :)

Cute. Pretty pictures and rather good sound. Like bmfs, I had issues on level 7 where the game stuttered for a moment and I just fell right through a vertical elevator. Guessing that you have some kind of variation timestep thing going? I'd recommend fixed timesteps to avoid such issues, and make things easier in general.

The jumping was a bit uncomfortable sometimes, maybe because of a too rapid crest in the arc. Stumbling with the buttons a moment will ruin a critical jump where you need all the height you can get. Should be more forgiving if there's a longer hover phase before falling again.

Actually, trying it again now I think it's more to do with the input keys used. It's very hard to double-tap up while at the same time tapping left or right to adjust your sideways movement. Jumping on Z should be more smooth since you will use both hands.

Another issue I found is that leaving the mouse pointer outside the applet will cause strange issues. Particularly when starting a level. I got a situation where I only saw single pixels spread out in a grid since the diamond wipe hadn't completed.
*Thank you* all for the precious feedback. The compliments make me feel warm and fuzzy =)

Valid point. I guess I implemented double jump because I like providing players with more possibilities to get immediate feedback following input. I should have made a better use of it in the level design and maybe save it for the later levels.
Don't worry, there were only 15 of them (+ the ending screen) so you did not miss much. I love Stratus by the way !
I wholeheartedly agree with your analysis of the jumping mechanic problem, thanks a lot for helping me putting words on it.

The collision bugs are much more fun than a timestep problem, the issue is that the moving platforms were coded using a display hack of my framework, and they're not actually moving in the game's world. This is what lead to issues for collision detection with them. Sorry about that.

description:
For some reason, you are in cyperspace. And things want you dead - get out fast. The faster the better, and mind that data!
RACE ON - Moving is just as hard as memory management. In ASM8086 ahaha... You'll see.
In empty-space - there are no gravities.
In cyber-space - there are no environmental physics.
In space - no one can hear you go WTF IS THIIISSS???? (A great movie)
Controls:  Arrow keys.
Bugs 96, 27, 110, 110 and 111 are still present resulting in weird behaviour when using the '`' key, 'esc' key, level lodaing, death / winning and audio respectively...
author: code_glitch
title: Cyperspace...
comments: I have the same problem as GigaClon on Windows XP.  At first, the game refused to even run and Windows was telling me I had not enough virtual memory, until I set its size to ~1GiB (I run Windows in a virtual machine with 768MiB of RAM).
Once the game run, it showed a white screen during a brief moment and then crashed with the following output on the console:
I've tried to move the folder to a path without spaces, with the same result.
I also tried to run the Linux version, but it seems that it uses libpng14 *and* libpng12.  I only have libpng14 installed on my system, so I couldn't test on neither platform.
Can't run it, can't rate it :'(
Darn, this is recurring. I'll re-upload this since it seems to me that the memory management bug is not fixed after all...

OK, I've downgraded the Prometheus Engine that seemed to be causing the crash and all seems better despite slower performance. It may freeze a bit at the start just dont overload it with clicks/button presses and I hope it works better now. Tested on windows 7 x64, Ubuntu 10.10 x64, Ubuntu 11.04 x64.
Its the same engine as my last entry so if that ran, so will this.
Seems I cannot edit, links are:
OK, contingency: I renamed the files so the initial links will work. Sorry for the fiasco - the engine I was hoping to use was a little bit rushed...
Still crashed. Something about "0,3" not being a float.
Can't run your game. No source code so I could build, and/or no Linux 32 bit build that I could run =X Can't play, can't rate.
foobaz: I take it you are one a linux system. I'll re-check again. This is a hassle... Fixed for 5:45 GMT

foobaz: what OS are you on? This could only occur if using the Win32 Data on a linux build or possibly an older version of windows. During development I got an error on windows that '0.3' was invalid and I had to use '0,3' while the opposite for linux.
N0_Named_Guy: All the packages contain source code - it is there, under the sub folder should be a LD21.pas file which can be built with FPC.

description:
*** DON'T READ COMMENTS! Until you've played the game! Thanks!  ***
Instructions inside the game. Please play before reading comments in case of spoilers. Thanks and good luck!
author: johanp
title: BATHOS
comments: I can't find the solution, I need a hint !
I had a nice little method of sorting the keys. As I would try one. I would throw it in a pile of used key. I finally found the right one :D
I did that, but I thought eventually, there was another way :/
Not working: you have typed <embed src="ld20.swf" width="640" height="480"> instead of <embed src="ld21.swf" width="640" height="480"> :]
Whoops! Thanks for spotting that. How could it ever work? Fixed now.
Also, thanks to all for not spoiling! :D

That was amusing, and very well made. I think I suspected what I was supposed to do after the third key I tried, but for some reason I felt the need to try all the keys anyway. I don't know why. This was clever, polished, and a bit funny, although it was really short, even for a ludum dare game.
I would have liked to examine your pixelling more closely, but the graphics weren't in the source.
Source updated! Pixels ready for examination.

That was absolutely amazing! When I got the solution I smiled so much :D I don't want to post a spoiler but, your game really managed to evoke an emotion that many big games can't even do. You made me feel smart for thinking outside of the box. Loved it!
Very fun game! Got agitating at first, I was ready to quit. Thinking it was a standard game I just pressed Esc, and I escaped. Neat game.
Excellent game! Nice idea, nice graphics, nice music...and very funny!
I've made a french review about it : http://oujevipo.fr/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=476:bathos&catid=36:10-minutes&Itemid=55
It's the puzzle everyone talked about doing, but it was done well :)
Very clever indeed! The solution was non obvious and those keys sure kept me busy.
This is one of my favorites!
Fantastic!  Can I vote for you for president?
Why can't I give you more than 5 stars for "Theme"? You deserve ALL OF THE STARS!
I came SO close to ragequitting without figuring it out
Oh god I can't stop laughing
For those of you that just don't find the solution :
This was frustrating, in a good way. Yesterday i rage quited, but today I thought THIS CANNOT BEAT ME!!! and now i feel so smart!!
(gotta check that wolfram tones thing, i've always had issues to create ambient music, and yours is awesome)
I love the juxtaposition between the different kind of /keys/, hah.

Haha this is the second game I've played this competition that used the rage quit mechanic. I can't believe having played that one a few days ago that I didn't think to try it on this one, damn! I literally tried every single key methodically and just when I had hit every key... I thought,  "no, not another one..." and I knew even before I hit it that it would work.  Freedom.  I feel like a fool.  Very well done and entertaining.
Hahaha. Took me longer than i'm comfortable saying to figure it out. :D  Enjoyable!  I'd love a full game of puzzles like this in this style!
Nice art, loved the music and liked the concept of a not-so-obvious solution (although once you find it, it's kinda disappointing).
You can't avoid feeling like you wasted your time once you manage to escape though. I didn't like that part. An overall good entry nonetheless.
The solution was spoiled for me, but I still enjoyed it somewhat.
Very nice art!  I also just loved the keys that kept falling, of all shapes and sizes (wrench, credit card, knife..).  One of my favourite games this LD, very ingenious take on the theme. :)
Seriously, you need to make a full-length adventure game!

Upset that it was spoiled for me. :( I was really giving it my all, though... even had the keys that looked like 'E', 'S', and 'C' separated from the rest, trying to somehow merge them  into some super-key by shoving all three into the door. Yeah, I probably wouldn't have ever figured it out . :)
Haha, got it. This is that one game this compo must have. You should've added more levels, though, right now it's just a novelty thing rather than a proper game.
Great game! Very emotional! I love the use of low life! Real smart!
Wow! Thanks for all the encouraging comments, I'm really happy that so many enjoyed it. For those who didn't, there's a reason it is called Bathos. :)
Great game, figured out the right key! :)
Very enjoyable, mainly the way the keys multiply.
Had to be done, and I'm glad you're the one who did it - that was awesome.
Great game! When I finally realised which was the right key, the brilliance baffled me.
At first at felt bad at being trolled, and then I was happy and smiled.  Thank you for this.
This actually isn't the first game I've played here that did this, so I figured it out quickly.
I want to give this a lower score but cannot justify it. This gimmick has been done in at least two other entries so far.
That being said, this game is so full of red herrings that it gets the innovation points from there. Nice work.
I appreciated the (fairly) subtle clues :) a few games have used this idea, but this if far and away the best I've seen this compo. Great work!

I kinda think you should not have included a web version, since rage quitting means just closing the browser! I admit at first I really did not like this game because I felt like it was a case of designer mocking player, but since then I've thought about it more and it's clever enough to win me back around :). great art and music too

Nice, very nice. Art is great, music is lovely, the solution is... outside the box. I suppose the more patience you have, the longer it takes :P Not that I didn't expect a lot of escape "key" puns, this one was well done.
Very nice and polished little game.

The solution is also very clever, but was really hard for me to find. I think you should make even more obvious clues when you have tried all the keys, so that people like me won't get so frustrated. :P

Lots of cute for so little a game. I did solve it, thankfully, but only after trying all the pixel keys. I wonder if you could easily do a larger moody puzzle with this atmosphere/music/art style and a series of (perhaps interconnected) screens with some more curious tasks that the player needs to find/figure out? It's both strangely relaxing and frustrating to know that you're staring at "all of it" and still can't quite find the solution.
You are a cruel cruel person.
Best use of this trick I've seen. I figured it out when I saw the credit card key... maybe I was beginning to think it anyway. :D
What really sets this one above some of the other similar games is that there's something very meaningful to do while puzzling out the solution.

description:
Arena Escape is a fun arcade like zombie mashup game! With of course a escape theme to it! The trick to winning, to break the barrier and run into the portal before you are mashed up by zombies. Sounds easy right? well it's not. You have your trusty gun and grenade combo plus your wits and not to mention a few boxes you could push around to help you out!
There are three modes and two surprises!
Easy
Regular
Suicide
Sorry if there's a few bugs... didn't have time to iron them out.
Have Fun!
author: ZiAzon
title: Arena Escape
comments: I think you really need to make ammo drops more frequent for it to be fun, and i sometimes got stuck to a zombie which was irritating.
Worst part was closing it though! Had to use task manager to shut the program down.
Would have loved a full auto option, my clicking finger is so tired :)
This was hard, even on easy mode.  Nice graphics and a good concept, would like to see it developed further.
Decently done, but needs polish. Got stuck in a box. The game is not really central to the theme.
I'm getting a 404 when I try to download it.

Playing on regular, after a while zombies started coming verrrry infrequently, so I used up all my ammo no the barrier, but no more ammo seemed to be coming. I stood by the barrier and eventually the explodey ones broke it for me. So it started out allright but it doesn't seem like it really went the way you intended.

description:
This is in some ways a 2d de-make of a 3d game idea that I'll probably never get round to actually making.
It's relatively typical flash platformer fare. However the antagonist is far away from typical anything, and it's coming to get you!
wsad or arrow keys to move, space or z to jump if that's more comfy for you.  Hope you enjoy it :-)
Special prize to whoever manages to complete it sub 3 minute run without dying?
author: Jonathan Whiting
title: Antagonist
comments: Fun but the jump feels a little stunted. Nice chase game.
This game is great! Graphics are amazing. I thought there was no hope for survival at the end, but I was wrong :p Awesome job.
I died at the end because I jumped to avoid the disappearing ground and this slowed me down too much :(
Pretty fun, but I'm not sure if I like the slowing down after landing.
I really liked how the ending played out, and I particularly enjoyed a lot of the level elements too.
As others have said, the sudden pause when you've jumped is REALLY annoying. Other than that, it's very cool.
Very hard for me, I kept getting trapped because of those spawners! Still looks like a good game. Graphics are pretty cool too; some good colours you use there.
My biggest annoyance is jumping. For it's too slow, and too low.
I got stuck somewhere before the end, but I enjoyed what I played.  Love the art style and soundtrack.

I also completely disagree with everybody else when it comes to the jumping -- I actually really liked the fact that the character had to recover before jumping again.  Too often characters have springs for legs.

Excellent! Difficulty was just right - I liked the parts where you had to backtrack a bit to progress. I also actually kind of liked the slow-down upon landing a jump - it made quickly jumping over multiple pits more manageable and "realistic".
Very cool concept! Running game with puzzle. It reminds me of the movies where the hero is outnumbered and being chase by the enemies, and he tricked and mislead the enemies.
Great music & sounds too. But, the antagonist teleport sfx is too painful for the ears. Did you do the music yourself?
Jerm:  Oh, wow, that's quite a time.  Have a couple of ideas for your prize, but need a little time to prep it.  Hope you don't mind the wait.

heck: Of course I made the music myself!  Spent a few hours on Saturday evening pulling something together in FL Studio.  I'm ever so glad you liked it, music is traditionally my weak spot.  That panicked but cunning chase seen feel is definitely something I was trying for.

Generally:  Thanks everyone for the kind words.  So happy you're enjoying it.  Also, yeah, it's not an empowering kind of jump, but for better or worse it was an intentional design decision; I wanted any progress to feel like it came from cunning, not intrinsic power.
Clever! I hope you make the 3D version one day...
Wonderful work on the balancing and level-design side. The difficulty feels almost every time "just right".

description:
This is easily my weakest attempt in LD so far. I spent too much time thinking of the idea and implementing stuff I didn't need!
Use mouse to aim and shoot and use items, and WSAD to move. You can scroll through the items with the mouse wheel or number buttons. Use E to drop an item, though you really don't need that function.
author: Hempuli
title: Bountyhunted!
comments: I think you are being too hard on yourself. It's charming and I enjoy the bullet duels.
It seems a little odd to explain the controls, while on a screen using different controls.
As the others commented, you're far too hard on yourself, dude.
This is an excellent entry by my count. Everything falls together in a beautiful well-playing package.
Only thing missing is a sweet, guitar-and-harmonica-heavy music track ;)
I caught the bad guy! This was actually a very fun little game, made me smile. :)

The beginning confused me a little, I actually thought I was supposed to use wasd to control the little dot and shoot. Other than that, no complaints. I like the style and the controls were good: for once aiming didn't cause any trouble. I wouldn't have minded playing a few more stages.
Not that bad... got confused by the first screen, but otherwise it's quite good... (if you think you suck, go rate few entries and you'll feel much better :)
I love your sound effects, simple, yet lovely.
This one was a great submission, maybe not as addicting as the Island theme one, but it is still a great submission nonetheless.
Reminded me of a lesser known indie game by dustingunn which I loved - Sombrero's. Utterly charming and would benefit hugely from some nice western tunes. Great work.
although the graphics were a little too small (maybe i am blind though) it was a neat little game. not a bad job!
One bug report: the wasd keys often get stuck in one direction and you have to tap them to unstick it.

description:
First ever Ludum Dare...Sparkles!!
Html and javascript
Aptana, Gimp, and Firefox for development
Use ADSW and arrow keys...bats have a slow down effect
Using arrow keys allow u to destroy blocks
Seems to work better in Firefox than Chrome
May take a sec to load
author: bcoxie
title: Ninja Princess
comments: Couldn't figure out how to play this one. The princess would jump, just not high enough to avoid anything. Original concept, though! :)
I quickly found out that all you have to do is quickly press up and right arrow key simultaneously (got to hiscore of about 1500 this way, then game was too fast and princess ended as barbeque.
Is there a way to escape? :)

This somehow reminded me of Fling Smash on wii ( strange i know ). Overall, mental,but good to see some progression in there. Possibly a little too random though so wasn't a game i felt i could get "better" at by playing it more.
So... press right and D to ad-infinitum to get the hi-score? Game runs nicely, glad to see another Canvas+JS entry! But there's nothing much to this game =(
The mechanic might have something to it, but without a limit, there's no reason not to use only arrow keys.
Not sure if it's a but but it would speed up randomly, also I went with w+d+UP+RIGHT for my tactic, did pretty well, but didn't take much strategy.

description:
Drill planets til they explode! Features two gameplay mechanics that combine into a whimsical race to escape the firey death of your home planet. Keep digging up more fuel to power your ship until you reach a suitable planet for your greedy ways.
In the Drilling Mode, collect minerals and fuel from the planets core while protecting your ship from the hostile natives. Upgrades are available to power up your ship!
In the Blast Escape Mode, navigate your ship to safety from the blast of the planet you just destroyed...
-----------------------------------
Controls:
Planet Selection Screen - Click and select the planets within your fuel range
Drilling Mode - A,S,D or Left, Down, Right to control the drill bit; Space to retract; Mouse to control laser, click to deploy.
Blast Escape Mode - W,A,S,D or Arrow Keys to control ship, Space to shoot
-----------------------------------
Team members:
Hal Helms (Ace20) - Framework/Interface Programmer [He Who Links Heaven and Earth]
Johan Soriao (Tenki) - Gameplay Programmer [He Who Pierces the Heavens]
Vu Ha (Strega)- Gameplay Programmer [He Who Penetrates Planets to their Very Core]
Rose Peng (RosyPenguin) - Art Director [She Who Birthed the Universe]
*********************************************
[EDIT 10/3]: We are gathering for a Post-Jam Jam with updates and improvements based on your feedback during the three-day weekend! Check out the link above for the latest build!
author: RosyPenguin
title: Planetration
comments: Amazing game in all respects! I like the drilling just a little bit more than the escaping. The asteroids are hard to avoid when they come at you from the sides.

Yeah, the drilling + defending work really well together.  Needs enemies that get stronger each wave or something that makes it harder as time goes by?  The asteroid escape seems too random/hard.  I really like the combination of the different mechanics into a single game, though.
Really cool! Don't know why more people haven't rated this.
I think there needs to be more challenge to the drilling stage. Maybe just more speed on everything.
As it is, it just seems like a patience game to get 100 fuel and as much money as you want.
Sadly, the game would always crash with a white screen after this stage for me :(.

description:
You play as an alien life form who was captured by some humans, and you must escape. The game is really short, but it might take awhile if you are not used to playing these kind of games.
Escape the bullets!
author: Knighty
title: Alien Break
comments: I already cant get around the 4th enemy :P
but this isn't a bad game.
It's well put together and I like the little spider/crab/hero guy even though I'm not sure what he is ;) I couldn't make it past the first boss,though, even on easy. I like the little music loop too.
Like the mix of bullet hell and top down walking around.
The circle enemy stumped me though.
This is a pleasant game well done but too short :(

I'm not sure that circle boss is beatable on easy. When he does the rings of bullets, sometimes the gap is often too far away to get to. I like the changing direction, but maybe separate shoot left and shoot right buttons would have been easier to get used to.
There are too many buttons to keep track of in the controls, otherwise it's pretty fun.

description: Having battled your way through to the centre of the complex, you now just have to end this fight.  Destroy the core and win victory for the cause.
author: Six
title: Ascapen Prime
comments: I actually really liked this, when the twist came and you started running away I actually went "Hah!" :D
Fun, though I can't get past the overdrive mode. The blocks are coming so fast that I can't react in time, especially when I'm dealing with meanies in front of me.
Maybe if there was epic music I'd be able to keep going :p
Agreed on music, a punishing dodging game like this pretty much needs an epic soundtrack to keep people at it.  Too bad I'm rubbish at music.
And a small tip: the spawn rate of the barriers actually is dependant on how far left you are, so if you hang closer to the core, less will spawn (but it's easier to be knocked into it :P ).
It would have definetly benefited with some SFXR/BFXR sounds.
great job. i really like the presentation of the plot and the simple but nice graphics. wish it was wider so i could see the walls coming and have enough time to dodge them.
2 stars on audio as I firmly believe no audio is better than bad audio.
I like the story progression - the set up and reversal and overdrive. The signs marking the distance to the exit are a nice touch too.
The difficulty was perfect for me - I won on my first attempt, but I felt like I was going to lose the whole way through. It was delightfully stressful...
